113 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1996


South Africa Foreign Trip Could Clear Constitutional Logjam


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) January 19, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Johannesburg - Over drinks in hotel bars in Germany last week, new
friendships were formed that bode well for the writing of the final
constitution.

During a week-long, fact-finding tour to Germany, Inkatha Freedom
Party (IFP), African National Congress (ANC) and National Party (NP)
politicians were able, for the first time since the IFP walked out of
the Constitutional Assembly last year, to talk to each other --
sometimes late into the night -- about South Africa's constitutional
future.

Back home this week, the delegates were cautiously optimistic about
the effect the mission would have on the constitution-writing process
and, in particular, on the stand-off between the IFP and the ANC over
international mediation. 

At this stage -- and it is early days yet -- the signs of a new
interparty rapport are good, with even the IFP delegates taking a more
amiable line than usual.

IFP negotiator, Correctional Services Minister Sipo Mzimela, said
this week he had already briefed party leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi about
the trip and Buthelezi had been "positively surprised" at what he had to
say.

Mzimela said of the trip: "I think we got the chance to interact
across party lines ... if the group had had the power to make decisions,
certainly there would have been movement on issues because we were able
to understand a lot of things collectively."

Mzimela believed there would be follow-up talks between parties on
what had been learnt, but would not commit himself on whether the IFP
would return to the Constitutional Assembly to participate fully in the
final, and most important, phases of the constitutional negotiations.

He said international mediation had not been mentioned during the
visit, and in any case "the media have overplayed the whole issue".

"If we in South Africa could solve our problems, we would not need
international mediation ... what we did realise abroad was that the
international mediation was not just an IFP and ANC problem, it was a
problem to be resolved by all the parties," he said.

A source in the German delegation said that a particularly good
relationship had been established between the three M's -- Mzimela,
National Party Constitutional Affairs Minister Roelf Meyer, and his ANC
deputy Valli Moosa -- the same trio who met to resolve the international
mediation crisis last year, and abandoned the attempt in bad humour.

Democratic Party constitutional expert Colin Eglin said this week the
trip could be intepreted as a "diluted form of international mediation",
as it was away from home and because they learnt from the Germans.

A report on the tour is being drawn up by the three technical
advisers who accompanied the team. It is possible that this report will
form the basis of further discussions with the IFP and parties within
the Constitutional Assembly.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January, 1996


Uganda UK Report Predicts Museveni Win In '96 Polls


BYLINE: The Monitor (Kampala) January 5, 1996 by Gerald Owachi


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Kampala - A report issued by the authoritative London-based Economist
Intelligence Unit (EIU) has predicted a Museveni victory in the forthcoming
presidential elections.

"It will be very surprising if President Yoweri Museveni, is not returned
to office next April as the elected president,: the just released 1995 4th
quarter country report, says.

The report, however, doubts whether all sections of society will accept the
legitimacy of his election. 

At the same time it casts a shadow over the loyalty of the army towards any
other person other than Museveni. "The army remains Mr. Museveni's trump
card," it states, therefore disqualifying the possibilities of the army
supporting any other democratically elected government.

It also suggests that the legislative elections in May 1996 will produce a
better political balance in parliament, and thereby defuse some political
tension.

According to the report, NRM is already confident of victories in Karamoja
-- because NRM has allowed the K'jongs to keep their guns. Busoga--VP
Kazibwe's home area, Bugisu, Kapchorwa and his traditional base the SouthThe report further states that, "Mr Museveni is even trying to tempt former
west.
president, Idi Amin, back to Uganda in order to capitalise on his support in
the North West.

The EIU report which briefly portrays the current political and economic
state of Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi, cites the new constitution and the
escalating military expenditure of the Uganda government as a possible source
of disagreement between the donor community and the Government.

According to the report, "the USA clearly believes that a five-year wait
before the issue of multi-partyism can again be tested is too long. It adds
that European countries previously reluctant to show their resentment on the
matter, have now formally joined the US in pressing for an early
constitutional amendment.

"The government reduced the defence share of budget expenditure from 36% in
1990/91 to 13% in 1991/92, but then raised it again during the following two
years and brought it up to 30% this year (1995)," the reports notes. The donor
community is not at all happy with this trend regardless of the insecurity in
the north and along the Sudan border.

The report says that the rift between president Moi of Kenya and Museveni
which used to be portrayed as a largely personal matter, has developed into "a
more substantial rift based on the different approaches to systems of
government." It blames the failure to achieve regional cooperation on this cat
and mouse relationship between these two leaders.

The strike by medical workers last September is cited in the report as a
possible beginning of demands to be floated by the public sector workers.
This, the report goes on, would result into an inflationary wage spiral that
would threaten the climate of economic stability which has been achieved in
recent years.

It is expected to be compounded by unfavourable economic prospects
especially following the recent decline in coffee prices. The end of this
coffee boom was marked by the October fall in the value of the shilling, after
a two year spell of stability, the EIU report notes.

Africa News


January, 1996


United States and Africa Investment Myths About Africa Dispelled in TV Program


BYLINE: U.S. Africa Chamber of Commerce January 15, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

New York - The U.S.-Africa Chamber of Commerce dispels investment
myths about Africa with its first televised program, "Africa: An
Emerging Market for the 90s." The 30-minute special, hosted by CNBC
Anchor Karen Gibbs, travels to businesses in Egypt, Ghana and South
Africa.

The program features a distinguished panel of experts on investing in
Africa including, international investor Jom Rogers; His Excellency
Ekwow Spio-Garbrah, Ambassador from Ghana; Donald Norland, former
Ambassador of Chad and Botswana; Susan Levine, Overseas Private
Investment Corporation and Maceo Sloan, president and CEO of Sloan
Financial Group, who served as moderator. 

It also features guest appearances by President Nelson Mandela (South
Africa), President Jerry Rawlings (Ghana) and celebrities Danny Glover,
Louis Gossett, Jr., Bryant Gumbel, Nigel Hawthorne, Iman, John
McLaughlin, Gary Player and Alfre Woodard.

The program will be seen nationwide on local stations in Atlanta,
Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and Washington, DC. It will air
throughout January, February and March. The producers anticipate pick-up
by cable outlets such as CNBC and BET in February and March.

"For so long I have wanted to show the U.S. audience what Africa has
to offer," says Elias Belayneh, president of the U.S.-Africa Chamber of
Commerce. "Now, I have the opportunity to broaden U.S. investor interest
in Africa. Watching this production will be unparalleled to any other
African special seen on television."

"Africa gets in your soul, you either love it or hate it," adds
participant Jim Rogers. "I love it; it's a great investment."

The show was produced by Noelle-Elaine Productions, a New York-based
production company. The U.S.-Africa Chamber of Commerce is an
independent, non-profit organization establishing ties between the U.S.
and foreign businesses, trade organizations, universities, foundations
and individuals to promote the efficiency and integrity of trade and
investment in the U.S. and Africa.

For more information, call Lisa Donadio, Noelle-Elaine Media
Consultants, 212 370-5485.

Africa News


January, 1996


Nigeria Press Group Condemns Attacks on Press


BYLINE: Africa News Service January 16, 1996


LENGTH: 907 words


 

New York - Statement by the New York-based Committee to Protect
Journalists.
The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), a nonpartisan advocate of
press freedom, condemns the December 23 arrest of Nosa Igiebor, editor
in chief of best-selling Lagos-based "Tell" magazine, and the recent
escalation of attacks against Nigeria's independent press.

Igiebor, the recipient of CPJ's International Press Freedom Award in
1993, was arrested by six members of the State Security Service (SSS) at
his home in Lagos. SSS agents also confiscated 20,000 copies of "Tell"
magazine's Christmas Day edition with the cover story "Abacha is
Adamant: Terrorizes the Opposition." On December 27, SSS agents made a
failed attempt to search his office for the company's tax records and
staff pay records. 

Authorities continue to hold Igiebor in solitary confinement without
charge, and are demanding that he reveal his sources for articles
published in Tell criticizing the military government. During
interrogations at Lagos State Command of the SSS facility in Shangisha,
Igiebor repeatedly stated that he receives financial support from
neither outsiders nor Nigerian citizens, and that any information he
receives arrives by mail.

CPJ also denounces the following attacks against the independent
press during the last two weeks of 1995:

* On December 31, the office of the magazine division of the
Independent Communications Network Limited, publishers of "The News,"
"Tempo," and "Tempofootball," was torched by arsonists using a petrol
bomb. According to Dapo Olorunyomi, editor -in-chief of "The News," the
fire destroyed property (including a new line of Gateway 2000 Pentium
computers) worth millions of naira. The arsonists managed to escape.

The office, located on the first floor of Tejumola House in Ikeja,
Lagos, houses the newsroom and production center of the three magazines.
It was the only floor of the four-story building that was torched.
Management expects publication of The News and Tempo to be suspended for
approximately two weeks.

On December 19, photojournalists Peter Obe, Bayo Ewuoso, Abiodun
Ajala and Segun Olakitan were assaulted and detained by police during
the National Democratic Coalition (NADECO) rally in Lagos. Their offense
was photographing the confrontation between NADECO supporters and the
over five hundred policemen who shot tear gas into the crowd to disperse
the protesters.

Ewuoso, a senior photojournalist with "AM News" was severely beaten
by over ten policemen who later transported him to the Surulere Police
Station for interrogation. Ajala of "This Day" newspaper, Olakitan of
"Tell" magazine, and veteran photojournalist Obe were also beaten and
seriously injured by police. Ajala and Olakitan were rushed to a nearby
hospital for treatment.

On December 16, ten security operatives lay siege to the "AM News"
office, demanding to know the whereabouts of editor-in-chief Bayo
Onanuga. They were seeking Onanuga to place him under arrest. Onanuga
remains in hiding. The security operatives reportedly did the same at
the offices of "Tell" magazine.

On December 16, all 55,000 copies of "Tell" were seized at the
printing house. The seizure followed the magazine's publication of an
article titled "The Release of (Chief Moshood) Abiola: The World Waits
On (General Sani) Abacha."

On December 15, arsonists torched the circulation department of "The
Guardian" newspaper. Damage was minimal because the fire was quickly
brought under control.

On December 15, Adedisi Dejo, Emmanuel Piper, Yeni Oldwolabi and Iyi
Isaac, reporters and contributors to the paper, were held for
questioning by Lagos police.

Finally, CPJ intensified its call for the release of the four
journalists (Christine Anyanwu, George Mbah, Ben Charles Obi and Kunle
Ajibade) who were convicted to fifteen years in jail for their alleged
participation in an alleged coup plot against the military regime.

For further information, contact Kakuna Kerina, program coordinator
for Africa at (212) 465-1004 x 103; fax: (212) 465-9568; e-mail:
kkerina@cpj.org


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January, 1996


Liberia Harassment of Journalists Intensifies


BYLINE: Africa News Service January 15, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

New York - Text of several recent news alerts by the New York-based
Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ).

On 12 January 1996, Stanton Peabody, acting managing director of the
"Daily Observer", was released after Press Union of Liberia attorneys,
through the Justice & Peace Commission, filed a bill of habeus corpus on
his behalf. Peabody was released on bail of $20,000 Liberian (US$ 400). 

Peabody will return to court on 16 January, as will editor-in- chief
of the "Daily Observer" James Seitua. However, the two journalists will
be tried separately on charges of "criminal malevolence."

Immediately after the court ordered Peabody's release, Director of
National Police Joseph Tate ordered seven police officers to re-arrest
him in the courthouse. However, the presiding judge announced that any
re-arrest would place Tate in contempt of court. Peabody plans to remain
at home until the upcoming court date.

On 11 January 1996, representatives of the Press Union of Liberia and
the management of the "Daily Observer" obtained a bill of release for
James Seitua, editor-in-chief of the "Daily Observer". Bail in the
amount of $25,000 Liberian dollars ($350 US) was paid. Under the
conditions of his release, Seitua cannot travel outside of Monrovia, and
must report daily to the police until the matter is resolved.

The charge against Seitua, as stated in his bill of release, is
"criminal malevolence." No charges have been filed against him in a
court of law. On 29 December 1995, the "Daily Observer" published an
article that disputed the claim made by United Revolutionary Front of
Sierra Leone spokesperson Eddie Hebron that he was interviewed in the
Ivory Coast by the British Broadcasting Corporation and Voice of
America. The article claimed that Hebron was in Monrovia, the Liberian
capital, during the interviews. James Seitua was subsequently arrested
on 9 January and detained; he has since been released on bail. Stanton
Peabody, in an attempt to intervene on Seitua's behalf, was also
arrested on 10 January. He remains in detention.

On 8 January 1996, D. Sompon Weah II, reporter for "The News", and
"The News" photographer Pewee S. Flomoku were attacked in Po River
(northwestern Liberia), where they were covering skirmishes between West
Africa peacekeeping forces (ECOMOG) and warring factions of the United
Liberation Movement (ULIMO-J).

The attack occurred shortly after their arrival, as they were
recording the state of security in the region. At the directive of the
executive director of the Liberia Refugees Repatriation & Resettlement
Commission, Mrs. Weade Kobbah Wreh, they were beaten by her personal
bodyguards and some ECOMOG soldiers. Flomoku's camera was destroyed.

For further information, contact Kakuna Kerina, program coordinator
for Africa at (212) 465-1004 x 103; fax: (212) 465-9568; e-mail:
kkerina@cpj.org


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Gabonese Media Urged To Campaign Against Ebola


LENGTH: 955 words


 

LIBREVILLE, Gabon (PANA) - As it was confirmed that 13 people had died of the deadly ' Ebola' virus in Gabon, the country's media organs have been urged to use local languages to spread the message on how the population can avoid infection.

The advise was given here Wednesday by a World Health Organization (WHO), Philippe Stroot from the Un health Agency's Media Relations section. 

He told the Gabonese News Agency (AGP) that infection prevention messages in the vernaculars should be aired on provincial radio stations for easy reception by population in remote areas.

Stroot was speaking on his return from Mayibout II in the north-eastern Gabon Ogooue-Ivindo Province, where 10 villagers were confirmed to have died of hemorrhagic fever caused by Ebola on Feb. 5 and 6, after eating a dead chimpanzee.

Stroot had visited the infected area in the company of two experts from the WHO, Bobacar Ndiaye and Dr. Maka.

He commended Gabonese health authorities for the precautions they were taking to curb the further spread of the Ebola virus.

The latest report by the WHO said that 20 cases have been diagnosed.Out of these, 13 people had died. Among them was a six-month old baby who was infected by her mother.

According to WHO experts, no new fresh cases had been diagnosed after the virus's incubation period, which is between two and 21 days.

The existence of Ebola was confirmed Monday by Gabon's Health Minister, who quoted research findings by the Franceville-based International Medical Research Center.

A similar outbreak of the Ebola-caused hemorrhagic fever in neighbouring Zaire killed 283 people between April and July 1995 in the Central region of Bandundu.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Budget Cuts Bite Zimbabwean HIV Carriers


LENGTH: 400 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - As a cost cutting measure, the Zimbabwean health ministry has decided to remove kidney patients who are HIV-positive or have Hepatitis B from the renal programme.

Announcing this last Friday, Health and Child Welfare Minister timothy Stamps said said new patients would not be admitted to the programme until sustainable funds were available. 

"We have taken a hard decision and decided to exclude any patient who is HIV positive or has Hepatitis B.

"We will also not be admitting new patients until sustainable funds are available," he said in a speech at Mpilo hospital in the South Western Matebeleland.

Stamps told senior government officials and kidney patients that the decision was with immediate effect.

The meeting was called by Makokoba member of parliament Sithembiso Nyoni whose constituency covers Mpilo hospital.

He convened the meeting after being informed that the hospital's renal unit was deprived, for two weeks, of haemodialysis concentrate solution, a special drug used during dialysis.

Stamps told the patients, some of whom have resorted to selling their cattle and clothes to buy medication, that the situation had not yet reached crisis proportions and the renal programme would not be abandoned.

The Bulawayo-based Orap-Zenzele clinic donated 100 litres of dialysis concentrate while five doctors from the city donated zd 3,000 (IUSD=9.058zd) for buying more medication for the kidney patients.

The Zimbabwe health sector has been among the most affected in the cost-cutting measures introduced under the country's Structural djustment Programme.

The budget cuts have forced hospitals to ask relatives of patients to buy the prescribed medicine and to feed the inpatients.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Netherlands Assits Zambia in Drug Importation


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Netherlands government Wednesday granted Zambia some USD 11 million for the importation of essential medical drugs during the next four years.

Under the agreement signed in Lusaka Wednesday by the two governments, the funds will enable the Zambian government procure a variety of essential drugs, mainly those against common diseases which afflict the rural populations. 

Zambia's National Commission for Development Planning deputy minister, Danny Pule, signed for his country, saying the funds would enable his government redirect limited resources to other needy sectors.

Netherlands ambassador to Zambia Jan Peter Dijkstra, who signed for his government, said Zambia's reforms in the pharmaceutical sector had been lagging behind.

He disclosed that a coordinator had been assigned with the task of coodinating the process intended to result in a draft pharmaceutical policy for Zambia.

Dijkstra said under the agreement, some of the money would be used for technical assistance and the rest for the supply of drugs to rural health centres, including support for community health workers up to the year 2000.

He said Zambia was one of the first countries in the Southern African region that had seriously shifted the focus on health services to the district level.

On average, the Netherlands government has recently spent some USD 8 million per year to support the health sector in Zambia. The assistance has covered the payment of Dutch doctors in the country and the purchase of esssential drugs for rural health and community health workers.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


121 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Vaccinations Reduces Yellow Fever Cases in Liberia


LENGTH: 334 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A concerted vaccination campaign has reduced yellow fever cases in war-ravaged Liberia from 356 cases and nine deaths between Nov.7 and Dec.15, 1995 to fewer than 20 and one death recently.

The World Health Organization, which spearheaded the campaign, said that all the cases and deaths occured around the port city of Buchanan in Grand Bassa County. 

According to the WHO, the campaign, which was launched in late November 1995,"has succeeded in vaccinating 1 million people in the wartorn West African country."

"Nearly 80 percent of the original target of 1.3 million people have now been vaccinated, including refugees, out of a total national population of 2.4 million."

The campaign was "the largest emergency vaccination campaign against the disease," said the United Nations health Agency.

However, according to Dr Fabrizio Bassani, director of WHO's Division of Emergency and Human Action (EHA), " in a number of areas, access had to be negotiated in order for the vaccination teams to do their work."

According to the WHO, there have been no confirmed cases in Monrovia, the capital although the city's population has swelled to three times its pre-war level.

However, as precaution, from Dec. 21 to 5 January, more than 600,000 of Monrovia's residents and the refugees were vaccinated.

The agency said poor water and sanitation provide "fertile conditions for the Aedes Aegypti mosquito which spreads the disease.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zimbabwean AIDS-Orphaned Children Turn to Begging


LENGTH: 494 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The majority of Zimbabwean children whose parents died of AIDS are facing severe economic problems and many of them have resorted to begging for food and other needs.

The chairperson of Emakhandeni home-based care group, Evelyn Magonya, told ZIANA in Bulwayo, the country's second city, that the situation was particularly desperate for children both of whose parents succumbed to the pandemic.

Revival of Hope, an organisation that looks after children whose parents died of AIDS had by the end of 1995 identified over 500 orphans in two low-income suburbs in Bulawayo. 

Health experts estimate that countrywide over 300 people were dying of AIDS every week in Zimbabwe, creating a frighteningly high orphan population.

It is estimated that one million people in Zimbabwe live with the Human Immunedeficiency virus (HIV) which causes the incurable Acquired Immunedeficiency Syndrome or AIDS.

Magonya, who appealed for assistance, said the children were suffering silently due to the harsh economic environment as most of them were being forced to drop out of school, ending up on the streets begging.

"The situation is now desperate. The department of social welfare says it has no money to help out," lamented Magonya, after a visit to some of the affected children.

One of the family of five orphans aged between four and 13 years, now being looked after by an unemployed 92 year old grandmother, had virtually no food in the house.

Three of the orphans have been forced to abandon school because their fees had not been paid.

Sipathisiwe Mhlanga, the 14-year eldest child said since the death of both parents the family had been surviving on handouts from individuals and churches.

Magonya said social welfare efforts were being overwhelmed by the increase in aids orphans, most of whom were of school-going age.

"The general high cost of living is making it difficult for home-based care groups to assist these children. Their future is now doomed because they cannot even go to school or fend for themselves," she said.

Bulawayo city council has already indicated that it could not offer assistance to hundreds of children orphaned by the epidemic.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Lymphatic Filariasis Rampant in Africa


LENGTH: 654 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Lymphatic diseases have prevented Mashala Kalogi, a peasant in Tanzania's Mwanza region, from wearing trousers.

For two decades, Kalogi has been suffering from elephantiasis or gross swelling of both legs and hydrocoele or grotesque enlargement of the male scrotum.

Kalogi is a famous paddy grower who lives in village near one of the most mosquito-infested shores of Lake Victoria. 

He is just one of the 106 million people who are afflicted by those diseases, identified by the World Health Organization (WHO) as "the world's second leading cause of permanent and long-term disability."

According to the United Nations health agency, the mosquito-borne diseases have already infected "a minimum of 120 million people in 73 endemic countries worldwide."

In Africa, only Algeria, Botswana, Lesotho, Libya, Namibia, Morocco, Somalia, South Africa, Sudan, Swaziland, Tunisia and Western Sahara are free from the infectious diseases, according to a map provided by the WHO.

The WHO says the prevalence of these diseases is growing due "to rapid unplanned urbanization in many endemic countries."

Lymphatic filariasis is caused by three types of filarial parasites--Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi and Brugia timori-- which are transmitted to humans by mosquitos.

Mosquitos transmit them in the form of adult worms or microfiliarae which settle into the human lymphatic system and mature over a period of three to 15 months.

When fertilised, female adults produce large numbers of microfiliarae which are then ingested by mosquitos and transmitted to other people.

If not eliminated, the majority of microfiliare remain in the body in immature forms for six to two years "moving, secreting, excreting and dying as foreign bodies, and doing immense damage to the host in the process," says the WHO.

Elephantiasis and hydrocoele occur when the macrofiliarae become longer and damage the lymphatic glands.

However, the health UN agency's Task Force for Disease Eradication has already placed lymphatic filariasis as one of the world's six ' eradicable' or ' potentially eradicable' infections diseases.

In a recent document, the WHO said the transmission of filarial infection can be reduced by the selective treatement of of people who actually have the disease with the drug ' Ivermectin' .

It said that an optimal single dose of ivermectin plus diethylcarbamazine (DEC) results in 99 percent reduction of microfilaraemia after one year.

However, this treatment should be accompanied by effective measures to control the mosquito vector by using insecticide-impregnated bednets and curtains, long-lasting indorr sprays "and community participation in vector management."

The WHO regretted the "low priority often accorded filariasis by health authorities" and suggested its integration into other health care delivery packages.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Montreal Hosts Biological Diversity Secretariat


LENGTH: 640 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - The secretariat charged with implementation of the Convention on Biological Diversity has moved to Montreal, Canada, following a decision taken by governments in Jakarta, in November 1995, the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has said.

A UNEP statement said here Monday the Executive Secretary, Calestous Jumo of Kenya and a staff of 21 professionals will service the treaty and its 140 member governments from the new headquarters at Montreal's World Trade Centre.

"Thanks to strong support from the city of Montreal, the Province of Quebec, the government of Canada, and UNEP in Nairobi, we are already operational," Juma said. 

"This spirit of cooperation will be invaluable to us as we carry out our ambitious work programme in the months and years ahead," he added.

One of the secretariat's first tasks will be to prepare for the next session of the subsidiary body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA), to be held from September 2-6 in Montreal, he said.

The meeting will assess the factual information that governments will need for making policy decisions at the third annual session of the conference of the parties to the Convention, which will take place in Buenos Aires from November 4-5.

The release said the work programme for 1996 includes research on the safe transfer, handling, and use of living modified organisms resulting from biotechnology.

Governments agreed last year to start drafting a protocol on biosafety that would help to minimize potential risks from both accidental releases and trade.

The next meeting on the subject will be held in Aarhus, Denmark, from July 22-26.

Work will also begin on the publication of a global biodiversity outlook, a series of in-depth reports on the implications of the convention for key sectors, such as agriculture and marine and coastal areas.

Another important focus this year will be indigenous and local knowledge.

The convention recognizes the special role that indigenous and local communities play in the protection and sustainable use of bioldiversity.

Biological diversity refers to the number and variety of living oganisms on the planet. Recent estimates suggest that the earth is host to between 13 million and 14 million species, of which only 1.75 million have been scientifically described.

These species and the ecosystems they form are being destroyed at an unprecedented rate, primarily by human activities.

Recognizing the immense value of the earth's biological resources, governments negotiated the convention on biological diversity ahead of the 1992 Rio Earth Summit.

Some 139 countries have become party to the treaty as of February 1.

The convention's objectives are "the conservation of biological diversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arishing out of the utilization of genetic resources".


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Road Construction Through Senegalese Park Endorsed


LENGTH: 360 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) has endorsed Senegalese government plans to construct a road through the Niokolo Koba national park, a ' world heritage' .

The 165-kilometer road between Dialakoto and Kedougou, in the eastern Tambacounda region, is to be inaugurated by President Abdou Diouf on Feb. 29. 

Endorsing the project, UNESCO however asked the government to meet several pre-conditions.

One of them requires Dakar to establish 40-meter wide fire breaks on both sides of the road, before it is open to traffick. This is to guard against bushfires.

The UN agency also asked the government to rehabilitate the land around along the road to allow for afforestation.

It also demanded that game rangers be provided with adequate equipment to enable them curb poaching.

UNESCO has designated several sites around the globe considered important to the whole of humanity part of the ' world heritage' .

Observers here believe UNESCO made these concessions to Senegal because of the proposed road's local and regional importance.

The road serves as a vital link to the major cotton growing southern Senegal and with the neighbouring states of Guinea and Mali.

Because the road passes through a rainy area with fragile soils, a series of drainage systems have to be established to prevent soil erosion.

The road is expected to cost 20 billion F CFA. The funding is to be provided by the government and several international financial institutions including the Saudi Development Fund, the Kuwaiti Fund, the Islamic Development Bank, the West African Development Bank and the Ecowas Fund.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Prolonged Conflict Threatens Liberia With Deforestation


BYLINE: Terence Sesay PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 640 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia (PANA) - Six years of civil war is threatening Liberia with serious deforestation.

Prior to the war, which started in Dec. 1989, 80 percent of Liberia was covered by forest.

The indiscriminate felling of trees for sale, started in earnest by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia, followed by the Liberia Peace Council, is now posing a serious threat to the country's forest reserves. 

Prior to 1992, when the NPFL controlled 98 percent of Liberian territory, logging was one the mainstays of its economy.

The establishment of a Forestry Development Authority by the rebel government failed, however, to control logging by its officials.

By mid-1991, Liberian logs had flooded the French and other European markets. The glut led to a sharp drop in European timber prices.

The NPLF's loss of several areas to the Liberian LPC in the south east and Ulimo in the west only exacerbated the problem.

Realizing the immense profit they stood to gain from logging, the warlords in the two factions put their very souls into the dark enterprise. Forest areas soon became the source of much fighting.

Meanwhile, environmentalists began to voice their concerns. They noted that the felling of certain species would cause deforestation even in thickly forested areas. The warring factions, however, took little heed.

Logging has to a large extent been restricted to the south east which is the most thickly forested region in Liberia.

But the war has resulted in the destruction of forests even in areas where logging is not possible.

Western Liberia, which benefitted from a reforestation programme funded by the German Technical Assistance Programme (GTZ) has also borne the consequences of this breakdown of law and order. In Foya district, where hundreds of hectares of trees were cultivated under the scheme, bush fires caused by fighters searching for hidden valuables as well as fuelwood have sabotaged the programme.

Not much logging has gone on in the south eastern county of Bomi where a forestry training institute was in operation before the war, and where extensive reforestation was carried out under the German sponsored programme.

But a flourishing charcoal industry has been a threat to the ecosystem in this region as well. Hundreds of citizens have become engaged in the trade.

Charcoal production is a booming business even in the Monrovia area. The fact that 75 percent of the production sector is inactive due to the fragile security situation has resulted in the the trebbling of unemployment.

Self-employment has thus become the most reliable means of survival. This has caused even educated residents to take to charcoal burning, an enterprise which does not require much capital outlay and has been traditionally looked at an occupation for the lowly.

Liberia's reconstruction programme after the war will require immense capital inputs to repair not only damaged infrastructure, but also restore the country's once huge forest reserves.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Unicef Invests in the Environment


LENGTH: 200 words


 

THIES, Senegal (PANA) - The 50th anniversary of Unicef in Senegal has been marked by the launching of a pilot project on ' Hygiene and Protection of the Environment in Urban Areas' in the city of Thies, 70 km from Dakar.

The project will improve the supply of drinking water to the town, organise garbage collection, as well as dig up and improve old water wells and latrines. 

The project, to cost 1 billion 200 million cfa (500 cfa = one US dollar) over a period of six years, should also contribute to improving the residential quarters of the poor in the town as well as promote economic and social development.

In the short term, the project will create 4,000 jobs.

The sanitation and cleaning of the city will be entrusted to to the Union of Sanitation Committees of the City of Thies which groups 38 committees.

128 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Combats Water Hyacinth


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 667 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A biological control of weed in one of Zambia's most economically viable rivers, the Kafue, has been launched by the Environmental Council of Zambia (ECZ) in collaboration with the Commonwealth Science Council of London and the Plant Protection Research Institute (PPRI) in Pretoria, South Africa.

The project is aimed at reducing the spread of the weed, water hyacinth, in the lower Kafue, southern Zambia.

Zambian environmental officials said in a recent report on the project that it had been observed that the weed reduced water quality, reduced fish catches by making the river less navigable, and had an adverse effect on the generation of hydro-electric power. 

The Zambian government is currently rearing some weevils (weed-eating insects) imported from South Africa which are to be released on to the weed this month, according project leader, Israel Zandonda, a biologist with the ECZ.

Zandonda said in his report that the weed had some very serious consequencies and negative environmental impact on the river and that there were fears it could spread to other water basins in the country.

Water hyacinth is said by scientists to have originated from Brazil and penetrated Africa through various water channels including the Suez Canal.

ECZ officials have said that native river weeds such as ' hippo grass", or ' vosnia' , and cyperus papyrus have now mixed with recently introduced foreign weed species, particularly the water hyacinth, a stud forming weed, resulting in the formation of large floating mats of weeds which sometimes became permanent floating islands on the river.

According to the water scientists involved in the project, the weed's disadvantages include rapid loss of water by a process called "evapotranspiration".

The scientists say that places covered by water hyacinth lose 46 percent more water than that lost by normal water surfaces.

The weed also makes the water "tasteless" for drinking purposes. It also changes the colour of water as it dies, rots, and sinks to the river bed.

This causes chemical treatment of drinking water from places covered by the stud-forming water hyacinth more expensive than normal.

Experts have said that it was possible that parts of, or the entire Kafueriver, could become blocked to traffic including speed-boats, canoes and even swimmers if the weed was left uncontrolled.

The Kafue, one of Zambia three major rivers, along with the Luangwa and Zambezi, is a major source for commercial and domestic water and serves large concentrations of both fish and wildlife.

There are two major hydro-electric power stations on the river in central and southern Zambia. Electrical engineers at the stations are said to be encountering problems preventing the weed from being sucked into water turbines that generate electricity.

Zambia's main electricity supplier, the Zambia Electricity Supply Corportation (ZESCO, recently set up an environmental division to deal with the weed problem.

Growth of the weed is thought by scientists to have escalated during the 1991/92 rain season when Zambia had its worst drought in living history.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


129 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zimbabwe's Lake Mutirikwi is Now 30 Percent Full


LENGTH: 187 words


 

MASVINGO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's largest inland dam, Lake Mutirikwi is now over 30 percent full and only needs about 60 million cubic metres of water to contain more water than any other dam within Zimbabwe.

Mutirikwi had 426.2 million cubic metres of water as of February 12, representing 30.93 percent, but more water has since poured into the giant reservoir. 

The dam's water level is now only 12.86 metres below the spillway but experts say there is little chance the dam will spill this season as Zimbabwe's rain season is drawing to a close.

The unexecpted could happen, however, if more rains fall within the dam's catchment area.

Manyuchi Dam in Mwenezi, the second largest dam in the province is spilling. It now holds 319 million cubic metres of water.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Uganda Reserves Reach Record High


BYLINE: Moses Draku PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda has accumulated over 440 million dollars in international rserves, the highest ever attained by the east African country.

The reserves rose from 219 million dollars in June 1994 to 386 million in June 1995, the Governor of the (central) Bank of Uganda, Charles Kikonyogo told chief executives of commercial banks in Uganda at the weekend. 

He told the second annual dinner of the Institute of Bankers that the reserves kept in various international banks abroad were equivalent to about four months of the country's imports.

"The performance of Uganda economy during the past year has been exceptionally strong" Kikonyogo said.

"All evidence suggests that the crown in national production has been well sustained in the current financial year. The rate of increase in domestic prices remains under control and the shilling is stable in terms of other currencies," he aadded.

Uganda was generally perceived by the international finance community as a country that has followed sensible economic policies and a model for other countries to emulate, he said.

But the governor warned that there was no room for complacency. "Much remains to be done if the nation is to sustain and improve growth and stability".

Kikonyogo said over time, banks must increase financing options open to borrowers saying the central bank's main obligation was to act in the interests of customers if the commercial banks were unable to meet minimum standards.

The chairman of Uganda Bankers Assocation Ezra Suruma called for immediate reform in the banking sector saying banks should be privatized and capitalized to avoid unacceptability in the financial sector.

"The public must be convinced that the banking system is safe and sound today, tomorrow and for decades to come" said Suruma who is also the chief executive the giant Uganda Commercial Bank.

February, 1996


Unesco Conference on Tolerance Opens Wednesday


LENGTH: 294 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - An international conference on "The African Diaspora and the Modern World" opens Wednesday at the University of Texas at Austin in the United States.

The gathering is co-organized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) and the University of Texas as part of activities to mark the UN's declaration of 1996 as the International Year for Tolerance. 

In a press release sent to PANA Monday the organizers said the conference will involve more than 50 scholars and cultural leaders from North, Central, and South America, the Caribbean, Africa and Europe.

The "International Year for Tolerance" was initiated by the U.N. in the light of a resurgence of racial, religious and ethnic conflicts around the globe.

"The event will also commemorate African American Month," which is observed in February.

The conference will focus on the essential role the estimated 12 to 20 million African slaves and their descendants have played in the development of the territories on the other side of the Atlantic.

Highlights of the meeting will include presentations by scholars and cultural leaders. There will also be a musical performance and a photographic exhibition.

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa's Transit Charges


LENGTH: 400 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - South Africa's Department of Customs has rejected appeals by Zimbabwean shippers to rescind a decision to raise duties on transit cargo.

Secretary for Zimbabwe's Ministry of Industry and Commerce, Kelbert Nkomani, said on Monday the South African Department of Customs had decided to implement the new measures with effect from March 1, despite appeals against the move by the Zimbabwe government and the Shipping and Forwarding Agents Association of Zimbabwe. 

Among other measures to control smuggling, the South African Department of Customs was demanding that exporters from such landlocked countries as Zimbabwe pay a cash deposit to cover 125 percent of the duty which would be payable if the goods in transit were imported into South Africa.

Further, the department said it would not accept road bonds as security for removal of goods in transit, and wanted all transit goods destined for other African countries by road to leave through the border posts of Beitbridge and Komatipoort.

The implementation of the measures had been temporarily suspended until the beginning of this month, pending the outcome of negotiations with the affected countries.

However, it seems the talks broke down without agreement.

"We are informed that the South African authorities have decided that the cash deposit to cover 125 percent of the duty payable will become a requirement with effect from March 1 1996," Nkomani said.

He said the duty would apply to textiles, clothing, electronic goods such as video recorders and televisions, tyres, wine, beer and cigarettes.

Industry sources said the new measures could force Zimbabweans to divert their cargo to ports such as Beira and Maputo in Mozambique.

Nearly 40 percent of Zimbabwean tobacco is now being exported through Beira.

LANGUAGE: English

Winnie Mandela To Visit Nigeria


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Winnie Mandela, the estranged wife of South African President Nelson Mandela is to visit Nigeria at the invitation of the National Council of Women Societies (NCWS), the official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reported Monday.

The agency said the invitation was given to her by the NCWS' president Amina Sambo, who visited South Africa recently. 

NAN quoted Sambo as saying Winnie, a member of the South African parliament, was "excited" about the visit.

Winnie last visited Nigeria four years ago with his husband shortly after he was released from 26 years in prison.

Sambo said Winnie, a South African woman activist had been invited because of "her positive contribution to women's cause...and her support for Nigeria."

"The invitation is part of our networking program among African women organizations aimed at improving their lot and to develop a coordinated effort at articultaing women issues," Sambo added.

She said her trip to South Africa was at the invitation of South African women's group.

The Nigerian women's council, she said, had also been invited to the August 40th anniversary of South Africa's ruling African National Congress womens' wing.

It was unclear how the planned visit would be taken in South Africa, which is locked in diplomatic row with the Nigerian government over the November 1995 executions of nine Nigerian minority leaders, among them author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

February, 1996


Monteiro Re-elected Cape Verdian President


LENGTH: 267 words


 

PRAIA, Cape Verde (PANA) - Cape Verde's President Antonio Mascarenhas Monteiro was re-elected Sunday after winning over 80 percent of the votes.

According to preliminary results issued here, only 45 per cent of those eligible voted. 

At least 200,000 voters were expected to cast their ballots in the poll in which Monteiro was the sole candidate.

With the strong backing of the ruling Movement for Democracy (MPD), Monteiro campaigned on the theme he is "President of all Cape Verdians".

He repeatedly called upon the islands' political parties to put aside electoral bickering and seek the national interest.

The presidential election marked the end of a two-month electoral process, which started with parliamentary and municipal polls.

During the legislative elections, the ruling MPD swept 50 of the 72 seats while the African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde (PAICV), formerly the sole party, got 21. One seat went to the Party for Democratic Convergence (PCD).

In the Municipal elections, the ruling party won in eight out of the 16 contested townships. The PAICV obtained four seats while another four went to independents.

February, 1996


New Zaire Slumps Again, CFA Gains


BYLINE: Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 214 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - After the misfortunes of the Ghanaian cedi last week, the new Zaire took another plunge this week, opening Tuesday at the nominal rate of 24,119 to the dollar from 23,132 last week.

Analysts attribute the fall to what they described as the "socio-economic situation of the moment", in reference to the introduction of new higher denomination bank notes by the Kinshasa government. 

The NZ exchanged at three to one dollar when it was introduced in October 1993 to replace the old "Zaire" which had almost become worthless when it exchanged at 20 million for one greenback.

But the CFA (African Finance Community) franc used in 13 French-speaking African countries gained six points, opening Tuesday at the nominal rate of 501 to one dollar from 507 to the American currency on the same day last week.

Similarly in Dakar, Senegal, the CFA exchanged Tuesday at 487 (buying) and 517 (selling) to the dollar. Last week the rate was 492 (buying) and 522 (selling) to one greenback.

February, 1996


Times of Zambia Managing Editor Sacked


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA)- The government-owned Times of Zambia newspaper's managing editor, Arthur Simuchoba, was sacked by his board of directors Tuesday.

A statement from the holding company, Times Printpak Zambia Limited, gave no reason for the dismissal. 

The company chairman, Ravi Devalia, said the company directors had at a meeting Monday "unanimously resolved" to sack Simuchoba on Tuesday.

Simuchoba in September successfully filed an injuction to restrain the board from sacking him and has been acting managing editor since then.

He has been replaced by Emmanuel Nyirenda, formerly managing editor of the government-owned Zambia Daily Mail.

Sources close to the Times said Tuesday that they believed Simuchoba could have been sacked for his sometimes "scathing" editorials against the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of President Frederick Chiluba.

Simuchoba had recently, in one of his hard-hitting editorials, suggested that government was being naive by showing open fear for former president Kenneth Kaunda in this year's presidential elections.

He was commenting on the current constitutional controversy involving government's recommendation in the new constitution that only second-generation Zambians should be allowed to contest the presidency.

Two weeks ago, Chiluba banned an edition of the independent Post daily newspaper which contained a story claiming the president had planned to call a snap referendum on selected constitutional clauses in a bid to catch the opposition unawares.

The Post's three editors, including the paper's managing editor Fred M'membe, have since been charged with publishing "classified material" and possessing prohibited publications.

Africa News


February, 1996


African Journalists Voice Concern Over Media and Democracy


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Zimbabwean media consultant has proposed the formation of an African media diversity trust funds to facilitate public ownership of newspapers, currently monopolized by governments.

Tawana Kupe, a consultant in the media and communication department at the University of Oslo in Norway, said this at a recent media management workshop in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare.

He noted that the media was in the Southern African sub-region in particular slowly being undermined by censorship and a weak economic base. 

The media, Kupe said, was open to pressure from economic interests and had to sometimes practise self-censorship because of real and imagined fears of upsetting dominant economic interests.

Kupe, who presented a paper on the "Media and Democracy" at the first media management course for journalists from Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe, said the proposed media diversity trust funds could be funded by governments, donors, foundations, private corporations and individuals.

The money could also be used to fund new media.

He observed that while a lot could be done in reorganizing the media to play its role more effectively, it was necessary for other institutions that impact on the media to restructure, reform and democratize.

Kupe expressed concern at the unethical decisions by media organizations in Africa who tend to push out editorial matter in order to accomodate advertisements so as to survive.

"Papers need advertising to survive but as the press becomes more commercialized information becomes less and less (important)," he said.

Veteran Zimbabwean journalist William Saidi said at the same course that in the southern region, the ideal editor was a myth. He said most editors in the region were directed by governments of the day.

He said it was pathetic to find that some news editors actually conspired with their governments on what to publish.

"It is a tragedy to have a paper which always praises government. Journalism in this region faces a big problem and editors are being killed slowly by government through pressure," Saidi said.

The three-week course sponsored by the NORDIC/Southern African Development Community Journalism Centre in Maputo, Mozambique, ran from January 29 to February 15.

It also looked looked at gender in the newsroom, media law, and journalism ethics.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Cameroon and Nigerian Leaders To Meet Over Bakassi


BYLINE: Randy Zormelo PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's miliary ruler Gen. Sani Abacha and Cameroonian President Paul Biya are to meet in March to iron out their differences over the disputed oil-rich Bakassi peninsula.

The Nigerian foreign ministry said the planned meeting came as a result of the mediatory talks held last week between the foreign ministers of both countries, Tom Ikimi of Nigeria and Ferdinand Oyono of Cameroon. Those talks were held under the auspices of Togo President Gnassingbe Eyadema.

Ikimi and Oyono will meet in the first week of March to work out details for the summit.

The Nigerian foreign ministry said the planned summit was "without prejudice" to the ongoing process at the International Court of Justice in the Hague.

Hostilities between Cameroon and Nigeria began in 1981 and resumed in 1994 over the peninsula situated on the southern border separating the two countries. A meeting scheduled in that year between the two leaders was called off at the last minute without any reason.

Then, Cameroon filed a complaint at the International Court. Nigeria responded in 1995 by filing preliminary objections to Cameroon's suit.

Fresh hostilities broke out February 3, 1996 with both countries suffering military casualties.

February, 1996


Museveni Vows to Crush Rebels


LENGTH: 427 words


 

MBALE, Uganda (PANA) - Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni has told rebels fighting his government in the north of the country to surrender or be wiped out.

In a strong statement he made Monday at a public rally at Mbale, eastern Uganda, Museveni said the national army had already gained the capacity to wipe out the Lord's Resistance Army led by Joseph Kony.

According to the Uganda government, LRA rebels infiltrated northern Uganda from Sudan last Wednesday and attacked Prongo trading centre in Gulu district, killing 14 civilians and burning two trucks and scores of homes. 

The rebels, estimated at some 500, on Saturday again ambushed a civilian vehicle convoy headed for the capital, Kampala, from the northwestern West Nile region. The number of casualties was not disclosed.

The government said in yet another battle between the Uganda People's Defence Forces and the rebels in Akalo-Chan, Lamogi division, 22 rebels were killed while three soldiers were seriously wounded.

Museveni said unlike in the past government troops were now highly mobile, making it easier for them to deal with the rebels.

"Anybody who tries to bring insecurity into Uganda again will be wiped out on the battlefield or go to jail," Museveni said.

Museveni, whose National Resistance Army (NRA) took over power in Kampala in January 1986, is expected to stand for his first election this year.

The polls are to be held under a "no party system" which bars aspirants from standing as representatives of political parties. They can stand as individuals.

The electoral method, endorsed by a constituent assembly last year, has been criticized by opposition leaders as a trick by Museveni to easily win the presidency.

Recently, the country's major opposition parties -- the Uganda People's Congress and the Democratic Party -- chose Paul Kawanga Semogerere as their joint candidate to challenge Museveni.

Firm Supports Nigeria's Hosting Of African Badminton Championship

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A Nigerian Petroleum company has donated one million naira (about 11,764 U.S. dollars) to the Badminton Federation of Nigeria, which hosts the All-Africa Championships, scheduled for March 17-24 in Lagos, an official of the federation said Friday. 

Federation Secretary Clement Iyaluegbeghe said the donation was cheering news and appealed to other corporations to do likewise.

Five countries -- Botswana, Ghana, Mauritius, Seychelles and Uganda -- have indicated their interest in participating in the tournament.

Iyaluegbeghe said arrangements had been concluded for a successful hosting of the competition.

No Clear Leader In Nigerian Premier League


BYLINE: Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's professional Division

One Football League enters week three this weekend with three teams justling for the top spot after two matches each.

Enyimba of ABA are perched on the top of table but only by virtue of a goal difference. The team shares the top spot with Sharks of Port Harcourt and Bendel Insurance of Benin.

Three teams are sharing joint second position and four, the third place. Four teams bring up the joint rear with no point from two matches in the 18-club championship.

Following are the teams standings and week-three fixtures:

Enyimba, Sharks and Insurance have six points each, Jasper United, Rangers International and Julius Berger (4) each, Gombe United, BCC Lions, Plateau United and Kano Pillars (3) each.

Eagle Cement, Shooting Stars and El-Kanemi (2) each, while Concord has one point. Iwuanyanwu, Udoji United, NEPA Lagos; and VIP Lagos have no point. Fixtures for Saturday: (ST) El-Kanemi vs Rangers Iwuanyanwu vs Berger BCC Lions vs Sharks NEPA vs Concord Plateau vs Jasper Gombe vs Enyimba Pillars vs VIP Udoji vs Shooting (match Sunday) Eagle Cement vs Insurance (match Sunday) (ST)

February, 1996


Lota Named Zambia's Footballer Of The Year


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's striker Dennis Lota was Friday crowned the counry's 1995 Footballer of The Year and Top Scorer of The Year at the Finance Bank Football Awards ceremony.

He received 350 U.S. dollars for the first award and 200 dollars as top scorer.

Lota, currently on trial with Dutch First Division side Feyenoord, plays for Zambia's Premier Division Konkola Blades Football Club in the northern copper-mining town of Chililambobwe. 

He finished the year with 23 goals, 16 in international games with the national team and seven goals in the local league.

He also received the top scorer award in 1994 with 23 goals.

Recently, at the 20th Africa Cup of Nations in South Africa, he scored three goals.

He was also the team's highest scorer at the 1995 All Africa Games in Harare where he notched four goals and two assists in during the four-nation Simba Cup Tournament hosted by South Africa in 1995.

The award for Super Division Champions went to Mufulira Wanderers Football Club from the norhthern copperbelt. The club recieved 2,000 dollars.

The First Division Award North Champions for 1,000 dollars went to Railway Express of Ndola, in the Copperbelt.

George Mungwa of Lifebouy Football Club in Ndola was elected Coach of The Year.

And Zambia has been rated first in Africa and 15th in the world after the Africa Cup finals in South Africa.

According to the World Soccer Rankings conducted by the world soccer governing body, FIFA, Zambia -- which emerged third in the 15-nation Africa cup tournament won by South Africa, is followed immediately by Ghana in the world ranking and second in Africa.

South Africa, making its first appearance in the Africa Cup tournament, is ranked fourth immediately behind Egypt.

Tunisia is rated sixth in Africa after emerging second best in Africa Cup finals and Cote D'Ivoire fifth.

Okwawu Sink Olympics To Stretch Lead


LENGTH: 267 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Okwawu United on Sunday stretched their lead to four points in Ghana's premier football league table when they humbled Olympics 2-0 at the Accra sports stadium while defending champions Goldfields stumbled at home to a 1-0 defeat at the hands of Accra hearts of Oak.

Okwawu scored a goal in each half through Usifu Yakubu and E. Hanson to secure the three points for Okwawu who now have 40 points. 

At the bottom of the league table, Voradep secured a 1-0 away win over King Faisal, through of a 24th-minute penalty. (ST)

February, 1996


Cameroon's National League Kicks off At last


LENGTH: 294 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - All the 16 teams in Cameroon's premier league played their first match Sunday in the National Football League.

This ended a long spell of uncertainty about when this year's championships would begin. 

The beginning of the league matches was characterised by poor standards of soccer which analysts attributed to the absence of some top strikers whose transfers are still in litigation.

In addition, most clubs have not yet held their statutory congresses. These are usually held before the start of the football season to discuss the financial, administrative situations and to plan strategies.

In last Sunday's matches, two of the three newly promoted teams, Kumbo Strikers and Olympic of Maroua, played their first, first division encounters. Dynamo of Douala returned to the division after a three-year absence.

Olympic and Dynamo drew 1-1 in Maroua while new comers Kumbo Strikers fell 1-0 to Leopard of Douala.

Defending champions Racing Bafoussam edged Prevoyance Yaounde 2-1. Canon Yaounde were beaten at home 2-1 by visiting Cotonsport of Garoua, Union Douala edged Stade Bandjoum 1-0.

Similar 1-0 scores were registered in the Fovu Baham-Ocean Krii and Unisport Bafang-Panthere Bangnagte encounrters.

February, 1996


Nigeria Prepares For Olympic Soccer Qualifier


BYLINE: Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 254 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria has forwarded to the world's soccer governing body, FIFA, a list of 16 Europe-based players to represent the country in the two-leg Olympic qualifier against Zambabwe, the country's football association official said Thursday in Lagos.

Nigerian Football Association Spokesman Austin Mgbolu said Nigeria decided to notify FIFA beforehand to prevent sabotage by their clubs. 

Nigerian international Kanu Nwankwo of Ajax Amsterdam is captain of the under-23 national squad, which includes Wilson Orumah of Lens in France and Austin "Jay-Jay" Okocha, who plays in Germany.

Home lads in the Nigerian team, coached by Willy Bazuaye, are being camped at the middle-belt city of Jos.

They will be joined by their foreign-based counterparts ahead of the first leg of the African qualifying series comes up in Harare March 2.

The return leg of the match takes place in Lagos later to choose one of Africa's representatives at the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta, United States.

Mgbolu said Dutchman Bonfrere Jo, Nigeria's senior team coach, has been drafted to assist Bazuaye in preparing the nation's under-23 squad for the crucial qualifying ties against Zimbabwe.

148 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Budget Dampens Money Market


BYLINE: Randy Zormelo PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - There was a lull in Lagos currency market at the weekend following the announcement last Friday of the country's budget.

Open market currency dealers better known here as the "black market", had expected the 1996 budget to scrap the dual exchange rate of the local currency and the central bank window, the autonomous fereign exchange market (AFEM), because it had been affecting business.

The government in the 1995 budget reregulated the exchange rate of the naira by fixing its official exchange rate at 22 to the dollar. The central bank also introduced AFEM from which investors bought hard currency through bidding often more favurable than the prevailing rate in the parallel market. 

The 1996 budget maintained the status quo, thereby depriving currency dealers of possible spin-offs that would have resulted from a total liberalisation of the exchange rate.

Between Friday and Monday, activitty on Braod Street, the "Wall Street" of Lagos, was dull with little movement in the value of currencies.

The dollar which had rebounded in the market to 86 naira was static just like the Deutsch mark which continues to exchange for 57.50 naira.

The British pound was in no better shape. Two days before the budget was released, it lost about 1.50 in trading, closing at 131 naira from 133 naira previously.

Since last year, the money market has been affected by events in AFEM as rates of the hard currencies usually dropped after an intervention or build-up prior to the next intervention.

Since November when the Nigerian Central Bank regularised trading at its window, most foreign currency rates fell in the black market.

For instance, the naira gained in value from an aveage of 95 to one United States dollar to to an average of 85 to one greenback.

In January, this rate dropped further to 84 after AFEM intervened for the first time in the new year.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


New Zaire Slumps Again, CFA Gains


BYLINE: Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 227 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - After the misfortunes of the Ghanaian cedi last week, the new Zaire took another plunge this week, opening Tuesday at the nominal rate of 24,119 to the dollar from 23,132 last week.

Analysts attribute the fall to what they described as the "socio-economic situation of the moment", in reference to the introduction of new higher denomination bank notes by the Kinshasa government. 

The NZ exchaged at three to one dollar when it was introduced in October 1993 to replace the old "Zaire" which had almost become worthless when it exchanged at 20 million for one greenback.

But the CFA (African Finance Community) franc used in 13 French-speaking African countries gained six points, opening Tuesday at the nominal rate of 501 to one dollar from 507 to the American currency on the same day last week.

Similarly, in Dakar, Senegal, Tuesday the CFA exchanged at 487 (buying) and 517 (selling) to the dollar. Last week the rate was 492 (buying) and 522 (selling) to one greenback.

Africa News


February, 1996


South African Exports To Zimbabwe On the Rise


LENGTH: 320 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The value of South African exports to Zimbabwe now equal those it sends to Germany, the republic's second biggest trading partner in the world.

The S. African department of trade and industry says in a report obtained from its high commission in Harare that the country's exports to Zimbabwe were increasingly becoming important and should be taken seriously. 

South Africa expected its exports to African markets, especially Zimbabwe, to have climbed to 9.1 billion zimdollars (1 billion USD) in 1995.

Zimbabwe is South Africa's top African trading partner, and trade between the two countries shot up 40 percent between 1993 and 1994 and surged a further 45 percent during 1995.

In 1994, Zimbabwe imported 6.5 billion ZIMDOLLARS (722 million USD) worth of products, exporting products worth only 2.6 billion ZIMDOLLARS (289 million USD).

The report says South Africa's intra-African exports were mainly chemicals, base metals, processed foods, vegetable products, paper and board, textiles, animal products, mineral products, manufactured items like furniture, cement and instrumentation.

Partial lifting of exchange controls allowing South African companies to invest more freely in the region, and this was expected to further promote growth and trade.

Zimbabwe and South Africa are currently discussing renewal of their outdated 1964 bilateral trade agreement.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


151 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


World Trade Achieved Record Growth in 1994


LENGTH: 307 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - World trade in goods which had fallen to an all-time low in 1993 grew 12.5 percent in 1994, the highest growth rate since 1990, according to International Monetary Fund balance of payment statistics year book.

Trade in services also increased in 1994 by 7.3 percent, but while this marked a sizeable gain for services trade, growth rate was well below that of 1990, when services trade grew by 20 percent. 

Much of 1994 increase in trade in goods and services was accounted for by industrial countries and developing nations in Asia and the western hemisphere.

Industrial countries posted a current account deficit of some 1,117 billion zimdollars (13 billion USD) and net capital inflows of about 387 billion zimdollars (43 billion USD) in 1994.

This was in contrast to 1993, when these countries registered a current account surplus of about 180 billion zimdollars (20 billion USD), accompanied by net capital outflows of roughly equal amounts.

Developing countries and economies in transition saw their combined current account deficit narrow by 30 percent in 1994, while their net capital inflows slowed down considerably.

The IMF said the reversal between 1993 and 1994 from a surplus to a deficit in industrial countries' combined current account can be traced to current transfers and the income components of the balance of payments.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Wheat Market To Be Liberalised


LENGTH: 600 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The wheat market in Zimbabwe is expected to be liberalised by April this year, allowing for the first time the private sector to compete with the state-owned Grain Marketing Board (GMB) to import the crop, producers said on Monday.

The Chief Executive of the Zimbabwe Cereal Producers Association, Peter Wells, said the liberalisation of wheat marketing would benefit producers, although they would have wished the government allowed them to export the wheat as well.

"Wheat marketing is to be further liberalised in April and the GMB will no longer have the sole right to import wheat. 

"But because of the lead time, from ordering to delivery, the GMB will probably carry on importing wheat up to June or July when the private companies will be able to bring their own supplies," Wells said.

He said farmers expected agriculture minister Dennis Norman to make a major agricultural policy statement soon, which was expected to include more details on liberalising agricultural marketing.

The government has, however, made it clear it would not allow export of wheat until national requirements have been met.

Wheat growers have been urging government to completely liberalise wheat marketing, as has been done with the coffee crop, which led to the formation of a privately-owned processing company.

"We are concerned that the liberalisation applies to imports and not exports as it puts producers at a disadvantage. otherwise, I think it will benefit the industry," he said.

Wells, meanwhile, said up to 200,000 tonnes of wheat was expected to be imported this year to meet domestic shortfalls caused by reduced production during 1995.

Wells said the GMB had been importing about 25,000 tonnes of wheat per month since the programme started last year, and supplies had come from as far as the United States, Australia and India.

The GMB on Monday announced it would soon go to tender for the importation of another consignment of wheat, but did not say how much it wanted to procure.

Output in 1995 was estimated at 85,000 tonnes compared with the 288,000 tonnes produced from 52,000 hectares in 1994.

Zimbabwean wheat is usually grown during the winter months using irrigation.

Wells said indications were that production this year would increase, mainly as a result of improved water supplies following above normal rains during the 1995/96 season.

Unrestricted national demand, once estimated at 400,000 tonnes a year, has been revised to between 325,000 and 350,000 tonnes, following the decontrol of bread and flour prices in line with the government's market reforms launched in 1990.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

February, 1996


Horticultural Exports On The Rise


LENGTH: 334 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe has so far earned 450.7 million ZIMDOLLARS (50 million USD) from exports of flowers and fresh horticultural produce this season.

Horticulture Promotion Council chief executive Stanley Heri said in an interview that despite the heavy rains which damaged some of the flowers, the 1995/96 season had been good and exports were on target. 

"Damage from the rains was very minimal and according to our export projections, we are on target. Fresh produce has been excellent due to the good weather," Heri said.

For the current season, the Council plans to export 12,300 tonnes of flowers compared to 9,200 tonnes the previous year.

Between July last year and January this year, 6,233 tonnes of flowers had been exported, Heri said.

For the 1994/95 season, 8,000 tonnes of fruit and vegetables were exported and 11,685 tonnes were expected to be exported by the end of June this year.

At the end of January 1996, 6,000 tonnes had been exported since July last year.

Earnings from flower and fresh produce exports in the 1994/95 season were 675 million zimdollars (75 million USD) and this was expected to reach 900 million zimdollars (100 million USD).

Zimbabwe is Africa's second largest exporter of flowers and fresh horticultural produce, and was increasingly strengthening its position in Europe.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Foreign Reserves Reach Record High


BYLINE: Moses Draku PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda has accumulated over 440 million dollars in foreign reserves, the highest ever attained by the east African country in many years.

The reserves rose from 219 million dollars in June 1994 to 386 million in June 1995, the Governor of the (central) Bank of Uganda, Charles Kikonyogo told chief executives of commercial banks in Uganda at the weekend. 

He told the second annual dinner of the Institute of Bankers that the reserves kept in various foreign banks were equivalent to about four months of the country's imports.

"The performance of the Ugandan economy during the past year has been exceptionally strong" Kikonyogo said.

"All evidence suggests that the crown in national production has been well sustained in the current financial year.

Domestic prices remain under control and the shilling is stable in terms of other currencies," he aadded.

Uganda was generally perceived by the international finance community as a country that has followed sensible economic policies and a model for other countries to emulate, he said.

But the governor warned that there was no room for complacency. "Much remains to be done if the nation is to sustain and improve growth and stability".

Kikonyogo said over time, banks must increase financing options open to borrowers saying the central bank's main obligation was to act in the interest of customers if the commercial banks were unable to meet minimum standards.

The chairman of Uganda Bankers Assocation, Ezra Suruma, called for immediate reform in the banking sector saying banks should be privatised.

"The public must be convinced that the banking systen is safe and sound today, tomorrow and for decades to come" Suruma who is the chief execuitive the giant Uganda Commercial Bank, told bankers.
