LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Mixed Reactions On Nigeria's 1996 Budget


BYLINE: Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 747 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - There have been mixed reactions to Nigeria's 1996 budget released last Thursday by military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha.

Some key business captains commend the seemingly liberal monetary policies it introduced while others say there were doubts on how they would be implemented.

Kayode Familoni, an economics consultant at the University of Lagos, is among those who support the government's decision to "consolidate" the gains of the fiscal and monetary policies of 1995. 

However, he suggests a fine-tuning of the policies "to match existing realities."

Some financial operators are however, adopting a a wait-and-see attitude to the budget, which maintains a 1995 ceiling of 21 percent on interest rate and a dual foreign exchange rate.

The 22 naira to the dollar rate is strictly for government transactions, while the currency floats at a rate of between 80 and 85 naira to the greenback.

Familoni said the 1995 inflation rate estimated at 80 percent by the Central Bank of Nigeria, coupled with the existing lending rate resulted in "negative real rate, and this in the long run, will discourage savings and investment in the economy."

The 125 billion naira or 5.68 billion dollars budget, is predicated on oil sales at the price of 16 dollars per barrel for fiscal 1996.

Oil accounts for more than 80 percent of Nigeria's total foreign exchange earnings and the country currently lifts some two million barrels of crude daily.

However, some economists say basing the budget on oil price of 16-dollar-a-barrel appears too "ambitious," pointing out that the 15 dollars for a barrel on which the 1995 budget was based would have been ideal, given the unstable international oil market.

A former Nigerian finance minister, Onaolapo Soleye, has dismissed the budget as "vague and empty."

Soleye, minister during the 20-month military regime of Gen. Muhammadu Buhari, claimed the 1996 budget was silent on how to reduce poverty in the populous west African country of some 100 people.

Abacha had announced tax relief and employment generation as some "poverty alleviation" measures in the budget.

But Soleye argued that the budget did not elaborate on how to arrest run-away inflation, which aggravates poverty in the country.

An official of the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria (MAN), michael Oladeinde, also picked a hole in the government's proposed measures against "double-taxation" imposed on companies.

He said lack of clarity on the issue and the setting up of panels to punish economic saboteurs, was a "delay tactic", and could continue to hinder economic growth in the country.

On the other hand, many industrialists, including Erastus Akingbola of the Nigerian International Merchant Bank, have praised the consistency in the 1996 budget, which they consider a welcome departure from previous budgets.

Akingbola said government deserved praise, especially for retaining key aspects of the "guided deregulation" policy.

Christopher Kolade, chairman of Cadbury Nigeria Plc, a leading foods and beverages retail outlet, also expressed happiness there was no "reversal of the positive moves made last year."

But like most other economic operators, Kolade feels it is too early to judge the estimates, warning that implementation remains a key factor.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


IMF Team in Zambia for Talks


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - An International Monetary Fund (IMF) team is in Zambia for consultations with government officials before Lusaka starts to draw from the fund's new Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF).

The team, led by the IMF director for Africa, Ekis Calamatis, is on a regular two-week annual consultation. 

Zambia in 1995 qualified to borrow under the more favourable ESAF after successfully executing a three-year Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP).

Zambian officials have expressed confidence that under ESAF, with its low 0.5 percent interest rates and longer repayment periods, the country could achieve an estimated six per cent annual growth rate from this year up to 1998.

The Paris Club donor community in December gave Zambia some USD 850 million aid under ESAF terms.

The donors have said that Zambia needs to complement economic development efforts with improvements in the quality of life for its nationals.

Zambian officials have acknowledged that about 70 percent of the country's nine million people are poor and that life expectancy is down to an all-time low of 40 years while the infant mortality has seen an upward spiral.

About one third of Zambia's 1996 budget, presented by finance minister Ronald Penza in January, has been financed by donors. Penza said that about two thirds on this year's capital expenditure would go to areas intended to stimulate economic growth and the social sector, to help improve the living standards of the poor majority.

The minister is next week expected to leave for Paris for further consultations on the country's USD 850 milllion loan.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


United States and Africa New President For The American Committee On Africa


BYLINE: American Committee on Africa (New York) February 22, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

New York - The highly respected human rights figure and former chief of staff to Martin Luther King, Jr. in the early 1960's, Dr. Wyatt Tee Walker, was elected President of the American Committee on Africa (AC0A) at a recent Board Meeting.

Dr. Walker is the Senior Pastor of the Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in New York's Harlem Community. His Presidency will significantly strengthen the efforts of the American Committee on Africa for human rights and justice at a time when there is an immense attack on programs for the poor in the U.S. and on development assistance for correcting centuries of injustices in Africa. 

The American Committee on Africa was formed to support the struggle for African freedom and self determination in 1953, at a time when there were only four independent African countries. Forty three years later, it continues to mobilize Americans on behalf of justice for Africa.

On accepting his new position as President, Dr. Walker indicated that "the assaults on the poor by the right wing radical leaders in our country is a travesty to the ideals of freedom, justice and democracy our people have been struggling for historically; this is true here in the U.S. as in Africa, where liberation and democratic successes are more and more overshadowed with social and economic injustices. Nevertheless, we are determined to wage our struggle for justice forever forward."

In April 1994, he led a Religious Action Network delegation to South Africa to observe the historic all-race election to end apartheid and returned a month later as an invited guest to celebrate the inauguration of Nelson Mandela as the first President of a free and democratic South Africa.

Dr. Walker's book, "Soweto Diary" gives an account of his experience during the election.

As Secretary General of the Religious Action Network, Wyatt Tee Walker addressed national and international gatherings, including the U.S. Congress and the United Nations on human rights, economic justice and development issues concerning Africa.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Cricket: Team Tactics to Beat Runs


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Mark Lamport-Stokes


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

Johannesburg - When it comes to any visiting cricketer's diet on the sub-continent, it is generally a case of forewarned is forearmed.

Stories of the debilitating effect of "Delhi belly" and "Bombay bug" are legion in both Test and one-day international cricket and many a player touring this part of the world has had to settle for run-accumulation of the erratic kind.

A few years ago an English agency journalist (who shall remain nameless) became such a victim and had to rely on his initiative while covering a Test series in India. Spending most of his time during the hours of play firmly rooted to the "gents", he arranged for a television to be placed in his line of sight and was then able to deliver accurate, running copy of the reliable kind.

To date, the 1996 World Cup has been no exception and several players have fallen victim to one or other virus. 

Seven members of the Netherlands side were laid low after eating spaghetti bolognaise in Baroda on the eve of their tournament opener against New Zealand, and Australians Shane Warne and Ricky Ponting had to miss a few training sessions in Bombay with upset stomachs.

Surprisingly, even one of the home countries was affected when Indian leg-spinner Anil Kumble contracted viral fever and came close to missing his side's victory over Kenya at Cuttack on Sunday.

Yet one side which has not been affected during their time in Pakistan is South Africa. This can be attributed to their astute, scientific preparation and the meticulous monitoring by the team fitness specialist Paddy Upton.

"At the risk of stating the obvious, it's no good having a team that's extremely fit and perhaps the best batting or fielding team in the world if the guys are sick," Upton says.

"We have to give everyone the best possible opportunity of performing at their optimum and, to keep the guys away from 'Delhi belly', we have prepared from a long way out."

Upton foucuses on two measures that can be taken to prevent the cricketer's nightmare on the sub-continent. "First of all, the guys in our team twice a week take a broad spectrum antibiotic to prevent it. Then the other method of prevention that we use is probably one of our strongest weapons against it -- and that's education.

"A year ago when the guys were first introduced to a way of eating in terms of a diet for weight maintenance -- be it for loss or gain -- and also for performance, I found I was needing to prescribe meals for the whole team. But now, instead of prescribing, I've more facilitated and educated them so they can sit down and pretty much know exactly what they should be ordering."

As all visitors to the East know only too clearly, the water is usually the common denominator with "Delhi belly".

"Obviously the water is a bug danger," Upton says. "There is a lot of virus in the water here and we try to stay away from it as much as possible. The players brush their teeth with bottled water and in the shower, and even with general horse-play in the swimming pool, they are very aware of not swallowing the water.

"Also, with fresh vegetables and lettuces which have been washed in water, the guys stay away from that. Normally, fresh vegetables and fruit are good for you but here we only eat fruit where you have to peel the skin off."

When it comes to the question of food and what to eat, Upton keeps everything simple and

logical: "The guys tend to avoid food where you can't really see what you are eating, and the favourites there are 'chicken a la king' where old chickens can be used.

"A few of the guys have eaten spaghetti bolognaise, but I think that's also a pretty dodgy one because old meat can be used and pretty much anything can be chopped up to look like bolognaise. But, with a piece of meat or a piece of chicken, you can actually see what you're eating and that can't really be doctored in any way.

"Then again the guys know that the number one food type they should be eating is carbohydrates -- which is your rices and breads -- and it is very difficult to get ill from eating that type of food."

Much of Upton's stringent preparation of the team food relates to match days. "On match days, the meals have been prescribed before we even arrive at the ground. Menus went out to the hotels so we know exactly what goes into them. And all the food at the ground is catered by the hotels that we're stayng at, so we have plenty of time ahead of the match to chat with the food and beverage managers about what they're going to prepare and how they are going to prepare it.

"We stay away from oils and fats on a playing day because that can impare performance or it impares the body from getting to the carbohydrates which is really your energy food. We also discuss things like spices for chicken curry and how hot it must be. All the hotels in Pakistan have so far been really good in that respect."

As Upton says, there is so much that can be done to educate the cricketer, but it is then up to him to call the shots: "The guys must then be able to choose for themselves. We've gone through every scenario where you can pick up Delhi belly or eat inappropriately and the guys in the team are all 100 percent aware of that and are on the lookout."

Intriguingly, Upton believes the local cuisine on the sub-continet is often a better alternative than Western food: "As long as the guys are eating in the top restaurants and the top hotels, the Pakistan dishes are often the best bet. But to eat from a corner cafe or a side-street cook-up is courting danger.

"If the players can see what they are eating, and it's not a minced up dish but a chicken dish or a chicken curry -- one of the specialities of the country -- in a lot of places that's probably safer than the Western option.

"With Western food, they're bound to be less familiar with its cooking, and because of that, the food sits in the fridge for longer and it might be re-used the next day. Then, on the other hand, the traditional dishes are being served up all the time and hsould be a lot safer."

Although South Africa are only a couple of weeks into their World Cup journey, the Upton philosophy of safe eating and fitness maintenance has been a resounding success. Not only are South Africa considered to be the fittest side at the World Cup, but their collective bill of health has been remarkably clean.

"There have been no problems so far," Upton admits, "and we very affectionately and jokingly call Tim Noakes (the team doctor) Doctor Dolittle because we haven't had many illnesses or many patienst to take care of.

"A few of the guys have had a few sniffles but nothinbg serious. Everything's been tidy so far."

If the secret to continued success lies in Upton's preparation, then that should remain the situation for the rest of South Africa's journey through the sub-continent.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


159 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Business Cola Wars Light Up Johannesburg


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Ricardo Dunn


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Johannesburg - The cola wars are lighting up Johannesburg, providing a new landmark and much pleasure for the city's bugs.

The new 15m-high sign on top of Hillbrow's Ponte building -- the largest and tallest in Africa -- is attracting the attention of passers-by and insects. Tenants say the lighting is attracting swarms of night-time bugs. 

After several attempts by Ponte management to lure companies to advertise on top of the 12- year-old residential block, Coca-Cola recently took the gap.

Although Pepsi was also approached by Ponte, their advertising agency felt that the sign was an unnecessary tactic in the cola war

"We were approached before Coke, but decided not to use the space as we felt that Coke needed the exposure more than we did," said David Haley, media group head at Saatchi and Saatchi.

Pepsi, although reluctant to reveal details on how it would counteract the sign, said that it had "something in the pipeline"

The sign, equivalent to a five-storey building, was installed by Johannesburg-based Natanya signs. Work began on the sign at the beginning of the Rugby World Cup last year and it was lit up at the close of the Africa Cup of Nations on February 9.

The lights are switched on every day from 5:30 pm until 5 am.

With a total weight of 6,4 tons, the neon sign consists of 20km of neon glass (84 000m of white neon and 12 3 000m of red neon). Manufacturers of this glass spent almost two months making the 4 250 individual neon units with 21 000m of wiring.

Most residents spoken to at Ponte City this week said they don't really mind that the top of their building now looks like a beacon for incoming air traffic. But the bright lights has also attracted a few unwelcomed visitors.

Although most of the residents said they were happy with the sign, Jerry Kae, a tenant said that although the sign gave the building a different look, especially at night, it did attract swarms of insects which started to annoy some of the residents.

Meanwhile, a tenant who lives in the penthouse said that unless it is cloudy the sign does not reflect into his home. "However when it is misty the the combination of the red from the sign and the white of the clouds transforms the place into a pink palace." he said.

Lebonetse Baloyi, who moved into the building at the start of construction, said he welcomed the sign but was annoyed that the construction company did not remove any of the rubble generated during construction of the sign.

According to recent statistics from Coca-Cola, South Africans consume at least 50 Coca-Colas every second throughout the year.

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Watchdog Wants Multi-Year Budget


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Lynda Loxton


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Johannesburg - First, there is the annual budget, in which government spells out its expenditure and revenue targets for the next year. But, running parallel to this is the Reconstruction and Development Programme Fund, which also makes allocations to various departments to build clinics or feed schoolchildren.

When departments find they are running out of money before the end of the financial year in March, they ask for additional funds, which are approved in the Adjustments Appropriation Bill. This bill also details those departments that have not been able to spend all their money for the year and need to get permission to roll it over to the next year. 

African National Congress MP Barbara Hogan told the committee she found it "very difficult" to keep track of exactly what government was spending. The sooner the government moved on to multi-year budgets under a medium-term expenditure plan, the better the committee would be able to do its job of being the nation's budget watchdog, she said.

The committee was drafting its report on the Adjustments Estimates Bill and the issue of roll-over funds was of particular concern.

The principle of allowing departments to roll-over funds not spent in one year to another was introduced in 1993/94 to prevent departments from going on a spending spree at the end of each financial year if all funds were not used up. The roll-over funds cannot be spent on recurrent expenditure.

This year, the roll-over funds have almost doubled to R6,9-billion and Hogan said this made it difficult to assess the budget allocations properly.

The Department of Defence's roll-over was a sizeable R1,2-billion but, Hogan said, there was no indication whether this was because it had ear-marked the money for a long-term project that had not yet got off the ground. Thus the need for multi-year budgets to give a clearer picture of what is happening.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa World Bank Bids Its Time


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Johannesburg - The plush Hyde Park offices of the World Bank in Johannesburg are more in keeping with a corporate bank than an organisation dedicated to alleviating poverty. And that dichotomy is reflected in the bank's role in this country.

South Africa last borrowed money in late 1993, from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and since then has followed a strict no-loans policy. 

Judith Edstrom, the new resident representative of the bank in South Africa, says the government's position is clear. Organisations such as the bank, the IMF and African Development Bank are held at arm's length, encouraged only to play an advisory role. But as she says, a lending relationship is not imperative. Indeed, as South Africa is classified as a middle-income country, it does not qualify for the World Bank's favourable interest rates.

More importantly, the government does not want to send out the wrong political signals -- borrowing from the World Bank would, for one, indicate a freer spending policy, with concomitant reverberations around the financial markets.

The bank is not a popular institution in Africa; even supporters of unbridled capitalism have reservations about the impact of its structural adjustment policies on developing communities.

Edstrom admits mistakes were made; safety nets for the poorest were not always in place -- nor very effective. But she cautions against blaming structural adjustment per se; it has become a catch-phrase covering every bank initiative that ever went wrong.

There have been successful policies, however, particularly in education and health -- of particular interest to Edstrom, who spent five years working for Unicef in Kenya. And it is in these areas, as well as on the bigger, infrastructure projects, that the bank's international experience is of value to the South Africans.

As a dyed-in-the-wool World Banker, she believes in market-oriented development; on that score, the bank has no reason to be unhappy. Indeed, South Africa is seen as something of a success story; the extent of the Bank's collaboration at government level is significant.

Edstrom points to the informal channels of discussion with politicians and government institutions on the whole gamut of development issues, from primary health care to regional trade.

There is still a huge need for aid agencies, as well as non-government organisations, and part of her job is to act as interlocutor between the various bodies. She emphasises their complementary r_les; being more specialised they cater to niche markets while, by virtue of the sheer size of its operations, the World Bank is often seen as blundering around like a "big elephant", especially at grass-roots level.

Under the bank's new head, James Wolfensohn, such collaborative relationships are actively encouraged. It worked in Vietnam, where non- financial support was provided for up to six years before a lending programme was signed.

But the bank is not known for its altruism. So how long can it continue offering technical assistance and development advice with no pay- back? As long as it takes, says Edstrom. It's not as if the government has issued an unequivocal "no" to any prospect of borrowing; it is merely considering its options. And as long as that advice is appreciated, the World Bank is happy to stay.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Planned Corridor to Link Mozambique and South Africa


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Karen Harverson


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Johannesburg - Three industrial projects -- still just a glimmer in the eye -- may be built in Maputo, if the R1-billion infrastructural corridor project to improve road and rail links between South Africa and Mozambique is successful.

Primary aluminium producer Alusaf may consider building a second smelter in Maputo as part of its long-term strategic planning. "The temptation would be to use power from Cahora Bassa," says managing director Rob Barbour, adding that it is still just a concept. 

The company is busy commissioning its R5- billion double-size smelter plant in Richards Bay with a production capacity of 460 000 tons. The first smelter was commissioned in December 1995 and completion of the second phase is expected by July this year.

Barbour says other international companies had looked at the Maputo option before but rejected it because of the lack of infrastructure. "Now, hopefully this won't be such a big factor in the future."

Two other projects, still under discussion, both involve state-owned Foskor and the international fertiliser market.

The first fertiliser project concerns Indian company Southern Petrochemical Industries Corporation (Spic), expected to arrive in South Africa within a fortnight to evaluate building a plant in Maputo to process phosphate rock, mined by Foskor, into phosphoric acid for supply to India.

Foskor managing director Danie Vorster says interest has been expressed by certain companies in India to establish a phosphoric acid project in Maputo based on phosphate rock from Phalaborwa. "It is possible that Spic is part of such a consortium but we have not had a direct approach from Spic in this regard."

He said the company had previously had discussions with Spic about the possible supply of phosphate rock to its facilities in India, but to date no real interest has been shown on their part for such a supply.

Foskor's phosphate rock is of a high grade and some 25% of production is railed to Indian Ocean Fertilisers in Richards Bay -- jointly owned by Foskor and the Togolese government - -- both for beneficiation and export.

If the project in Maputo got the go-ahead, it is likely that the company would increase its production as its reserves are believed to be enormous.

Two options for transporting the rock to Maputo could be considered: one involves the building of a slurry pipe to transport the rock but this is dodgy because of the general shortage of water in the area. The second option would be to rail the rock, and this could be facilitated by the plan to build an artery off the main development corridor from Witbank to Maputo up into the Tzaneen region.

"At present, there are no pipeline facilities for the delivery of rock to Maputo and phosphate rock is not exported via Maputo by Foskor," says Vorster.

In the second proposal, Maputo is being considered as a second option only. It involves a large fertiliser complex being built in Richards Bay with players Sasol, Phalaborwa-based Foskor and Norwegian company Hydro Agri each bringing their competitive advantage to the table.

Sasol would supply gas from Secunda, Foskor would provide the phosphate rock and Hydro Agri would supply its marketing network in the international fertiliser market. "As an option, other sites such as Maputo could be considered because it is closer to Phalaborwa," says an industry source.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Listening To The Voices Of The Poor


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Lynda Loxton


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Johannesburg - The top-down approach by governments and development agencies in dealing with rural poverty came under attack this week at the first regional conference to deal with the issue.

Katherine Marshall, World Bank director in charge of the region, asked whether southern African governments were relying on rhetoric rather than real action on the ground to deal with the problem.

President of the International Fund for Agricultural Development, Fawzi Hamad Al- Sultan, warned that this could be a short- sighted approach as it was contributing to the endless migration of poor people from rural to urban areas. "It is the lack of opportunity in the countryside that pushes the migrants out, adding to urban unemployment and straining urban civic services to breaking point," Al- Sultan said. 

"Poverty is increasing but we know we have the knowledge and the means to end it ... if we fail, the poor will tell us themselves and if we wait too long, their judgement will not be gentle."

Marshall said that in South Africa, 81% of the poorest people live in rural areas; in Lesotho, the figure is 91%, in Malawi 95%, in Zambia 76% and in Zimbabwe 92%. "The gap between the rich and the poor may be wider in this region of the world than in any other," she said.

She attributed this to the persistence of barriers bred in colonial times that still blocked the rural poor's access to fertile land and resources, as well as their isolation from major markets and poor access to social services.

Both she and Al-Sultan believe the answer lies in a more sustainable programme to make small- scale farming productive; and improved infrastructure and social services. Opening the workshop, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said an integrated process was needed that took all these factors into account, plus skills development.

All speakers, however, stressed the need to "hear the voices of the poor" and involve them in all planning and implementation.

Marshall said the poor could not continue to be "passive actors" in their development if attempts to improve their lot were to succeed.

This could be more costly and time-consuming than "old ways of doing business, but it is the only way of guaranteeing that our efforts are effective and successful".

As a representative of the World Bank, Marshall talked about the need for macro- economic balance and especially the need to ensure that the "myths" surrounding the kinds of painful structural adjustment programmes undertaken by many countries in the region did not undermine political leaders and development programmes.

"As economic growth begins to return to southern Africa, we need to turn our attention to the more difficult policy issues by focusing on the quality of that economic growth ... to ensure that the poor are not bypassed, so ensuring they are not treated as some sort of economic afterthought," she said.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Business The Double-Edged Sword Of Privatisation


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Simon Segal


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Johannesburg - Amid all the fuss about what to do with state assets, does the improved performance of South Africa's public enterprises make it easier or more difficult to privatise them? It is, as information service group BusinessMap points out, a "double-edged sword".

Privatising these assets -- or in government-speak, "restructuring these assets" -- becomes less attractive to government the better they perform. Why get rid of something good and potentially lucrative both financially and politically? The unions are particularly sensitive about this.

But, on the other hand, the assets become more valuable and thus realise greater proceeds from any sale. Indeed, a primary objective of these enterprises over the past few years has been to make them commercially viable for any future investor. In this regard, government can talk about success. 

Consider Transnet, Eskom and Denel, by far the three largest public enterprises (Telkom and the Post Office are structured differently with the state their sole shareholder. they do not fall under the ministry of Public Enterprises).

Transnet, the state-owned transport group, operates South African Airways (SAA), Spoornet (the railways), Portnet (harbours), Petronet (pipelines), PX (container distribution) and Autonet. Its assets are R39,2-billion. The 1995 financial year marked a significant milestone for Transnet when it reported its first profit (R118-million) in four years. Of this, Spoornet contributed R734-million (R576- million in 1994), Portnet R1,1-billion (R766- million), SAA R217-million (-R23-million), Petronet R144-million (R149-million), Autonet R20-million (R17-million) and PX a R297- million loss (-R344-million).

Without its almost R1,8-billion pension contribution, the group would thus have made R1,9-billion.

BusinessMap reports that Transnet is doubling its capital investments from R1,2-billion in 1994/95 (of which R750-million was for expansion) to R2,5-billion this year (R1,5- billion).

Eskom has seen its net income rise 20% over 1995 to R2,7-billion and operating income rise 6,5% to R5,8-billion.

Total revenue is up 11% to R17,1-billion and the debt/equity ratio dropped to 1,45 (1,73 at the end of 1994). Its assets are R41-billion.

Arms manufacturer Denel (formerly Armscor) began trading as a private company in 1992. Its assets are worth R4,1-billion.

Its two-pronged strategy of exporting and diversifying have seen military exports double from R480-million in 1992 to R996-million in 1995 and commercial exports grow from R31- million to R186-million over this period.

Total income is up from R2,8-billion in 1992 to R3,2-billion in 1995 and net income before tax is up from R290-million to R325-million in 1994. Denel paid a R70-million dividend to government last year.

Says BusinessMap: "The reports are so glowing that it might well be asked why government thinks it's necessary to have a national strategy of restructuring its enterprises -- rather than simply addressing a few problematic ones and leaving the ownership of the rest intact.

"However, all that glitters is not gold. Profitability is improving, but it can be argued that with restructuring, government could get more from its enterprises."

The public enterprises form an integral component in shaping and supporting the economic infrastructure behind government's reconstruction and development programme (RDP). Because of their strategic products and size -- -- the Financial Mail ranks Eskom and Transnet as South Africa's 10th and 11th largest businesses respectively in terms of assets -- they are in a position to play a dramatic supportive role in South Africa's socio-economic transition.

Their products, particularly electricity and rail, ship and air transport, are the engine room for the economy's development and well- being.

Thus, what to do with these state assets has immense consequences politically, socially and economically.

Minister Stella Sigcau has overseen the shift in policy from being broadly neutral -- neither privatise nor nationalise, but commercialise -- to one of accepting their "restructuring".

However, Telkom, not under Sigcau's authority, is likely to be the first state enterprise to test government's new restructuring policy when it obtains a strategic equity partner, possibly this year.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Business South African Reserve Bank Ponders Rand's Decline


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Johannesburg - The rand's slide shows no sign of abating and sentiment is still heavily weighted against a turnaround. At the time of going to press, the dollar rate was heading for R4, while sterling had already broken through the R6 barrier. 

Intervention by the Reserve Bank has been sporadic and light, underlining the government's reluctance to fight the markets. And comments made earlier in the week by governor Dr Chris Stals and finance minister Chris Liebenberg did little to calm the jitters.

Many economists believe the correction was justified and anticipated -- only the extent and timing of the slump came as a surprise. But credibility among foreign investors, in particular, has been badly dented. Between now and the budget, the markets are going to want some clear signs of action on exchange controls if the rand is to recover some lost ground.

Says Peter Hilsenrath, chief economist at Syfrets: "The rand's slide has created a window of opportunity for the government to relax exchange controls. With high real interest rates and a very weak currency, there is less chance of hefty capital outflows."

Keith Lockwood, South Africa Chamber of Business economist, agreed: "The authorities should push ahead with easing exchange restrictions to demonstrate their faith in the economy and their policies. Foreign investors need a concrete sign that the government is committed to freeing up the economy."

Against a basket of currencies, however, the rand's depreciation is less severe, providing some consolation on the inflation front. Indeed, most economists had factored a depreciation into their inflation calculations, so 6% still looks a reasonable bet for this year.

An early cut in interest rates is now ruled out, however; Stals will need all the help he can get to prevent a further free-fall.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Algeria and South Africa Nzo Mollifies Algerians


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa this week patched up its friendship with Algeria after an earlier meeting between President Nelson Mandela and Algerian exile leader Anouar Haddam sent tempers soaring in Algiers.

Mandela received Haddam, the United States- based leader of a faction of the outlawed Islamic Salvation Front (FIS), at his Cape Town residence last week. Algerian President Liamine Zeroual's government accused Mandela of fraternising with a "terrorist" and threatened to recall its Pretoria ambassador, Said Kitouni.

South Africa moved fast to patch up the relationship. On Tuesday night Mandela phoned Zeroual, and Foreign Affairs Minister Alfred Nzo met ambassadors from 12 Islamic countries, including Algeria, on Wednesday. Foreign Affairs defended the Haddam meeting, saying it had been "in the context" of South Africa's stance on democracy and human rights, but blamed Haddam for "misrepresenting" the nature of the contact. It announced Nzo's deputy, Aziz Pahad, would visit Algeria at the weekend.

That seemed to mollify Algiers, but it is unclear why Zeroual was so offended by the Mandela-Haddam meeting; after all, there have been moves towards dialogue between the Algerian government and the FIS, which is potentially more conciliatory than the extremist Armed Islamic Group. One explanation is the Algerian government is scared it will lose control of the process. Pat Chacker, of the Economist Intelligence Unit, said: "They (the Algiers government) signal that they want to talk, but it's that they want to talk on their own terms."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Malawi Mauled By The 'Lion of Malawi'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by David Beresford


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Johannesburg - Outside Malawi's administrative capital of Lilongwe, above the gate at the entrance to a country estate, a life-size lion stands on its hind legs leaning languidly on a spear. At the end of the 2km driveway is New State House, the nine-bedroom palace with bowling-green lawns tended by 190 gardeners which was the home of Dr Hastings Kamuzu Banda.

The self-styled "Lion of Malawi" only spent one night in his new residence before being turfed out of power in the 1994 multiparty elections. His successor, Bakili Muluzi, has scorned the pretensions of his predecessor, refusing to take occupation. So it stands as a bizarre memorial to one of the more eccentric dictators thrown up by a continent of despots. 

"Eccentric" is perhaps too affectionate a term to describe the 30 years of Banda's rule. There was the delightfully dotty side to him, the Mr Chips who found himself president -- giving expression to a passion for Plato by creating a society of serfs, guardians and would-be philosopher kings. But when one considers the basket-case status to which he reduced a potentially vibrant nation the charge must be of a more criminal nature.

The country's cabinet ministers no longer need fear having their heads stoved in with tent- peg hammers. The Tontons-Macoutes-like "Young Pioneers" no longer haunt the bars and other public gathering places in hopes of over- hearing chance remarks which could be crafted into leg irons, or worse. But the ravages of Banda's rule are still overwhelming in their legacy for this country of some 11,5-million people.

His concern solely for the interests of a small elite translates into contemporary statistics, Malawi being not only the ninth- poorest nation in the world, but ranking only after Brazil for the highest level of income inequality between the haves and have-nots. Nearly one in four children cannot be expected to live beyond the age of five. Every other child displays signs of stunted growth. Girls can expect to have nearly seven children in their life-time -- contributing to a population explosion running at 3,2% per year.

At the last count, 80% of the people were living on $55 (about R220), or less a year. Only 45% of the population is literate in vernacular languages (30% in English) thanks to Banda's contempt for the educational requirements of the masses which matched that of Hendrik Verwoerd. The country has no television station, one radio station, no cinemas and a grand total of seven traffic lights.

It all amounts to the most basic of base lines from which the nation can hardly fail to progress. And progress is at least there, in such gestures as President Muluzi's edict that primary school education is free (if not yet compulsory) and the withdrawal of state funding for Banda College, President Chips' notorious Eton-in-the-bush where expatriate teachers force-fed the children of the political elite a diet of such as Cicero and Caesar.

The most striking manifestation of multiparty democracy is a familiar one -- the flowering of the newspaper industry. There are about 20 extant titles struggling to find a corner in a tiny market. They tend to be party-aligned. But they show a fine disregard for the sensitivities of the political elite, glorying in the exposure of such ministerial pecaddillos as failure to declare to airport customs first-world goodies culled on overseas trips and berating the polygamous Mr Muluzi for such breaches of constitutional niceties as politicking on the presidential budget.

That blight of African politics, corruption, does rear it head from time to time: one minister piously justifying the award of a state haulage contract to his own transport company on the grounds that it is the best in the country; another inexplicably accepting a UK tender three times as expensive as a South African bid. But an anti-corruption commission was voted into existence during the last session of parliament and the principle of clean government is at least established.

Democratic rule looks safe, at least in the interim. The coalition government seems shaky on occasion; recently the junior partner, the Alliance for Democracy (AFORD), threatened to pull out in protest against regional favouritism -- charging that 50 of the government's 57 "principal secretaries" were from Muluzi's stronghold in the south (the term "permanent secretary" was banned by Banda with the reported remark that "I am the only permanent thing around here"). But for the time being, at least, the Congress Party, still under the leadership of the now senile Dr Banda, is offering no coherent challenge for power.

Real power anyway belongs to the international community in Malawi at the moment, thanks to the country's overwhelming dependence on foreign aid. The focus of that power is on a grandiose building in Lilongwe, the design of which local guide books liken to a grain basket -- symbolic of the wealth of the country. Mathews Chikaonda, the governor of the Reserve Bank which the building houses, likens it to an upturned saucepan, the symbolism of which is indicated by the snort of laughter which accompanies the sally.

Dr Chikaonda (41) was persuaded to give up a professorship at Canada's Memorial University of Newfoundland in August 1994 to join Malawi's Reserve Bank. As governor he plays a role in Malawi today that can be likened to a receiver put in to oversee the affairs of a bankrupt business.

In November 1994, the Malawian government, under heavy pressure from international donors to take radical measures to halt the nation's runaway economy, agreed to introduce a cash budgeting system. Aimed at forcing the politicians to cut their proverbial suits according to the cloth available, it tied government departments to a monthly budget based on the previous month's revenues.

To police the new regime the Reserve Bank turned to the private sector, transferring ministerial accounts to the country's commercial banks to take advantage of their stringent supervision of overdraft facilities -- which were simply refused to government departments.

In the first month under the cash budgeting system 47 departmental cheques were bounced. At Chikaonda's urging the cabinet passed a regulation by which officials responsible for presenting dishonoured cheques were given a warning on the first occasion, demoted with a cut in salary on the second and fired for a third infraction. In Malawi, government cheques no longer bounce.

The system is a crude, if effective means of financial administration, bringing pressure for cut-backs in a parasitical civil service -- accounting for over 20% of formal employment in the country. A survey uncovered a body of some 30 000 workers hired on short- term contacts under the Banda regime who had mysteriously become permanent employees. A schools census magically cut the teachers' salary bill by some 15%, having apparently flushed out a legion of "ghost-workers".

But, for all its effectiveness the system makes for harsh administration. This month the country's teachers and doctors were threatening a strike in protest against non- payment of last month's salaries. At Blantyre's Queen Elizabeth Hospital -- Malawi's biggest -- the operating theatres came to a standstill last month when they ran out of surgical gloves. This month they have run out of Paracetemol. Locals call the hospital "the departure lounge".

Life is thin on the edge.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Farmworkers Row Threatens Cape Elections


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Johannesburg - With both Western Cape MEC for Local Government Peter Marais and the African National Congress threatening court action, the elections scheduled for May 29 in the Western Cape are in jeopardy again.

The ANC is disputing a model proposed by Marais for rural local government which it says disenfranchises farmworkers. Marais counters that the model was proclaimed last December, and that the ANC's protests have come too late.

The ANC's objection is that if the model is implemented, it is likely to remain in force until the next local government elections, after 1999.

The ANC says Marais's proposal -- that transitional rural councils have 60% of their councillors nominated on the basis of half the positions going to farmer organisations and half to farmworker organisations -- gives unfair representation to farmers .

It also objects to the definition of a farmworker, which excludes any person working on a farm for less than six months of the year.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa A Rotten Life On The 'Fruit Route'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Rehanna Rossouw


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Johannesburg - The "fruit route" which wanders through the Boland town of Grabouw is not as well known as the Cape's wine route, but the panorama it offers is easily on a par. Apple trees weighted down with starkings and golden delicious apples send a sweet perfume wafting through the air.

Hidden behind the valleys and dales studded with trees are huge packing sheds, where conveyer belts send thousands of apples hurtling towards hundreds of women who grade and select the best for packaging and export around the globe.

It's apple season in the Cape and the harvest needs the labour of thousands of people to pick and pack the fruit. Seasonal workers are roped in for a three-month period until the end of the harvest in May. Most live in the area, raise their children and spend their income there, but will be precluded by Western Cape Local Government MEC Peter Marais from participating in the rural councils on May 29 if they work for less than six months a year. 

The majority of the seasonal workers at Mizpah Farm in Grabouw are women, colourfully decked out in green scarves and overalls and white boots.

Maria Windvogel has lived in Grabouw for 13 years. Every season she waits anxiously for the farm manager at Mizpah to let her know whether there is work for her at the packing shed.

"My mother, my sister and I only have fixed employment for three months every year. At the end of the season we have to ask for other work, and most of the time it's work outside in the orchards," she says.

"I don't really like working the orchards because it's so tiring. When the trees are pruned they expect the women to carry the heavy ladders all over the orchard all day. We're doing the work men used to do before because women work so much harder but they get paid less than men.

"But when the farmers give full-time work, the men get those jobs. A single mother like me can't find work and farm housing, but a young man without a family will find it easier to get a house."

Windvogel would like to vote on May 29 as there are many issues she would like addressed by a rural council -- like housing and improved conditions at the farm school her children attend.

"I voted in 1994, but didn't enjoy it at all. The farmer where I was working loaded all the workers on to his truck on the afternoon of the last day of voting and said we must all go and vote for the National Party. I did what he said and only found out afterwards that I could have voted for anyone I chose.

"This time round, I know who I want to vote for. I want to vote for the people who are going to make life better for the seasonal workers. If the union puts people up to stand in the elections, they will get my vote."

The 1991 Agricultural Survey, conducted by the Western Cape government, showed there were 79 281 seasonal workers employed in the region. The lowest income, in the Little Karoo, was R515 a year and the highest, in the Cape metropolitan area, was R1 010.

According to researchers Andrienetta Kritzinger and Jan Vorster, whose report was finalised in November last year, up to 72% of all seasonal workers are women. "The use of female workers has increased on nearly half the farms over the past five years."

They added that the extension of the Wage Act to the agricultural sector could result in farmers decreasing their permanent workforce.

But workers like Windvogel have seen an increase in their earnings in the past two years, largely because of the efforts of the South African Agricultural and Plantation and Allied Workers Union (Sapaawu).

Joanie Fredericks, the gender co-ordinator of Sapaawu, works full-time at Mizpah and is the only female forklift driver in region.

Fredericks says if the union nominates her as a councillor, she will probably be prepared to stand, as the position offers a greater chance to improve the lot of seasonal workers.

"Marais has made sure seasonal workers can't speak for themselves. But he's in for a big surprise if I get on to the council," she says with a cheeky grin.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa And Now For The IFP's Gun-runners


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Johannesburg - The next "third force" trial in the Pretoria Supreme Court will implicate senior members of the Inkatha Freedom Party in a massive gun- running operation that may have fuelled the high levels of violence in KwaZulu-Natal and the Reef at the time of the 1994 elections.

As the marathon Eugene de Kock trial nears an end, officials in the office of Transvaal Attorney General Jan D'Oliveira have been collecting evidence that is likely to implicate KwaZulu-Natal's former safety and security minister, Celani Mtethwa, IFP senator Phillip Powell, then-Transvaal party heavyweights Themba Khoza and Humphrey Ndlovu, plus other officials, in fomenting political violence.

De Kock has also indicated he is planning to make a submission to the truth commission (probably in the hope of obtaining a presidential pardon or mitigation of the sentence expected in his current trial) that will provide extensive details about a massive gun-running and paramilitary training operation he helped run for Inkatha in 1992 and 1993. 

Both hearings will come after the Magnus Malan murder trial, which begins in Durban on April 4 and will focus on the 1980s training of Inkatha hit squads by members of military intelligence and their involvement in the 1987 KwaMakutha massacre.

The Vlakplaas supply of weapons and training to Inkatha will probably emerge as a sequel to this earlier bout of the security forces' backing for Inkatha -- and De Kock has told reporters his evidence to the truth commission will implicate at least a dozen police and army generals.

Some evidence about the 1990s paramilitary operation has already emerged in the current De Kock case. Documents shown only to Justice Willem van der Merwe during the trial indicate that Mthetwa and Khoza were registered Vlakplaas informers and were paid between R1 000 and R2 000 a month each from the police's secret fund from 1990 to 1992.

De Kock's senior counsel, Flip Hattingh, has also admitted that his client personally supplied six truckloads of arms, ammunition and explosives to IFP officials in Ulundi in October 1993, "at the request of IFP senator Phillip Powell".

The materiel -- which included 700 anti-tank mines, 182 RPG7 rockets, 1000 hand grenades, 120 mortar bombs and some 30 000 rounds of 7.62 ammunition -- has never been recovered. The forthcoming trial will explore evidence that some of it was used in political murders that have become endemic in KwaZulu-Natal.

De Kock's admission corroborates evidence given to the Goldstone Commission by the colonel's former colleagues Brood van Heerden and Willie Nortje. They provided details about a flow of arms to Inkatha units on the Reef in 1992 and continued links between De Kock and senior party officials after Vlakplaas was disbanded in April 1993.

Nortje gave details about military training that had taken place at the Mlaba camp near the Umfolozi game reserve in northern KwaZulu- Natal. The training was run by Powell assisted by De Kok and two Vlakplaas colleagues, "Snor" Vermeulen and Simon Radebe.

"Radebe told me about 500 IFP recruits on a two-week course had been trained in the use of SADF-issue rifles, AK-47s, RPG7s, explosives and the planting of land mines."

Nortje's evidence to Goldstone states that Humphrey Ndlovu, his brother Victor, and James Ndlovu were also on the police's secret payroll.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa The Judge And The AG: Were They Duped?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Johannesburg - Evidence led in the Eugene de Kock trial has indicated that two of the country's most controversial legal figures -- retired Supreme Court Judge Louis Harms and KwaZulu- Natal Attorney General Tim McNally -- failed dismally to uncover the existence of death squads in the police.

Police defector Dirk Coetzee told the Supreme Court in Pretoria that Judge Harms had been "led by the nose" by a clique of security policemen known as "the mafia", who were adept at manipulating evidence put before judges and inquiries.

The judge was appointed to head a one-man inquiry into Coetzee's allegations that death squads were operating in the police force in January 1990 by then-president FW de Klerk in the wake of sensational death squad revelations by Coetzee. 

Harms was dubbed the "Prince of Probes" at the time and the president promised that the enquiry would "cut to the bone" allegations about politically sanctioned murder. In the end, the inquiry reported that it had failed to come up with evidence to back Coetzee's revelations.

"The (security police) "mafia" influenced Judge Harms to such an extent that he said to me: 'How must I believe this crap you're talking?' and in the end I was dismissed as mad," Coetzee told the court.

"Judge Harms absolutely did not believe me. The things I said there, that the police denied under oath at a high level, have since proved to be the truth."

Evidence in the case also suggests that McNally, the KwaZulu-Natal attorney general who recently faced questions by a parliamentary committee about his alleged reluctance to prosecute Inkatha members for involvement in murder, was duped by failing to uncover evidence that the police's Vlakplaas unit took part in political killings.

McNally, then Free State AG, had been appointed along with CID chief General Alwyn Conradie in 1989 to investigate early claims by former Vlakplaas member Almond Nofomela that the police unit had murdered human rights activist Griffiths Mxenge.

The McNally report presented to the National Party government in November 1989 says: "Nofomela's allegations in his statement do not correspond with the facts made available to the Committee" and "the Committee finds it difficult to attach any value to Coetzee's allegations and declarations".

"With respect, I think the two presiding officers (McNally and Conradie) have had to swallow their words, because it has since, I think, more than once, been shown that the bunch of lies and blind accusations against high-up people I have been accused of making left and right are true," Coetzee told the De Kock trial.

Coetzee claimed the commission had made a fundamental mistake by accepting falsified police evidence that Joe Mamasela, one of the Vlakplaas operatives who participated in the Mxenge murder, had only been employed by the police unit in February 1982, some eight months after the murder.

He said of the McNally findings: "Well, this was typical security police procedure in my time: smear, cover up and make out as a renegade the person that stands up, dares stand up, against the hierarchy ..."

Earlier in the De Kock trial, Mamasela said in evidence that he has applied for indemnity with regard to his role in the Mxenge murder.

Mamasela also described how he and other Vlakplaas officers had falsified records to show that he had only joined the police unit after the Mxenge murder.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

172 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa De Kock: How Murder Became Routine


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

Johannesburg - A line from one of Leonard Cohen's new, but still depressing, ballads sums up the message which has emanated remorselessly, almost every weekday for more than a year now, from Room DG3 in the Pretoria Supreme Court, where more than 80 witnesses have testified about the horrors committed by Colonel Eugene de Kock and members of his C10 police unit.

The song says there are killers in high places who still say their prayers at night and, unless we do something about this evil, it will envelop the cracks through which the light gets in. The problem is that, even with the truth commission and a revamped justice system in place, this is not going to be an easy task.

The central theme of the De Kock trial, both in its content and the way it has been treated in the media, is that politically motivated murder had become so routine and so commonplace in the apartheid era that we have inherited a public realm filled with people who were directly or indirectly implicated in these acts -- and many of them already appear to have obtained an informal immunity from punishment.

And, paradoxically, the remorseless and repetitive accounts of outrageous acts that come out of the courtroom DG3 have, instead of outraging the public, created a kind of moral numbness -- as revealed in the following anecdote. 

When Judge Richard Goldstone first received information about the activities of a host of senior security force members in early 1994 and then made his sensational allegations a month before the elections, it was decided between Nelson Mandela and then-president FW de Klerk that the country was too jittery for De Kock to be arrested then.

The loyalty of the security forces, particularly the police, had not been secured.

The investigators believed an enormous risk was taken in the delay. De Kock had sold his house, liquidated all his other assets, and his family had gone overseas. He was finally picked up two months after Goldstone said there was indeed a "third force".

Today, as the year-old trial wraps up, most news media -- with the notable exception of the Sunday Times, Business Day, and to a lesser extent the Sowetan -- almost ignore it.

There is a related theme which emerges from its proceedings. Former Askaris, Umkhonto we Sizwe guerillas who turned into brutal assassins for apartheid's police, spoke about the white officers who captured them and then "forced" them to murder. De Kock's old Vlakplaas buddies told the court about the extraordinary sway, sometimes through fear, but mostly because of the routine nature of their job, that their unit commander wielded over them.

Then, this week in court, De Kock's lawyers sent a strong signal that they will use details, ironically provided by witnesses for the state, to formulate two well-worn arguments when they try to mitigate the crimes their client committed. He acted on orders from above, some of them from men who still occupy high office. And, if De Kock is guilty, why should he be punished rather than the superiors and co-conspirators who still walk free?

Next on the roll-call at the supreme court will be a massive case that hauls at least some of those generals implicated in the De Kock trial into the dock for their involvement in a massive gun-running operation to Inkatha paramilitaries based on the Reef and in KwaZulu-Natal -- an operation that fuelled the massive levels of violence there in the early 1990s (see story on facing page).

You can already see the words formulating on their lips as they glance upwards: "We were just doing our jobs. It was the politicians and their policies who sanctioned what we did."

De Klerk says he will appear at the truth commission. No doubt he will go armed with arguments about the "political realities," the mindset, the milieu, the inheritances of the past ...

This tendency by perpetrators to shift the blame for atrocities one level upwards and then to argue that their actions were part of their routine working environment endorsed by a superior order is reflected in testimony given by Sergeant Steve Bosch, the Vlakplaas technician who helped make the cassette bomb which blew apart the head of lawyer Bheki Mlangeni.

The sergeant told the court about a time when he was out driving with his commander. "He (De Kock) turned to me and said he did not understand why he had to do all this dirty work ... It was difficult to refuse. If you didn't do it the following guy would do it. So the feeling was you must just do it and get it done."

Bosch's evidence suggests, to paraphrase Hannah Arendt's famous report on the Adolf Eichmann trial, that evil in the apartheid era was widespread not so much because its proponents were profoundly diabolical but because their work had become so routine, so banal, that they could do it without even thinking of its morality.

The record of the trial is replete with similar examples. Vlakplaas operative Joe Mamasela participated either directly or indirectly in the murder of 53 people, including lawyer Griffiths Mxenge and Dr Fabian Ribeiro.

De Kock's lawyers read into the court record a description of Mamasela, made by Dirk Coetzee to the Harms Commission, which says: "He is a killer. He had this so-called terrorist Vusi on his knees praying: 'Our Father who art in Heaven'. I don't know whether Joe knew that one (sic). And he kicked the poor guy to pieces. It was just blood running down in the heat of the sun."

The court record shows that Mamasela kept notes in a secret book about killings carried out by the Vlakplaas unit. Asked why he was selective in recording the names of people killed, Mamasela said: "If I had to write all the names of the victims, I would be having a Bible ... I cannot be writing all the deaths. I mean, I will be a mortuary chap or what? I could not do that."

Mamasela refused to incriminate himself during the trial but was prepared to make this point: "Myself, I am a victim. I was acting against my own will and made a killer machinery against my own people. I was captured by the police. I was assaulted severely. I was brutalised. I am telling you. And then the police used me against my own people ... I did not commit one of them I will have been dead, I will have been Brian Ngqulunga today. If I did not become productive by killing these people, I will have been killed. I have no doubt in my mind about that." (The court was told Brian Ngqulunga, an Askari, was killed, as he was about to tell the truth to the Harms Commission.)

What to do about the banality of all this murdering, and the determination of its proponents to throw up their hands and say they were acting on superior orders -- this is the great moral issue which will confront members of the Truth and Reconciliation Committee's amnesty committee, as well as the judges who will preside over the "third force" trials which will follow the one now wrapping up in Room GD3.

The prosecutors seem confident there is little doubt that De Kock should, and will, get a long prison sentence. But initial indications are that many of apartheid's other killers could slip through the net.

All of the Vlakplaas operatives who gave evidence against "Prime Evil", as De Kock has been dubbed, have been told they will be indemnified from prosecution in connection with the 120-odd charges, including eight of murder, laid against him.

There are reliable reports that Mamasela is working, at least informally, with one of the country's existing intelligence agencies and has also had a recent meeting with Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. He earned some R400 000 in severance money from Vlakplaas, paid mainly to keep him quiet, and used it to start a business that still thrives.

The truth commission legislation stipulates that people who committed crimes of a "heinous" nature will not be granted indemnity. Some of them appear to have it already.

Another potential problem is that the truth commission law promises that all revelations and confessions made in applications to the amnesty committee cannot, unlike evidence in a court of law, be used against a culprit -- even if the application is turned down.

Some lawyers say this could make it very difficult, if not near impossible, to prosecute perpetrators of gross human rights crimes who talk to the amnesty committee before they have been independently investigated by any of the country's attorneys general.

There are also serious doubts about the capacity of the criminal justice system to prosecute all the crimes that emerge during forthcoming trials and truth commission hearings.

Then there is Mandela's constitutional right to pardon anyone responsible for human rights abuses. So far, he has not exercised this enormously sensitive power. But at least one human rights lawyer says he is working with amnesty applicants from Umkhonto we Sizwe who are adamant that some political leaders are beginning to broker deals which promise this kind of pardon.

This is the single most important lesson of the De Kock trial and the proceedings that will follow it: precisely because atrocious acts became so routine during our recent past, the granting of informal and formal amnesties could become just as commonplace.

If that happens, if those guilty of gross crimes against humanity are allowed to go free simply because they were "given orders" , then it will not be long before those in the public realm accustomed to killing will use the same argument to justify new crimes.

Leonard Cohen's song says the time has come to ring the bells that still will ring. To do that, and to prevent the evil of the perpetrators from contaminating the morals of the political system that replaced them -- that is the greatest challenge that faces this country's justice system and its new truth commission.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

173 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Who's Making The Buggers Look Silly?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Johannesburg - Just recovering from allegations that it had bugged some of the country's most senior policemen, South Africa's intelligence community is reeling under new charges that it is spying beyond the bounds of the law. Now strong counter-claims suggest there is an "agenda" to discredit the spies.

Justice Minister Dullah Omar and Deputy Intelligence Minister Joe Nhlanhla joined forces at a press conference on Thursday to claim the anti-spy reporting was not incidental. Said Omar: "The leaking of information was a deliberate attempt to destroy the intelligence capacity of our new democratic society." 

Omar's stance appears to be backed by a still- secret report of the National Intelligence Co- ordinating Committee (Nicoc), which brings together the National Intelligence Agency (NIA), the external South African Secret Service, Military Intelligence and the intelligence arm of the police.

The report details the findings of its investigation into claims that top police officers had been bugged, and that the National Intelligence Agency (NIA) had tasked former police hit-man Dirk Coetzee to spy on national police Commissioner George Fivaz and other senior officers.

The claims, which first surfaced early last month in reports by the Spectrum investigative unit of the Independent newspaper group, appeared at the time to be confirmed by Fivaz. Next week, Fivaz has to appear before Parliament's Joint Standing Committee on Intelligence to give his version of the story. Just like the Independent titles that carried the story, Fivaz may have to wipe egg off his face.

The hearing to be held by the parliamentary committee is one of three initiatives announced last month to get at the truth. Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said there would be a judicial inquiry, while Nicoc started its own investigation.

The judicial commission has not yet been appointed -- presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana said this week an announcement can be expected soon -- and the parliamentary committee is only just starting its process. But the Nicoc report is understood to be so firm in its exoneration of the NIA that the judicial inquiry may be redundant, save to help restore confidence in the country's spies.

Fivaz's liaison officer Sally de Beer this week declined to comment on the commissioner's apparent embarrassment in the face of the Nicoc findings, saying the separate inquiries first had to run their course.

But a source close to Fivaz pointed out that the commissioner had never directly blamed the NIA when he responded to questions: "All he did was confirm certain information as had been reported to him at that time, and he did not blame anyone; in fact, he tried to exonerate the NIA."

The source pointed out that Fivaz -- though he had repeated allegations that the NIA had told Coetzee to spy on him -- had told Spectrum he doubted the NIA was behind the "bugging" and that it could as well have been done by "old guard" police, by organised crime or by foreign agencies.

It is understood the report does not only exonerate the NIA as "spotless", but finds that the reported incidents were without substance altogether. The "bug" found on police management forum chair Superintendent Gideon Oosthuizen's home phone, for example, was a misinterpretation by Telkom of a service interruption, while the wires in the office of Gauteng Commissioner Sharma Maharaj were from a previous "in-house" recording device not in use anymore.

The report also found in favour of Coetzee, apparently choosing his version above that of police Inspector HT Moodley, who told Fivaz that Coetzee had told him he was under orders to spy on the police top structure. Omar said the report was also being handed to the parliamentary committee, and that he would ask for it to be released publicly.

Should the report -- which was unanimously drafted by all four agencies represented on Nicoc, including the police -- prove to be the final word, Fivaz may look silly, but no one has accused him of authoring the spate of spy-critical reporting that ensued. Instead, the report points a cautious finger in the direction of the source of the original leak of information to Spectrum; information which the Nicoc report holds to be misrepresentative of the true facts.

One among six terms of reference of the Nicoc investigation was to consider the source of the leak. The report points in the direction of an unnamed member of Fivaz's staff. The role of that person is understood to have been discussed with the Ministry of Safety and Security.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
