174 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology R20m Bid To Save Kruger's Elephants


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa's conservation organisations have split down the middle over a controversial offer by two international animal rights groups to give the National Parks Board (NPB) some R20-million in an effort to stave off this country's elephant culling programme and its traditional support for the international ivory trade.

David Barritt, representative of the United States-based International Fund for Animal Welfare (Ifaw), told the Mail & Guardian his organisation had been holding sensitive negotiations with the parks board for more than a year about using the R20-million to purchase land for expanded elephant wildlife habitat.

Ifaw and the Humane Society of the United States are each offering US$2,5-million for the expansion of elephant reserves in an effort to deal with arguments from the parks board that the annual cull of Kruger's elephant population is neccessary because the country's existing protected area estate is not big enough.

A coalition of local wildlife NGOs -- including the Endangered Wildlife Trust, the Africa Resources Trust (ART) and the local branch of the World Wildlife Fund -- are vociferously opposed to this because they believe that the survival of conservation areas in Africa depends on the right to hunt animals and sell their products on local and international markets. They say this will allow parks to receive a financial return. 

ART representative Victoria Hylton told the M&G that the American groups are imposing an external agenda on African issues: "A draft of the contract being negotiated stipulates that South Africa will not cull elephants for the next five years on land bought by this funding and that it will submit no elephant (trading) proposals to Cites (the Conference on International Trade in Endangered Species) in the next five years.We believe this is in an infringement of South Africa's sovereign rights."

Hylton added that the Humane Society has stipulated its share of the proposed grant be used for research into elephant contraception, mainly the development of a pachyderm "pill", that can be used as an alternative to culling the animals in wildlife reserves.

She said Art's information is that conservation agencies will not be able to manage elephant populations on land purchased with the two groups' funds unless they retain the right to control herd sizes through culling.

"South Africa already has a policy on elephant management (that includes culling), which the parks board has placed under review. If these contracts are signed now, they will preclude a full review process from taking place. All policy in South Africa has been opened to full public scrutiny -- why has the parks directorate done the same?"

Barritt said recent research had indicated that very little money from the "consumptive utilisation" of animals found its way to rural communities, as is often claimed by the proponents of culling and trophy hunting.

He said most of the revenues were appropriated by hunt organisers and conservation agencies -- and that South Africans stood to gain more from the expansion of widlife areas that can cater for the current tourism boom than from culling and hunting.

"This is a fight for the soul of conservation in South Africa. It is between those who want to preserve animals and those who want them as utility animals that can be killed and their parts sold" he said. "It will have repercussions for years to come. Our organisations are willing to put hard cash on the table and have a vision for a huge increase in wildlife areas."

Representatives of the NPB were not available for comment at the time of going to press. But it is believed that the organisation is caught in the crossfire between the lobby that wants game reserves to protect animals from all forms of hunting and the NGOs that insist African countries must have the right to trade in animal products if conservation is to survive on the continent.

The parks board has recently adopted a flexible position on the debate and appears to have suspended its culling programme in Kruger, as well as its previous support for other Southern African countries that are lobbying Cites to relax its international ban on trade in ivory and other elephant products.

It is believed that the debate will be dealt with at an NPB board meeting at the end of March.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Kicking Up A Stink In 'A Skunk Of A Town'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Justin Pearce


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Johannesburg - Potgietersrus gets up early. By 7am on Wednesday -- the last day of racial exclusivity for Potgietersrus Primary School -- four little girls were already on duty in their fluorescent orange vests. At the blast of the whistle they would raise their stop- signs to enable another barefoot blond child to trot across the road, their routine unshakeable despite the near-total absence of cars on the tree-lined street.

Round the corner, a group of parents were conducting a different kind of vigil. The men in khaki shirts and boxer shorts, the women in dorp uniform, crimpolene and perms, had set up a mini-laager of plastic patio chairs inside the boundary fence and were drinking coffee. They would not say why they were there. 

It was left to one of the patrol girls to explain the politics of the situation. "It's fine for blacks to come to our school," she said. "They just mustn't sit next to me." But little did this girl know that a few hours later parents of several black children would be registering their offspring at the school.

After the Transvaal Supreme Court refused the school leave to appeal against a court order that the pupils be admitted.

All of this, and local and international headlines, have gained the sweltering little Northern Province town a reputation as the new Ventersdorp. Or, as the town council executive committee chair Doctor Ramaru puts it, "a skunk among towns".

Mayor Boysea Thole is worried investors will be turned away from the town by the strident noise of bigotry from the town's white community.

Yet the good burghers of Potgietersrus express almost as much confusion as the patrol girl's self-contradictory assessment of the situation -- -a babble of conflicting voices in a town which has yet to learn how to deal with conflict.

Many of the parents at the school, and white citizens of Potgietersrus in general, react with a defensive "no comment" when asked about the school. Others shelter behind the need to preserve "Afrikaner culture", an argument which has found no favour with the courts.

"It's not about excluding black children," insists a Ray-banned, walrus-mustached man dropping his children at school. "The media has misrepresented it."

'The black children can't speak Afrikaans or English," says Nola Venter who works in a hardware store, oblivious to the fact that parents such as Alson Matukane have sought to enroll their children at a school which offers English since they cannot write their mother tongue, Pedi.

"I know they are Christians, but their way of practising religion is different from ours. Look how they bury their dead. It's completely different from how we bury our dead," Venter said.

Christians excluded from a Christian school, the Matakane children had an unexpected holiday on Wednesday. The Indian school they attended until this week, was closed for Eid

Some white citizens are more forthright in their racism. "Why don't they stay at their own school?" asked an elderly woman who would not give her name, but who works in Potties Blanket Centre -- a shop whose clientele appeared to be entirely black. "At their school an E is a high grade -- our children must get A grades."

Yet many whites have come to accept the inevitable. "They are mad!" says florist Wendy Marshall of the school authorities. "It was going to happen some or other time. They must accept it!"

And while many white residents share the view that the end of segregation was the inevitability rather than a moral imperative, the parents encamped at the school have long since lost the support of apartheid's one-time moral apologist, the Nederduitse Gereformeerde Kerk just across town.

"I respect other people's values and they don't threaten me," says Dominee Bernant Rademeyer. "There is no need for fear. Besides," he adds, "2,3% of the population in this province are white. They won't change anything with the protest action."

The black parents whose children have been kept out of the school for more than a month agree that history is on their side. Yet caution persists.

Matukane, provincial director of water affairs, spent most of this week battling against floods, and looks weary as he tells of his protracted effort to enroll his children at Potgietersrus Primary.

Matukane spent from 1992 to 1994 doing a master's degree in the United States and returned after the elections to find a much happier South Africa than the one he had left. Only having moved to Potgietersrus this year, he says, "I didn't know my children would be the first black children at the school. So I was surprised to meet the forces at the gate."

He believes most white parents are on his side, but won't speak out: "There is a general fear of expressing oneself among the white community."

Leslie Phatudi, who also wants to register his daughter at the school, says he has encountered no racism while living in white Potgieterus, other than from the hostile school parents. But he distrusts the ability of the present school authorities to implement the court order which demands admission and fair treatment for the pupils, and hopes the provincial government will exercise its powers to appoint a new management committee and principal.

Matukane, who seems to be motivated equally by crusading zeal and the simple need to get his children into the nearest neighbourhood school, is ambivalent about whether he still wants his children to be educated by the people who tried to drive them away.

Over in Mahwelereng the number of parents who are considering the newly-open Potgietersrus Primary as a future option for their children is enough to cause sleepless nights in the laager. Yet local schoolteacher Rose Manyatela has no illusions. "I wouldn't send my children there. They'd still oppress them," she says.

The parents on their plastic chairs, who'd held out against the government, the courts, and according to the NGK, God, realised the end was in sight on Wednesday when the court refused them leave to appeal. But they went down fighting, some talking of petitioning the Constitutional Court, some of using "whatever means necessary."

Returning from registering his children at the school, Matukane said: "The battle is only beginning."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Top Secret No More


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Johannesburg - If the old guard in the former South African Defence Force had had its way, the documents revealed on these pages would have stayed locked up in a supreme court vault. When Commandant Jan Anton Nieuwoudt sued the SADF for a payout on the eve of the elections in 1994, both sides called for the matter to be heard in camera as Nieuwoudt's job had included the recruitment of sources, the interrogation of hundreds of guerillas, and the identification of targets for overt and covert operations.

The lawyers involved stated that the matter needed to be in camera to prevent exposure of current covert military operations, meaning clandestine operations under way the month the elections were being held. 

The case was initially held in camera, but after two days' evidence the judge replaced this ruling and opened the court. The proceedings halted the same day and an out-of- court settlement was reached in a hurry, apparently to stop any further exposures.

The matter was considered so sensitive that the then SADF chief General Kat Liebenberg asked the minister of defence for authorisation to pay out Nieuwoudt more than the court awarded him, apparently in order to keep the details of the clandestine operations quiet.

Until this week it was believed that the matter had always been closed to the public. Then the records were discovered by Colonel Gerrie Hugo, who was looking for evidence about the clandestine unit Nieuwoudt ran in Ciskei to use in his own civil claim.

The Nieuwoudt documents essentially back up everything that Hugo previously accused the International Researchers-Ciskei Intelligence Services unit of doing, and show that the SADF still regarded the ANC and PAC as military enemies after 1990.

In an attempt to silence Nieuwoudt and prevent public access to these documents, the then SADF chief General Kat Liebenberg wrote to the minister of defence in March and again in April 1993, asking for authority to pay out Nieuwoudt.

Liebenberg suggested paying out Nieuwoudt the difference between what the supreme court ruled the military should pay him, and Nieuwoudt's own minimum demand, which amounted to R400 000.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Some Ghosts Just Refuse To Die


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Louise Flanagan


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Johannesburg - After the military's discredited Civil Co- operation Bureau (CCB) was officially closed down in July 1990, many of its principal members and shadowy activities were taken over by a key Military Intelligence's (MI) front organisation.

The CCB was shut down after a year of scandals over its joint intelligence-gathering and operational activities, and allegations of its involvement in the assassination of prominent political activists.

But instead of shutting down completely, documents which emerged this week indicate the CCB's functions were taken over by the existing MI front, Pan Afrik Industrial Investment Consultants cc (PAIIC). 

PAIIC was based in MI's offices in Momentum Mews in Pretoria until those offices were raided by the Goldstone Commission in November 1992. It's existence was exposed in the Mail & Guardian a year later.

Evidence from the civil case brought by former MI member Commandant Jan Anton Nieuwoudt against the military for a payout in early 1994, indicates that PAIIC was a crucial part of the military's plans for covert operations both locally and internationally in the run-up to the elections.

Nieuwoudt's evidence came to light this week. His case was initially heard in camera, but that ruling was quietly lifted, unknown to the public.

Nieuwoudt told the court that PAIIC emerged out of a more informal system called "Hotpoint", which had been used previously to hide members' links to the South African Defence Force. He said the members of the PAIIC closed corporation included the SADF's chief of staff intelligence at the time, General Witkop Badenhorst, and the director of Covert Collection, Brigadier Tolletjie Botha.

Nieuwoudt said there were three types of people who worked under PAIIC. These were Permanent Force members who needed good cover in order to operate internationally, members of the National Intelligence Service and members of the police.

In this way PAICC was similar to the CCB -- it grouped together operatives from the key intelligence services and its members operated outside South Africa's borders.

PAIIC members apparently continued to operate outside the country even after the ANC was unbanned, as Nieuwoudt referred to plans for using PAIIC for this himself after he had left Ciskei in late 1992.

PAIIC appears to have been regarded as a crucial part of the military and was possibly expected to continue operating without official sanction even after the elections.

Nieuwoudt explained the organisation's importance to the court: "I just want to say to you, you cannot close down PAIIC. PAIIC is the defence force. The director of Covert Collection said that, because we said to him, brigadier, there are indications that people are working against us; then he said boys, the guys cannot close down the defence force, no matter who controls this country.

"The defence force must always be there and that was the agreement."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa How Military Intelligence Tried To Recruit Modise


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 23, 1996 by Louise Flanagan


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Johannesburg - Military Intelligence (MI) tried to recruit present Minister of Defence Joe Modise nearly two years before the 1994 elections, relying on a belief that Modise was willing to smash the ANC-SACP alliance in order to secure his own position under a future government.

The plan is outlined in a top-secret memo, one of only four official copies, which was drafted in September 1992 and sent to the head of MI's Directorate of Covert Collection (DCC). There is no indication of what happened in the recruitment attempt.

The three-page memo discusses the conflict within the African National Congress (ANC) between the militants, headed by Chris Hani, and the moderates, headed by Modise. 

The memo, which was drafted by senior DCC officer Commandant Anton Nieuwoudt, suggests strengthening the government of the day's position by discrediting South African Communist Party (SACP) and militant ANC members, by "recruiting ANC agents of influence", and by "exploiting the conflict within MK (Umkhonto weSizwe)".

The memo then immediately goes on to discuss how "Agent 241/222 is prepared to have a secret meeting with the defence force, along with: J Modise (MK commander), L Moloi (chief of operations, MK), MK Zakes (regional commander PWV), MK Maincheck (commander of MK outside South Africa) and J Mnisi (commander Pretoria)".

Elsewhere in the document, "Agent 241/ 222" is referred to as an MK regional commander.

Modise this week denied that he had ever attended such a meeting, but declined to answer any furhter questions.

Nieuwoudt notes that Modise and his four colleagues were targeted because they could be used against Hani. They were regarded as open to recruitment due to their own self-interest.

"This discussion is also with people who want to promote their own agenda (assuring own positions), but who are also prepared to break the back of the ANC/SACP backbone," he states in the memo in his motivation for the meeting.

The memo notes that Modise had key support within MK.

"This meeting could be instrumental in beginning to neutralise the SACP/Hani/(Ronnie) Kasrils faction. It could also be used to win votes in an upcoming election if the SACP participants could be neutralised," says the memo.

"The MK (old trained leaders) with their decision-makers such as those named in paragraph 5 (Modise and company) do not wish to fight with the SADF. Hani and his young militant guard want to fight.

"The options which could come out of such a meeting are legion, for example, the incorporation of moderate MKs, the empowerment of compromised witnesses against the militants, the utilisation of own ANC members as instruments at street level.

"This meeting can take place completely anonymously, it is however our feeling that a powerful delegation has to talk to such members to ensure exploitation, shock action, mobility and good communication in the final phase of this objective."

Although there is no indication whether any of the group aproached were indeed re-cruited, at least two now hold senior positions. Modise is the minister of defence and in June 1994 Lambert Moloi was promoted to major-general and made chief of the Service Brigade.

The memo is from a bundle of military documents used in Nieuwoudt's civil claim against the South African Defence Force for a payout after he lost his job following the Goldstone raid on DCC offices in November 1992.

The claim went to court in early April 1994 and was settled out of court just after the elections. The case was initially heard in camera, but it has now emerged that that ruling was lifted.

At the time the memo was written, Nieuwoudt was MI's Staff Officer First Class, Internal Sub-Theatre Western Front. He wrote the memo under a colleague's name (for "security reasons") and signed it with his pseudonym "Fox", but gave his real position in MI. He sent the memo to his DCC boss, Colonel At Nel, and DCC director Brigadier Tolletjie Botha.

All three officers were among those fired by then president FW de Klerk following the Goldstone raid just two months after the memo was drafted.

In evidence during his civil case, Nieuwoudt stated that just before the Goldstone raid, the DCC was busy recruiting "a very senior member of the intelligence service of the ANC".

Referring back to the period just after the memo was written, he commented that MI already knew then which of their sources among the MK members would be appointed as generals, brigadiers and lieutenant-colonels in the new military.

In a second top-secret memo from September 1992, of which only one official copy existed, Nieuwoudt outlines to Nel plans to close down some sources and to go ahead with others. One of those sources, described as "in place (ANC) and going ahead", was Agent 241/222.

Other well-placed sources within the Pan Africanist Congress were also maintained.

A third top-secret document, again the sole official copy in existence, was sent on December 9 1992. This document noted how "Fox" had "efficiently executed his duty as a principal agent controlling eight handlers and their respective source networks in the Witwatersrand area" and had produced 431 intelligence reports. The memo urged retaining "Fox's" services into 1993.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Students Union Issues Ultimatum To President


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 22, 1996 by George Jambwa, Sheikh Chifuwe and Kunda Mwila


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba has been given 18 hours to resolve the impasse between his government and the University of Zambia Students' Union (UNZASU) in a latest ultimatum issued by students after their meeting with him ended in a deadlock yesterday.

The mood at the University of Zambia (UNZA) main campus was last night tense as students pondered their next move which UNZASU President Emmanuel Tembo says will be known from the events after midday.

"We have given government up to 12:00 hours today to solve our problem. If they fail to do that we are doing something but that will be seen after mid- day tomorrow" Tembo said in an interview last night. He said students have so far exhausted all channels and were surprised about how lowly government thought of the university. 

"These people don't just care about this place," Tembo said. "It is shocking that they not only know little about the university but they don't even see the need to maintain it." He disclosed that the meeting with President Chiluba, forced at the height of a student demonstration at State House yesterday, was a deadlock. "The President was basically merely playing with words. He gave nothing concrete," Tembo said. "He in fact claimed not to know anything about our plight."

He said the President was not even sure the institution had opened. President Chiluba told the students in the meeting, also attended by education minister Alfeyo Hambayi that he needed more time to consult with education officials before he could make a decision.

But his non committal position has angered students who feel he is indecisive. The students are demanding an increase in the meal allowances from K60,000 to K90,000.

The closed meeting held after President Chiluba failed to agree with the more than five hundred demonstrators over the matter. In his address, President Chiluba pleaded with the students who marched to State House demanding an explanation from him on the delay to increase their allowances to give him time. "I am not here to hoodwink you but I will immediately get in touch with the Minister of Education so that the meal issue is quickly sorted out," the President assured.

But his appeal angered the students who wanted to know whether their demands would be met or not, forcing them to refuse to leave the State House grounds.

Earlier in the day University of Zambia students marched to the Ministry of Education headquarters to petition government over their plight. The demonstration, which comes a day after UNZASU and the Bursaries Committee reached a dead-lock on the students' demand, was led by UNZASU president Tembo. Students marched from the Great East Road campus yesterday morning to Ministry of Education headquarters where they brought operations to a standstill for about three hours.

Education permanent secretary, Kasanda Sichalwe, had a difficult time trying to reason with the students who poured tonnes of a motley assortment of insults on him.

"Excuse me please," Kasanda said as the students shouted at him. He later tried another way asking: "What is the problem?" In reply, the students asked the permanent secretary to explain why they have not been paid their meal allowances, including an increment, two weeks after the academic calendar had commenced.

The students demanded to be paid their allowances the same day (yesterday). Sichalwe tried to speak through interjections to respond to the question. "I have got your message, but the issue cannot be resolved right now," Sichalwe pleaded. "As for the allowances, we have compiled all the data and some of you, particularly first year students, will get your money tomorrow (today), but for returning students you have to wait probably until Friday or Monday. But be aware that we were working on old rates because we don't have money for the new rates."

The students were not satisfied. They booed him and demanded to be addressed by his boss the education minister Alfeyo Hambayi. Hambayi fueled the mood when he told the students he had never heard of their problem.

"I have seen your placards. This issue is being raised for the first time and it cannot be resolved now," said Hambayi amidst missiles of insults which he could not withstand: "We cannot continue because you don't want to give me a platform," he said as he walked away. Hambayi later met students leaders and offered to meet only 75 per cent of the demand but the students were not pleased with this either.

Immediately they crossed over to the finance ministry for a showdown with finance minister Ronald Penza. However, neither the finance minister nor his permanent secretary were in office. And frustrated, some students started deflating tyres of all government motor vehicles.

It was at this stage that the student leaders consulted each other over the demonstration, which was - serve for deflation of tyres and insults - peaceful and under the constant police vigil.

The UNZASU president later announced the new direction-State House. "We will not give them chance this time over these allowances," UNZASU president Tembo said in an interview yesterday . "We feel cheated." And from here the students headed for State House.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

February, 1996


Zambia Speaker Stops Nikuv Debate


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 22, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Speaker of the National Assembly, Robinson Nabulyato, ruled in parliament yesterday that any debate on the Israeli company, Nikuv, was subjud-ice. Nabulyato made this ruling when Solwezi National Party member of parliament, Humphrey Mulemba, asked Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda what the role of the company would be since he (Miyanda) had moved that the house adjourn sine die on Friday to enable members of parliament go to their constituencies and assist in the voter's registration exercise. 

But the move was challenged by Kasanengwa UNIP member of parliament Professor Patrick Mvunga who argued that if debate on Nikuv was subjudice then government was not in order to tell members of parliament to go and assist in the voter's registration exercise.

"Since the issue of Nikuv is subjudice, is the government in order to tell members of parliament to go and assist in a matter that is subjudice?" Mvunga asked. He was supported by Mongu National Party member of parliament, Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika, who also questioned the government's wisdom in sending members of parliament to go and assist in the voter's registration exercise when most of the logistics and materials required for the exercise were not in place.

"If we are serious, all the films for the National Registration Cards, the papers, the workers and doors to the registration centres must be open and in place if the targeted figure is to be reached," Lewanika advised.

In his reply, Miyanda admitted that there were indeed logistical difficulties but implored the members of parliament to assist in the exercise as they were stake holders.

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Few Register To Vote


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 22, 1996 by Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - ONLY 1.6 people million have registered as voters through out the country as at February 9, Elections Office public liaison officer Joe Sikazwe disclosed at a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday. Sikazwe said these are the latest figures for the just ended extended registration period.

"The national total of registered voters collected to February 9 is 1,624,094 people," Sikazwe said, " which is 37 per cent of the eligible voters." The figure has shocked the Foundation for Democratic Process (FODEP) leadership. 

"The 1.6 million is unbelievable, it is not encouraging at all," said FODEP secretary Bishop John Mambo in an interview yesterday. "There is still a lot of work to do and I hope we will utilise the remaining time to register at least 3 million people." Mambo attributed the apathy to the organisation and coordination of the registration exercise.

"We do not understand why the Elections Office has to work in isolation when NGOs who are monitoring elections are left out in such important programmes," Mambo said.

Mambo also dismissed the call to postpone the elections to 1997. "We just have to work hard and educate the people about voting, so that they can register, putting off the elections to next year will only complicate this democracy," Mambo advised. "Neither can I welcome the idea of having the elections with the old register because we will be depriving a lot of people of their basic right to vote. I can only welcome the continous registration exercise till the voting day as all other NGOs are suggesting."

And Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) has maintained its position on continous registration of voters and supported the idea of putting off the elections to next year if a democratic government is to be elected by the majority vote.

ZIMT president Alfred Zulu said in an interview yesterday that the current exercise has failed and wondered if the remaining 9 days before the programme ends will register another 1.6 million people.

"For elections to take place, at least 3.6 million people should register and I wonder if in the remaining 9 days 2 million people will register," Zulu said. "It will be better to put off the elections to next year so that we can register as many people as possible." And opposition UNIP vice-secretary for information and publicity, Pickson Chitambala, called for an immediate stop of the exercise.

"We called for the renewal of the voters register but we did not know that it will lead us to this mess of Nikuv and such apathy from the people," Chitambala carped in an interview yesterday. "Why did they bring in Nikuv to rig the elections for MMD? That is why we should have the elections this year using the old register."

February, 1996


Zambia Sacked Editor: I Am A Victim of State House


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 22, 1996 by Bright Mwape and Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - Sacked Times of Zambia editor, Arthur Simuchoba yesterday claimed he was a victim of State House manoeuvres. Simuchoba believes his dismissal cannot be divorced from the manoeuvres of State House and press aide Richard Sakala has several times expressed governments open disgust for his 'negative' attitude towards the MMD government.

"And obviously Sakala was working on instructions," Simuchoba said in an interview yesterday. "Not that I have anything personal against him. As far as I was concerned we were friends. But I understand. Work is work." 

The former Times editor said he was aware of severe relations between him and MMD members on the board over his journalistic stand. He claimed he has since being recalled not been invited to any board meeting at the Times.

" Even junior members received invitations not me. Everything happened behind my back at the Times," Simuchoba said. "I was only doing my job but I believe I was misunderstood."

But Simuchoba maintained he had no regrets that he did not compromise on good press freedom values to appease partisan wishes.

"This is an assault on press freedom, not me," Simuchoba said. "To me it was something that I saw coming one day but I had a job to do and I wanted to do it well.

But yesterday the Zambia Civic Education Association was busy mobilising a public protest re-scheduled to today, against Simuchoba's dismissal. By mid day large size posters had been flooded in several strategic points and several printed flyers had been produced.

According to organiser and ZCEA board member Chibembe Nyalugwe the demonstration will start from the assembly point in the main post office car park on Cairo road at 09:00 hours this morning. ZCEA has since been joined by the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT), Afronet and the Press Association of Zambia (PAZA) in condemning the Times move against Simuchoba.

"The man is a very competent journalist and he tried to run the Times competitively with the privately owned Post newspaper, he was critical and his editorials were professional," said ZIMT president Alfred Zulu, adding: "His dismissal is nothing but political. They want to hijack the paper to use it as a campaign medium." Zulu joined the ZCEA in calling for the dissolution of the Times board. And Afronet executive director, Ngande Mwanajiti, in a statement released in Lusaka viewed the termination of Mr Arthur Simuchoba's contract "as suspect and a gross human rights violation".

PAZA, according to its president, Francis Kasoma, has taken up legal action against the Times Board over Simuchoba's dismissal . "Simuchoba's dismissal confirms PAZA's stand that government owned media can never be free," Kasoma told the press yesterday.

On the Copperbelt the Zambia Union of Journalists resolved at the end of their meeting to hold back their action saying they would stand by PAZA's legal action.

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Finance Minister Roasted Over Customs Bills


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 22,1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Finance minister, Ronald Penza, was yesterday taken to task by back benchers over the Customs and Excise (Amendment) Bill which he presented in parliament for second reading.

Penza is seeking to amend the Customs and Excise Act so as to, among other things, harmonize the Act with that of the Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) Act of 1993, strengthen the powers of the Commissioner of Customs and Excise in the implementation of the Act, strengthen various sections concerned with compliance and enforcement and revise the nomenclature of the tariff and the rates of duty for Customs and Excise.

But Bwana Mkubwa MMD member of parliament, Andrew Kashita, told Penza that this proposals do not address the fundamental freedoms of citizens and the rule of law. 

Kashita said that some of the things Penza was proposing in the bill were not in his budget speech. He was particularly concerned about clause 5 sub section 7 of the bill which empowers the Commissioner of Customs and Excise to go to any bank and get information on individuals' bank accounts.

"We should be careful otherwise we will go back to the days of Special Investigation Team for Economy and Trade (SITET) which was used to fix certain individuals," Kashita said.

He was supported by Kafue MMD member of parliament, Yusuf Badat who wondered why the government wanted to give the ZRA additional powers when it managed to collect 35 per cent more than the targeted revenue last year.

"The key problem is at the point of entry. There is chaos, no orderliness and the infra structure is run down," Badat charged. He said the solution was to give customs officers at points of entry arresting powers, minimise the harassment of people and have a disciplined customs staff.

"If we are going to give the ZRA powers to seize goods and search banks, we are going to have an organisation similar to SITET," Badat added. However, Penza rebuffed the claims saying "the purpose of the legislation was essentially to curb smuggling and money laundering".

February, 1996


Zambia Party Distributes Campaign Cars


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 22, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The ruling Movement For Multiparty Democrary (MMD) has finally distributed 46 of the 80 vehicles it imported from South Africa late last year.

The 46 vehicles were parked at State House and last Saturday and Sunday number plates and their respective destinations were being fitted and painted on them by government employees. And 36 of these vehicles were parked at State House's old guest house and 11 at Nkwazi House. The work on the vehicles was being supervised by Presidential aide Fabian Mumba. 

MMD national secretary, Michael Sata refused to confirm this saying "the vehicles had nothing to do with the The Post."

"People are phoning me about more important things and you want to talk about MMD cars,"Sata complained in a telephone interview yesterday. "What have those cars got to do with you? Are they yours?"

But defense minister, Ben Mwila last October confirmed the purchase of the 80 vehicles to be used for party campaigns during the local government and presidential and general elections.

It was understood at the time that 80 drivers from the military intelligence had been sent to South Africa to pick up the vehicles at a cost of K63 million in maintenance allowances. Mwila denied the exercise was at the expense of the government. "It is the party which has bought these vehicles and there is nothing wrong for us to use the military because we are paying for their expenses," Mwila said in interview last year.

This time, 47 drivers from different government institutions and private organisations have been delegated the job of making sure the vehicles are taken to their various destinations.

And the drivers were addressed by President Chiluba on Saturday in the presence of Sata. The President advised the drivers to move safely saying the vehicles were for the party and that he would thank (reward) them very much upon their return. He is also said to have told the drivers that he was confident of winning the elections and that the vehicles were meant to boost the campaign at district level.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Voters' Apathy: Sign of Loss in Faith in Leaders


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 23, 1996 by Sibalwa Mwaanga (Column)


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Lusaka - The problem of voter apathy seems to be one which has defied all efforts to solve. Clearly,one of the reasons why voters shun the polls in this country is because they feel that the entire exercise is a total waste of time. "Why should I waste my time registering to vote?" a middle-aged civil servant asked me recently. "These people (politicians) are just the same."

Despite the numerous civic education campaigns aimed at encouraging the citizens of this country to exercise their franchise, this cynical attitude is widespread among the citizenry and poses a real danger to the survival of our fledgling democracy. But how can it be changed and how can the ordinary folk of this nation be persuaded to participate in the democratic process by voting? 

Obviously people will not change their attitudes unless they are convinced that their votes will make a difference in the political equation, and this goes beyond merely deciding whether it is Mr A or Mr B that will represent them in parliament.

If both Mr A and Mr B happen to be hopeless candidates with nothing to offer to the people, as has too often been the case in some constituencies, then the election of one or the other makes little difference to the voters either way and they are unlikely to be motivated to go to the polls next time around.

Let's face it, the calibre of some of our parliamentary candidates leaves a great deal to be desired, to say the least. You cannot realistically expect a semi-literate, debt-ridden political chancer to go into the National Assembly and do a good job of representing his constituency. There are cases of members of parliament who have sat in the house for many years and said nothing of substance. With such people offering themselves as candidates, it is not surprising that voters are not enthusiastic about entering the polling booths.

Political parties must be more serious about the candidates they adopt if they want people to respond to the call for them to particparte in the electoral process.

In fact there is need to establish minimum standards for MPs and only those meeting the laid down criteria should be allowed to stand. A basic level of education and a demonstrable ability to contribute effectively to the business of the house should be essential criteria. MPs should also be compelled by law to visit their constituencies a minimum specified number of times per year and to initiate development projects in their areas. They should also make themselves available to the people in their constituencies for consultation and to report on their activities.

Such measures are necessary to ensure that only individuals of high calibre find their way to Manda Hill. It is not fair to the electorate for unscrupulous political charlatans to cheat their way into parliament with sweet stories and once there to concentrate on enriching themselves, ignoring the suffering masses who voted for them.

Such a state of affairs does not augur well for democracy at all. It is therefore a matter of priority for minimum standards of performance for MPs and candidates to be set because we can only strengthen the voters' confidence in the electoral system and boost their willingness to vote by presenting them with quality candidates to choose from.

In the last presidential and general elections, the question of quality was completely overlooked in the headlong rush to get rid of UNIP. The consequences of that haste can be clearly seen in the quality (or lack of it) of some of the individuals who wormed their way into parliament in 1991. We should place a definite emphasis on quality in the forthcoming elections if we want see an end to voter apathy in Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


186 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Editors & Columnist Await Jail Sentence


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 23, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Two Post editors and a columnist found with a contempt of parliament case to answer by Speaker Robinson Nabulyato await a minimum of four months in jail.

Nabulyato, on Tuesday this week found Post editor-in-chief and managing director Fred M'membe, managing editor Bright Mwape and columnist Lucy Sichone guilty of violating the parliamentary privileges act. 

Nabulyato referred the matter to the Standing Orders committee dominated by the ruling MMD party.

"Our duty as a committee is to see what punishment can be meted out. We have a maximum of twelve months with hard labour to think about and with mitigating circumstances a more reasonable sentence will be reached," said a source who is a member of the Standing Orders Committee.

The source did not rule out speculation that the MMD dominated committee intended to use its position to achieve what the government has failed in courts and give the two editors a sentence of at least four months imprisonment with hard labour.

The member of the Standing Orders Committee also revealed that minister of legal affairs Remmy Mushota was expected today to raise a point of order on an article "Miyanda and Patel in their Master's shadow" by another Post editor Masautso Phiri which appeared in the Wednesday February 21, edition of the paper. The standing orders committee is chaired by Speaker of the National Assembly Robinson Nabulyato.

And the MMD members of parliament are today expected to hold a caucus meeting at 8:30 hours. By press time yesterday it was not known whether the ruling party caucus would be addressed by President Chiluba or by the Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment Rikki Shuts Down Recording Studios


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 23, 1996 by Jeff Kapembwa


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - Rikki Illilonga has shut down his multi million Kwacha recording studios in Lusaka's show grounds because of what he termed "undue frustrations".

Illilonga said Wednesday that he has been prompted to close down the studios set up last year because some people owning some stands in the show grounds were threatening his landlord, whom he named, with eviction.

"I have closed the damn studio because a clique of some businessmen did not like my presence there and complained that I was making noise with my music," he said adding, "apparently they did not like some people who patronised the premises for fear of a break-in." 

Illilonga has since decided to look for land to construct his own studio to be called Bongo.

"I have started looking for a piece of land to set up my ultra-modern studio near Soweto market. But I wouldn't like to disclose the amount of investment and I am hopeful it will be operational before the end of this year.

The setting up of the studio was intended to serve as an alternative for musicians to record and produce their music after the demise of Teal Record Company in Ndola last year which has left most of them in the cold.

Illilonga, now based in Denmark used the same studio to record his single titled "Viva City" in praise of Lusaka premier league side City of Lusaka football club.

Illilonga chided government for failing to recognise the role musicians played in making Zambia gain a cultural identity on the international scene. He has called for the implementation of the musicians living wage and copyright protection.

"This government has a moral obligation to ensure that musicians are given a living wage inspite of the royalties from their works," he said, adding, "Countries in Europe, take the state as a partner in the success of artists."

On whether he recognises the role of Zambia Union of Musicians (ZUM) in ensuring the protection of copyright and composers are adhered and promoted, Illilonga carped.

"Forget about ZUM, it has been a non starter from the onset. What we need now is government's direct protection of musicians' copyright," he said.

He added: "In Denmark I pay 100 per month to Danish Musician's Union as a guarantee for the safety of my life and welfare. Why can't the government do the same, ZUM has not been helpful all along and it is up to the government to protect its artists."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996

Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Soccer: FIFA Rates Team The Best In Africa


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 23, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has been rated the best African football team and the 15th in the world, according to the latest FIFA rankings.

The rankings, which were released on February 21, have cheered Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) with general secretary, Hermann Mpashi expressing his excitement over the 'good news'. 

"It's a very big achievement for us that for the first time, Zambia has been rated the best soccer nation in Africa in the second FIFA/Coca Cola World Ranking this year," said Mpashi at a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday.

Zambia was last year ranked 23rd.

New Africa Cup winners South Africa's Bafana Bafana are placed 23rd with 50.74 points while Zambia has 53.16.

Ghana is the second best African team at 16th place in the world with 52.63 points. Egypt is ranked 22nd followed by Cote d'Ivorie, Tunisia, Morocco, England and then Belgium.

While 1994 World Cup champions, Brazil, maintained their first position, Nigeria, the 1995 Africa Cup champions are at 39th position.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996

189 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Veteran Actor Dies


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 23, 1996 by Jeff Kapembwa


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The only living symbol of the once versatile Kanyama theatre club has finally gone. Actor Maxwell Tembo is dead.

Tembo, 36, died on February 6 at UTH after an illness and was buried at Leopards hill cemetary in what the artistic fraternity has described as an" eradication of artistic talent in the country". 

The deceased's sister, Magaret Tembo confirmed the death in an interview yesterday.

"My brother died on February 6 and we buried him on February 9. He had complained of persistent chest pains and he died in UTH after an illness" she said. "We have lost a brother as well as an actor who lived to fulfil the essence of promoting theatre for development".

Tembo, one of the initiators of Kanyama travelling theatre in 1980, has been inspirational in the promotion of theatre for development in the country in collaboration with various NGOs.

The group comprising Chris Zulu, Robert Manda, Charles Phiri and Maxwell Tembo( namesake to the deceased) and Tembo, had soon after inception embarked on various developmental drama shows in various parts of the country and abroad which earned them fame.

After more than a decade of community theatre, death creeped into the club claiming the life of Robert Mpande in 1992. Two years later Chris Zulu and Charles Phiri died.

As though a bad omen had come to stay with the club, Maxwell" kawale'' Tembo died in January last year. Tembo, who from inception had been group leader steered the club until his death early this month.

He however managed to fulfil the club's ambition when he last year initiated a civic awareness programme with Southern University(SU) and received K4.2million to be undertaken in two phases.

The first phase started in October and ended in December while the second phase has continued from January and expires next month and will be accomplished by another group of artists Tembo had hired to assist him accomplish the task.

190 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Sudan Party Adopts plan To Overthrow Regime


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) February 23, 1996


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

London - Six months after the ground breaking conference in Asmara, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) leadership returned once more to the Eritrean capital in January in order to formulate a strategy leading to the overthrow of the National Islamic Front(NIF) regime. Meeting between 12 and 15 January, the NDA leadership adopted measures concerning both the political and military struggle.

The meeting was chaired by the NDA chairperson, Mohamed Osman El Mirghani of the Democratic Unionist Party(DUP), and was attended by representatives of all the member groups. Alamin Mohamed Said, secretary general of the Popular Front for Democracy and Justice (PFDJ) of Eritrea, attended the conference on behalf of the Eritrean government, whilst Fatima Ahmed Ibrahim attended as an observer for the Sudanese Women's Movement. The following resolutions and recommendations were adopted at the Asmara leadership conference:

On the Political Plane

(1) The NDA Leadership Council unanimously reaffirms that the first choice for the NDA is the unity of the people of Sudan based on choice and free will, which is, in turn, based on citizenship, equality and justice. The NDA leadership also reaffirms its commitment to the right of Self-determination as contained in the Asmara Declaration of June 1995. 

(2) The NDA leadership further affirms that the unity of the Sudanese opposition movement on issues of destiny, which was achieved during the Asmara conference in June, is the only basis for achieving the implementation of the Asmara resolutions. The leadership resolves to maintain that unity until the people of Sudan achieve that implementation, which is the best basis for achieving the political objectives of all the people of Sudan.

(3) The NDA leadership resolves to accelerate and redouble its efforts in the political and military fields in accordance with the plans to bring about a quick overthrow of the NIF regime, now that the political vision for the future of the country is clear and the national, regional and international climate is favourable.

(4) The NDA leadership resolves to strengthen and promote the institutions of the alliance to keep pace with national, regional and international developments.

(5) The NDA leadership resolves to provide the Sudan People's Liberation Army(SPLA) with all material support, so that the SPLA will maintain and sustain the military initiative which it has enjoyed since its successful offensive of October 1995.

(6) The NDA leadership resolves to strengthen its media organs to expose the external isolation of the NIF regime, to support the unity of the opposition inside the country, and to protect and safeguard that unity to enable the internal opposition to launch a popular uprising to overthrow the NIF regime.

(7) The NDA leadership resolves to mobilise international public opinion and support for the cause of democracy and freedom in Sudan.

(8) The NDA leadership resolves to boycott the elections charade that the regime has announced it intends to hold in 1996, believing that it is merely designed to improve the regime's image internationally and will not be a true exercise in democracy. Furthermore, the leadership resolves to mobilise the Sudanese public to boycott the elections.

Regional and International Planes

(1) The NDA leadership welcomes the international condemnation and isolation of the NIF regime, and particularly appreciates the resolutions in December 1995 of the United Nations General Assembly, which condemned the regime's human rights record and the resurgence of the slave trade in Sudan.

(2) The NDA leadership welcomes the outcome of the London Conference of November 1995 and applauds its resolutions, which are a step forward towards the attainment of peace and democracy in Sudan, because they have combined the Asmara Declaration with the Declaration of Principles of the Intergovernmental Authority for Drought and Development(IGADD) committee on peace in Sudan. This has given an impetus to the search for peace and democracy and has provided the opportunity for the Sudanese opposition outside of the NDA to share its views on the future of Sudan.

(3) The NDA leadership registers its satisfaction with the regional initiative to contain the recent conflict between Eritrea and the Yemen, particularly the roles of Egypt and Ethiopia, which enabled the conflict to move away from military confrontation to a peaceful resolution through mediation and arbitration in accordance with international law.

(4) The NDA leadership registers a vote of thanks to all the governments and international organisations that have supported the just cause of the people of Sudan.

(5) The NDA leadership calls on all the countries that support the NIF regime with arms and ammunition to refrain from doing so and to prevent their weapons being used against the people of Sudan. The leadership, furthermore, wishes to assure all the governments which support the regime that the NDA does indeed represent all the social and political groups in Sudan other than the NIF and wants to avoid any situation which may complicate relationships with those governments once the regime has been overthrown.

On Terrorism

(1) The NDA leadership condemns the NLIF regime for using terrorism against the people of Sudan ad for exporting it to the Arab, Islamic and African worlds. The leadership also condemns the regime's sponsorship of international terrorist groups whose presence in Sudan is destroying resources and creating insecurity for a people renowned for their religious tolerance and rejection of all forms of terrorist violence.

(2) The NDA leadership condemns the NIF regime for its part in the assassination attempt on the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa last June, as well as for its refusal to hand over to Ethiopia the Sudanese and foreign terrorists responsible for that outrage who have since sought sanctuary inside Sudan.

(3) The NDA leadership supports the complaint made by the Ethiopian government to the Organisation for African Unity (OAU) and the United Nations Security Council concerning the terrorist activities of the NIF regime, and urges the two organisations to impose wide ranging sanctions with the intention of forcing the regime to hand over the terrorist suspects and to close down the terrorist training camps inside Sudan, which are a constant threat to the security of the region.

(4) The NDA leadership calls on the international community to impose an oil and armaments embargo on the NIF regime so as to frustrate the regime's criminal activities against the people of Sudan, and prevent it from destabilising and undermining the security of neighbouring states. The leadership also calls on the international community to check and control the regime's capacity to subvert international order and security through the imposition of sanctions similar to those imposed on other rogue regimes around the world.

Other Decisions

The NDA leadership also approved the applications for membership of the NDA by the Sudan Federal Alliance led by the veteran politician from Darfur, Ahmed Ibrahim Diraige, and the Sudanese Women's Movement. Mr. Diraige is likely to be invited to join the eleven member leadership council at the next NDA conference scheduled to take place within the next three months. Such an invitation can only be issued by the full conference. The January meeting also allowed Fatima Ahmed Ibrahim to attend as an observer, representing the Sudanese women until the next meeting of the full conference.

No DUP Controversy

Before the January meeting, there had been press reports that the DUP's commitment to the Asmara Declaration of June 1995 was a half-hearted one, and that it had refused to sign the document last June because it wanted to change the wording of some of the resolutions and clauses. Some of the Sudanese newspapers published from Cairo sought to play on this imaginary disagreement within the NDA, simply because they were themselves opposed to Self-determination.

The January meeting dispelled the rumours, as the DUP had never made any conditions about the document. True, the DUP had been concerned that the clause on unity ought to be at the forefront of the document, but had never suggested alterations to the contents.

The DUP's concerns about drafting will be tabled for discussion at the next full NDA conference. Meanwhile, the Asmara Declaration of last June has been signed by the representative of the DUP and countersigned by Sayed Mohamed Osman El Mirghani himself in his capacity as chairman of the NDA.

In spite of the very positive developments at Asmara in January, "Al Khartoum" newspaper, which had been at the forefront of the campaign to create divisions within the NDA over the question of Self-determination, ran a headline on 16 January suggesting that the NDA had endorsed all the DUP's amendments which would place the emphasis on unity rather than Self-determination. It is a fact of life, however, that even when proved wrong, some newspaper editors have a habit of creating controversy where none actually exists.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Sudan and Ethiopia UN Asks Regime To Respond To Charges


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette(London) February 23, 1996


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

London - In the middle of January, the United Nations Security Council considered the Ethiopian government's request that the National Islamic Front(NIF) regime hand over for extradition three terrorist suspects implicated in the June 1995 assassination attempt on Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak. The regime's minister of foreign affairs attempted to cloud the issue by asking the Security Council to debate an alleged invasion of Sudan by Ethiopian forces, but this crude attempt at sabotaging the main debate was quickly dealt with out of hand.

The regime's foreign minister, Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, left New York with little to show for the price of his air ticket. He had clearly failed to side-track the Security Council and had to relay the news back to Khartoum that the regime was merely being given time in which to comply with the Ethiopian request. 

Issues of Terrorism

The Security Council plainly considered the issues of international terrorism to be more significant than any run of the mill border dispute between the two countries. The council urged the NIF regime to cooperate with the Ethiopians by extraditing the three suspected terrorists to Addis Ababa. This urging did not amount to a full resolution, which would have required near instant compliance or the risk of punitive sanctions.

As it stands, Khartoum has been given an unspecified time to comply with the request while the issue will remain on the council's agenda. If and when the council considers that a reasonable time has elapsed without compliance, the issue will be considered once more by the council and a formal resolution is likely to be issued. Punitive action would then become automatic if the regime insisted upon non-compliance.

The Ethiopian Case

The regime's international standing has been further damaged, even if it were to comply in full with the Security Council's request, because it has been formally documented as a pariah state which sponsors international terrorism. Khartoum's denials have become totally unbelievable and unacceptable.

The Ethiopian investigation into the failed assassination attempt concluded that the Khartoum regime was directly involved in the plot and had assisted in its planning and execution. This was revealed in a report published last September, thirty-two days after the outrage. At that time, the Ethiopians had come to the conclusion and made it plain that no interests would be further served by covering up the Sudanese involvement. Quiet diplomatic attempts to persuade Khartoum to extradite the three terrorist suspects had failed between June and September, and so the Ethiopians had little option but to go public with their findings. Khartoum's intransigence since September, in spite of a valid extradition treaty between Sudan and Ethiopia, left Addis Ababa with little option other than to take its case to the United Nations.

Flawed Arguments

The NIF regime has presented a flawed argument in defence of its position. Ignoring the evidence of the quiet diplomacy which took place in the period between the end of June and the beginning of September, the regime has sought to use the time which elapsed between the outrage and the publication of the Ethiopian report as a reason why it is in no position to hand over the terrorist suspects. Khartoum has implied that the terrorists, if they were ever in Sudan, have long since departed and are beyond their jurisdiction. Khartoum has blamed Ethiopia's speed of response to the outrage as the reason why it cannot hand over the suspects.

Through its request, the Security Council has shown that it does not believe the NIF regime's version of events. The Security Council, especially its five permanent members, cannot be seen to be sanctioning assassination attempts on heads of state, and so had little option than to back up the Ethiopian case. Now Khartoum must deliver the three terrorists or face the music.

No Evidence of Invasion

The NIF regime claimed in January that Ethiopian forces had invaded Sudan, captured five border villages and moved seventy miles into Sudanese territory. No evidence was presented to back up this claim, and the Ethiopian authorities denied that any border incidents had taken place, let alone a full scale invasion.

The Ethiopian government has stated that it would hardly jeapardise its very strong case against the NIF regime by invading Sudan. For its part, the Security Council instructed Khartoum to pursue its case against Addis Ababa with the relevant UN bodies and agencies that regularly deal with border disputes between member nations. Meanwhile, the NIF regime has made no request for the UN to send observers to the border region to witness at first hand the alleged invasion, which would have seemed a logical move to make in the circumstances.

There are, of course, other reasons why the NIF regime has decided to target Ethiopia as the villain of its propaganda piece. With diplomatic relations between Sudan and Eritrea suspended, and Asmara's public declaration of support for the Sudanese opposition National Democratic Alliance(NDA), there would be little to be gained from targeting Eritrea. The Eritrean government would be unlikely to rise to the bait. The regime dearly wants to convince its dwindling number of international supporters that it is the victim of a regional conspiracy because of its "civilisational orientation", a euphemism for Islamic Fundamentalism.

Whatever Khartoum's reason for spreading the invasion story, it certainly backfired at the Security Council. It now remains to be seen whether the regime will comply with the Security Council's request over the terrorist suspects. If not, it must be clear that the Security Council will not let the matter rest there.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


United States and Africa Labor Leaders Endorse Embargo Against Nigeria


BYLINE: AFL-CIO Executive Council February 21, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Bal Harbour, Florida - Despite increasing international criticism and isolation, the renegade regime of General Sani Abacha continues on a course of widespread violation of the most basic rights of Nigerian citizens.

Violence and illegal arrests continue, much of which has been targeted against the country's trade unions and their leaders. 

Among those under detention is Brother Frank Kokori, general secretary of the National Union of Petroleum and Natural Gas Workers (NUPENG), arrested July 4, 1994, who remains in prison without charge. Milton Dabibi, general secretary of the Nigerian oil and gas workers' union PENGASSAN, was arrested last month and is also being held without charge.

The AFL-CIO, in solidarity with Nigeria's independent trade unions, believes that more effective and forceful measures are urgently needed to force the Abacha regime to stop the violence and torture, restore civil liberties including an end to arbitrary arrests, and immediately release all political prisoners.

Specifically, the AFL-CIO joins others in calling for a complete embargo of Nigerian exports, sanctions on those organizations and nations that refuse to honor the embargo, and an embargo on shipment of equipment and replacement parts to Nigeria. In addition, foreign bank accounts of Nigeria's ruling generals must be frozen and their stolen millions preserved for the Nigerian people.

Ninety percent of Nigeria's foreign revenue comes from oil exports with nearly fifty percent of this oil exported to the United States. For our part, the AFL-CIO will continue to do everything in its power to support Nigeria's besieged independent trade unions and to pressure U.S. oil companies to admit their culpability by easing their support of the Nigerian military regime which violently abuses human and worker rights to degrade the environment and make massive profits from the blood of its citizens.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

193 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Rapid Government Response Stems Ebola Outbreak in Gabon


BYLINE: World Health Organization February 23, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Geneva - Control measures instituted in Gabon by the Ministry of Health and an international medical team appear to be containing further spread of Ebola haemorrhagic fever in the country, according to assessments by World Health Organization (WHO) team members.

The number of cases and deaths from the disease have remained essentially unchanged during the past four days. All of the cases are reported to have originated in the village of Mayibout II, located in a remote area of northern Gabon. Additional suspected cases are currently under surveillance in the same region. 

("Cases" are persons confirmed by laboratory tests as being infected, or who develop a syndrome compatible with Ebola haemorrhagic fever and are known to have had contact with a source of infection. "Suspected cases" are persons who had contact with a source of infection and are exhibiting some symptoms of the disease.)

Having established sufficient control measures, the Ministry of Health and international medical team are now conducting a retrospective investigation of the outbreak. This will lay the groundwork for follow-up research into how the outbreak took place, and what can be learned from it about the natural host of the Ebola virus.

In a press conference yesterday in Libreville, the Minister of Health, Dr Serge Mba Bekale, said that "as soon as the government suspected that the illness in Mayibout might be due to infection with Ebola virus, and before the exact cause was known, all appropriate measures were taken to limit the outbreak."

WHO attributes the limited spread of the outbreak in Gabon to several key factors. One was the rapid response by the Ministry of Health in recognizing the threat at an early stage and reacting appropriately. Control measures included the isolation of actual and suspected cases, which reduced the odds of secondary infection.

Another important factor was a large-scale information campaign conducted by the government to inform the public about haemorrhagic fever, its mode of transmission and ways to avoid infection.

Finally, in contrast to last year's epidemic in Zaire which struck in an urban zone, the outbreak in Gabon occurred in a rural area with low population density, a natural advantage in limiting the further spread of infection. Some sporadic secondary cases of Ebola are nevertheless expected.

Of particular concern to investigators was the possibility of secondary infections among health workers in the provincial hospital of Makokou, where the Ebola patients were admitted on 5-6 February. The 21-day incubation period is still in effect, but no health workers have manifested symptoms of the disease.

WHO will continue to work with Ministries of Health in countries at risk to strengthen their capacity for responding to suspected outbreaks of Ebola haemorrhagic fever and to ensure that appropriate materials are available for preventing spread of the disease.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Business Tunis Stock Exchange to Introduce Computer Trading


BYLINE: Tunisia Press Agency February 24 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Tunis - In order to add more transparency to stock market transactions the Tunis Stock Exchange (La Bourse) is to introduce real-time computer trading next June, announced Finance Minister Nouri Zorgati in a press briefing held today in Tunis. The minister noted also that the process of privatization of public firms will witness an increase in 1996 in sectors such as transportation, tourism, and industry. 

Twenty seven firms are scheduled to be privatized in 1996, versus 20 in 1995 thanks to the reorganization of La Bourse and the introduction of a new law last year regulating the activities of stock brokers and shifting the duties of oversight from La Bourse to a newly established Financial Market Council (Conceil du Marche Financier.)

The main objectives of the new reforms are to privatize one company per month and to introduce new mechanisms guaranteeing accurate and fast transactions through computerization.

Despite the absence of such mechanism, the stock market had good results in 1995, rising 25% overall.

Tunisia Great Lakes Summit Announced


BYLINE: Tunisia Press Agency February 24 1996


LENGTH: 93 words


 

Tunis - The presidents of Burundi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire will hold a summit March 3 -5 in Tunis to examine prospects of joint effort to resolve the humanitarian crises of Africa's Great Lakes region.

It will be the second such summit organized by the Carter Center, based in Atlanta, Georgia. The first summit was organized in Cairo, November 27-28, 1995.
