196 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


United States and Africa New Clinton Administration Trade Policy (Excerpts)


BYLINE: Africa Policy Information Center February 24, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2547 words


 

Washington, D.C. - The U.S. Congress, in approving the Uruguay Round Trade Agreements in 1994, included a provision that the President should develop and implement a comprehensive trade and development policy for Africa, and present annual reports on its progress over a four-year period. The first report, excerpted below, was presented on February 1.

Initial reaction from Congress and from non-governmental organizations has been that the report falls far short of the stated objectives, pointing out that it is mainly a compilation of existing programs, includes an uncritical endorsement of questionable structural adjustment programs, and fails to address the critical issue of Africa's debt.

A bipartisan congressional caucus on Africa Trade and Investment is being formed, which will prepare its own response to the administration's policy over the next few months. The caucus welcomes input from a wide variety of sources on the strengths and weaknesses of the administration policy, as well as new suggestions relevant to presenting a more adequate alternative. 

Comments should be sent to Charles Williams, Chief of Staff, Office of Rep. Jim McDermott, 2349 Rayburn Building, Washington, DC 20515. Phone 202-225-3106; fax: 202-225-6197.

The text below includes sections 1 and 2 of the document prepared by the United States Trade Representative's office in the White House.

A COMPREHENSIVE TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT POLICY FOR THE COUNTRIES OF AFRICA A Report Submitted by the President of the United States to the Congress

I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This report presents a comprehensive policy framework through which the United States will pursue its trade and development strategy with the 48 countries of Sub-Saharan Africa. Increased economic growth in Africa would not only stabilize the region financially and politically, but also create greater opportunities for U.S. businesses and investors and more jobs for Americans.

To seize the opportunity for partnership aimed both at supporting African objectives and pursuing U.S. interests, this policy establishes a framework for supporting and facilitating African efforts to create an enabling environment for the promotion of trade, investment, and sustainable development. To address effectively the wide spectrum of challenges that confronts African development, the policy framework outlined in this report is structured around five basic objectives: trade liberalization and promotion; investment liberalization and promotion; development of the private sector; infrastructure enhancement; and economic and regulatory reform. This report offers a summary of these objectives and the initiatives being pursued in each area. This Administration is also opening a wider dialogue with interested parties in Africa and the United States for the purpose of sharpening the focus of the U.S. role in the years to come. Developing a coherent strategy for promoting trade and development in Sub-Saharan Africa requires a coordinated effort among the Administration, the Congress and the private sector.

The United States recognizes the difficulties African countries have faced in their efforts to develop both human and economic capital. Problems such as overwhelming debt burdens, flawed economic policy choices, poverty and widespread unemployment, weak private sectors stifled by dominating parastatals, environmental degradation and an absence of democratic political institutions have combined in the past to hamper Africa's aspirations for growth and development. However, change has begun to sweep the African continent as countries are increasingly abandoning the discredited statist policies of the last three decades and committing to policy changes based upon democratic political principles and market-based economic reforms. This growing commitment to democracy and structural adjustment inspires optimism about the future of Africa and provides new opportunities for the United States both to support African efforts and to pursue American economic and security interests.

Indeed, African countries have begun to recognize the critical importance of creating a policy environment conducive to investment and growth. A recent World Bank report documents a direct correlation between those countries that have embarked on major policy reforms and those that have experienced the greatest economic growth. In addition, the report shows that bilateral and multilateral assistance have been instrumental in supporting a stable policy environment. This allows reforms the time necessary to take hold and has helped catalyze private investment, which will be the engine of future growth.

The challenge is to promote increased growth, often drawing upon the continent's fragile but rich resource base, in a manner which is sustainable and promotes individual initiative and private investment. Many countries are making significant progress in implementing policies which promote the husbanding of the resource base, however, environmental concerns still threaten many short term growth options.

Between 1990 and 1994, the United States provided $13.6 billion in all forms of bilateral and multilateral assistance to Africa. These funds promoted trade and development, helped develop the private sector, enhanced infrastructure, supported economic and regulatory reform, encouraged democracy, provided technical assistance and food aid, and helped stem environmental degradation.

In addition, multilateral institutions have also played a major role in assisting development in Sub-Saharan Africa: between 1993 and 1995, the World Bank Group provided over $3.7 billion for structural adjustment, private sector development and civil service reform in Africa; the International Monetary Fund had total credit outstanding to Africa of about $9 billion as of June 1995 to promote viable financial and balance of payments positions; and the African Development Bank committed over $13.6 billion to Africa (including North Africa) between 1990 and 1994 to support policy reform and economic development.

However, resources available to the United States Government, multilateral institutions and others providing official development assistance to Africa are in decline. This requires U.S. policy to focus on appropriate allocation of available funds and on successfully attracting more private sector participation and investment. U.S. policy will also seek to increase cooperation among donor nations and multilateral institutions.

This report outlines a comprehensive trade and development policy for the countries of Sub-Saharan Africa aimed at accelerating economic growth. It first notes the policy challenges and the reforms necessary for economic development and social stability. It then offers a brief summary of the critical policy choices the countries of Africa have made. After reviewing both bilateral and multilateral policies and programs currently in operation, this report defines objectives and new initiatives for increasing trade and development in Africa.

II. POLICY STATEMENT

The primary objective of the Administration's Comprehensive Trade and Development Policy is to work with the people and leaders of Africa in the pursuit of increased trade and investment, and sustainable economic development.

Achievement of these objectives would, in turn, enable the countries of Africa to become more fully integrated into the global economy and share in the prosperity enjoyed by participating countries.

The thrust of this policy is captured in the following passage from the Communique from the June 1995 G-7 Halifax Summit which appeared under the heading of Promoting Sustainable Development:

A higher quality of life for all people is the goal of sustainable development. Democracy, human rights, transparent and accountable governance, investment in people and environmental protection are the foundations of sustainable development. The primary responsibility rests with each country but bilateral and multilateral international cooperation is essential to reinforce national efforts. We are committed to securing substantial flows of funds and to improving the quality of our assistance.

As this statement makes clear, the responsibility rests with African countries to commit themselves to these objectives and to make the policy choices that will enable them to achieve these objectives. Help from outside Africa cannot overcome lack of commitment or wrong choices by the governments or people of Africa. However, if the commitment is there and the right choices are made, external assistance can make a valuable difference. The commitment and right choices now being made by a number of African countries give us ample reason to re-energize our efforts and to join with those countries in a partnership to pursue our mutual interests in democracy, political stability and economic growth.

These historic policy changes offer a critical opportunity to the United States. By supporting African countries in the pursuit of their development objectives, many of our own interests -- from the promotion of American trade to international security concerns -- can be advanced simultaneously. Economic development in Africa will mean expanded trade with the United States, resulting in economic growth and new jobs for Americans as well as for Africans. The continued development of democratic institutions in Africa will not only stabilize the environment for this economic growth but will also help counter forces that threaten U.S. security, such as terrorism, refugee flows, narcotics trafficking, humanitarian crises, and environmental degradation.

Strengthening the synergies between trade and development is a major objective in U.S. policy toward Africa. The successful experiences of East and Southeast Asia demonstrate that rapid expansion of trade leads to rapid economic growth and employment. The resulting increase in incomes, in turn, leads to greater foreign and domestic investment and increased demand for foreign goods and services. Foreign development assistance is replaced by increased trade and foreign and domestic private investment. Development then becomes self-sustaining.

Creating a more hospitable environment for private investment is critical to the success of Africa's development. We are in an era of declining official development assistance, both bilateral and multilateral. Future official aid programs will not be large enough to provide all, or even the majority, of the financing needed for Africa's development. Instead, they increasingly will serve to prepare the policy and management context for, and to catalyze, inflows of private capital. The emphasis, whether in aid councils or business development activities, must be on supporting those countries that show a willingness and ability to implement reform.

Given the current fiscal constraints faced by the United States, the Administration will not request any additional funding at this time. Funding for these activities will come from within current budgets. Moreover, since the budgets of the agencies participating in this policy are expected to decline in the short-term, it is probable that current levels of activities may even decline.

The United States will focus its support on those countries in Africa that are pursuing meaningful structural adjustment and economic reform because they have the greatest chance of success. Specifically, the United States will:

* join in multilateral efforts to assist those African countries undertaking meaningful economic and regulatory reform, including debt reduction where warranted;

* support efforts to improve essential government and non-government institutions.

* support efforts to improve physical infrastructure needed in a modern market economy;

* create a more growth-oriented business climate that will attract foreign as well as domestic investment and generate expanded trade in which U.S. firms can participate as effective commercial partners;

* remove barriers to trade in Africa and increase African participation in the world trading system, including the WTO, in the U.S. GSP program, and strengthen intellectual property protection;

* expand advocacy and support programs for U.S. exporters and investors in Africa; and

* promote greater regional integration within Africa.

The full text available on the World Wide Web at http://www.ustr.gov/reports/africa. Distributed by the Africa Policy Information Center, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: apic@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


197 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


United States and Africa Commerce Secretary Leads African Mission


BYLINE: US Department of Commerce (Washington) February 7, 1996


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Washington, D.C. - Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown today announced that he will lead a commercial development mission to Sub-Saharan Africa February 17-25, 1996 to advocate for increased U.S. trade in the region. Brown will encourage local representatives of U.S. companies in Africa and international lending executives to join him in discussions with government leaders representing nearly 40 African countries.

Brown will visit Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Kenya, Uganda, and Botswana. During the Botswana visit Brown will represent the United States at a meeting of the 12-member Southern African Development Community (SADC). He will hold multi-lateral discussions in Cote d'Ivoire and Kenya and bi-lateral meetings in Ghana and Uganda. 

Prior to departing on the mission, Brown will meet with U.S. corporate executives interested in doing business with Africa. During his mission, Brown will identify specific opportunities for U.S. businesses and bring together U.S. corporate executives, lenders, and government leaders to address issues concerning U.S. commercial interests. Brown also plans to meet with African business interests to explore methods to encourage more trade with the United States. "Trade is a two-way street. We want to see African businesses succeed in trade with the United States just as we anticipate expanded opportunities for U.S. companies doing business in Africa," Brown said.

Brown pointed out that private investment in Africa, when coupled with sound government, economic and social policies, has delivered exceptional returns. In 1993, U.S. companies enjoyed a return on investment of over 25 percent in Africa, where similar ventures in all developing countries equaled only 17 percent. This can be compared with a return on investment in developed countries of less than 9 percent. "These outstanding economic results demonstrate the exceptional opportunities offered by progressive African countries," Brown added.

The trip is planned in conjunction with release of Clinton Administration's Africa trade and development policy report to Congress. The report, released this week, encourages African countries to liberalize trade and investment policies within a framework of democratic initiatives, market-based policies and creation of an enabling business environment. "Investors want to see open, democratic societies and efficient, frugal government management of public resources," Brown said. The Clinton plan centers on encouraging individual African governments to embrace socio-economic reform, regulatory restructuring, and the lowering and leveling of barriers to trade and investment.

Brown stated that he will stress the Clinton Administration's commitment to democratic values, market-based economic policies, increased regional integration and aggressive competition for a large share of African trade. "Europe's era of economic dominance and trade hegemony in Africa is over," Brown said. Citing President Clinton's report to Congress, Brown explained that the U.S. share of Sub-Saharan Africa's markets stood at only 7.7 percent in 1994, while the European Union captured over 40 percent of these markets. "The United States will no longer cede these important markets to former colonial powers and we will support a policy of democracy, human rights, fiscal responsibility and regional cooperation to achieve our goals," Brown said.

The Clinton Administration's plan is to level the commercial playing field by offering responsible African governments and businesses top-level access to the strongest and most innovative capital market in the world---the United States. "This initiative will mean more prosperity for Africans and more jobs for Americans," Brown said.

The meetings and conferences with government officials, international lending institution representatives and the private sector will focus on encouraging regional economic partnerships. "Most of the small Sub-Saharan African countries simply cannot compete in the global market standing alone. Just look at the rest of the world. The Europeans have strong trading bloc, we have a successful partnership in the Americas, and Asian economic coalitions are getting stronger every day. Market survival today depends on forging strong bonds with your neighbors through sound government economic policies, elimination of trade barriers and a peaceful social structure supported by democratic principles. This is the way to grow and prosper into the next century," Brown added.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Uganda Beware: the rains are playing tricks (Editorial)


BYLINE: The Monitor (Kampala) February 7, 1996


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Kampala - This year's first rains have come two months earlier than expected in most parts of the country. Which has raised some concerns among our farming population.

Many farmers are just in a state of confusion. They do not know whether to respond to the rains by planting crops or not. Besides, most of them were caught unprepared with the fields not yet cleared while others were still harvesting the last crops. 

The worries by the peasants are not unfounded. There's the temptation to respond to the rains by planting because of a number of reasons. The pattern of the rainy seasons could be changing. In which case if they do not plant now they might miss the season since it's unlikely the rains will continue through the usual months.

The other fear is that if they responded by planting, the early rains could have been just a teaser and could stop with the crops having barely found life in the ground. In which case their labour would have been lost.

The worst fear is that of famine and hunger in the event that they miss the season as they keep contemplating. So what do they do in the circumstances?

Somebody somewhere in the Agriculture Department ought to have come out on this question. But, perhaps not surprising, it's mum.

This inertia is unpardonable. It's common knowledge that Uganda depends on agriculture, not only for food, but also for our exports as well. In which case we would be taking anything to do with weather like something threatening our life line.

For example, as some foresighted peasant farmers think, the disruption in the rain patterns spell famine and hunger. In these circumstances, people need to stock a big chunk of their most recent harvest in preparation for the likely harsh times ahead.

But even without the early rains, the weather in Uganda has a tendency to change for the worst almost every three years on average. So when drought strikes, in most instances it would have been expected. There's no need to wait and react like we've been taken by surprise.

There is a lot of expert knowledge lying idle which would help the farmers cope with the consequences in the changing weather pattern. All someone has to do is put it out--just five minutes a day on state radio for a week will do wonders.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


199 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Uganda's Cranes back into Africa Nations Cup


BYLINE: The Monitor (Kampala) February 7, 1996 by Hassan Badru Zziwa


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Kampala - The Uganda national team, the Cranes, have been readmitted and drawn in the 1998 Africa Cup of Nations -- the continent's most prestigious soccer meet-- The Monitor learnt late last night.

The man credited with this feat is Kenya Football Federation boss, Job Omino, who used his regional CAF executive membership credentials to save Uganda.

The draws were made last Friday in South Africa without the Uganda Cranes, following the failure of FUFA to enter the team for the tournament whose finals will be played in Burkina Faso. 

"I talked to CAF Secretary Mustapha Fahmy and CAF president Issa Hayatou and we agreed in principle to re-admit Uganda," Omino told "The Monitor" last night on phone.

"Following this turn of events, Uganda Cranes have now been drawn in Group Three," he added.

Uganda Cranes will play against Egypt, Ethiopia, Morocco and Senegal, from which the two top nations shall qualify for the finals.

The round-robin matches for Group Three kick off in October with a match between Egypt and Morocco.

Omino revealed that he learnt Uganda's fate last Friday, after receiving a call from one time UFA Secretary, Sam Kiwanuka, while in South Africa.

"It was shameful--I had to react fast to convince both my bosses in CAF to re-admit Uganda. CAF will communicate to you about the rest of the details," he said.

National Council of Sports(NCS) General Secretary, Abbey Lutaya, had earlier on told The Monitor that Uganda's failure to pay the US$240 registration fee was due to lack of commitment within FUFA.

Efforts by "The Monitor" to talk to FUFA boss, Twaha Kakaire, proved futile as he was reported to be in a closed door meeting, while the General Secretary Chris Rwanika, was reported to be in Kabale.

Earlier, the news of Uganda's missing out in the 21st Africa Nations Cup draws took soccer fans by surprise and shock. The whole soccer fraternity was baying for the entire FUFA executive to resign.

Most of the blame was put on FUFA Secretary Chris Rwanika. But Rwanika shot back--saying that, it was "sheer rubbish". He said his colleagues were using him as a scapegoat to cover up for their own shortcomings.

Meanwhile, in a meeting last night, FUFA made several amendments, among which is the removal of a rule which prohibits a player from moving to another club before serving a term of three years.

With effect from next year, players will be free to move from one club to another after serving one year. But a club will not lose more than four players in a season.

Clubs representing the country in the CAF inter-clubs tournaments will not lose more than two players.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Ban on Post Extends to Internet


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa February 16, 1996


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Maputo - Text of Media Alert from the Media Institute of Southern Africa.

The Internet edition of The Post newspaper of February 5 - banned by President Frederick Chiluba in terms of Section 53 of the Penal Code - has been removed from the paper's World Wide Web (WWW) site.

Mark Bennet of Zamnet Communications, the privately-owned Internet service provider which hosts The Post's WWW site, says Zamnet was left with little choice but to make the February 5 edition of The Post inaccessible on the Internet. 

Bennet says Zamnet kept the banned version of The Post on the WWW for two days after it was published, but was then warned by a "someone senior in the police" that the company was liable to be raided and charged with possession of a prohibited publication. The President's ban of edition 401 of The Post covered "all forms" of the paper, says Bennet.

Visit The Post's WWW site (http://www.zamnet.zm) and you will find the February 5 edition listed in the paper's archive of back editions, but click on the edition and the file will not open. However, following editions of the paper - containing stories about the banning, the police raid on The Post's offices, and subsequent arrest and charging of Editor-in-Chief Fred M'membe, Managing Editor Bright Mwape and Special Projects Editor Matsautso Phiri with contravening the State Security Act - can be read. The State Security Act charges relate to a report published in the February 5 edition of The Post revealing the government's plans to hold a referendum on the adoption of a new constitution.

A recent addition to the Zamnet WWW site is "Zambia Today" - stories from the state-run news agency ZANA, which are up-dated every couple of hours. "State House was very keen that the world didn't see The Post newspaper alone," said Bennet. "We kept telling them that we were going to keep The Post, but that we were happy to put up a State House page, or a page for ZANA. We are trying to actively encourage them to be positive."

Bennet stresses Zamnet was an independent company and would not succumb to self-censorship as a result of political pressure. Zamnet is housed at the University of Zambia, which has a 52 per cent share holding in the company. Although funded by the government, the University enjoys academic autonomy, says Bennet, "so there is no possibility of pressure (being exerted on Zamnet) through the University".

M'membe, Mwape and Phiri are due to appear in the High Court today to hear whether or not their bail - granted last week Wednesday (February 7) after initially being turned down by a magistrate - can be reviewed. If the court decides their bail can be reviewed, the three stand a chance of returning to jail to await trail on the charges of contravening Section 4 of the State Security Act, which prohibits the publication of classified information. If convicted, the journalists could be jailed for up to 25 years.

However, speaking on Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) news this morning (February 16), Mwape said he was not deterred by the prospect of a lengthy term in jail if convicted. "It is about time such a challenge was made," said Mwape. "The freedom we are talking about will only come if we are prepared to make sacrifices for it."

For futher information, contact Fernando Lima, P O Box 4484, Maputo phone: 258-1 742291. Fax: 490872. E-mail: lima@medcoop.uem.mz


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


201 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Business Foreign Companies Eye Zambian Complex


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 19, 1996 by Jeff Kepembwa


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - Five foreign companies have shown interest in turning the "'new' United National Independence Party (UNIP) headquarters" into a hotel and work is expected to commence before the year ends, sources in the tourism ministry disclosed to The Post on Friday.

Albion of India, AITA and three other USA companies are said to have indicated their willingness to invest in the 10-storey building after a meeting with tourism minister Gabriel Maka in London last month.

"Officials of these companies will arrive in the country next month to conduct feasibility studies," the source said. 

The source said more than K3 billion to transform the structure, which was initially designed for office accommodation, into a hotel.

And the Sheraton group of hotels of USA, who had conducted feasibility studies in February, last year seem to have lost interest in the project, forcing the government to look elsewhere.

"We have asked the prospective investors to come and assess the structure and tender after conducting feasibility studies," the source said. "We will pick the one with enough capital to run it."

But the Hotels Catering Association of Zambia (HCAZ) and the Tour Operators Association doubt the feasibility of the project.

"The government should sell the structure and plough the money into tourism because it is not ideal for a hotel," HCAZ chairman Gaudenzio Rossi said in an interview on Tuesday. "It will be costly to transform the project than it did to build it because it is lacking several facilities."

Rossi added: "The government has been saying they have talked to this one and that one but nothing is materialising. Why should we pretend?"

And Tour Operators Association chairman Mark Harvey also insisted the project will not make financial sense.

"The building should be sold and utilised for office accommodation as no hotel firm will have the financial capacity to make the venture a reality," Harvey said in an interview last week. "We totally agree with Rossi that government should sell the building and the money should go into tourism which has been given a paltry K8.9billion in this year's budget."

Zambia Sports Experts Arrive


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 19, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Lusaka - A team of sports experts have arrived in the country from the Netherlands to help in the development of soccer, parliament heard last week Friday. 

Sports minister, Patrick Kafumukache told parliament when he was winding up debate on his ministry's estimates of expenditure that the team has already started work.

"The team will develop soccer from the grassroot level," Kafumukache said, adding that the team will also assist in funding.

Meanwhile Kafumukache revealed to parliament that government is probing the performance of the Zambia National Soccer Team in South Africa.

"A committee to investigate our performance has been set up and a report will be made public soon so that we know what happened," Kafumukache said.

203 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Political Parties Now Just Toothless Bulldogs


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 19, 1996 by Chibembe Nyalungwe (Column)


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Lusaka - Political parties are proving more and more to be toothless bulldogs. Their role and relevance to society, particularly the disadvantaged is diminishing with alacrity.

In the plural party political era we are in, it is numbers that count. Our opposition leaders may stand before cameras and smile, issue press statements, protest and demand, until the cows come home, but if there are no numbers to back their stands, they are toothless. With the current apathy towards politics, it is obviously quite difficult to mobilise support in sufficient numbers, to be taken seriously, however, this must be the main thrust of opposition parties, if they are to be of relevance. 

Lest I be mistaken, I am not merely referring to the need to mobilise numbers towards a general election, but towards influencing parliamentary, government and civic decisions between elections. I am referring to an activity that I may term (innocently ) a "flexing of muscles" or a "show down of strength". It is a tactic that would be used much in the same way that China conducts military manouvres off the coast of Taiwan!! Whilst it is not very neighbourly of China, it certainly keeps Taiwan and the Americans on their toes, and would similarly be ideal for keeping government on its toes. The press, lobby groups, and other interested parties use the same tactic, in opinion polls. It tells decision makers what sort of support or opposition a particular decision will have, and is a very powerful tool in swaying the thinking of politicians particularly.

The recent banning of Post newspaper edition 401 is fertile ground for opposition parties to prove their worth, by standing by to defend those upon whom the full might of the State machinery is unjustly turned. When the Post edition was banned, some of its staff detained, and a ridiculous decision made threatening anyone found with a copy, with arrest, all parties should have rallied round.( not by unleashing Sebastian Zulu on unsuspecting and unwilling clients). Party cadres and leaders should have been offering K2,000.00 for every copy of that edition they could lay their hands on, also making photocopies, and sticking them on their cars, backs and other available spaces, to show solidarity. Can you imagine 10, 000 assorted party cadres and citizens (we would all join of course) pitching up with these papers and photocopies, at Central police station and other police stations countrywide, demanding to be arrested as law abiding citizens, in accordance with the decree from the Fuhrer. Aubenschweir Francis Ndhlovu SS would have a fit.

What has happened to the zeal and enthusiasm with which KK and his compatriots marched into prisons, jails and police stations, in defiance of unjust and discriminatory laws. Why didn't he lead UNIP to the police stations, in Lusaka, Copperbelt, Livingstone, Mongu, etc waving copies of the banned edition. What of Humphrey Mulemba and Aka, where is the manifestation of their support?

Dean Mungomba could have posed for another full page pin up, this time with the Post 401 in hand! Dean may have been in diapers when KK was doing the rounds of jails in the 60s, but he could make use of Hazwell Banda who should be well versed with the art of mobilising "monks from the ruins", and should have done so in ZADECO!!

It may sound as though I am promoting anarchy, far from it, I am a true believer in and law order and justice, and honestly, who could describe an assembly of thousands of Zambian citizens at police stations, silently holding copies of The Post 401 as anarchy?

I must however admit that when ridiculous decrees are made to suppress the rights of people, aiding government and its wings to change roles from protector of the oppressed to suppressor of the people, such decrees should not have support of any segment of society, and such lack of support should be evident. The act of banning the Post edition 401, was one of political cowardice, gross abuse of office. Discussions pertaining to the constitution, and its mode adoption, cannot at any stage of discussion, and in the wildest of dreams be considered a national secret. If cabinet wants to establish who is leaking the secrets, they should do it in the professional way, by instituting quiet and high skilled investigations.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Bank Explains Kwacha Decline


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 19, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The depreciation of the kwacha will soon be halted as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and other donors honour their pledges to Zambia, Bank of Zambia assured on Friday.

Explaining the poor performance of the kwacha, in response to a Post query, Bank of Zambia spokesman, Kabinga Pande, attributed the decline to high demand for foreign currency as a result of the new tax incentives in this year's budget and seasonal influences.

"The exchange rate is determined by the financial markets based on the demand for foreign exchange," Pande said in a statement on Friday. "If demand outstrips supply there is pressure on the exchange rates to depreciate." 

And according to Bank of Zambia, the tax incentives provided in this year's budget encouraged imports and consequently raised the demand for foreign currencies.

"Incentives in the budget can also have an impact on the demand for foreign exchange," Pande said, "particularly any measures taken to lower trade taxes and encourage growth."

Bank of Zambia, however, noted that this has has become an annual trend. There is always a rise in the demand for foreign currencies towards the close, and the earlier quarters of every year, as companies restock after the festive season. And it is also during this period that most companies remit dividends.

And manager of Lusaka's Delta Bureau de Change, Adrian Banda, in an interview on Friday said: "There is very high demand and the dollar is hard to come by. We don't have a stable rate.We have experienced rates going up by K5- K6 almost everyday in the last two weeks.The rates were stable at K965 from last year but they have risen to K1, 090."

Bella Jhaveri the manager of Prudence Bureau de Change had a similar story.

"The US dollar has become scarce and beginning February there has been a sharp rise in the exchange rates due to high demand against little dollars in circulation," Jhaveri said in an interview on Friday.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


205 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Journalists Urged To Unite


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 19, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - Journalists should not break up now because government still has intentions of creating a media council to license and regulate journalists, Press Association of Zambia President Francis Kasoma has pleaded.

Kasoma, whose association has been threatened with a split, said it would be folly for PAZA members to be divided at a time such as this.

"We have information that the government still intends to go ahead and create the media council and if that is done," Kasoma warned, " it will be the end of media freedom in Zambia." 

Copperbelt based journalists last week announced that they are organising a breakaway from PAZA unless Kasoma's "silent" executive calls an urgent extra-ordinary annual general meeting within two weeks.

The Copperbelt journalists steering committee of Mike Moono, Victor Kaira and Pius Katwishi has accused PAZA of being docile and unrepresentative.

"PAZA has been operating in isolation with an administration catering only for a small clique," Kaira charged in an interview last Friday. "If the AGM is not held in the next two weeks we shall consider breaking away."

But Kasoma warned that this would spell doom for all journalists in Zambia.

"We as PAZA have already taken the Chiluba government to court over the creation of a media council and if we start quarreling they will think we are not able to manage our affairs," Kasoma said. "There is no way the government can force an organisation on us."

Kasoma said he would be travelling to the Copperbelt this week to meet the Moono group and discuss their concerns.

"I agree with them on the holding of the AGM in a neutral place but I want to meet them to discuss the logistical problems of holding the AGM outside a town where most of the executive members live," Kasoma said.

But Kaira maintained nothing short of calling an AGM to choose new office bearers will be acceptable.

"As per our ultimatum, two weeks is ample time to organise a meeting and if they think they are still popular enough then they will go through in the elections," Kaira said.

There are up to 30 PAZA journalists on the Copperbelt alone.

The Post and its staff last year withdrew its membership of PAZA claiming the association was almost 99 per cent dominated by government media journalists whose interests and concerns were, in most cases, very different from those of the independent media.

"The divide between us and journalists working for the government is clear to all. They are not targets of the authorities as they can easily deal with them administratively," Post editor for special projects Masautso Phiri said in an interview yesterday, adding: "There are instances when the government has unleashed its journalists on us, to discredit us and our work in defence of State House lies. How can we be members of the same organisation?"


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Business and Finance Bank Governor: Zambian Economy On Right Track


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 19, 1996 by Mabeni Sikalyabwanda


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambian economy is on track even though a few problems were being experienced, assured central bank governor, Jacob Mwanza in Livingstone on Saturday.

Mwanza disclosed in an interview that there was a lot of suspicion from both local and foreign investors at the performance of Zambian economy after the collapse of several banks. 

"The closure of the banks was a normal practice and an indicator that such banks had bad shareholders and managers," Mwanza said."Only genuine and well managed banks would remain in the end."

The Bank of Zambia governor maintained the failure of these banks should blamed on their managers.

"Banks went down due to people managing them with ultra motives," Mwanza charged. "They did not have the interests of the depositors hence no one should blame the tough economical stand the government has taken."

Mwanza, who is in Livingstone accompanying an IMF delegation led by E. Calamitsis who is IMF director of the African department, said: "More investors have instead shown interest in investing in Zambia even after learning that banks were collapsing which was an indicator that the economy was doing fine."

And Calamitsis, in an earlier interview in Livingstone on Saturday, said the Zambian economy was doing fine even though the government has an uphill battle to convince people that what it was doing was the right thing. "As an African, I know that it was difficult for poor countries like Zambia to claim to have a good economy and expect people to believe when the grassroots were suffering," Calamitsis said.

LANGUAGE: English

207 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Speaker Lays Charges Against Post


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 21, 1996 by Goodson Machone


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - Speaker of the National Assembly, Robinson Nabulyato, yesterday established a prima facie case against two Post journalists and a columnist for contempt of parliament.

Nabulyato, who made the ruling after Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda raised a point of order on January 30, 1995 on three articles written by Post editor-in-chief Fred M'membe, managing editor Bright Mwape and columnist Lucy Sichone, has refered the matter to the standing committee of the house for further consideration.

The three articles referred to are "What Will Replacing Public Order Act Mean" by Fred M'membe and "Miyanda Has Forgotten About Need For Justice" by Lucy Sichone which appeared on January 29, 1996 and "Miyanda Missed Point Over Writer's Article" by Bright Mwape which appeared on February 1, 1996. 

Vice-President Miyanda complained that the articles would, in the long run, intimidate members of parliament and make them afraid to debate in the house.

"To avoid a situation of the Arab and the camel where slowly this house will be brought into ridicule, is it in order for this paper and the three authors to present the matter in the way they did, particularly that they were not accurate and they were one sided?" Miyanda asked the Speaker.

Before making the ruling, Nabulyato outlined the powers and privileges enjoyed by members of parliament and described what contempt is and what constitutes breach of parliamentary privileges.

He said that it was clear from the provision of the National Assembly ( Powers and Privileges ) Act Cap 17 of the laws of Zambia, especially section 3, 23 and 25 that the authors of the three articles not only committed a breach of parliamentary privileges but also committed an offence.

"The articles were manifestly contemptuous of not only his honour the Vice- President, the Speaker and the honourable deputy minister of energy, but also libellous against their person and the house," Nabulyato ruled.

He singled out M'membe for stating that "our peoples parliament is an imitation, including the Speakers robe and the constitution of Zambia".

"These remarks were highly injurious to the house. They were deliberately calculated insults against members of parliament and meant to put the house into odium, contempt and ridicule," Nabulyato said.

Nabulyato added that as Speaker, he had the duty to protect the house and its members "from wanton and calculated attacks".

"Having found a prima facie case against the three, I am refering the cases to the standing orders committee for their further consideration," Nabulyato said.

The offence carries a fine not exceeding K1,000 or twelve months imprisonment with or without hard labour or both.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Livingstone Baboons On Rampage


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 19, 1996 by Mabeni Sikalyabwanda


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Starving baboons have taken over the affairs of Livingstone immigration and customs officials at the Victoria Falls border where they walk at will into the offices, grab anything they want and majestically walk out.

Both Immigrations and Zambia Revenue Authority officials have said they are tired of informing the National Parks management about the baboons which have resorted to fighting back when one tries to stop them. 

Livingstone honorary wildlife scout, Benjamin Mibenge (not former UNIP secretary general), blamed officials of the two departments for having encroached on the baboons, territory around the Falls.

"What would you do if someone invades you in your house?" Mibenge asked in an interview on Saturday. "People provoked them into behaving the way they are doing and no one will move them out from the area."

But an immigration officer threatened to shoot the baboons if National Parks failed to find a solution to the new border problem.

A Post visit at the border disclosed that huge male baboons were more interested in harassing women cross-border traders with food items while leaving the male traders.

The baboons have literally pumped fear into foreign tourists whom they harass, snatch cameras and handbags from while armed police officers look on helplessly as they can't shoot them without the authority of National Parks. This has forced members of the Livingstone Tourism Association to ask for government protection for foreign tourists from both Zambian petty thieves and baboons.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Soccer Star Turns Agent


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 21, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - National soccer team skipper Kalusha Bwalya has ventured into the export market and has ganged up with five others to set up a company that will act as agents in exporting Zambian players to overseas leagues.

His local partner in Zambezi Sports Promotions, Andre Mtine confirmed that the company was formed in December last year in England and would soon start exporting Zambian players to pursue professional soccer.

"We registered the company in December last year and though we were supposed to have started exporting players by now we decided to wait because the season in Europe is coming to an end, but we will start as soon as possible" confirmed Mtine in a telephone interview from his Ndola base yesterday. 

Mtine, whose father Tom once served as Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) chairman, named the other partners in the company as two Zambians based in England, Joe Kasolo and his brother , and a British lawyer Howard Datin, whose services the firm is using for approval from FIFA.

"We don't need a licence as such because we have a solicitor and according to the latest FIFA rules, you don't need to pay any money once you have a solicitor. We are acting legally and I only hope things will be fine as we go on," said Mtine, disclosing that John Fashanu was also consultant.

"He is going to be helping us where we need help as he is a consultant. We want to get as many players as possible in the European leagues,"said Mtine.

A new FIFA circular number 571, dated December 4, 1995, regulating players' agents, states a solictator does not need to pay any money . In the past, agents were required to pay $200,000 to get FIFA a licence.

Among the markets Zambezi Sports Promotions has gone to are Holland, England, France, Saudi Arabia and Italy.

Meanwhile, Mtine, chairman of Ndola Wanderers, a northern zone first division side, has hinted that he may not contest the coming FAZ elections.

"I may contest if they will allow me to remain an official at Ndola Wanderers ," said Mtine.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996

210 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia President Accused Of Blackmail


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 21, 1996 by Bright Mwape and Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Lusaka - President Chiluba is using state security information for political blackmail of government leaders threatening to abandon him, a former minister has claimed.

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) secretary general and former deputy minister in the Office of the President, Derrick Chitala, charged in Lusaka yesterday that it was shameful to have a President who only sees 'evil' when a person differs with him fundamentally.

"It is a shame that whoever differs with President Chiluba, he takes it personally and either attacks them through their business or cooks up charges against them," Chitala said in an interview yesterday.

Chitala was reacting to the questioning by police of former commerce, trade and industry minister Dipak Patel, who resigned from government last Friday, on charges of illegal dealing in scrap metals, which charges have now been backdated to December 1987. 

Foundation for Democratic Process (FODEP) secretary Bishop John Mambo said the position of his organisation on the Constitution had not changed and expressed worry at the action of the state against the former commerce minister.

"We are concerned with what is happening," Mambo said. "If a citizen asks, we will approach the government and assist."

Police recorded a warn and caution statement from Patel on Monday on metal dealings of a company, Alloy Metal Products Limited, on whose board he once sat.

Both his brother, Shirish, and senior investigations officers involved in the matter have since disputed the professional wisdom of raising the matter against Patel when police investigations failed to establish anything and the case was closed last year.

Police last year made a futile search of Alloy Metal Products in a bid to find something against Patel's brother Shirish.

But Chitala charged that the matter has been raised in Chiluba's 'typical' "let me fix him" style.

"It is a sick way of conducting politics. The same thing has happened to other leaders that have resigned like Chuulu Kalima. A lot of those remaining now cannot leave because Chiluba has blackmailed them. They don't know what he may release on them. But they should be able to if they are clean enough, it is just that they are spineless. Its dirty," Chitala said.

A Cabinet source said in Lusaka yesterday that Patel's resignation was the climax of two weeks of tension over the Constitution and described the charges on Patel as a case of "sour grapes".

"The height of the issue was the Monday The Post published the banned story on the referendum. Cabinet and MMD's national executive committee members were scheduled to discuss the matter the same day but were shocked by the story in The Post that morning. The President was extremely disturbed about it but the mistake was that he allowed the meeting to proceed," the source said.

At the meeting Patel expressed reservations about the political approach to adopting the Constitution. He felt the people were supreme and should adopt all controversial issues.

When queried in Lusaka on Tuesday Patel maintained that whatever else was being clouded on his resignation would not take away the fact that he is principally opposed to the President's approach on the Constitution.

"I would rather have the people say they want a Zambian born of black parents or whatever to lead them at whatever level, than a cabinet or parliament of a few MMD men passing that in the Constitution. On principle, I can not accept that," Patel said. "There are issues government can mess up, but for goodness sake not a Constitution."

When pressed to discuss the major differences between him and Chiluba Patel declined saying he for now wants to hold his pledge not to be confrontational with the President.

And Zambia Civic Education Association lawyer, Christine Kunda, said it was a strange coincidence that the state has found a case on Patel at the same time as his resignation.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


211 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Ebola Haemorrhagic Fever Diagnosis Confirmed in Gabon


BYLINE: World Health Organization February 19, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Geneva - Scientists working on specimens from nine of the youths hospitalized in Makokou, the provincial capital of Ogooue-Ivindo in Gabon, have confirmed the initial diagnosis of the Ebola haemorrhagic fever by isolation of the Ebola virus. This was done at the Centre International de Recherches Médicales de Franceville in Gabon and at the WHO Collaborating Centre in the Institute Pasteur in Paris. Both the Ministry of Health of Gabon and WHO have been officially informed.

As of today, there are 20 cases and 7 suspect cases of Ebola haemorrhagic fever in Gabon. Thirteen of the cases have died. 

All 20 cases come from Mayibout II, an isolated village with some 150 inhabitants which is situated some 400 kilometers east of the capital city, Libreville. Twelve of the dead have been confirmed to have had direct contact with the blood of a dead chimpanzee. The thirteenth, most recent death was a six-month old child of one of the original 19 cases. Another child of the same parent has developed fever and has been hospitalized in Makokou.

Of those 19 cases originally admitted in the Makokou provincial hospital on 5 and 6 February with symptoms of high fever, bloody diarrhoea and severely reddened eyes, 9 patients have died in the hospital and 3 back in their home village of Mayibout II. The average age of the patients was 18 years.

No cases of Ebola among the health personnel of the hospital have been registered, though some may have been exposed to the virus and could be infected.

The international team of medical experts with members from the Gabonese Ministry of Health, La Cooperation Francaise (the French Bilateral Aid Agency), the Centre International de Recherches Medicales de Franceville (Gabon), the Institute Pasteur (Paris) and the World Health Organization (WHO) arrived in Mayibout II on Friday night, 16 February, after a nine-hour river trip by motorized pirogues.

The team is investigating all possible contacts of the patients, as well as rumours of illness in two neighboring villages: Mayibout I and Mvadi, a village of 800 inhabitants 10 kilometers from Mayibout II. Persons who accompanied the patients to the hospital in Makokou and who returned with the dead bodies to bury them are known to live in these two villages.

In Mayibout II, the international team has identified, isolated and put under close surveillance 6 persons with symptoms which could be early Ebola infection. A small field laboratory is being established in the village to test blood specimens from the local population suspected to have the infection.

In the Mayibout bush, a number of dead animals have been found: one chimpanzee, one wild cat, one antelope and two gorillas. A team of the Gabonese government is ensuring surveillance of the animal life in the affected area.

In Makokou, part of the international team is searching for 10 additional persons who accompanied patients from Mayibout II to the provincial hospital. This team is also searching for any persons with symptoms which could be early Ebola infection.

At the request of the Gabonese government, La Cooperation Française has sent to Gabon the necessary protection material, transport means and drugs. The logistics system of the French military in Gabon was also put as the disposal of the Gabonese Ministry of Health.

"For the time being, WHO does not recommend any travel restrictions to or within Gabon. If proper isolation of all persons with suspected early Ebola infection is ensured, there is no need for quarantine measures. The early action taken by the Gabonese Ministry of Health was prompt and effective. With the precautions taken, and investigation of the outbreak and sensitization campaigns of the population in the affected area under way, it is hoped that the spread of the epidemic will be minimized", concludes WHO's Division in Geneva dealing with new and reemerging diseases.

The outbreak in Gabon is the second recent outbreak of Ebola haemorrhagic fever in Africa. In May 1995, the disease struck in Zaire infecting 316 and killing 245 people, a 77% case-fatality rate. There was also one single case of Ebola in Cote d'Ivoire last December. The patient survived.

The Ebola virus is transmitted by direct contact with blood secretions or body fluids from infected person. The symptoms of the disease include the sudden onset of fever, followed by vomiting, diarrhoea and massive bleeding. The incubation period is between 2 and 21 days. No specific treatment or vaccine against the Ebola haemorrhagic fever exist.

For further information, please contact the office of Health Communications and Public Relations, WHO, Geneva, Tel. (4122) 791.3223/3221/2532/2543, or Fax (4122) 791.48.58.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


212 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


United States and Africa Lobby Group Calls for Landmines Ban


BYLINE: American Committee on Africa February 21, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

New York - Text of statement by American Committee on Africa calling for action In support on a total ban on landmines.

Numerous human rights groups are working together to promote a comprehensive ban by the United States on the use, production, stockpiling and export of antipersonnel landmines. An estimated 100 million landmines have been laid in more than 60 countries. About one third of these landmines are in Africa. These landmines kill or injure 26,000 people each year. 

Archbishop Desmond Tutu has called on the international community to unequivocally condemn landmines which he noted are "excessively cruel, cause horrific injuries, and - even after the cessation of hostilities - target unarmed civilians indiscriminately."

LEAHY-EVANS AMENDMENT: In January 1996 President Clinton signed legislation, introduced by Senator Patrick Leahy and Representative Lane Evans, which imposes a one year moratorium on the use of antipersonnel landmines by U.S. forces except along international boundaries and demilitarized zones. This provision takes effect in 1999. The bill also extends the current moratorium on U.S. landmine exports for one year, through 1997.

INTERNATIONAL: In his address to the United Nations on September 1994, President Clinton called for the eventual elimination of antipersonnel landmines. However, since that time the U.S. has not taken any steps to secure agreement on such a ban.

Internationally, 22 countries, including most recently Canada, have banned the use, production and export of antipersonnel landmines. However, the U.S. has not adopted these measures, and has not argued for a comprehensive ban in the negotiation on the Convention on Conventional Weapons. The concluding session for these negotiations is scheduled for April 22 through May 3. These negotiations are the logical place for the U.S. to push for the elimination on antipersonnel landmines. The Clinton administration, while favoring some restrictions, has not pushed for an outright ban on antipersonnel landmines. Rather, the U.S. has proposed that antipersonnel landmines should be made to "self-destruct" after a period of time.

LANDMINE CLEARANCE: In Angola alone there are an estimated 9-15 million landmines. Other countries where there is a significant landmine threat include Mozambique and Somalia. However, even some countries that have been at peace for many years, including Namibia and Zimbabwe, have areas where landmines still need to be cleared.

ACTION NEEDED: Write President Clinton and your congressional delegation and urge that the U.S. join other countries and adopt a comprehensive ban on antipersonnel landmines. Further, in the re-negotiation of the Convention on Conventional Weapons the U.S. should strongly support a comprehensive ban on landmines including use, production, stockpiling and export.

For more information contact the American Committee on Africa.

Please send us copies of your letters.

The American Committee on Africa, 17 John Street, New York, NY 10038 tel: (212) 962-1210.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

February, 1996


United States and Africa American Media Group Condemns Attack on Nigerian Publisher


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists February 21, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

New York - Letter to His Excellency General Sani Abacha, president and commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces, from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists, February 15, 1996.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) is writing to condemn the attempted murder of Alex Ibru, publisher of the Guardian Group and a former Internal Affairs Minister in your government.

Ibru was shot at point blank range in his car as he traveled from his Lagos office late on Friday, February 2, 1996. Ibru received several injuries including bullet wounds to the left side of his head and to his leg. On Sunday, February 4, 1996 after initial treatment at a Lagos hospital, Ibru was flown to a London hospital for treatment and underwent a six-and-a-half hour operation. Police have called the attempted murder of Ibru a foiled armed robbery and arrested nine men in connection with the heinous crime. However, we note with concern that nothing was stolen from Ibru's car or from his person. 

We are deeply alarmed at the increasing incidence of assaults, intimidation and repression directed against the independent media. "The Guardian" was allowed to resume publication in July 1995 after your government lifted a year-long ban on it. In December 1995, an arson attack on "The Guardian"'s editorial office gutted a section of the building. We wrote to Your Excellency previously on several occasions urging you to lift the ban on "The Guardian" and condemning the arson attack.

We now urge Your Excellency to initiate a thorough investigation of this crime to bring the culprits to justice. Furthermore, we call on you to ensure the freedom and protection of journalists in your country.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Please direct questions to Kakuna Kerina, Program Coordinator for Africa, (212) 465-1004, ext. 103, or Azeen Salimi, Research Associate, ext. 118.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


United States and Africa American Media Group Protests Ghanaian Arrests


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists February 21, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

New York - Letter to His Excellency Jerry John Rawlings, president of the Republic of Ghana, from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists, February 15, 1996.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) protests in the strongest terms the detention of Nana Kofi Coomson, editor in chief of the "Ghanaian Chronicle," Ebeneezer Quarcoo, editor of the "Free Press," and Tommy Thompson, publisher of the "Free Press," who were remanded into custody on February 14.

On February 9, police arrested and questioned Coomson, and later released him on bail of 10 million cedis (US$6,700). Quarcoo and Thompson were away from their offices when they were summoned to police headquarters for questioning the same day. They reported to police headquarters February 12 and were also released on bail of 10 million cedis each after interrogation. 

On February 14, Circuit Court Judge Nuhu Bila revoked the bail_without explanation_and the three were immediately remanded into custody until February 22, when their case will be heard. Counsel for the three journalists has filed an appeal with the High Court.

Coomson, Quarcoo and Thompson were charged with "publishing false news with the intent of injuring the reputation of the State," a violation of Section 185 of the Criminal Code of 1960, an ordinance of the colonial era. If convicted, they could face a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison.

The "Free Press" and the "Ghanaian Chronicle" reprinted in their January 31 and February 1 editions, respectively, a story published in the New York-based bi-weekly "The African Observer" reporting that Ghanaian diplomat Frank Benneh, of the Ghanaian Permanent Mission to the United Nations in Geneva, had been arrested in Switzerland for selling drugs. The article also alleged that Your Excellency's government has used proceeds from illegal drug sales to buy arms.

As a non-partisan group of journalists dedicated to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ contends that Kofi Coomson, Eben Quarcoo and Tommy Thompson have been jailed for exercising their right to practice their profession. We also believe that Section 185, under which those journalists have been charged, contravenes the right to free expression, guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights; Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights; the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press, all to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Ghana is a signatory.

CPJ urges Your Excellency to ensure the immediate and unconditional release of Coomson, Quarcoo and Thompson. Furthermore, we urge Your Excellency to revoke Section 185 of Criminal Code as an assurance that the independent press in Ghana may work freely.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Please direct questions to Kakuna Kerina, Program Coordinator for Africa, (212) 465-1004, ext. 103, or Azeen Salimi, Research Associate, ext. 118, 330 Seventh Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, New York 10001 USA.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
