Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large World Bank Supports African Poverty Reduction Network


BYLINE: The World Bank February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Washington, D.C. - The World Bank is supporting the initiative to establish the African Poverty Reduction Network. The Vice President of the Africa Region, Mr. Edward V.K. Jaycox, said today he strongly supported the work of the Network, created in Oslo, Norway in January 1995, with assistance from the Norwegian, Dutch, Japanese and Canadian governments. 

The Network group was initially brought together by the Africa Region of the Bank to obtain an African input into the preparation of the report of a task force on Taking Action or Poverty Reduction in Africa. It is made up of distinguished Africans from government, non-governmental organization, academia and the private sector. Network members are expected to bring a new perspective to the search for ways of effectively reducing poverty in Africa.

The second meeting of the Network was held in Washington D.C. in December last year to review the Bank s analysis of actions required to reduce poverty in Sub-Saharan Africa, and to define the scope of its work. It was agreed that the Network would:

* serve as an advocacy group with governments, donors, an civil society to draw attention to the urgency of the need to effectively reduce poverty;

* promote the participation of the poor and relevant grassroots organizations and other stockholders in programs and discussions aimed at poverty reduction;

* act as a think-tank to identify and find solutions to the challenges of poverty reduction, and develop prototype activities;

* review analytical work and strengthen the system of poverty monitoring.

It is anticipated that a number of donors will support this initiative intended to harness African intellectual input into the poverty reduction endeavor.

The interim Vice Chairwoman of the Network, Ms. Pauline Biyong of Cameroon, will be in Washington soon to initiate arrangements for the establishment of a small Network Secretariat.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


216 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Ministers And Bank President Agree On Capacity Building


BYLINE: The World Bank February 20, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Washington, D.C. - Finance Ministers from Burkina Faso, Gabon, Kenya and Uganda met today with the President of the World Bank, Mr. James D. Wolfensohn. Led by Mr. Doupamby-Matoka of Gabon, the Ministers had been delegated by their counterparts across Africa to discuss an action program for building Africa s human and institutional capacity.

Capacity refers to trained and experienced personnel in both the pubic and private sectors, as well as to the institutions in which they work. A lack of skilled professionals, coupled with poor design and management of institutions is widely recognized as a key barrier to economic growth in Africa. The Ministers agreed that "Capacity . . . allows people to achieve the objectives they set for themselves." 

Lacking human and institutional capacity, countries must rely on foreign expertise and resources to perform the elemental tasks of development.

Recognizing that past attempts to solve these problems have met with little success, the African Finance Ministers broached the subject with Mr. Wolfensohn at the World Bank s Annual Meeting last October, and he asked his staff to work together with the Ministers to develop proposals for effective action to build Africa s capacity. In collaboration with the Bank s African Executive Directors, and after extensive consultations with African authorities and experts on capacity building, government officials, business people, academicians, non-governmental organizations and others, the group agreed on a set of principals:

First, the focus of capacity building efforts must be the national level. Donors can no longer simply devise solutions on their behalf; Africans must feel they own the process and must grasp the initiative in building capacity.

Second, donors must incorporate the principle of Africa ownership within their programs for capacity building. They should approach technical assistance issues so as to increase local participation in planning and implementing development projects.

Third, a strategic approach needs to be devised that addresses the chronic problems that underlie the capacity problem in Africa, such as building strategic human skills, transforming government, strengthening the private sector, and enhancing the self-sufficiency of local communities.

The President agreed with an action program proposed by the Ministers. This includes a set of sub-regional meetings in Africa to build consensus on capacity building goals and approaches. National-level capacity assessments, which will serve as the basis for planning coordinated strategies, will be carried out in a sampling of African countries by local consultants. In addition, a team composed of African experts and World Bank staff will study the impact of the Bank s operational practices on capacity in Africa, and it will identify best practices for capacity building from around the world.

Based on the results of these meetings and assessments, the African Ministers will meet again with Mr. Wolfensohn to discuss a detailed plan of action. The Finance Ministers and Mr. Wolfensohn also discussed possible improvements in areas of critical importance to building Africa s capacity, including education and information technology.

They agreed on the need for increased utilization of local African professionals, ad for addressing political and administrative obstacles to the smooth functioning of institutions.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


217 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


United States and Africa Reporters' Group Protests Zambian Editors' Arrests


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists February 14, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

New York - Letter dated February 6, 1996, to His Excellency Frederick Chiluba, President of Republic of Zambia, from William A. Orme, Jr., Executive Director, Committee to Protect Journalists.

Your Excellency,

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to condemn in the strongest terms the arrests of Fred M'membe, Masautso Phiri and Bright Mwape of "The Post," as well as the banning of the February 5 edition of the independent daily.

Managing director M'membe, editor-in-chief Phiri, and managing editor Mwape were arrested in the early morning hours of February 6, after 18 armed and plainclothes police officers conducted a search of the editorial offices of "The Post." These searches violated a law requiring that searches only be conducted during daylight hours. 

Police searched computer files and documents in the office for material relating to a February 5 article about a secret government plan to promulgate a controversial draft constitution in March. "The Post's February 5 edition was banned by presidential decree and declared a "prohibited publication" under Section 53 of the Penal Code. The decree warned the public that anyone found with a copy of the edition would be committing a criminal offense under the Prohibited Publications Act.

M'membe, Phiri and Mwape were charged with two counts of receiving information that is knowingly in contravention of the State Security Act and unlawful possession of a prohibited publication, namely the February 5 edition of "The Post." They now remain in the Woodlands Police Station, where they await a magistrate to hear their request for release on bail.

CPJ has documented with alarm the countless attacks against "The Post" since its founding in 1991. As a non-partisan group of journalists committed to the protection of our colleagues' rights worldwide, we are deeply troubled by this pattern of harassment. We believe that Section 53 has no place in a democratic society because it undermines the right to free expression, guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights; Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights; and the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press, all to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zambia is a signatory.

We strongly urge Your Excellency to drop the charges against the three editors, and to release them immediately and unconditionally. We also call on Your Excellency to ensure that attacks against the independent press cease, and that M'membe, CPJ's 1995 International Press Freedom Award winner, and all his colleagues can work freely.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

(The editors have since been granted bail and released.)

For further information, please contact Kakuna Kerina (x 103), Program Coordinator for Africa, or Azeen Salimi, Research Associate (x 118) at CPJ, 330 Seventh Ave, New York NY 10001, U.S.A., tel:+1 212 465 1004, fax:+1 212 465 9568, e-mail: africa@cpj.org,


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


218 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Department of Public Works Announces RDP Initiative


BYLINE: Africa News Service February 14, 1996


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Pretoria - Text of a Statement: Regionalising the RDP - Creating a Common Economic Community for the Construction and Allied Industries in Southern Africa, 12 February 1996

The Southern Africa Construction Industry Initiative is being held at Eskom Megawatt Park and the Development Bank of Southern Africa this week to consider and ratify protocols of co-operation between ten countries in the southern Africa sub-region and to investigate the main constraints which have hampered the development of the viable national construction capacity in each of the participating countries.

The goal is to formulate policy options which will encourage and advance local participation in the industry. This will improve the sector's performance and contribution to the economic development in each country and ultimately the region as a whole.

Hosted by the Department of Public Works (PWD) and the Council of Construction in South Africa (COCOSA) the conference is attended by 150 delegates including ministers, senior officials and private sector representatives from Angola, Botswana, Namibia, South Africa, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Mozambique, Malawi, Swaziland and Zambia. 

In a paper delivered at the conference, Deputy Director General of the Public Works Department, Sivi Gounden, proposed that the principles of the South African Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) be extended to include the neighbouring states.

"In other words," he said, "the construction industries of the African states would develop a set of operating and business practices to ensure that in the provision of construction goods, they also realise the more qualitative developmental objectives of the RDP."

These would then open the construction markets, level the playing fields for construction companies in different countries, standardise the procedures under which development projects will be funded, facilitate the movement of construction firms and personnel and contribute towards creating a more equitable process of development.

The RDP is not merely about the provision of houses, services and facilities, it requires the qualitative transformation of the industry so that certain basic objectives such as providing jobs, housing, telecommunications and transport, developing human resources and building the economy can be met. However, the main benefit of the RDP will come from the active participation of all sectors of the South African economy. Public sector funding is essential to kickstart the development process and to create the operating framework for construction work more generally.

The public sector has the leverage to introduce and promote new productions and business practices in the industry.

The PWD in conjunction with the departments of Trade and Industry, Labour, Education, Housing, State Expenditure, Transport, Water Affairs and the RDP Office, has launched an initiative to ensure that the objectives of the RDP and related initiatives by government are realised in the construction and allied industries. These interventions will comprehensively transform the construction economy in South Africa.

He cautioned that whilst the RDP will have a positive impact on South Africa, the economies of neighbouring states could suffer as a result. In the past, imbalances in the regional economy often meant that development for South Africa gave rise to the under-development of her regional partners.

Inequalities such as the skewed distribution of wealth and the resources to general wealth in the regional economies give rise to poverty, unemployment, social and physical debilitation, which eventually impact on South Africa. As a result of the increase in construction supply required by the RDP neighbouring countries might find their construction sectors depleted of appropriate skills as technical supervisory and managerial staff turn to South Africa for more attractive opportunities.

"Apart from being callous, such practices can only harm the South African economy in the long run," he said.

Mr Jeff Radebe, Minister of Public Works said that in the interests of all regional partners, extending the practices and benefits of the RDP beyond the borders of South Africa will bring about reconstruction and development for all.

"During the past two years, we have been working in close co- operation with COCOSA. It is important that neighbouring governments maintain regular contact with one representative industry umbrella body such as COCOSA. This will encourage problem solving and mutual understanding," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


219 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Cape Town - President Nelson Mandela's text.

Prime Minister Harlem Brundtland;

Minister Godal

Deputy President Mbeki;

Deputy President De Klerk;

Honourable Ministers;

Members of the Diplomatic Corps;

Distinguished Guests;

Ladies and gentlemen,

Our countries could scarcely be situated further apart, lying at almost opposite ends of the globe. Geography and history have bequeathed us only limited economic relations. But the bond between us could not be closer or warmer. 

It is therefore a special pleasure, now that we have achieved our freedom, to welcome you, Mme Brundtland, as the leader of a nation that elected to stand with us and make our cause their own, at a time when it was neither fashionable nor easy to do so. Indeed, we do know that this was not without cost. For that we thank you from the bottom of our hearts. Your support for sanctions, and your humanitarian and development aid have been of immense benefit in providing support and succour; in making educational opportunities possible; and in contributing to victory in struggle.

Above all we thank the Norwegian people for respecting the judgment of the oppressed in South Africa as to what kinds of struggle could achieve their liberation. This is the mark of a country which has had to struggle for its own independence and for the preservation of its own freedom.

Even after the advent of democracy, that respect for our judgment informs Norway's generous development assistance, In your support for our programmes for uplifting the quality of life of all our people, and for strengthening democracy and peace, you have again made our goals and priorities your own.

The quality of your caring was eloquent in your visit yesterday to Robben Island, and your gift to help ensure that the Island remains a living symbol of freedom, peace and reconciliation. It is consistent with the Norwegian people's recognition, through the Nobel Prize, of the contribution which the people of South Africa have made to world peace.

For us your visit is therefore an opportunity both to celebrate, and to re-affirm, the partnership between our countries, and to ensure that the bonds forged in struggle flourish in freedom.

The development of all round relations will be furthered by the agreements which we signed this morning.

We attach great importance to the development of economic relations between our countries, as a sound and lasting contribution to economic growth in South Africa. We appreciate in particular the fact that our exports to your country have been facilitated by Norway's extension to us of the Generalised System of Preferences. We are confident that this visit will allow your delegation and South African business to identify opportunities for further trade and investment.

South Africa is immensely proud of the achievements of its sports-people and grateful for the contribution they are making to uniting our nation. But sport also has the capacity to draw nations closer together. We are therefore pleased to see amongst your delegation the president of the Norwegian Confederation of Sports, and look forward to co-operation between our countries in sport and physical recreation.

Prime Minister; your own determination and courage in fighting for the rights of women and children is widely admired. Norway is in the world's vanguard in matters of gender equality and serves as an inspiring example. Our own government is committed to implementing the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, and the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, both of which it ratified last year.

We are committed too to joining with Norway in working for peace and stability, for development, prosperity and human rights everywhere. We therefore appreciate in particular the steps to co-operate in the fields of peace-keeping in Southern Africa and nuclear non-proliferation. We welcome the presence in your delegation of Foreign Minister Godal - this will help to cement bilateral relations and to take our co-operation in international affairs to a still higher level of partnership.

Ladies and gentlemen;

Allow me to propose a toast to His Majesty King Harald V and the people of Norway, and to the flourishing of friendship between our peoples. SKOL

(EMBARGO 19H15: CHECK AGAINST DELIVERY)

Issued by: Office of the President


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Government Unveils New Tourism Policy


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 15, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The government will soon adopt a new tourism policy for Zambia, parliament heard yesterday. Tourism minister, Gabriel Maka, told parliament that the final report on a new policy and attendant medium-term national tourism strategies and plans of action has been received and will soon be recommended to cabinet for approval.

Maka was responding to various contributions by members of parliament on the estimates of expenditure (including capital, constitutional and statutory expenditure) on the committee of supply for the tourism ministry. "As a result of the introduction of this new policy and strategy, new legislation is being developed which will harmonise and facilitate its implementation," Maka said. 

He said that the problems and impediments being experienced in the development of tourism in Zambia are a consequence of inadequate systems and structures and these will be addressed in the new policy.

Meanwhile, Maka also told parliament that the government intends to amend the National Parks and Wildlife Service Act of 1991 to introduce new wildlife legislation and strengthen enforcement provisions against wildlife crime.

He said that the new legislation will provide a new autonomous structure for the efficient management of the wildlife eco-system and foster the economic and social well-being of the local communities in game management areas.

He was responding to a complaint by Mfuwe MMD member of parliament Paul Lumbi who said that game management areas were not benefiting the local communities.

And, the Ministry of Tourism will in the near future start operating a steam safari on the Mulobezi railway line, parliament heard yesterday. "This follows the successful rehabilitation and delivery from Zimbabwe of the first class deluxe coach in December last year," Maka said.

He was responding to Lukulu West MMD member of parliament Simon Ngombo who wanted to know what measures the government had taken to diversify tourism. Maka also said Zambia has made a commitment to the United Nations to sign the Agreement on wildlife crime after meeting other UN members on the matter.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Prominent Group Lobbies For Debt Relief


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 15, 1996 by a Correspondent


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda and four other prominent African leaders spent last week touring Britain and Ireland addressing meetings on the debt crisis in Africa.

Kaunda, with Archbishop Khotso Makhulu, former SADCC chief executive Simba Makoni, former African Development Bank chief Prof Adebayo Adedeji and Prof Bade Onimode visited Manchester, Leeds, Leicester, Bristol, Edinburgh, Glasgow and London "where large numbers of people came to hear them".

"They were invited to Britain by the Debt Crisis Network, to alert European political opinion to the scale of the excruciating burden of external debt imposed on the people of Africa who are 'the poorest of the poor' of the world," a DCN press release says. 

According to DCN, the distinguished African leaders "met British and Irish ministers, representatives of the International Monetary Fund, including Michael Camdessus, the World Bank, the British Treasury and British businessmen with interests in Africa."

They also released a signed press statement yesterday describing the purpose of their visit.

"The aim of our visit has been to impress on British and European public opinion, the urgent necessity for debt cancellation for the most severely indebted least developed countries, if the appalling conditions of the African people are ever to be ameliorated," the statement reads in part.

Kaunda, who spoke at the "Africa Needs a Fresh Start" conference at Westminster on February 10 also travelled to Austria where "he met both the Austrian chancellor and the President and called for urgent debt cancellation for countries of Africa."

The former Zambian president also gave a Bruno Kreisky lecture on February 12.

DCN, which has a strong Christian involvement, embraces more than 40 organi- sations dedicated to "achieving drastic reductions in Third World debt".

DCN which has produced its own report on debt in sub Saharan Africa, includes several churches and related organisations such as Christian Aid, Council of Churches for Wales, United Reformed Church, Church Missionary Society, Baptist Union, Colombian Fathers and Methodist Division of Social Responsibility.

Other organisations include Action Aid, Abantu for Development, Debt and Development Coalition Ireland, Oxfam, World Action and World Development Movement.

222 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Israeli Firm's 'Deal" Invalid


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 15, 1996 by A Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Lusaka - The Nikuv contract for the updating of the voters' register is "invalid and unconstitutional and opens the electoral process to external manipulation and potential rigging".

These are among the claims contained in the affidavits filed in the High Court of Zambia by opposition UNIP and the Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) on February 7, this year in their suit against the Attorney General and the Vice-President of the Republic of Zambia over the Nikuv Computers (Israel) Limited contract.

"I have been advised by my advocates and I verily believe that the said contract is invalid as being contrary to the Constitution of Zambia and the Electoral Act," UNIP secretary-general Sebastian Zulu said, citing article 77(9) of the Zambian Constitution and section 14 of the 1991 Electoral Act.

UNIP and LPF are arguing that Nikuv is not entitled by law to conduct the actual registration of voters in Zambia. 

The two political parties allege that the Electoral Commission has abdicated its duties of registering and conducting elections and want the court to declare the government action as both illegal and unconstitutional.

"The exercise by the third respondent (Nikuv) of the statutory functions exercisable only by the Electoral Commission be declared null and void," UNIP and LPF have demanded.

In another affidavit sworn by Zulu, the two parties claim that the decision to have voters cards made in Israel was suspect.

"By reason therefore I verily believe that the process of the voters registration and election could be subject to manipulation and rigging on an unprecedented scale," Zulu claimed.

Zulu claimed both the Vice-President and the Electoral Commission admitted to this fact at a meeting they had at Cabinet Office on November 16, 1995.

At this meeting Vice-President Miyanda questioned the ability of Nikuv to distribute voters cards long after registering voters.

Zulu argues that like Vice-President Miyanda correctly observed, the Nikuv contract would disenfranchise a lot of Zambians.

"By the matters aforesaid I verily believe that the contract signed will disenfranchise a lot of people who would be unable to collect their voters cards form whatever centres after the third respondent (Nikuv) brought them in the country from Israel where they would be printed," claimed Zulu.

UNIP and LPF are also worried by the absence of a mechanism to issue duplicate cards to those who would be registered but lose their cards.

According to the affidavits the parties are uncomfortable about clause 30 of the Nikuv contract which says Nikuv will be independent and will neither consider itself an employee or agent of the Zambian government.

"By reason thereof I believe that the third respondent(Nikuv) would not be accountable not only to the Electoral Commission but also to the voters as a whole," Zulu says.

The suit is also challenging the classification by the government of the Nikuv contract as a "secret" when it was awarded by public tender.

"A further order that the current registration of voters being conducted in Zambia under the direction and supervision of the third respondent (Nikuv) be halted forthwith and that the said registration exercise be declared null and void as being contrary to the laws of Zambia," Zulu prayed to the court.

Zulu said he only learned of the award of the tender to Nikuv in the press and through an advertisement on September 22, last year by Ted Mulonga, an MMD cadre now director of the tender board, and claims he was "not aware whether the government had signed a contract" with Nikuv and on what terms.

"At the time the director of the tender board made his statement defending the board's decision to award the contract to Nikuv, I was still not aware of the terms of the contract until January 31, 1996 when I had first sight of the said contract," Zulu says.

The parties believe the terms of this public contract should have been made public. The contract has been filed along with the affidavit in the High Court.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large World Bank Appoints Two Vice Presidents For Africa


BYLINE: The World Bank (Washington) February 14, 1996


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Washington, D.C. - The World Bank's Africa Region will be headed by two new Vice Presidents, Mr. Callisto Madavo and Mr. Jean-Louis Sarbib.

They replace the departing Vice President, Mr. Edward V.K. Jaycox, who will retire on March 31 following a 31-year career with the World Bank.

Announcing the appointments, World Bank President, Mr. James D. Wolfensohn, said that the two were selected on th e basis of their demonstrated strengths as managers who have shown initiative and leadership, a concern for delivering services which meet client needs, an ability to engage their staff in developing a shared vision, and a strong sense for teamwork . He explained that the purpose of naming two Vice Presidents was to maintain close contact with African countries, while preserving an Africa-wide perspective on issues that cross country boundaries. 

A single office will support the two vice presidents. Madavo and Sarbib said that the major guiding principle is to maintain one Region, one vice presidential office, and one management team. They emphasized teamwork, supported by a single structure of support and advisory functions.

Madavo and Sarbib said that while the Africa Region will remain unitary, it is important for people outside the Bank and the Region (clients and partners) to have a clear picture of who their primary contact is at the vice presidential level. Country responsibilities will reflect geographic contiguity.

Mr. Madavo will have primary responsibility for Angola, Botswana, Burundi, Comoros, Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Rwanda, Seychelles, Somalia, South Africa, Sudan, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Mr. Sarbib will be responsible for Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Chad, Congo , Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Nigeria, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo.

The two Vice Presidents will also divide responsibility for the Africa-wide initiatives and fora where the Bank plays an important institutional role. Mr. Sarbib will take primary responsibility for the Capacity Building Initiative launched last October, the Global Coalition for Africa, and the Special Program for African Agricultural Research (SPAAR). Mr. Madavo will be responsible for the Special Program for Africa (SPA), the UN Initiative for Africa, and contact with African institutions (UN Economic Commission for Africa, African Development Bank, Organization for African Unity, etc.).

Mr. Madavo, a Zimbabwean national, is currently Country Director in the East Asia & Pacific Region of the World Bank. Joining the Bank as an economist in 1969, he has served in senior positions in the Transport and Urban Projects Department, the South Asia Country Programs Department, and within the Africa Region prior to assignment to his current position in 1991.

Mr. Sarbib, a French national, is currently Director for the Western Africa Department of the Africa Region of the World Bank. He joined the Bank in January 1980 as a Planning Advisory Officer, and held senior positions relating to Eastern, Central and Southern Africa prior his appointment as Division Chief for Country Operations in the Sahelian Department in 1990. He was appointed to his current position in 1994.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Editors' Bail Hearing Adjourned


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 14, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - High Court Judge David Lewanika yesterday adjourned the ruling in the case relating to the continued bail for the three Post editors who are charged with receiving classified information under the State Secrets Act to this Friday.

In a hearing yesterday to review the bail for Post editor-in-chief and managing director Fred M'membe, managing editor Bright Mwape and editor special projects Masautso Phiri, defence counsels for the trio raised a preliminary issue "as to whether or not the court had jurisdiction to review its own decision in a criminal matter".

The defence counsels argued that Order 39 rule 1 upon which the state was relying to make its application only applied to review of civil, and not criminal, charges. 

They went on to argue that even if Order 39 rule 1 applied to criminal matters the court could not review its decision as no new matters were brought up which were not raised and argued in the court below.

It was further argued that all the matters raised in the affidavit filed by the state did not warrant the reopening of the case. The defence went on to argue that there must be some finality to judgments and it did not matter if the state would not be able to appeal to the Supreme Court against the decision.

The state conceded that the Criminal Procedure Code did not provide for the review of criminal matters but they argued that the same code did not also prohibit the same.

State Advocates William Lewis and Linus Eyotia Eyaa argued that there was a need for the state to show that the decision by the Director of Public Prosecution to issue a certificate under Section 123 (4) of the Criminal Procedure Code certifying that it was likely that the interests of the Republic of Zambia would be prejudiced by the three editors being granted bail was not malafide but bonafide.

The court has set Friday, February 16 for ruling on the preliminary issue raised.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Business Zambian Finance Minister Welcomes Capital Fund


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 14, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - Finance minister Ronald Penza yesterday welcomed the launching of the Zambia Venture Capital Fund and described it as a necessary link to foster development of private investment in the country.

In an interview after the launch of the fund by President Chiluba, Penza assured the private sector of government's support. 

"We welcome the fund as it is a necessary link to enhance investment development in the private sector," Penza said. "We now have an instrument which will go a long way in the private sector development and I would encourage more Zambians to invest in the fund."

The fund has been set up by Commonwealth Development Corporation (CDC), the European Investment Bank, the German Investment and Development Company and First Merchant Bank of Zambia with an initial cash injection of US$2.5 million intended for private sector financing.

CDC's London based chairman, Lord Cairns, revealed that the fund had already received 200 applications from business houses although it had not yet started operations.

"There has been an overwhelming response from the local businesses as we have already received 200 applications even before starting operations," Lord Cairns said in an interview. " We are likely to start operations by the end of March under the chairmanship of David Phiri but we still have to set up the board before this is possible."

And President Chiluba expressed happiness at the diverse investment in the country and the bringing in of capital by external investors to supplement govern-ment's limited resources.

"What is most encouraging is that external investment is not restricted to one sector, there is a widespread investment embracing, agriculture, mining, tourism and now with the bold move of the venture capital fund, the financial sector," Chiluba said at the launch.

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Kaunda Immunity Divides Party


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 14, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Parliament will today debate a private motion by ruling party members aimed at removing former president Kenneth Kaunda's immunity.

Titled "Removal of legal immunity in respect of the former president", the motion quotes terms of article 43 (3) of the Republican Constitution but does not specify the criminal charge the former president will face after his immunity is removed. 

MMD members of parliament are said to be divided on the issue which some believe is a private agenda of a few and which others blame on the proposer of the motion, Mandevu MP Patrick Katyoka.

But other political observers believe the motion, which will be supported by Dundumwezi MP Myers Maingaila, is intended to test public reaction to the government's move.

However, speculation was rife by late last night that the motion would be withdrawn either before debate or on the floor because several senior MMD members were not amused by Katyoka's move.

"There are pressures within the MMD to have the motion withdrawn and there is a lot of lobbying," a senior member within the MMD said last night.

And reacting to the proposed motion Mongu Central MP Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika condemned the move.

"This is not in anybody's interest in Zambia and it is wrong and dangerous. It is wrong because it is unjust to withdraw the right of someone without any specific charge being levelled against him," Lewanika said in an interview last night. "If the motion goes ahead it will be a disgrace to the MMD more than to anybody else. It will make a hero of Kaunda for nothing."

Africa News


February, 1996


Business Zambian Copper Firm Increases Production


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) February 14,1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) last month produced 2,186 tonnes of copper more than in December, 1995.

ZCCM spokesman Francis Musonda disclosed in an interview on Monday that the company had even over-shot their estimated target of 24,000 tonnes in last month's production levels, which was an improvement in production levels

"We have recorded an increase of 2,186 tonnes in the production of finished copper," disclosed ZCCM spokesman Francis Musonda in an interview on Monday, adding: " We have in fact recorded an increase over our estimated production for the month of January." 

The rise in production has been attributed to the good performance of the oxygen plant at the Nkana Smelter which has eased the refinery process.

The rise comes barely a month after the company underwent a management shakeup, with chief executive Edward Shamutete opening an office on the Copperbelt to assume direct supervision of operations.

In making the changes last month, Shamutete said ZCCM's metal production had declined to an alarmingly low rate in the last two years and measures had to be taken to arrest the situation.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large South Africa's Olympic Team Hots Up For Atlanta


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Julian Drew


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Johannesburg - It's going to be hot in Atlanta during the Olympics, and steamy Durban was the perfect venue for South Africa's Olympic squad to get used to these conditions.

Last week in Durban the National Olympic Committee of South Africa (Nocsa) staged an eight-day training camp for 115 athletes from 13 different sports codes as part of its preparations for the centennial Olympic Games which take place in Atlanta in July. It was the first time a multi-code sports team had assembled for a camp of this nature in South Africa.

The camp was aimed at simulating the hot and humid conditions that will be encountered in Atlanta in July and as such the guardians of the weather managed to deliver the perfect climate to ensure a sticky time was had by all. The week prior to the camp had been cool and overcast but, sure enough, as the squad assembled the sun came out with a vengeance. By Thursday the humidity level was comparable to a real steamer in Georgia according to the Olympic team's attache, Ron Davis, from LaGrange, a town 100km south west of Atlanta, where the team will attend a pre-Olympic training camp. 

The objectives of the camp were threefold according to Nocsa president Sam Ramsamy. "We wanted the athletes to be able to train in conditions as close as possible to those they will have to compete in during the Olympic Games and we felt that Durban at this time of the year would be the best place in South Africa to find those conditions. This training camp has also provided us with an opportunity of getting to know one another and building a team spirit which will be so important in Atlanta. We have also been able to monitor the level of fitness and health of the team and discuss the medical tests that have been done on the athletes since August with them and their team coaches," said Ramsamy.

Two important members of the camp were Davis and his colleague from Atlanta, Tommy Phillips, who will be the South African team envoy during the games. The envoy programme was first used by an Olympic organising committee for the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles and was also used at the last Olympics in Barcelona.

"The South African team will have a total of 15 people assigned to it through the envoy programme. There will be five staff members and 10 drivers. Each person on the programme will have undergone two years of intensive training by the time the Games begin. Our task will really be to make it easy for the athletes, coaches and team management to concentrate on the real business of the games and not have to worry about fundamental things like getting to training and competition venues and other logistical problems, " said Phillips. Both he and Davis were able to get to know the squad and spend time fine tuning their planning arrangements with the Nocsa management team.

Davis is the director of athletics at the LaGrange Sports Authority which administers the sports programme at LaGrange College where the South African team will acclimatise for two weeks before the Olympics. The college boasts an excellent range of facilities including two synthetic athletics tracks, indoor and outdoor swimming pools, plus a gym and indoor facilities for other sports. The nearby West Point Lake will cater for rowing and canoeing and an equestrian centre is just 23km away.

One of Davis's tasks in Durban was to talk to the team's nutritionists to determine the dietary requirements of South African athletes. Any athletes who want to carbo load on mealie pap needn't worry, however. One of the African athletes on the Olympic solidarity programme has already planted his own mealie field!

>From a medical point of view the chief medical officer to the South African team in Atlanta, Dr Shorty Moolla, was very happy with the proceedings in Durban. "We were very fortunate that the weather conditions turned out so well. Most of the athletes were uncomfortable with the climate and we had three track and field athletes who had to be treated for dehydration and one for heat stroke. Myself, Dr John Hawley, who is a sports scientist and nutritionist, and Dr Philda de Jager spent three days with each coach and athlete going through their scientific and medical test results. We homed in on nutrition and made recommendations about their diets and any supplements they should be taking," said Moolla.

The athletes were all tested for steroids and many with injury or health problems were X-rayed and put on remedial treatment while at the camp. There were lectures in the early mornings and evenings covering nutrition, sports psychology, acclimatisation and other medical issues.

"The camp was an absolute success and from our perspective what is important is that we can assess the level of fitness and mental state of the athletes and what effect their training is having on their bodies," said Moolla. There will be a further set of tests done in March and April on athletes who have been selected for the team but these will be more specific to the actual sports pursued by the individuals concerned.

"I must admit some of us were a bit sceptical beforehand but right from the word go everything has been done so professionally," said a member of the rowing team. "The people were there to meet us as arranged at our stopover on our journey down here and when we arrived at the hotel everything had been attended to. With so many people involved I must take my hat off to Nocsa for the job they've done,"

All the rowers do their training at Roodeplaat Dam outside Pretoria where the altitude is a definite advantage, but even they were pleased with their stint at the Campsdrift Canoeing Club on the Dusi River in Pietermaritzburg. "The training has been great because the change of environment and the whole team spirit associated with being part of the Olympic squad has really focused us," said John Callie, the stroke in the men's lightweight coxless fours boat from Vikings Rowing Club.

But besides the training there was also the social bonding between people from different sports codes who would not normally meet one another. The restaurant and particularly the bar in the evenings saw many new friendships struck and the fostering of a camaraderie which could make that little extra difference when the chips are down in Atlanta.

The final morning of the camp saw the athletes go behind closed doors for the announcement of the first batch of team members for Atlanta. There were no major surprises although the men's hockey team were clearly relieved after all the media speculation over whether or not they would be selected. There were 43 confirmed team places although some, as with the two rowing crews, the hockey side and the women's swimming medley relay team, will only have names entered later.

There will be many other opportunities for some of the other sports to qualify for the team, particularly athletics and swimming who will name their full contingents after their respective national championships in April and March.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Cricket: Twelve Contenders In Troubled Cup


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Vic Marks


LENGTH: 2094 words


 

Johannesburg - The 12 contenders in the troubled sixth World Cup.

Holland

The average age of the Dutch squad is 32, and it is only that low because they have included an 18-year-old schoolboy, Bastiaan Zuiderent. Four of their players have substantial first-class experience. Nolan Clarke, aged 47, cracked 159 for Barbados against Mike Denness's tourists in 1974. His opening partner, Peter Cantrell, used to represent Queensland, while the sturdy medium-pacers Paul-Jan "Nip" Bakker and Roland Lefevbre are familiar on the English county circuit. Their batting could sparkle but they will struggle in the field.

Odds: 1 000-1

New Zealand

IN 1992, New Zealand were brilliant. But for Martin Crowe's torn hamstring and a ferocious last-ditch assault by Pakistan's Inzamam ul-Haq in Auckland, they would have stunned the pundits by reaching the final. No ploy was too outrageous for captain Crowe; off-spinner Patel opened the bowling, Greatbatch slogged from ball one and a gaggle of motley medium-pacers were used in mesmerising two-over spells. 

Patel, now 37, survives, but Crowe's knee has forced his retirement and Greatbatch is out of favour. The Canterbury wicket-keeper Lee Germon has taken on the captaincy after a tempestuous two years for New Zealand cricket and no matter how innovative he is, it is hard to envisage the inexperienced Kiwis reaching the semi-finals.

Chris Cairns is their most potent cricketer. He is a more orthodox batsman than his father, Lance (not too difficult), a pacier bowler and an equally tenacious competitor.

Odds: 33-1

Pakistan

Assuming he gets a game, Javed Miandad will become the only cricketer to play in all six World Cups. We have learned not to be easily surprised by the machinations of the Pakistan Cricket Board, but the recall of Miandad, now 38 years of age, is an astonishing move even by their standards. He has been out of the team for two years with a leg injury; his fitness is unproven. And do they really believe that Javed has become the peacemaker to unify a tempestuous dressing room?

In the space of 15 months, Pakistan have had four captains: Wasim Akram (removed -- players' revolt); Salim (removed -- bribery scandal); Moin Khan (removed -- only a stopgap); and Ramiz Raja (removed -- lost to Sri Lanka) before reverting to Wasim. Of these, only Moin is missing from the World Cup squad.

But Pakistan possess supremely talented cricketers, such as Sohail, Salim and Inzamam. Wasim Akram is a magnificent one-day bowler. Waqar Younis used to be; in the recent series in Australia, though, he was short of full pace and less devastating as a result, while wrist-spinner Mushtaq Ahmed had a fine winter touring Australia.

But to retain the Cup they will have to improve their fielding significantly, cope with the mighty expectations of a feverish home crowd and ensure that all the ex-captains are four-square behind Wasim.

Odds: 7-2

South Africa

After their comprehensive 6-1 defeat of England in the one-day series, the perceived weakness of the South African team -- a dearth of quality batting -- does not appear to carry much weight. They are supremely confident that someone will score enough runs to allow a powerful bowling attack to win the match. The development of Gary Kirsten as a rock-solid opener and the introduction of Jacques Kallis has been reassuring for coach Bob Woolmer, especially while Hansie Cronje, their most dangerous one-day batsman, has found runs hard to come by.

So has the emergence of a potent spin attack that may be vital in the sub-continent. The fiercely competitive off-spinner Pat Symcox clawed his way back into the squad with gritty performances against England, while batsmen will want to have a good look at the freakish left-arm spinners of the nerveless Paul Adams before launching an assault. He will trouble the best. However South Africa's greatest strength lies in their flawless fielding, with Jonty Rhodes as their talisman, and their pace bowling. The contrasting trio from the recent Test series -- Donald, Pollock and Matthews -- are joined by the irrepressible Fanie de Villiers.

Odds: 11-2

United Arab Emirates

The UAE were the surprise winners of the ICC Trophy in Nairobi in 1994, which assured them a place in this World Cup. They are led by Sultan Zarawani, one of only two nationals in the squad (the other is Saeed Al Saffar), a player more noted for his captaincy skills than his spin bowling or lower-order batting. The rest of the squad are made up of exiles from Pakistan, India and Sri Lanka.

Odds: 2 000-1

Australia

The Australians, in Group A, should justify their status as hot favourites. Mind you, they were in a similar position four years ago on home soil when they bombed.

This time they have sensibly introduced fresh bodies and minds into their squad -- Michael Bevan, recalled with immediate success for the World Series matches; Ricky Ponting of Tasmania, Stuart Law of Queensland and Shane Lee of New South Wales (22), a no-nonsense all-rounder.

Meanwhile the old-timers are not that old. The Waugh twins, arguably the world's best one-day cricketers, have finally reached the age of 30. Steve will clock up his 200th one-day international during the World Cup and is playing the best cricket of his life. So is kid brother Mark. Taylor is a positive leader. McDermott now has more reliable support from McGrath and Reiffel. There's also Shane Warne. But no favourites have won the World Cup since West Indies in 1979.

Odds: 5-2

India

No home side have ever won the World Cup. But this little statistic will not worry the Indians. The final is in Lahore and India have a good chance of making it.

Unlike their neighbours', India's cricket has been notable for its stability in the past five years. Regional rivalries have not spilt on to the cricket field. Under Mohammed Azharuddin's dignified captaincy India have yet to lose a home one-day series.

The form of the vice-captain, Tendulkar, is critical. He has been opening the batting so that his dazzling strokeplay can exploit the 15-over regulation. If the little genius (and he's still only 22) fires, India win. He also bowls his medium pacers with supreme confidence.

Their main bowlers have all flourished in English county cricket -- the fast-improving Srinath, Kumble and the arch streetfighter, Prabhakar. If the Indians have a weakness it is in their fielding.

Odds: 9-2

Kenya

The Kenyans, runners-up in the ICC Trophy, are improving rapidly under the guidance of former Indian Test player Hanumant Singh. Their squad includes three teenagers: Odoyo, Patel and Suji. They are led by the impressive Maurice Odumbe, a prolific run-scorer as well as a handy off-spinner. Like all the minnows, their batting is more impressive than their bowling.

Odds: 2 000-1

Sri Lanka

Through no fault of their own, the Sri Lankan cricketers may yet be denied home advantage in their preliminary matches against Australia and West Indies, but they should qualify for the quarter-finals anyway. No one dares to take them lightly any more.

Their strength lies in an experienced batting line-up, five of whom have played in more than 100 one-day internationals. Skipper Arjuna Ranatunga, a canny left-hander, has been playing Test cricket since 1982. His deputy, Aravinda de Silva, is capable of destroying any attack. Maha-nama is a steady opener while Tillekeratne has two one-day centuries against the West Indies to his name.

However their bowling is weak. They rely heavily on makeshift trundlers and tweakers. Moreover, their young off-spinner Muralitharan has been called for throwing in Australia. The Sri Lankans have included him anyway. Given all the recent confusion in Colombo Muralitharan is the least of their worries.

Odds: 8-1

West Indies

They have the best batsman in the world -- Lara -- and arguably the best bowler, Ambrose, yet they are still unfancied for the World Cup, which they won under Clive Lloyd in 1975 and 1979. West Indies (minus Lara) were beaten to the finals of the triangular World Series tournament by Sri Lanka, a clear indication of their decline.

The return of Lara should guarantee more runs in the upper order if not greaters harmony in the dressing room. Richardson has clung to the captaincy and must start scoring some runs if he is to keep it. Holder replaces the injured Hooper while there are recalls for veteran off-spinner Roger Harper, who has recovered from the "yips", and Cameron Cuffy, the beanpole paceman. To succeed they need Bishop to stay fit, one of their young batsmen --Campbell or Chanderpaul? -- to assert themselves and their fielding to return to former glories. It would also help if Richardson and Lara shared a few rums together in pursuit of a common agenda.

Odds: 9-2

Zimbabwe

The largest of the minnows, Zimbabwe could embarrass other Test-playing countries. The Flower brothers' opening partnerships can be breathtaking, if only for the instinctive understanding and speed of their running between the wickets. Heath Streak, a quality new-ball bowler, could be partnered by Henry Olonga, Zimbabwe's first black Test player.

Odds: 200-1


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Business South African Battle 0ver Business News


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Jacquie Golding-Duffy


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

Johannesburg - Business Report has a new editor who says he is sharpening the market-place battle with main rival Business Day. Business Report is gearing up to supersede Business Day as the irreplaceable financial daily for business people.

On the editorial side, the rivalry is hotting up with at least eight senior reporters being recruited on to the Business Report team, and plans are well underway to have the supplement carried by the Sunday Independent in a bid to improve weekend business coverage.

But when it comes to advertising, the new kid on the block still lacks support, with Business Day having cornered the bulk of advertising.

Business Report, usually eight pages, is carried by various newspapers in the Independent group, and has a circulation of 182 850 (January to June 1995) while Business Day (an average of about 32 pages daily), for the same period, has a circulation of only 36 960. 

Despite the immense difference in circulation figures, Business Day still has the lion's share of business-orientated advertising. According to Nielson Adindex, the advertising shared by these two publications for the period April to November 1995 converts into Business Day carrying 64,8% of the brand advertising (which excludes financial reports) while Business Report has 35,2%.

What Business Report lacks in advertising, it makes up in its gung-ho approach to its editorial efforts. Business Report's first editor, respected writer Jim Smith, only lasted until January when his successor, Peter Bruce took over the reins.

Bruce (43) is the new broom sweeping clean. His office is modest, stark almost. On the desk sits the computer and on the table is a large ashtray, semi-full of cigarette butts. "Smoking in my office is obligatory," he said this week as he lit a cigarette before detailing his history.

Bruce was born and bred in Umtata but spent most of his time abroad with work-related spells all across Europe.

In the autumn of 1978, he left for London and began a lowly job at the Financial Times. "I then began clawing my way up the editorial ladder during my time at the Financial Times," he said.

Nearly 10 years later, he was Financial Times' home-desk editor when he accepted an offer from the Independent group to head its latest venture -- Business Report. He replaced Smith, who moved on to become features editor in the group.

"It didn't take much persuasion for me to return. Although I had travelled extensively, I had never had the chance to carve out a home anywhere. England is expensive, cold and lonely, it never felt like home and returning to South Africa felt right," he said.

"I believe that I could do things that weren't being done before and with the press in a dilapidated state since the early nineties, I thought I could make a contribution in correcting that."

Bruce runs his fingers through his greying hair before starting his assault on his self-confident rival whose offices are a block away.

"Business Day is fat and lazy. It's complacent, and who can blame it, having dominated the financial reporting field for a decade with no competition," he said.

He leans back in his chair: "Business Report could not destroy Business Day and that is not our objective at all. I am glad Business Day is around because it gives us something to shoot at. Nothing gets the adrenaline going as much as competition and nothing makes you work harder.

'Our objective is to set a new agenda for readers and to find new stories. We definitely do not aspire to be a paper of record as Business Day purports to be.

"I want added value from my reporters. While Business Day is not a bad newspaper, it's stretched in its ambition to be a paper of record."

Bruce sees Business Day's business coverage as its "vulnerable side".

"Unlike Business Day, I don't have to worry about the general news of the day. All I have to concentrate on is the business side of things and with this sole purpose, I can ensure that business coverage is of an excellent, in-depth quality."

"Business Day can continue on its cheery way and disregard us but our focus is to produce a good paper which will be of such value, it will become dangerous for businessmen not to start off their day by reading us."

Bruce said local business journalists were talented but because of the lack of competition, they sometimes failed to report beyond the obvious. He stressed that local reporters could walk into a job anywhere in the world but they were not pushed nor stretched to their full potential on local publications. "Reporters have slid into notice-board reporting where companies want you to record things which they feel the public must read," he said.

"I want Business Day to remain an established newspaper and to worry about maintaining that position while I concentrate on excellence" he said.

On the issue of advertising, Bruce said part of the mountain that Business Report had to climb was to become credible and a necessary read, in a bid to attract and keep advertising.

Business Day editor Jim Jones sounded like a man who has seen and heard some of this before. He said Business Day's circulation had reached record levels in excess of 38 000 which was high for a "serious newspaper". In contrast, since the advent of Business Report, its parent newspapers, the Star, The Cape Times and the Natal Mercury had all fallen "precipitously".

"Business Day does not seek circulation by scratch cards and so forth and yet our circulation is up by about 5,8% on the year before."

Jones said that because Business Report was an insert in mass circulation publications catering for a broader spectrum of people and Business Day was a "niche publication", the latter was read and respected by the upper strata of business people as well as by politicians and unionists.

Business Day deputy editor Alan Fine said competition was always welcomed. "The better the competition, the greater the challenge and how much of a challenge depends on how good the competition is," he said.

Fine said the entrance of Business Report had only done Business Day good. "Since Business Report's advent, things have been getting bigger and better for Business Day.

"Commercially, Business Report has not had a negative effect on us whatsoever," Fine said, refusing to take the bait offered by Bruce.

"I don't believe Business Day is complacent at all. In fact we have weathered the storm quite well by progressively expanding and improving our comprehensive financial and business reporting.

"To try and separate politics and finance is silly because the two are so interlinked. One of the functions of Business Day is to indicate to government what it believes is economically possible and to indicate to business what it believes to be politically possible. I believe there is a place for both of us," Fine said.

Media Shop managing director John Barham said although Business Report had a bigger circulation, it also had more wastage. "Although they are getting a lot of circulation via the Star, one cannot tell if everyone or anyone is reading Business Report.

"Business Day is a quick, precise read in the morning whereas Business Report, if you buy it at midday it has no fresh news -- it contains nothing you have not read already.

"Business Report definitely has its merits and must be seen as added-value to the newpapers which carry it. I don't feel there is room for two standing dailies and I don't think it will be as successful as Business Day in securing advertising."

Ivor Jones media analyst Peter Armitage said Business Day had an "entrenched market and the big plus of the publication is that roughly three-quarters of its sales are via subscription.

"The papers attempt to do different things and Business Report handles in-depth articles while Business Day is to the point. Each caters for its own markets. It will be a gradual process but, given time, I think Business Report will secure more advertisers."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
