Africa News


February, 1996


Mozambique Maputo Bows To Tourism Over Pulp And Paper


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Karen Harverson


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Johannesburg - Mozambique's rejection of Sappi's R200-million afforestation scheme has boosted the chances for a tourist development.

Maputo's rejection of pulp and paper giant Sappi's forestry project in southern Mozambique may have more to do with economic considerations than with green issues.

Sappi's R200-million proposal to plant between 20 000 to 30 000 hectares of Eucalyptus trees, creating about 1 200 local jobs, may have seemed attractive back in 1991 when it was first approved but since then the government has had other carrots dangled before it, including a multi-million dollar tourism development.

The forestry project has also provoked a huge outcry from environmentalists who say Sappi's plantation would negatively affect the unique ecosystem of the area and was not the best form of land use. 

The cancellation of the project, announced in the press last week, took the R13,2-billion company by surprise as it had received no such indication from the Maputo government.

Sappi Forests managing director Barry Melrose said the company had been given a written undertaking by the minister of agriculture in August 1995 of the Cabinet's commitment to abide by a 1991 cabinet decision that unconditionally approved the afforestation scheme in southern Mozambique.

"The only remaining issue was the total area to be afforested, which was subject to an environmental impact study. This study has been completed and has recommended an area of 21 000 hectares," said Melrose.

He said he had spoken to the minister of agriculture on Monday evening, but was unable to find out for certain if the project was indeed cancelled.

"The minister answered 'You know what the press are like' and suggested that we meet face-to-face on Thursday to discuss the matter," said Melrose.

The outcome of this meeting was not known at the time of going to press but it seems likely that Sappi will be asked to pursue the project -- in a different area.

Melrose would not comment on the action Sappi would take if the deal was off and remained tight-lipped on whether he would agree to a proposal by government to relocate the project, saying he would not comment until he had spoken to the minister.

Earlier this week, Melrose indicated that no other area would be suitable for this specific project. The timber from the project would have been used to supply the Ngodwana mill, near Nelspruit, and the Enstra mill in Springs.

"The consequences of the deal being rejected means less timber would be bought locally and more bought overseas, and future expansions at these plants could be jeopardised," said Melrose. Sappi owns and manages 400 000 hectares of timber plantations in southern Africa, which supply only 50% of the company's domestic wood requirements.

"The costs of siting this project in the area proposed are reasonable as there is an existing rail infrastructure. The timber plantation would be sited about 120km from Ngodwana and is within economic transport costs."

If the forestry project were sited further north, the timber would have to be railed to Beira, shipped to South Africa and then railed again.

Melrose said the company had explored other areas further north in Mozambique but these were being considered for a different type of project involving a processing plant. He added that the company would reconsider these plans if the forestry project fell through.

He said the company had also had minor contact in Angola and other southern African countries and planned a full-scale investigation into available opportunities later this year.

American entrepreneur James Blanchard, who plans to build an $800-million tourist scheme, which will create 12 000 jobs in the same region, called a press conference on Tuesday to commend the Mozambiquan government on its 'brave' decision to turn down the Sappi project.

"It's a short-term loss for a long-term gain," he said. Although sketchy on the exact details of how the project would be financed, Blanchard said he believed he was close to winning a concession agreement from the government, which would be a stakeholder in the scheme.

He was not concerned about the possibility that, like Sappi, any concession agreed on might be rejected later. "I'm confident the truth is on our side."

Blanchard's project -- which he likened to a Sun City/Pilansberg-type concept -- includes the development of exclusive homes on the Peninsula connected by steam train railroad to the Maputo Elephant Reserve, which he intends restocking with game. Also on the cards are a casino and golf course.

If granted the concession, Blanchard plans to sell sub-concessions to other developers to build the luxury homes. "We'll invest in the infrastructure and bring in the game."

Although Blanchard admitted he had no experience in this type of development, he said his area of expertise was in fund-raising and financial planning.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Public Service Restructures Amid Hopes And Fears


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Simon Segal


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Johannesburg - One of government's top priorities, and a key component of the Reconstruction and Development Programme, is the restructuring and rationalisation of the public service.

Success in this political field is one of government's most important tests and indicators of its determination to deliver on its election promises.

Data from the Central Statistical Service (CSS) show that one year after the Government of National Unity came to power, fears about the public sector growing uncontrollably have proved unfounded. The wage bill has also not surged. 

The public service grew marginally -- from 1,24-million people in June 1994 to 1,25-milion in June 1995. But this is down from 1,26-mllion in December.

The quarterly wage bill dropped from R11,5-billion in June 1994 to R10,7-billion a year later,.

If the state's contribution to funds are included -- namely pensions, medical aid, sick-pay and unemployment contributions -- the quarterly salary bill amounts to R13-billion in June 1994 and R12,3-billion a year later -- a drop from an average R3 502/month to R3 293.

This is for the public service, whose salaries are paid out of the State Revenue Fund and accounts for some 38% of the total budgeted expenditure.

For the public sector as a whole - that is the public service plus local authorities, public corporations, agricultural marketing boards, parastatal institutions, universities and technikons -- employment increased from 1,84-million in June 1994 to 1,86-million in June 1995 or 13,1% of the economically active population. The quarterly salary bill went up marginally from R17,548-billion to R17,552-billion. Average salaries fell from R3 185/month to R3 153.

As for the composition of the public service, whites accounted for 22,3% of employees, 32,8% of the wage bill and 147% of the average wage in June 1994. By last June these figures were 21,1%, 32% and 152% respectively.

For the public sector as a whole, in June 1995 whites comprised 22% of employees (23,7% in June 1994), 33,9% of total salaries (35,9%) and 154% of average wages (152%).

In its white paper outlining its policy framework, the department of public service and administration, officially called the Office of the Minister for the Public Service and Administration, sets out eight priorities.

One of these is affirmative action. The main target groups are blacks, women and the disabled. No targets or time-frames are identified. But it is stated that "within four years all departments must endeavour to achieve at least a 50% black management level and at least 30% of new recruits to middle and senior management echelons should be women. Within 10 years people with disabilities should comprise 2% of public service personnel".

The result has been a dramatic change to the face of the top echelons of the public service. The data in the table above do not reflect trends within the year (CSS does provide quarterly data) but only compare two dates one year apart.

Employment numbers are the total full-time equivalent employees; that is, the number of part-time workers are converted to full-time equivalent workers.

Government's first step was to rationalise and restructure the public service to create a unified national operation out of the fragmented state administration systems inherited from the apartheid era. The 1994 Public Service Act created the basis for integrating 11 administrations in South Africa, the former homelands and TBVC states.

This process included restructuring senior management by filling posts. The deadline for completing the integration and senior management shifts by May 1995 was extended to November.

With this unifying process nearing completion, the emphasis falls on creating a more cost-effective service.

The expectation is that a year from now CSS data will reflect a drop in employee numbers of about 100 000. Such a major transformation is inevitably complex and controversial.

This was highlighted by the sharp rebuke Auditor General Henri Kluever received from Minister Zola Skweyiya when he spoke about the civil service being like the Titanic heading for an iceberg. Kluever effectively expresses the many fears, especially among whites, over the future of the civil service.

The new constitution will influence the structure and function of the public service.

Minister Zola Skweyiya's response expresses the aspirations and hopes of the RDP. He has an immense task to convince sceptics from outside about future standards, and those within about opportunities, without aggravating white fears and black aspirations.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


233 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Business Reserve Bank Governor In The Grooming?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Johannesburg - Glance at his curriculum vitae and one could be forgiven asking why Timothy Thahane should forsake an illustrious career at the World Bank to join the Reserve Bank as deputy governor.

The Reserve Bank refutes the rumours, but there is no denying they are growing in intensity. Thahane is being groomed for the top job. Dr Chris Stals has three and a half years left to go on his current contract, and there is a dearth of potential successors within the bank. 

Stals, however, is adamant the appointment has nothing to do with his own future at the bank. "We needed someone with international experience and regional know-how, someone with specialist knowledge of the African scenario.

"As South Africa's role grows in importance within the African continent and globally, such experience is vital for an institution such as ours. Thahane is amply qualified for the position."

On the subject of his own succession, Stals would not be drawn. "I'll cross that bridge when I come to it," he said.

The finance minister was equally recalcitrant. "I cannot predict the future," said Chris Liebenberg. "But we chose the best man for the job."

Thahane, no stranger to South Africa, having been involved in the Lesotho Highlands project as well as the Southern African Development Community, is enthusiastic about his roleas deputy governor, which he takes up in April.

He hinted at the Reserve Bank's staid image, but denied his appointment signalled a shake-up, either of personnel or policy.

"The bank will continue to consult on a regular basis with politicians; it is not at variance with government."

Indeed, he saw no reason to change the bank's modus operandi: "The Reserve Bank functions much as other leading central banks -- it operates with autonomy but not outside the political structure. It is part of the process of government machinery, working with it, not against it."

But meeting the challenges facing South Africa may take longer than his five-year contract, he says. So there may be truth to the rumour after all.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


234 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


d Arts, Culture and Entertainment In Place Of Fallen Icons


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Neville Dubow


LENGTH: 1894 words


 

Johannesburg - "The collection offered here will form the basis of a future museum against apartheid. But first these works will be presented in a travelling exhibition ... throughout the world."

Thus the words of the founders of the Art Contre Apartheid exhibition, the artists Ernest Pignon-Ernest and Antonio Saura, in the introductory catalogue essay written in 1983.

After wide exposure internationally (but, as far as we are concerned, waiting offstage for a decade and a half), Art Against Apartheid has made its South African appearance in the corridors and hallways of Parliament.

An anticipatory article in the Mail & Guardian raised a couple of pertinent questions: what is the exhibition doing in Parliament? Does it belong in the halls of power? 

The short answer to that, in my view, is "yes". For the six months it will spend in Parliament it has instantly assumed the kind of high profile it might not otherwise have had. It might also do a job of work. Parliamentarians need to be exposed to creative energy, as opposed to the formulaic hagiography that is their usual visual backdrop.

A more extended answer would have to qualify that "yes". The exhibition has both the strengths -- in the symbolism of its genesis -- and the weaknesses, in terms of quality and coherence, that one could expect from high-minded gestures of this kind. It is a show of uneven quality. It contains some powerful works; but it also includes a lot of journeyman stuff that would scarcely raise an eyebrow if encountered within the usual art gallery context. Certainly for anyone familiar with the routine provocations of international art production of the Seventies and Eighties, there is no more than a core of work that is particularly challenging.

But experiencing it within the corridors of Parliament gives the show a collective cutting edge and a thrust, heightened by one's awareness of the fallen icons it has supplanted. A couple of cases in point: works that have to do with themes of transience, such as Paul Rebeyrolle's painting Mortal Remains or Emilio Tadini's Body and Mask are unlikely to cause much of a flutter when encountered in a bland museum context. But experience them in close proximity to a display case that houses the Act to constitute the Union of South Africa of 1909, and you get a different kind of reading of the pervasive nature of transience.

Similarly, Josep Guinovart's The Drape with its anthropomorphised St Andrew's cross (placed in the exact spot that housed a bust of Cecil John Rhodes) brings to mind the kind of crosses that people put into ballot boxes in April 1994, which ultimately made it possible for the work to get here.

But, inevitably, it is a cross of another kind that is likely to be the talking point of the show: Wolf Vostel's Black Crucifixion of 1982. Those who are able to recall the atmosphere in which artists had to work here in the Sixties may remember that a Johannesburg artist, Harold Rubin, had to face a charge of heresy for a work on a similar theme. Vostel's work, with its exposed bones and mocking reversals of traditional iconography, appears to have been the subject of some delicate shifting. It was originally displayed in the entrance foyer; it has now found its place on an upper floor where those who are likely to be shocked will at least have time to become acclimatised to its challenge.

The hanging team, aided by staff from the South African National Gallery, has done a good job in difficult circumstances. I like the way the optical works of Jesus Raphael Soto have been placed against the multi-coloured marble panels and floors of the new wing: a question of op art having to slug it out with the vulgarity of the architectural background, somewhere between post-modern art-deco and art bordello. The Soto wins.

It might become clear, then, that anyone expecting a thematically unified show is going to be disappointed. What links these works has as much to do with gesture as original creative intention: that is to say the act of artists giving their work, as a token of solidarity, is as significant as the reason why they were made in the first place.

Without wanting to be pedantic, to call the show Artists Against Apartheid would give a more accurate index of what the works are really about. Few of them deal with the substantive issues of racist ideology that drove the apartheid machine. Even fewer have any reference to South African identity. Only one series, by Gavin Jantjes, is of South African origin, informed by direct experience. (It is in fact related to work that he did as a student at the Michaelis School of Fine Art.)

Of the few entries by international heavyweights that are specifically addressed to the anti-apartheid theme, the contribution by Robert Rauschenberg encapsulates the point, and limitations, of solidarity art. It is a 1982 collage, apparently designed to be reproduced as a poster, featuring two basketball players, one white, the other black. The work is untitled, but the artist has scrawled across the top of it: "World artists against apartheid".

And that is what the show is really about. Symbolism and solidarity have precedence over substance. This is not to underplay the importance of either symbolism or solidarity in the context of this show. Its very raison d'etre serves as an index to the broad range of international artists who felt sufficiently strongly about apartheid to give their work in the belief that change would come. But in its formal substance, this exhibition has primarily to do with the look of international art production in the Seventies and Eighties.

Nevertheless, those with an eye for irony will be quick to note that the icons from the discredited past (whose displacement will be mourned by few) have been replaced by images which are likely to perplex many. Further to that is the added irony that, in the ongoing debate about cultural identity, with its sterile binary oppositions of Eurocentrism versus Africanisation, Parliament is hosting a show of unabashed eclectic internationalism.

But that's alright; even if it does nothing else, the exhibition might be the start of art education for some parliamentarians and even a challenge to others. For South African artists not exposed to international formalism, this show gives something to measure themselves against. And there need be no feelings of inferiority.

In fact, it would have been possible to put together a thematically focused show of work done by South African artists in the decades of the Seventies and Eighties which would more than hold its own. Isolation cut two ways. If anything, the local art community, even in the darkest years of apartheid, knew more about what was happening internationally than the international pundits knew about the quality of resistance art that was being produced here.

Now that we are back in the world and establishing our new identity -- from polecat to paragon -- we need to be careful about role models. Some of our official cultural institutions, notably our national broadcaster, have not kicked the nasty habit of knocking Eurocentrism while accommodating the worst of North American schlock. (Witness the parade of soapie mini-stars and silky lawyers who descended the stairs of the SAA Boeing which poked its nose, like some rerun of Airport with lasers, into the recent SABC TV launch.)

Several issues remain.

The first is the fate of the pictures and portrait busts of the old order, which are now in storage and awaiting restoration. Where will they end up? Surely there is a case for evaluating and differentiating the displaced works. Whether we like it or not, they are part of the record. Not all of them have value as art. But we have to face up to our history. I notice that the parliamentary museum still exists. Filled with colonial relics, haphazardly displayed, it reeks of must and neglect. Surely there is a case for reorganisation here. Squaring up to our history inevitably means contextualising the new order in relation to the old -- and vice versa. It's a question of interpretation and we are not short of interpretive skills.

The other issue is the fate of the Art Against Apartheid show. Originally indicated as coming to the South African National Gallery, it is now under the custodianship of the Mayibuye Centre, which has thus far handled the issue with common sense and flair. After its projected national tour, where will it end up? Is there not a more creative alternative than a "museum against apartheid"? When that phrase was coined it was in the nature of an imaginary museum. Imagination now has to be translated into concrete terms.

The final issue, no less important, is what kind of work is going to hang in Parliament once the current exhibition comes to the end of its six-month run. There is a strong case to be made for showing work by South African artists, including photographers, who kept their integrity in the apartheid years. That could serve as an instructive parallel exhibition to the present one.

And after that we need more "Madibagraphy".

Who will be commissioned to record the current government of national unity, and the dispensation that will succeed it? And who will be the new commissars? What is it about ourselves and our new era that we wish to reflect? The physical likenesses of parliamentarians, or the creative energy that they will need to draw on to build a viable and sustainable democracy?

Will artists be chosen who are capable of producing artworks over and above pictorial records? A critical honesty to replace the old hagiography?

Let the debate begin.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment TV: Unshackling the Zanzibaris


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 199 by Hazel Friedman


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Johannesburg - They are called the "lost tribe", a dispossessed community of black Muslims descended from slaves who live in the Indian township of Chatsworth. But the "lost" label, although well-intentioned, is both inaccurate and offensive. The Zanzibaris are not lost. They know where they come from, who they are and what they want.

This virtually unknown community is the focus of a two-part documentary to be screened on SABC 1. Directed by Durban-based Junaid Ahmed and produced by the Centre for Democratic Communications, it examines the history of this insular group, their sense of cultural and religious identity and their double betrayal by both the old and new South African government -- undermined and oppressed by the former, ignored by the latter. 

The story of the Zanzibaris is, in many senses, a microcosm of the history of all enslaved and exiled communities. Their existence can be traced to 1873, just after the abolition of slavery in Britain. Captured from East Africa by Arab and Portuguese slave traders, they were crammed into the dungeons of Zanzibar, awaiting export to Europe and the Middle East. But the British "liberated" 113 of them and shipped them off to Natal as indentured labourers, thereby rescuing them from one kind of slavery and imposing on them another set of shackles.

Shortly after this, another 500 traumatised and malnourished Zanzibaris were shipped in and the swelling community was scattered in overcrowded settlements around Durban. They were separated from the other "Kaffir servants" because they were Muslim, but denied schooling because they were deemed unworthy of education.

And the indignities didn't end there. Land purchased for them by the Mohammedan Trust along Durban's Bluff area was expropriated by the Nationalist government after the Group Areas Act took effect in the early 1960s. And with the Population Registration Act, their pariah status was entrenched, not by the government, but by the surrounding Indian, black and coloured communities. The community, which numbers 10 000 today, was subjected to eight different racial classifications, including African, coloured, Indian and finally "other Asiatics".

"I remember growing up near Chatsworth where the Zanzibaris were forcefully relocated," recalls director Ahmed, "and thinking that they were intruders. I felt hostile towards them because they were black yet they were practising my religion. It was only later that I began to appreciate their strength and the degree to which racism practised towards them by oppressed communities had contributed to their plight."

In 1995 Ahmed embarked on a small mission of restitution. Over 12 days, he filmed them, not as exotic curiosities, but as South Africa's smallest minority group whose fortitude and faith has remained constant in the face of overwhelming odds.

The result is a documentary which is notable for its beautiful footage and sensitive approach. It provides fascinating insights into the ancient customs still practised by the Zanzibaris.

Circumcision, for example, is still performed on young boys. After the operation, the initiates are taken to a remote hut where they remain until their liminal period (the stage between boyhood and manhood) is over.

Young girls, although not subjected to "operations", also remain in seclusion during menstruaton in order to successfully complete the necessary rites of passage into womanhood.

Then there is the ratieb -- an ecstatic Arabic dance traditionally performed by Muslim saints -- during which the trance-like dancers pierce their bodies as a reaffirmation of the power of their faith.

One of the film's subtexts is the role played by Zanzibari women who confound Western assumptions of female repression in Islamic societies. Zanzibari women are not forced to hide their sensuality behind veils. Although deeply pious, they seem to revel in the fulfilment of all the senses, as scenes of celebration and sport suggest.

But most importantly, perhaps, the documentary focuses on the Zanzibaris' struggle to reclaim their land.

"They are frustrated that the new government has ignored their rights, and have taken action themselves. The Zanzibaris Civic Organisation has been formed, through which they are staking their land claims and seeking ways of improving their conditions", explains Ahmed.

Yet the greatest peril facing the Zanzibaris lies ahead. Overcrowding, a 90% unemployment rate, the increase of alcohol and drug abuse and the inevitable lure of greener pastures might well subjugate the community more effectively than the dungeons of Zanzibar or the matchboxes of Chatsworth ever could.

The Zanzibaris will be screened in two parts on SABC 1 at 7pm on February 20 and 27.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology What Ostriches Can Teach Us


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Saliem Fakir and Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

Johannesburg - Ostriches and rooibos tea provide insights into how South Africa can prevent the pillaging of its fauna and flora.

The plight of South Africa's wild plants and animals has been in the news lately with the publication of two hard-hitting reports that document a large-scale, illicit drain of valuable indigenous species from the country over the past two decades.

The Kumleben Commission's report described extensive illicit trading in ivory by the South African military in the 1980s, while a study by Traffic, an international body which monitors illegal trade in fauna and flora, found a thriving illegal trade in South African birds, reptiles and plants.

Both reports propose more stringent regulations and customs control, with additional resources for police and other enforcement agencies. 

But two South African species - the ostrich and a type of fynbos that grows only in the sparse climate of the Cedarberg - provide useful lessons about how expensive state controls can be supplemented with measures that promote responsible entrepreneurial use of indigenous products.

Wildlife conservation in South Africa has in the past been dominated by a protectionist mindset: game reserves were fenced off and patrolled by paramilitary anti-poaching patrols; bureaucratic permit systems were set up to control the export of animals, plants and fertile embryos of native species; and rigid agricultural marketing controls restricted innovative industries which could have made constructive use of wildlife products.

This policing-from-above approach, along with government restrictions on legal commerce in wildlife, involved inevitable failures, mainly because the state lacked the capacity and finances to enforce its regulations. Today, the new government is even more hard-pressed to release funds for conservation.

The recent histories of the ostrich and the rooibos leaf show, in different ways, how commercial and entrepreneurial exploitation of plant and animal products can provide more vibrant, cost-effective and efficient ways to preserve rare species - without taxing ordinary people and the state's coffers.

The African Black Ostrich, whose genes were originally indigenous to the Karoo, is the basis of an extremely profitable rural industry - even though the fashion market for the bird's feathers, which first provided the impetus for farmers to domesticate them, collapsed in 1914.

They are valued for meat, in high demand in many European countries because of consumer fears that beef carries mad cow disease. The skin is prized for quality leather products. Eggs are used in the curio industry. Oil, for cosmetics and moisturisers, is extracted from their fat. Feathers are used to make non-static dusters for computers. There is a specialised demand for feathers from the organisers of Mardi Gras carnivals like the one in Rio this month. And bones and toe nails are crushed to make bone meal.

Sid Birch, an ostrich farmer in the Little Karoo, estimates the industry has the potential to earn the country a whopping R550-million every year in foreign exchange.

The problem lies in the way the Klein Karoo Co-operative imposed a tough, single-channel marketing system on farmers until October 1993, insisting that it handled the sale of all ostrich products. The co-op also pressed the government to legislate, in terms of the Livestock Improvement Act, against the export of fertile birds and eggs.

The result: smugglers had a field day, sneaking birds out through Namibia and Bophuthatswana, while South African farmers were forced to accept prices for their birds way below the international market levels. There were few incentives to develop local meat-processing plants or tanning factories which added value to the bird's primary products.

At the same time, farmers in other unlikely parts of the world began working with smuggled South African birds, which are prized over species found in other parts of Africa because they are more docile, female birds lay more eggs than their counterparts, the chicks mature more quickly and the skin of our ostriches has more pimples - making it more attractive in the leather market.

Now Texas has nearly as many African Black ostriches as Oudtshoorn. Italy has plants that turn the meat into salami. There are 50 modern ostrich farms in Britain, mainly in the Oxfordshire district. They have so many African Blacks running around on them that a local animal rights group, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, is demanding that the government protect their welfare. And Holland has 120 ostrich farmers whose birds have adapted surprisingly well to the cold climate.

The ostrich industry in South Africa was deregulated in the late 1980s after farmers took legal action against the monopolistic practices of the Klein Karoo Co-op. Bird farming has since taken off all over the country and these wild animals have spread to almost every province.

But all this may have come too late. The single biggest obstacle to expansion of trade in ostrich products is this country's failure to capture the international export market at an early stage - especially for manufactured goods with added value.

"The increasing international interest in ostrich farming (with the giant South African bird) is posing a threat to the ostrich industry and its worldwide dominance," reports an October 1995 edition of Farmer's Weekly.

Rooibos, or Aspalathus linearis, presents the opposite lesson in how creative commercial use can cultivate a national species.

Records show that Khoisan people used the leaf to make a tea-like brew for centuries. White settlers then used it. The first modern industry began in 1904, but it only really took off when a group of local entrepreneurs formed the Rooibos Co-op which, despite its name, operated as a private-sector company from 1993.

About 18 000ha has been put under rooibos cultivation, much of it farmed by small-scale coloured farmers in the Clanwillian area. About 4 700 tons of the tea is produced annually with close on 2 000 tons being exported. No single player controls the market and growers are allowed to trade freely. The result: a vibrant local industry which, unhindered by government interference and red tape, has captured the international market and has created a significant source of livelihood for small farmers.

The different experiences of the bird and the tea leaf underscore two vital points. South Africa is among the 10 countries with the richest biological diversity. This natural wealth has, if managed in a flexible but strategic way, a massive potential for creating rather than consuming funds for conservation.

Commercialisation creates several opportunities: it provides new activities for farmers and alternative crops; it develops a technology and research base that can be applied to other potential products; it diversifies the economic base (especially in a sector prone to natural hazards such as drought and flooding); and it creates multiple job opportunities.

This marks a major shift from a protectionist approach, to creating more value out of our primary natural resources, which traditionally would be exported and re-imported as manufactured products at higher prices.

The lesson is simple: if we don't encourage economic development that thrives on the rich diversity of this country's natural assets, the threats to our biological riches will triumph.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Returning Humanity To Dry Bones


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Johannesburg - The South African Museum in Cape Town is planning to develop a "sensitive and responsible" curatorial policy that takes into account the interests of all stakeholders in a collection of human bones, skulls, skeletons, and 14 plaster casts of Khoisan women's genitalia, which were collected by scientists during this country's period of colonial rule.

Patricia Davison, assistant director at the South African Museum, said this week that the museum had about 1 500 skulls, teeth, jaw-bones and "post-cranial bones" (bone material other than skull) in its skeletal holdings, which derive mainly from Khoisan groups who lived in Southern Africa.

Some of the skeletal material in the museum had been actively collected by academic researchers, but much was donated after being discovered by members of the public. 

The museum also houses a collection of body casts that were taken from living Khoisan people between 1904 and 1927. There are 69 full body casts of naked men and women, and 14 casts of female genitalia that were collected as part of a project which sought to record what was thought to be a vanishing racial type (see main story).

The museum has always allowed academic researchers access to the collection and is now taking note of a growing debate in academic and human rights circles about how to manage the presence of controversial human remains and images of indigenous people.

"In the case of physical anthropology collections, scientific views have changed considerably since the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries ... Physical anthropologists no longer study human skeletal remains in relation to racial typology, but with regard to the physical development of humankind and the relationships of people to changing environments through time," said Davison.

The Griqua National Conference, which claims to represent the interests of Khoisan people, last month wrote to President Nelson Mandela to demand that he intervene to ensure that various remains of indigenous people are returned, and an end to "dehumanised portrayals" of them.

Minister of Arts, Culture, Science and Technolgy Ben Ngubane then announced he has had contact with his French counterpart to demand back the pickled brain and genitals of a Khoisan woman called Saartjie Baartman, stored at the Musee de l'Homme in Paris.

And this week Chief Nicholas Gcaleka from the Eastern Cape plans to take a delegation of traditional healers off to Scotland in order to find the head of a famous Xhosa warrior chief, whose head was allegedly cut from his body and taken to a military museum after being killed in battle against British colonial troops in the 1830s.

"Our policy is to be entirely open about our holdings and to work together with relevant stakeholders in the process of negotiating a curatorial policy that is both sensitive and responsible," Davison said.

She said the museum would negotiate with any legitimate party which lodged a claim for human remains housed in the museum, and it was considering ways to meet any demands that may arise without destroying scientifically valuable material.

'The Southern Africa Museums Association (Sama) has invited an Australian specialist in cross-cultural studies to address the issue of sensitive material in museum collections at its forthcoming annual conference in Kimberley in April. It is recognised that policies regarding human remains must be developed in partnership with relevant institutions and community groups," she said.

"The historical importance of the collection should not be overlooked. Collections from the past are powerful reminders of the ideas that contributed to the shaping of cultural identities and thus have an important educational and cultural role to play in the present."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology An Obsession For Khoisan Genitalia


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Pippa Skotnes


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Johannesburg - After recent publicity raised by indigenous peoples' activists over human body parts in museums, South African curators are arguing that these artefacts are still of educational and cultural value.

When Khoisan communities were first subjected to the European gaze,they were portrayed, by and large, as barbaric: without religion, without morals. Their language was considered a babble, their behaviour beastly, their habits inhuman and their bodies were seen to reflect these qualities.

But as Europeans expressed disgust at the apparent moral corruption of Southern African aboriginal people, they were almost absurdly fascinated with Khoisan genitals - and the fixation was reflected in a series of academic expeditions that set out to photograph, cast and study these peoples' body parts. 

Ideas of European racial and intellectual superiority were promoted by an almost obsessive need to establish physical difference. By the middle of the 19th century, Khoisan bodies were considered so extraordinary that thousands of people in England and Europe were prepared to pay to see them.

They were apparently the pygmies and the cranes that Herodotus had described, the strangest of people at the furthermost corner of the earth. The London papers at the time of the Great Exhibitions described the "Bosjesmans", or "Earth People", or "African Pygmies" as "resembling monkeys", "cruelly deficient of all the attributes which belong to human beauty", "clucking", or "dwarfishly savage", with their minds in "torpid darkness".

When a Khoisan woman called Saartjie Baartman was taken overseas in the early 19th century and exhibited in London and Paris, it was not only the "prodigious size of her buttocks" (as it was described by St Hilaire of the Natural History Museum in Paris) that was the great source of fascination, but the imagined strangeness of her genitals.

Travellers such as Le Vaillant, in the 18th century, had painted images of women flashing long pendulous labia. Captain Cook, when he visited the Cape, had written that the "Hottentot" women had labia which "resembled the teats of a cow", and reports had reached Victorian English ears that some women had labia, like an apron, which hung down to their knees.

By the end of the 19th century, Khoisan bodies had been the subject of hundreds of photographic "essays". Most of these photographs were part of scientific projects that examined racial difference. Many of these photographs survive in museum collections and archives.

Typically, they depict men and women, standing naked against a measuring stick, from front and side views. Many collections also included images which particularly focused on genitals; men being photographed most often to the side to show the tilt of the penis, and women being persuaded to grasp their labia to expose their length.

Despite the profusion of these images, both published in early photogravure books, and unpublished, (and the many that she herself took), Dorothea Bleek, South Africa's first female anthropologist, was able to write in 1911 that it was exceedingly difficult to get "photos of the natives without their clothes on".

At the same time, the scientific community in South Africa was concerned to preserve some physical trace of what they perceived to be a race of people heading for extinction. These were known as the "Bush and Hottentot races".

In 1907 the director of the South African Museum, Louis Peringuey, wrote to the Cape government for support to find "pure specimens" whose bodies could be cast, and thus who could provide a lasting record of their vanishing "type".

For more than 50 years, photography had provided this record; now Drury, the museum's modeler, was to begin a project which would result in remarkably lifelike figures, finely and accurately painted.

Part of Drury's "brief" was to cast separately the genitals of a number of women. This involved the packing of plaster (which, as any art student will tell you, when it sets will prick and burn) around the labia majora and into the folds of the labia minora.

That this was achieved, and with such detailed accuracy, speaks of an extreme degree of coercion, in which women were persuaded to expose themselves in a most undignified way.

When Drury and his colleague, Drennan, wrote of research he had done into the genitals of the "Bush race", he described his experience in the following way: "On asking a woman of these tribes to remove her loin cloth or apron, one could not at first detect any difference between her and an ordinary woman ... On separating the lips of the vulva it was easy to grasp the labia minora with a pair of forceps and pull them out for examination. This increased exposure gave rise to a distinct accession of shyness on the part of the women ..."

The body casts, dressed in skins, are still on display in the South African Museum, set in painted and idealised dioramas, and the genital casts are kept in a safe in one of the museum's storerooms.

Khoisan people of the 19th century are no longer seen as an homogeneous racial type, but as a diverse population comprised of different cultures with their own languages, histories and practices which, like all cultures, have changed and accommodated new influences.

Marking, scarring, mutilating and analysing the body have always been ways of portraying cultural or ethnic difference and superiority - and such motives clearly influenced science and anthropology a hundred years ago.

But this does not mean that the casts, as well as the photographs and documents, that pertain to the whole colonial process of structuring racial difference are not valuable and precious artefacts that must be preserved.

The challenge facing museums is to come up with new methods of display and presentation, so that this material may be recast in the light of contemporary thinking,and the role they can play in understanding history.

The irony that we should remember, however, is that the methods used by 19th century scientists, and the museum objects they produced, tell us more about the European mind than anything about the people they sought to describe, classify and ultimately subjugate.

Pippa Skotnes is a senior lecturer in Fine Art at the University of Cape Town. These issues form part of a forthcoming book and exhibition: Miscast: Negotiating the Presence of the Bushmen


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa SA's Most Powerful Media Boss


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 199 by Mark Gevisser


LENGTH: 2200 words


 

Johannesburg - When he was a reporter at the Rand Daily Mail in the late 1970s, Zwelakhe Sisulu led a group of black colleagues from the publication on a protest march to John Vorster Square, where they were summarily arrested. Upon release, they were summoned into a senior editor's office, who bawled them out: "How could you do this? It's a discredit to the paper!".

Sisulu challenged the editor: "I'm baffled. What we did was a concrete expression of the Mail's editorial policy."

"Ah, this is where you don't get it," the editor responded. "You don't march. You write!" 

Sitting now in an office on the top floor of a perpetual controversy about the relationship between the public broadcaster and government, Sisulu remembers that earlier confrontation as a watershed: "For me, it showed the thin line that, in a sense, was beginning to define me out of South African journalism; that I was now, in a sense, a black activist."

Cleaving a branch for his own personal destiny apart from that of his legendary family, Sisulu insists that "I did not set out to be an activist. My activism began with my journalism."

He spent two years in devastating detention; he set up and edited the New Nation, the ANC's functional internal mouthpiece; his political profile has propelled him to the most powerful media position in the country. And yet Zwelakhe Sisulu's professional identity solidified in those five years, from 1975 to 1980, when he was a working journo in the newsrooms at the South African Association of Newspapers.

And he carries with him, even now, the psychology of the journalist; a psychology captured most pithily by that doyen of post-war British journalism, James Cameron, who said something along the lines of: "Every day, when I sit down at the typewriter, I think, 'This time they will find me out.'"

Zwelakhe Sisulu is high on the charm. He is clever, articulate, charismatic, and blessed with those gemutlische Sisulu features that radiate hospitality and dependability; cheeks you could settle into with a cup of tea. But, like most good hacks, he is palpably insecure; one senses, lurking beneath the bluster, a man who feels he's a little bit of an imposter.

An example from the SABC gossip mill: For months, Sisulu took his lunches at the Johannesburg Country Club across the road from the SABC. Then, one day, his secretary called to make a reservation, and was told that if Sisulu wanted to continue dining there, he had to become a member. He has not been back since.

The story says much about Sisulu's diffidence. A government official, who has known him for years, says "He is one of the shyest people I know. When I looked at him at that launch, I saw an expression on his face which seemed to me to be saying, 'I just want to sit in my office and do my job! I don't want to be on stage in front of a Jumbo Jet.' Zwelakhe is a low-profile person with a high-profile name."

His dilemma is that he carries with him not only the name but the chromosomes of his parents. He was propelled into leadership by those around him who saw this. Thus was he pushed, by fellow black journalists, into leading the Writers' Association of South Africa (WASA) in 1977. Thus was he pushed into setting up the New Nation in 1986; into becoming heir apparent at SABC in 1994. There is as much duty (filial or national) as drive in his upward mobility.

His contract at SABC expires in October next year. Will he make himself available for re-appointment? He will not say. He believes, however, that he will eventually go back to newsprint: "There's no doubt in my mind that TV is the medium of the present and the future. But I do still think, if one wants to engage intellectually, that print is the best way."

One of his senior staff, with much experience in television, says that "he has been here for two years, and I still don't get a sense that he has any passion for television. TV just doesn't seem to be in his blood; he doesn't have an instinct for it."

He agonised over his appointment and took it, say those close to him, with extreme caution and anxiety. These emotions, unfortunately, were writ large on his features every time he spoke. He had a hard time fostering confidence or providing vision.

His greatest error, once he became chief executive in 1994, was to announce far-reaching reforms and objectives, and then not implement them speedily: employees feared retrenchment and rapid transformation, and then, when it didn't happen, the air at the SABC became poisonous.

It has been, for the past three years, a nightmarish place: rudderless, chaotic, back-biting, anguished. Last year, as more and more people "took the package" and got out, Sisulu and his senior staff found themselves concentrating more on strategic planning.

Things fell apart while no less than five bulky instalments of the SABC's vision-document, "Delivering Value", were presented to the Independent Broadcasting Authority. (Sisulu is the first to admit the wrong-headedness of this, and blames the IBA for "not being clear about what it wanted from us.")

His detractors in the sector -of whom there are many- feel that Sisulu, lacking confidence, has been overly reliant on bad advisers and that he has shielded himself from the corporation with a ring of yes-men (he is obsessed with "loyalty to leadership"). They point, too, to the appalling way that the New Nation was managed, and at Sisulu's very poor relationship with journalists there.

But the SABC, and the South African broadcasting sector, have often proved themselves to be better producers of bile and gossip than programming. How fair is the flak Sisulu gets?

Certainly, I have found myself riveted to the screen almost every single night since the relaunch ten days ago. I've seen some brilliant documentaries (mainly from Britain); some great old movies (Midnight Cowboy); some inspired magazine programmes (the Channel 4/SABC co-production, Africa Express, on Monday nights); and more than a little lunacy masquerading as language policy - like the debate between Jacob Zuma and Frank Mdlalose last Thursday. The two native Zulu speakers, after having been introduced in Setswana, spoke English to each other.

Never mind the Babelish proportions of it all and the fact that non-Setswana speakers mightn't even think to tune in -thereby missing a critical debate. Far more worrying is the dishonesty of it all: that programme was as much Setswana-speaking as I am.

Then there's the local content issue: a cursory glance at Wednesday's schedules reveals that, out of 24 hours of viewing on SABC1, only two and three-quarters are locally produced: of that, only one and a half were produced externally, outside the SABC. Much the same is the case on SABC3, and the ratios on SABC2 are only slightly better. Sisulu answers these and other criticisms of the schedule with the rote -but not unacceptable- response that "we are building capacity".

As to the criticism that the launch sent the wrong message in having both President Mandela and broadcasting minister Pallo Jordan offering perorations, he is unswayed: "We couldn't do better tactically than getting the President and Pallo to say, in their own words, that the independence of the public broadcaster is inviolate."

But Mandela said something else too: he called Sisulu "Comrade Zwelakhe". It was more likely the collegial greeting to the son of his oldest friend than the deliberate attempt to make a political point, but the effect was nonetheless the same. Which brings us back to marching versus writing, or, in this case, broadcasting.

Sisulu's record - party loyalist or free-expression warrior - is ambivalent. Launching WASA at a conference in 1980, he maintained that all journalists were "propagandists" - the question was simply whether "one is a collaborationist propagandist or a revolutionary propagandist ... if expressing the aspirations of the people is propagandist ... then surely we are propagandists."

His role at the New Nation was unmistakably one of publicising the ANC; not inappropriate, given the ANC's banning. But, says one senior journalist who worked with him there, "as soon as things started getting more complicated, and there were a number of conflicting ANC positions, he found himself in trouble". The paper, for example, steered well clear of the Winnie Mandela controversy - another instance of Sisulu's life being complicated by his family connections.

Certainly, at the moment of the ANC's unbanning, Sisulu - also unbanned - connected immediately with his mother-movement; working as Mandela's first press attache. Later, though, he stalled when offered the editorship of the ANC's ill-fated daily newspaper: he was apparently uncomfortable with the control that would be wielded from Shell House.

Now, at the SABC, he is under constant pressure from government. A revealing incident took place at the time of Joe Slovo's death. TV news had, ill-advisedly, decided to broadcast only an hour of the state funeral. Sisulu received calls from dozens of parliamentarians demanding that the whole event be screened from start to finish. According to sources at Auckland Park, Mandela even phoned, and Sisulu - knowing that he would not be able to say "no" to the Old Man - told his secretary to say he was unavailable. The eventual decision, taken by the chief executive himself, was based entirely on "newsworthiness": the proceedings were screened for only two hours.

Zwelakhe Sisulu feels that the relaunch of television was yet another watershed for him: he confesses to having been terrified that "it might not happen", but, now that it has, he clearly feels more confident. One of his senior managers feels that "he is growing in confidence, now that he believes this job isn't beyond him after all".

One senses, too, that he has also grown weary of marching, and desperately wants to start writing again. Whatever his future trajectory - first black editor of the Sunday Times, member of Parliament, political columnist - he is unmistakably part of the new ruling elite, tied by the umbilical cord to South Africa's destiny. Two of his siblings, Max and Lindiwe, chair portfolio committees in Parliament; his sister-in-law, Sheila, is special adviser to the Minister of Education and a member of the SABC board.

Pippa Green wrote about the Sisulus in Leadership in 1990 that you could "measure the political climate" of apartheid South Africa by the Sisulu family's "suffering, its fears, and its hopes". That was at the moment when the family was reunited after 30 years of exile, imprisonment and perpetual harassment.

Now, perhaps, you can measure this land's reconstruction, and the vagaries of the new black power elite, by the Sisulu family's current achievements. Unlike that lift that takes you to Zwelakhe Sisulu's 28th floor office, things are going up quickly. It's kind of hard to get off, even if deep down you think you might want to.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Election Losers Line Up Against ANC


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Vuyo Mvoko


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Johannesburg - Opposition parties in Soweto have come together in an attempt to rob the African National Congress of its dominion over local politics. But, already, it's not plain sailing.

The Community Alliance Councillors (CAC) is a coalition of former candidates of minority political parties who clubbed together on their own accord after they were trounced by the ANC in the local government elections last year. 

For the past couple of weeks they have been meeting regularly at a Soweto secondary school. Now they believe they have found that elusive formula which might pave the way for a national initiative.

In what they presume will be a massive show of strength, on February 17 they will be holding a rally at the Jabulani Amphitheatre in Soweto, where leaders of minority political parties whose members serve in the structure are scheduled to speak.

The executive committee of the coalition, however, is hitting snags already.

The alliance is dominated by the Democratic Party and draws also from the Pan Africanist Congress; from a horde of "community-based organisations" which mushroomed just before the elections - such as the South African Residents Association (Sara) and the Community Indaba, as well as from the Inkatha Freedom Party and the National Party.

A vengeful Inkatha Freedom Party is partially inside, still busy hitting out at its Soweto leaders like Timothy Mtshali who, prior to the elections last year, dumped the IFP branch chairmanship and stood on the card of Sara. Mtshali is on the coalition's executive committee.

According to IFP spokesman and Gauteng MPL Humphrey Ndlovu, Sara was meant to have been the IFP's "surrogate and younger sister" but, "to our surprise", it was not to be.

Ndlovu feels such things need to be cleared first, although he said he "instructed" his party members to attend the coalition's meetings, "while we are planning to sit down and discuss it fully".

The NP, on the other hand, has expressed doubts and reservations. But the party's Ben Madumise is also on the coalition's executive.

What initially gave birth to the coalition, according to organiser Sam Makurube, was solidarity. "We were harassed just for being members of the DP and for putting up posters."

As to what will happen beyond the 17th and whether the respective political parties will be able fund the coalition's programmes to weaken the ANC, Mtshali said "we cannot divulge anything at this stage, but we have something".

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Black Nats Try To Fill The Vacuum


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Vuyo Mvoko


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Johannesburg - Vusumuzi Vincent Thusi, a Gauteng National Party MPL, gazes up at the pictures on the walls of his party's reception room in the chamber, then smiles wryly at the unfolding contradiction.

"Do you remember those chaps?" he asks, pointing at the huge pictures of Hendrik Verwoerd, Hans Strydom, DF Malan, and PW Botha. "They are the ones who thought we would vanish from the face of this earth. This party must bury all those photographs." 

Thusi is one of the new recruits to a political party still haunted by its ugly past and desperate to fill a vacuum in opposition politics.

To achieve its goals, many believe the NP needs to strengthen its credibility among black voters, as well as show that its transformation is more than cosmetic.

NP leader and deputy state president FW De Klerk announced lrecently that plans are afoot for a new-look party. He announced that Roelf Meyer, Minister of Constitutional Affairs, will relinquish his position at the end of this month to focus on rejuvenating the party as its first secretary general.

But, as black NP parliamentary representatives admitted this week, the roughest road still lies ahead.

Says Thusi: "We have a lot of white people who, for a long time, were living a different lifestyle and felt that blacks were not really human beings. Now, coming into the party, I am fighting to make them break loose of that attitude."

He adds: "I must be honest with you. Some do not share the same ideals that De Klerk and some of the top leadership share. Some still feel that, as a minority white grouping, they can do something, but fortunately they are in the minority."

In parliamentary discussions, the party sometimes puts its black members in awkward situations which have a serious impact on their attempts to recruit for the party in the townships.

Senator David Malatsi, the most senior black in the NP, blames this on the fact that the party sometimes criticises where it should not, like lashing out at RDP minister Jay Naidoo.

Not that the NP should not criticise "non-delivery of certain issues", Malatsi argues, but it should bear in mind that the RDP is meant to "redress imbalances of the past". Although some of the criticism is valid, he says, it is often "not communicated properly".

Malatsi is deputy leader of the NP in Mpumalanga, and is mooted as a possible candidate for the post of deputy speaker, which is to be vacated by Dr Bhadra Ranchod who will be taking up a diplomatic post.

The dilemma of black NP leaders, however, stretches beyond the friendlier walls of Parliament to the attitudes of some of their colleagues in the dusty townships, where "the spirit of tolerance cultivated by President Nelson Mandela and Deputy President FW de Klerk has not, as yet, permeated", according to Malatsi, where the main problem he has encountered is the "intolerance of the ANC alliance structures on the ground".

Has the NP really changed? "It has changed," insists Thusi, "it's just that the baggage of the past is too much for people to realise that."

The biggest problem faced by the black Nats is credibility. Says Thusi: "If you speak on behalf of the NP, to a very large extent you are not talking policies but race."

"The NP has really shed its past. It's just the perception that still exists. People still see old Nats who were known for certain things which were hurting black people."

'When I looked at what De Klerk wanted to achieve, I felt 'here is one leader, white leader, who has led his people, taking them from those dark ages of apartheid, of Verwoerd and all those guys. He is trying to bring reconciliation, I must try to assist (him)."

To assist De Klerk, Thusi joined the NP in 1993 from the dungeon of the discredited black local authorities, of which he was a councillor despite, by his own admission, "knowing full well that the structure was illegitimate". But he has no regrets: "I had to respond to the calling of the people who voted for me."

Regarding the possible change of the party's name and of forging alliances, he agrees there has to be a move, "even if it means we must leave the NP to form a new movement with new norms and standards".

His dream party will first have to "submit" itself to God, "whether we call him Allah or in Hindu". Secondly, it must look after minorities. "A Venda who comes to Gauteng should not find that the Zulus are dominating.

"If we bash the whites for merely being white and for belonging to the NP, we'll lose a lot of expertise.

'We need more people of colour, who must come into the party and hold them (whites who want to leave the country) by the hand and say: 'Look, you are part and parcel of South Africa in spite of all the wrongs you have done.'"

The question of a black leader for the NP? "It's a simplistic way of looking into the matter. A mere black face will not help. What will help is when the power is with the people.

"This process (of a rejuvenated NP) will breed a new leadership which will change the terrain of our political spectrum.

"We need to inculcate a new mindset into our political terrain. As things are now, we are moving towards a one-party state, which is not good for our fledging democracy."

Malatsi adds that the NP needs to be proactive, otherwise, if it concentrates on being in opposition, "it will remain so even when there is nothing to oppose".


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Mandela Calls MPs To Order Over Language


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela has cracked the whip in the African National Congress's parliamentary caucus with a ferocity that took MPs aback and left some bruises.

In a strongly worded address to the first caucus meeting of the year, he warned MPs not to act in ways that could destroy, in one stroke, months of painstaking effort at fostering national reconciliation - and reminded them that "nobody is above the ANC".

The focus of his anger was a recommendation made last month by Parliament's Joint Standing Committee on Defence that English replace Afrikaans as the language of command in the South African National Defence Force. 

Singling out committee chair, firebrand Tony Yengeni, for a stinging rebuke, he spoke of the effort he had put into building national reconciliation and his concern that it could be undone by a single action.

Mandela was addressing the caucus last Thursday, the day before he delivered the opening parliamentary address that called on South Africans to rally behind a new patriotism and work together to make the country a winning nation.

It is understood that Mandela was furious about the way the matter was handled by the committee and particularly angry that he had not been consulted before any announcement was made on an issue he is said to view as a matter of extreme national importance.

Informing the committee's recommendation on language was a belief that by maintaining Afrikaans as the language of command and instruction, new SANDF members who did not speak the language would be disadvantaged in terms of their integration and promotion in the defence force.

Mandela intervened swiftly after the committee announced its recommendations, which included the suggestion that no religion be imposed in the SANDF and that there be no discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation. It is known that he met Defence Minister Joe Modise and his deputy, Ronnie Kasrils, as well as SANDF chief George Meiring, who issued internal SANDF communication bulletins to the effect that these decisions were not final and that the status quo would remain.

Mandela later told a gathering of leaders of Afrikaans women's organisations that he had told the committee it was "completely wrong" and that if one wanted to "reduce the country to ashes", one had only to tamper with the language of a group.

His message in caucus was that MPs should realise they were in government because they had been put there by the poorest of the poor, and that nobody could put themselves above ANC policy.

He outlined to the caucus all the efforts he had made to bring Afrikaners into the new political order and accept reconciliation, listing all the disparate Afrikaans groups which he had met. He warned MPs that he would not allow individuals to destroy these efforts and pledged to stop them from doing so.

Committee member Lindiwe Sisulu Guma was also singled out. Mandela addressed her as "my daughter", but surprised those present with the directness accompanying his attack. Other committee members allegedly named by Mandela were Linda Mti and Thenjiwe Mtintso.

One caucus member, who declined to be named, said that Mandela was right in what he said "but when the old man goes over the top, he really goes all the way over".

Approached for comment, Guma said the issue was "too sensitive". Yengeni also declined to comment.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Nats Seek New Path To Opposition


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Johannesburg - The National Party has caved in on its central constitutional demand and the African National Congress says it does not believe it will be challenged by the Nats in wrapping up negotiations on the final Constitution.

While the Inkatha Freedom Party and the drafting of Kwazulu-Natal's provincial Constitution and its re-entry into the Constitutional Assembly remain a perpetual headache to the ANC, the NP is laughed about behind its back, and ANC MPs talk openly about the Nats' "stupidity".

This week, Constitutional Development Minister Roelf Meyer asked the negotiators in the Constitutional Assembly to scrap the clause in the draft final Constitution which would entrench power-sharing after 1999 - a central demand in the NP's constitutional package. 

ANC negotiators say they are bemused at how easily the Nats conceded this principle and have developed a newfound contempt for them for not putting up more of a fight.

Said ANC negotiator Dirk Du Toit: "The NP has no big constitutional vision left and it is too late for it to develop another ... it has nothing left to trade."

'That's cheap politicking," retorted Meyer this week. " I don't know what the ANC is talking about. The Constitution does not only consist of the Government of National Unity - there is a whole variety of checks and balances we want in the Constitution, which we have put into our submissions. There are other alternatives on the table. All we have conceded is that the model of the GNU as it now stands should not be continued. You can't be in a GNU and be an opposition party, it goes against the grain."

Some of the most important checks and balances on executive power will be vested in provincial governments and the debate on this chapter of the final Constitution continues behind the scenes. These bilaterals, however, are characterised by growing consensus rather than party political disputes.

The sacrifice of the GNU principle reflects the belated drive within the NP to become an effective opposition party. It reflects the realisation that he who attempts to have his cake and eat it - be within the GNU and oppose it from within Cabinet - ends up with the crumbs.

This was apparent in FW de Klerk's first speech in Parliament this year. He drooped to new impotence when he pleaded with the ANC to recognise in its government partner an opposition worthy of respect.

"Please listen to what I say," he said to mocking ANC MPs in the National Assembly, "and then debate with us ... on the basis of what we are - and not on the basis of taking pot-shots at the distorted image of us that you yourselves have created."

Democratic Party leader Tony Leon is chuckling at the NP's first real attempts to establish itself in opposition.

"FW is like an ugly person on a first date, trying to talk his way past his face - 'I have inner beauty,' he's saying ... it's all rather pathetic."

Scrapping the GNU clause from the Constitution means that De Klerk and his better-looking crown prince Roelf Meyer will ultimately have to rely on the crumbs from the ANC's table until they develop the sort of inner resilience, spite and spunk that being an opposition party demands. If there is anybody in the NP who realises this, it is Meyer, whose withdrawal from Cabinet indicates that he would rather develop the National Party's power base through working in civil society than cling to a seat in an ANC-dominated Cabinet.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

February, 1996


South Africa Call For Probe Into Cross-border Raids


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - An African National Congress MP, who spent 11 years in exile in Mozambique, has written to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission urging it to "get to the bottom" of cross-border raids and attacks during the apartheid era.

Rob Davies, formerly a researcher at the Centre for African Studies in Maputo, analysed the war waged by the former regime against South African exiles and neighbouring countries.

Questions Davies wants answered include:

l Who authorised South African Defence Force (SADF) support for Renamo and what, if any, rules of engagement or operational orders applied, given the numerous atrocities committed by Renamo troops against Mozambican civilians? Co-ordinated by the Department of Special Tasks 2 of the Chief of Staff Intelligence of the SADF through an operation code-named Mila, this support was supposed to have ended with the 1984 signing of the Nkomati Accord. Two accused in the Malan trial were involved: Colonel Cornelius Johannes van Niekerk and Colonel Cornelius Jacobus van Tonder. 

l Who authorised continued support for Renamo? The "Gorongosa documents" captured at Renamo headquarters in 1985 mentioned generals Constand Viljoen, Jannie Geldenhuys, PJ van der Westhuizen, Kat Liebenberg as well as a Major Philllips who worked with Renamo in Malawi.

* What role did SADF personnel play in supporting Renamo and on whose orders? Who ordered the use of specialist saboteur teams - including a mid-1987 push which resulted in massacres of hundreds of civilians at Homoine and Manjacaze?

* What operational orders were given and what were the rules of engagement in the Matola raid in 1981, the first of a series of attacks on "ANC bases" - homes in a suburb outside Maputo?

* What are the long-term consequences for the victims of the 1983 South African Air Force raid in which the creche of a jam factory bore the brunt of an attack on what the SADF claimed was a "terrorist base"?

* What was the role of Cabinet-level decision-making in cross-border raids? What was the role of then foreign minister Pik Botha and his depatment? If there was Cabinet-level decision-making, did it also involve the head of the government, PW Botha?

Davies has offered to make documentary and research material he has collected available to the commision.
