Africa News


February, 1996


Rwanda and South Africa Arms Embarrassment At UN Security Council


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Johannesburg - The Department of Foreign Affairs admits a "communication problem" delayed co-operation with a United Nations commission investigating embargo-busting arms exports - from South Africa, among others - to Rwanda's defeated Hutu army.

The delay, which embarrassed South Africa at the UN's Security Council, is the latest hitch in efforts to clamp down on illicit arms trafficking to and from South Africa, and to clean up the country's image as an international arms rogue.

The lack of effective law enforcement to ensure compliance with South Africa's new arms control policy is understood to be a key issue in the second report to President Nelson Mandela by the Cameron Commission, appointed in 1994 to investigate illegal weapons trading. The report, delivered to Mandela late last year, has not yet been made public. 

Department of Foreign Affairs liaison staff this week said inadequate "communication" at South Africa's New York UN mission appeared to be the reason the government had not responded to a request for information from the UN investigative commission.

Foreign Affairs Deputy Director General Abdul Minty said: "We are trying to find out what happened, because it would be bad for us to appear not to want to give an answer."

The UN Security Council established the investigative commission last September after allegations that its arms embargo against the former Rwandan government's army was not complied with.

The allegations, first made by the US-based Human Rights Watch, included that South African officials, said to be members of the Armscor old-guard, had helped arrange a 1994 arms consignment from the Seychelles to forces of the former Hutu government, and that clandestine consignments were flown directly from South Africa early last year. The Hutu army and allied militias perpetrated most of the 1994 genocide in the Central African nation, and have been exiled in neighbouring Zaire since their defeat at the hands of the Rwanda Patriotic Front later that year.

Lack of co-operation with the commission almost led to its premature closure, when UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, in a letter accompanying the commission's interim report to the Security Council on January 29, recommended the commission be disbanded, apparently because of its lack of progress.

That report of the commission said it was "persuaded" the allegations were true, but that it had been unable to gather sufficient evidence. The report singled out China, South Africa and the Seychelles as not having responded to requests, made in November and early December, for information.

Last week the Security Council, against Boutros-Ghali's advice, extended the life of the commission and resolved to protest formally to countries not co-operating. The commission has, in the meantime, visited the Seychelles, where it is understood to have found information supporting the allegations against South Africans.

Meanwhile, the Cameron Commission is soon to start its own investigation into the Rwanda allegations - but after a six-month delay. A request from the commission in the middle of last year for permission to appoint an investigative arm to look at the claims was approved by Cabinet last year, but the commission was notified only last month.

Commissioner Laurie Nathan said this week policemen had been approached and were willing to serve as investigators.

Nathan said while South African arms control procedures had been reformed, they were not policed adequately, and that responsibilities seemed not to have been assigned. "In the view of the Cameron Commission, enforcement agencies, including the police, intelligence agencies and Customs and Excise, should have a formal brief to monitor the flow of arms into and out of South Africa, investigate allegations of illegal traffic in arms, and should be formally incorporated into the government's arms control system."

One of the weaker links in arms control is South Africa's smaller airports, a number of which have no customs presence after hours - a problem government has been aware of for a while. It is understood the National Intelligence Agency monitored some airports after the Human Rights Watch allegations were made in May last year, and found unscheduled cargo flights - which could have been carrying arms or other contraband - were indeed taking place.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


246 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Justice Minister Wants To Dilute Human Rights


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by David Beresford


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Johannesburg - The Minister of Justice, Dullah Omar, wants key elements in the Constitution protecting individual rights watered down to facilitate the government's fight against crime.

Omar said on Thursday that he would support amendments to the Chapter of Rights protecting citizens' rights to privacy, freedom of information, and the rights of an accused to bail and legal representation. He also indicated that he supported a tougher stand in dealing with pornography, saying adults needed to be protected from it. 

In a statement presented at a parliamentary briefing session for journalists, Omar conceded that his proposed dilution of fundamental rights was "controversial". But he said that "a starry-eyed and over-romantic approach to the question of rights is costing our country too dearly."

The minister cited three sections of the Constitution which he said were giving an advantage to criminals:

l Section 13, which says that "every person shall have the right to his or her personal privacy, which shall include the right not to be subject to searches of his or her person, home or property, the seizure of private possessions or the violation of personal communications"

l Section 23, which says "every person shall have the right to access of all information held by the state or any of its organs at any level of government insofar as such information is required for the exercise, or protection, of any of his or her rights"

l A section making provision for an arrested person to be released with or without bail "unless the interests of justice require otherwise", and for legal representation of a person's choice "where substantial injustice would otherwise result".

Omar also suggested that Section 33 of the Constitution - a limitation clause on certain rights - should be reviewed "to give the state greater capacity to fight crime by imposing reasonable limitations".

Questioned about the justification for limiting freedom of information, Omar said it was particularly important, in dealing with the prosecution of organised crime, that suspects do not have access to police dockets "at a crucial period of investigation".

He also supported critics of the government's latest censorship Bill who regard it as too permissive.

"I am for freedom and individual liberty, but I do think there is a need to protect children; there is even a need to protect adults", said Omar.

"We need to look very critically at the Bill, to ensure that we are not just giving the green light to pornography. Maybe I am very conservative in that regard, but that is my view."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Assembly Speaker Irks MPs


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Johannesburg - Frustration among African National Congress MPs about the way Parliament is functioning is focusing on the role of the Speaker in the National Assembly, ANC MP Frene Ginwala - said to be "about as popular as a rattlesnake in a lucky dip" among members of her own party.

Criticisms that were only whispered during the strains of last year's session - with a Parliament that had a radically new way of operating, but had still to reform its staffing and structures in order to cope - have now reached a crescendo.

In the corridors this week there was talk that at least three ANC whips wanted to resign and that committee chairs - the overwhelming majority of whom are ANC MPs - were reaching the end of their tethers. It has been widely rumoured that Deputy Speaker Dr Bhadra Ranchod's decision to quit for a diplomatic post lay in part with differences he had with Ginwala's approach. 

Acutely aware of the gossip and backbiting, Ginwala said this week: "People forget I was elected by caucus. I was not appointed by the ANC. It was a contested election. If I lost the confidence of caucus I would resign."

She had been prepared to answer to criticisms at an ANC caucus meeting last year and had gone to it prepared to do so, she said. "The issues were not raised."

Unlike past speakers who left Parliament's running to the secretariat and its civil servants, Ginwala swept into office determined to reshape the institution.

Her hands-on approach brings her into regular contact with staff, whips and committee chairs and thus also exposes her to criticism. No one questions her efficiency, but her management style is described as high-handed and autocratic. Critics say this results in people feeling disempowered and frustrated.

But there are those who defend her. "Many of the frustrations people are experiencing are not her fault, but lie with the administration. She sets very high standards and this doesn't go down well with a lot of people. But the honeymoon is over and we have to get to work," said an ANC whip. "People should also question whether the whips are functioning as they should."

Ginwala's chief problem appears to be a lack of communication within Parliament itself. There is widespread confusion about the massive R82,7-million transformation project she is driving. Democratic Party leader Tony Leon says she is "building an empire" and wants to know to whom she answers.

The political agreement she forged before seeking foreign funding appears fragile.

It was agreed that Parliament should be funded from public coffers as a matter of policy and that any private funding should be temporary, with any costs arising phased into Parliament's budget over three years. But within ANC ranks there is lingering concern at the message this sends about the possibility of undue foreign influence on Parliament.

A major area of dispute revolves around the functioning of portfolio and ad hoc committees in terms of their scheduling and funding, and their relationship with the executive and the National Assembly.

Committee chairs want funds to pay for support such as researchers and also to perform duties other than processing legislation - such as attending conferences, making foreign trips, visiting the provinces and arranging public hearings on Bills.

Chaotic arrangements last year saw the house repeatedly in want of a forum because members were in committee. Members of minority parties found themselves required to be at several meetings simultaneously.

Ginwala's attempts to have a line drawn between the work of the National Assembly and that of committees and her unyielding grip on the purse strings has not endeared her, and it has been suggested that she is involved in a power struggle, determined not to allow the committees -- a powerful bloc - to undermine her. She dismisses this. Committee requests for funding go not through her but a separate committee.

"Last year I instituted fortnightly meetings with the chief whips, saying I needed to consult on a range of issues. Every single thing has gone through them. It is not my responsibility to consult with individual MPs," Ginwala said.

"There was no political agreement on how committees should be funded. A committee was set up and tasked to draw up guidelines and regulations on the funding of portfolio and ad hoc committees.

"This committee, chaired by the chief whip of the majority party, was set up in March last year. It has not yet produced any regulations."

Guidelines were necessary because there was no common view on the role of committees and their relationship with the National Assembly, Ginwala said. Key questions, including ethically fraught issues such as whether committee chairs should be allowed to raise funds from foreign donors or private companies, were among a range of questions that had yet to be answered.

Ginwala admits there are flaws in the transformation project documents: they were drawn up against a tight deadline to negotiate funding from foreign donors. Any problems would be worked out during implementation, she said.

MPs returned to Parliament for the new session with the hope that last year's problems would have been sorted out and that they would have support in the form of administrative and research back-up. Staff are being appointed and help is on its way. But a lack of communication is compounding frustrations.

ANC chief whip Reverend Arnold Stofile would not respond to questions about tensions between him and Ginwala. "I would rather say that we in Parliament are many MPs who had not worked together before. Naturally there are bound to be tensions from time to time, but we are dealing with this." He denied "categorically" that there were ANC whips who wanted to resign.

ANC whip Jannie Momberg said: "If whips or chairs have problems with the speaker, they should be aired in forums where they meet."

DP whip Douglas Gibson said: "You just have to compare her with other speakers - like Louis le Grange - and thank heaven for the new South Africa."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


248 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa Who'll Get Amnesty, And Who Won't?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) February 16, 1996 by Jacko Maree (Column)


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Johannesburg - It has been reported that the Amnesty Committee of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission has already received 2 000 applications for amnesty. The question is: "Who will receive amnesty and who will not?"

To establish an acceptable amnesty test will be a very difficult task for the committee, because the granting of amnesty since 1990 has been a messy and dishonest affair. Direct political interference, double standards, blackmail, secrecy and unlawful administrative acts all featured strongly in the granting of amnesty to date. To develop an acceptable amnesty test, the committee must, in terms of truth commission legislation, take cognisance of criteria applied in the past. 

In terms of the legislation, the committee must grant amnesty if the offence committed was done for political reasons, in proportion, and therefore justified, if weighed against the political objective that was pursued.

The committee, therefore, has to work, firstly, with a very vague proportionality test.

In Namibia, Professor Norgaard developed a set of rules to help establish when amnesty could be granted and when not. Many Namibians who had committed political offences were not granted amnesty because their deeds were judged to have been too serious and, therefore, out of proportion to the political objective pursued.

Secondly, the committee is charged to apply the norms that were used to grant amnesty in terms of the 1990 and 1992 Indemnity Acts. This will cause the committee enormous headaches, because the proportionality norm (Norgaard Principles) and the other norms used in terms of the 1990 and 1992 Indemnity Acts are not compatible.

To understand the committee's problem fully, we must revisit the past.

The 1990 Indemnity Act states that "for the sake of reconciliation and for the finding of peaceful solutions" amnesty had to be granted. The upshot of this was that thousands of prisoners - the exact figure is unknown - benefited. These prisoners received the normal one-third remission of their sentence, but, in addition to that, they received one full year simply because they were "related" to the African National Congress (ANC). Prisoners who belonged to other political parties did not and could not benefit from this strange remission arrangement.

In addition to the thousands who received remission, many others were granted amnesty. Initially, the Norgaard Principles were applied. More than 8 000 ANC members automatically received indemnity because they fell into certain categories and 1 400 applicants, all ANC members, were released on an individual basis.

But, the ANC were still not satisfied. They rejected the application of the Norgaard Principles and requested the release of all "political" prisoners. The government, however, was adamant that the Norgaard Principles should be applied and a stalemate ensued. The ANC then walked out of the Codesa talks in June 1992 and insisted that 350 prisoners - the names of whom it published - should be released before it would return to the negotiating table. In response, the 1992 Indemnity Act was passed. A new test to qualify for indemnity was developed.

In terms of the new test, a prisoner had to be released if the release might "promote reconciliation and peaceful solutions". Robert McBride, Barend Strydom and others who had received the death penalty or life sentences were released. A total of 168 long-term prisoners, nearly all of them affiliated to the ANC, benefited. With few exceptions, all of them had been sentenced for murder, and even multiple murders. The party returned to the negotiating table.

After the April 1994 elections, Minister of Justice Dullah Omar appointed the Currin Committee to attend to pending amnesty applications which were lodged before May 6 1994.

The committee carried out its task in the most extraordinary manner imaginable. It arranged for 56 people who were sentenced, but not in jail, to receive remission, 86 prisoners who were in jail were released and 104 people who had not yet been sentenced received indemnity.

The committee acted outside its mandate by arranging for amnesty to be granted to people whose applications had previously been rejected and, therefore, were not pending. They also granted amnesty to criminals who had committed crimes of a non-political nature. The many non-political prisoners released included the following: Jabulani Khubeka, ANC, sentenced after the death of Stompie Seipei; Elian Mabena, ANC, robbed and shot the owner of a taxi; EK Mabilu, ANC, sentenced in 1994 to 18 years imprisonment for killing people he believed to be witches.

The common feature of the criminals released by the Currin Committee is that, with very few exceptions, all were ANC members or ANC sympathisers.

The committee has been most kind to the ANC and its followers. It is not surprising that the ANC component in the Justice Committee has decided to protect the Currin Committee as best it can and has, to date, refused all requests to have the curious conduct of the committee investigated.

Minister of Justice Dullah Omar has also come to the defence of the Currin Committee. He said in Parliament, when he was questioned about the erratic behaviour of the committee, that he was very happy with its work!

At present, most ANC members or sympathisers have already received amnesty or indemnity. They are immune, therefore, from criteria the Amnesty Committee may apply. The only exceptions are the 77 top-echelon ANC members, like Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and ministers Joe Modise and Pallo Jordan, who were granted temporary indemnity. The Amnesty Committee will have to deal mainly with security force applicants, their ANC opponents having escaped the net.

The relevant legislation demands that the committee ensure an even-handed approach between those who have already received amnesty and those who still have to receive it.

The committee will have to make a close study of what happened during our recent history of amnesty granting. They will find inexplicable, unlawful and sordid things have occurred. How will this influence them? What criteria will they develop out of this chaos? We will all be watching with great interest.

Jacko Maree is a National Party MP and a member of the Justice Sub Committee.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Religious Freedom Media Network To Close Down


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 16, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Nairobi - A major church news agency, the News Network International (NNI), ceases operation soon owing to a financial crisis.

The network has over the last several years concentrated on highlighting the plight of the suffering Church worldwide, supporting the rights of individuals to hold their religious beliefs and has provided background information for lobby groups of religious freedom.

In a letter dated February 8 to correspondents of the news agency, the Publisher and Chairman of the Board of Directors Mr. Richard Burow said funding priorities by a major donor of the NNI had changed and the news agency will no longer receive an annual grant. There was not enough time to look for alternative funding and so the board made the decision to close down permanently. 

"There is no doubt that NNI has made a lasting impact on the importance of reporting on religious freedom issues. The rights of individuals are important and I believe we have successfully made many aware of what happens when nothing is said in the face of great injustice," said Mr. Burow in his letter.

The agency which officially closes its doors on February 29, 1996 has supplied news and information to editors globally, filling the void in reporting on the church around the world and its particular problems and concerns.

NNI has keenly reported on the conflicts and persecution of Christians in Muslim dominated countries and harassment against the church. The aim has been to support the cause of the voiceless and the persecuted church.

The agency has had an editorial staff of close to 20 people scattered all over the globe. Major supporters have included foundations, organizations and individuals.

Said Mr. Burow: "We trust we have provided a valuable service to those who have not had a voice or access to the media...As scripture states so well, for everything there is a season and NNI has had quite a season."

The agency published a bi-monthly news and feature service by the same title and a monthly in depth feature service "Perspective".


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

February, 1996


Sierra Leone National Conference Wants Elections As Scheduled


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Freetown - A national consultative conference in Sierra Leone has voted to go ahead with elections scheduled for February 26, despite pleas from Head of State Brigadier Julius Maada Bio and Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels for a postponement.

At the same time the government and rebels have agreed to send delegations to Ivory Coast for talks on February 28, two days after the planned elections, to end the five-year-old civil war. 

Addressing the conference in the capital, Freetown, last week, Brigadier Bio urged delegates to postpone the presidential and parliamentary elections until after talks had been held with the rebels as the latter had requested.

But reports say 80 delegates from political parties and civilian groups rejected the delay and urged the government to proceed with the polls. Brigadier Maada Bio, who seized power in a bloodless coup on January 16 this year, agreed to hold talks with rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, during a radio conversation the two men had last week.

Sankoh called for the postponement, saying with the raging civil war, it was useless to hold elections. "Without peace in the country, the elections will prove futile," he said during their conversation.

He denounced politicians as corrupt and blamed them for Sierra Leone's problems.

Meanwhile, as the date of elections approaches, tension is mounting in the capital with attacks reported on election officials and arrests of some political party leaders for unspecified charged.

Late last week, it was reported that unidentified gunman in Freetown attacked the home of the national Electoral Commission Chairman, Mr. James Jonah, and the commission offices. No one was hurt in the grenade and gun incident.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Zimbabwe Complaints About President's Foreign Trips


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Harare - Zimbabweans at home are asking serious questions about President Robert Mugabe's unlimited trips abroad.

Zimbabweans, suffering from the effects of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank inspired economic reforms want their leader to cut foreign trips to save scarce funds.

Famous writer and winner of the prestigious Commonwealth Noma Award for publishing in Africa, Chenjerai Hove, in an opinion article published in the weekly Financial Gazette here recently wrote; "Despite the fact that this Government is clearly broke, the nation is continually informed of our President travelling to all sorts of places." 

Hove said the expenses are borne by a nation struggling to feed itself, a nation that has lost the worth of its citizens. "Our nation would like the president to remain in the country to go around the country talking with various sectors of the leadership of this country at all levels, seeking solutions to our problems."

In a letter to the editor of the Sunday Gazette, one writer complained bitterly about the President's trips abroad. He wrote: "I wish to register dissatisfaction with the way the Government is handling its monetary affairs. I have read in newspapers about ministries being ordered to be very strict about their expenditure, public investment programmes being suspended for lack of money and the health budget being cut by Zimbabwe dollars 23 million (US dollars 240,000), all this is being done in the name of reducing Government expenditure, fair and fine but I feel the Government should take stern measures in the reduction of overseas travels by Government officials including the President."

The writer said he thought the President is travelling more than necessary. Concluded the writer: "We have tightened our belts beyond limit and our waists are about to rapture."

Opposition politician Wururayi Zembe, Secretary-General of the Democratic Party (DP) said President Mugabe's trips abroad can be likened to an "absentee landlord. Mugabe is hardly in the country for consecutive 30 days," said angry Zembe.

An irate newspaper vendor had these harsh words for the President: "Why then appoint ministers if he (President) wants to do everything by himself. Why are there two vice-presidents for a small country like Zimbabwe, why do we have foreign missions and why do we have the Ministry of Foreign Affairs." The southern African country has a population of some 9 million people.

The vendor said Zimbabwe is a poor country which cannot afford such visits. The vendor added; "Why can't Mugabe behave like (President) Bakili Muluzi of Malawi who could not go to other meetings of Heads of State because his country did not have money?"

"How can Mugabe justify that the government has no money for the Zambezi water project to bring water to the people of Matebeleland," asked one Bulawayo (in the south) city resident who has endured water rationing for the past three years. Another Bulawayo resident who only gave his name as Victor for fear of victimization, said he was disappointed by the attitude of the government which was painting itself good outside while its people were suffering.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Meeting Calls for Emphasis on Causes of Conflict


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 16, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Nyeri, Kenya - Peace building in Africa should emphasize the structural causes of conflict, delegates to a meeting here, marking the 12th anniversary of the Nairobi Peace Initiative (NPI) have recommended.

The 50 delegates, meeting in this Central Province town, some 170 kilometres north of the capital, Nairobi also stressed the need to promote capacity building in order to develop Africa's capabilities to deal with conflicts. They were drawn from different countries in Africa, Europe and the Americas. 

Peace education, directed at everyone particularly the youth and strategy development through information sharing and analysis should also be developed, the delegates meeting here from January 28 to February 1 further recommended.

On its part, the NPI shared its views for establishing a long-term educational programme for peace in Africa.

"The programme is aimed at assisting co-workers in various conflict situations to play roles of mediators, peacemakers, reconcilers, healers, peace builders, thinkers and trainers," said Mr. George Wachira, a programme officer at the NPI.

NPI which works closely with churches and Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) dealing with peace issues, was instituted in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi in 1984, under the name-Nairobi Peace Group.

Its formation then was seen as a response to events in the Horn of Africa. In that year, massive drought swept through much of the continent and its effects were felt mostly in the Horn of Africa where thousands of lives were lost as a result of starvation.

An international NGO, whose aim is to promote peaceful resolution of large-scale social conflicts in Africa, NPI was started by concerned Nairobi-based scholars and church leaders as a discussion and reflection group to explore ways of addressing chronic conflicts in the region.

The name, Nairobi Peace Initiative was adopted in 1989. Over the years, the initial Nairobi Peace Group has grown from a discussion group to an organisation that undertakes peacemaking and reconciliation roles in many civil wars and countries in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


253 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Pope Sends Greetings To Muslims Worldwide


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Vatican - Pope John Paul II has sent a message of congratulations to Muslims the world over as they mark Idd-Ul-Fitr, a feast celebrated at the end of the holy month of Ramadhan.

In his message, released by Nigerian Cardinal Francis Arinze, who heads the Pontifical Council for Inter-Religious Dialogue, here, the Pope observed; "For us as Christians and Muslims to reach beyond tolerance to reconciliation and love, there is still a long way to go."

The head of the Roman Catholic Church in his message emphasised that Christians and Muslims can become an example of reconciliation and instruments of peace in today's world. 

This year's papal message to the Muslims as they mark the end of Ramadhan is based on the theme, Beyond Tolerance.

The papal message does not carry the date of the commencement of the feast (Idd-Ul-Fitr) because the marking of the occasion differs from one region to the other depending on the sighting of the moon.

Talking to APS, Kenyan Islamic scholar, Sheikh Ali Shee, said "there is already discussion among Islamic scholars that the sighting of the moon should be standardized.

"As of now, there is some confusion. The local sighting of the moon take precedence, yet there exists an international system of sighting the moon. My only hope is that one day, we, Muslims, shall be able to go by the international standard of sighting the moon," he said.

Sheikh Shee noted that in some parts of the world, the sighting of the moon becomes controversial when some Muslims decide to follow the local system while others go for the international method.

In his message, the Pope says... "I take this opportunity of offering you my heartfelt greetings. Throughout the month you have fasted, prayed, and shared, with those in need what God has given you."

Describing the time of fasting as a privileged period for asking pardon for sins committed and seeking to be reconciled with God, Pope John Paul II emphasises; "For Christians too, pardon is important, for according to the Gospel, God will grant pardon to those who repent their faults if they in turn grant pardon to those who have sinned against them."

The Pope says relations between Christians and Muslims are continually on the increase but stresses that "it is not only the weight of the past that has to be taken into account."

The grievious conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina for example has been falsely interpreted by some as an example of Christian-Muslim confrontation, he observes.

On the Christian-Muslim relationship in the Sudan, Pope John Paul II in his message, says, "the war in southern Sudan, protracted for so many years, has doubtless many causes, but the state of relations between Muslims and Christians can be considered as one of the elements contributing to the conflict."

In some countries, the condition in which various minorities find themselves can be a source of tension, the Pontiff notes, adding.."These sorry situations call for reflection on our part, reflections carried out in God's sight in order to set them right."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Media Institute Pleads for Journalists


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Windhoek - The Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) has urged all people of goodwill to write to Zambian President Frederick Chiluba and urge him to stop the persecution and harassment of three journalists working with a Zambian newspaper, The Post.

The trio comprises Editor-in-Chief Fred M'membe, Managing Editor Bright Mwape, and Special Projects Editor Matsautso Phiri.

The three have been charged with treason and being in possession of a banned publication (their own newspaper issue dated February 5). 

The three journalists are currently out on bail of Kwacha 250,000 (US dollars 250) granted by the High Court on February 7.

They had been detained on February 5 following the publication the same day of classified information (plans submitted to the cabinet for a referendum on a new constitution).

President Frederick Chiluba summarily banned the February 5 edition of the bi-weekly Post saying, the newspaper had contravened Section 4 of the State Security Act.

According to human rights organisation, Amnesty International, the charges carry a maximum penalty of 25 years in jail.

Although out on bail, the State has asked the court to review bail terms but the court has delayed judgement until February 16.

If the judge decides bail can be reviewed there is a likelihood the three will return to jail unless they can successfully argue their case.

The Post is well known for crusading investigative journalism. In 1994 as Managing Director of the bi-weekly, M'membe was summoned to give evidence in the trial of a minister who accused President Chiluba of drug trafficking, an allegation made at a press conference. M'membe declined to testify since other newspapers were not called.

Earlier the same year, he was charged following the publication of controversial remarks by another minister who had quit his post.

The paper is well known for its efforts to expose corruption and mismanagement of State resources in Zambia.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Uganda Chaka Mchaka Courses: Indoctrination or Civic Education?


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Kampala - The British envoy to Uganda, Mr. Edward Clay has renewed his attack on Uganda's Chaka Mchaka (political emancipation) courses, equating it with political indoctrination. Ugandan authorities insist Chaka Mchaka is the equivalent of civic education within a strict military environment.

Speaking at a congress of Uganda's mayors, town clerks and other municipal leaders in south-western Uganda on February 9, Mr. Clay, among other criticisms related to Uganda's forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections due in April/May, lamented the continuation of Chaka Mchaka courses. He said it was a matter of regret to see the courses continuing unabated when elections were so near. 

But speaking soon afterwards, his host, Uganda's Minister for Foreign Affairs Dr. Ruhakana Rugunda challenged the British envoy, telling him to be ready to undertake a Chaka Mchaka course at the Kyankwanzi School of Political Education in central Uganda "so that he knows exactly what is offered." The course normally lasts a couple of weeks, but Dr. Rugunda offered to design a shorter course for Mr. Clay.

Dr. Rugunda said Chaka Mchaka was considered "a very important course that had enabled Ugandans to know and understand their country - its history, politics and economy." Even more important, said Rugunda, Chaka Mchaka "had demystified and democratised the gun."

President Yoweri Museveni who introduced Chaka Mchaka when he assumed power 10 years ago, said Uganda had been ruled by dictatorial regimes in the past who had terrorised the citizens because peasants in particular were mentally ill-prepared to resist tyranny. He insisted that by teaching people their rights in addition to drilling them militarily, future dictators would have an uphill task in subjugating Ugandans.

Thousands of Ugandans in responsible posts have undertaken the Chaka Mchaka courses at Kyakwanzi over the last 10 years.

A number of Uganda's opposition leaders have previously called for the abolition of Chaka Mchaka. Prof. Dan Nabudere, a self confessed socialist and member of the Uganda Peoples Congress, (UPC), called for the abolition of the Kyankwanzi School arguing that the courses amounted to political indoctrination.

Africa News


February, 1996


Uganda Trouble-Torn Diocese Gets New Catholic Bishop


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Kabale, Uganda - A priest of the White Fathers, Monsignor Robert Gay, is the new bishop of the Diocese of Kabale in Western Uganda.

The announcement of his appointment was made by the head of the Catholic Church in Uganda Emmanuel Cardinal Wamala who said the appointment by the Pope was based on the recommendation of the Uganda Episcopal Conference. It became effective on January 22. 

Monsignor Gay, a Canadian, replaces Bishop Barnabas Halem 'Imana who resigned in July 1994, following an act of rebellion by two priests within the diocese of Kabale which in turn split the congregation.

Matters became chaotic at the height of the crisis in mid 1994, a fight ensued at the church resulting in damage to property.

Two priests in the diocese refused to go on transfer as ordered by the Bishop and instead resorted to writing a series of protest letters to higher authorities of the church. A number of churches were reportedly closed due to the activities of partisan groups.

Following Bishop Halem 'Imana's resignation in July 1994, Monsignor Gay took over on a caretaker basis. He will be ordained Bishop of Kabale on March 9 at Rushhorozi Cathedral here.

The 69-year-old Bishop was the Superior-General of the White Fathers in Rome for six years. He is described as "a very friendly person."

Observers say by appointing an expatriate to take over the troubled diocese, the Catholic Church has handled the matter well. This approach helps discourage internal wrangles and dissensions within the ranks of the Catholic Church in Uganda.

This is where the Anglican in Uganda can learn from the Catholics since similar dissensions have led to serious troubles in the Diocese of Busoga with further trouble looming in the Diocese of West Ankole.

In Busoga Diocese, the House of Bishops decided to send Bishop Cyprian Bamwoze on sabbatical leave for a second time in one year, but he defied the ruling and has continued with his duties.

Bishop Bamwoze is supported by the Diocesan Council of Busoga who also turned down a reconciliatory prayer service by Archbishop Livingstone Nkoyoyo late January.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


257 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Ethiopia Israel Make Minor Changes To Blood Bank Policies


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 15, 1996


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Israeli Ministry of Health will make only minor changes to its policy regarding blood donations from Ethiopian Jewish immigrants.

The Israeli Minister of Health Dr. Ephraim Sneth, convened the Advisory Council on Immuno-hematology and Blood, on January 25 in the aftermath of the Israeli Blood Bank scandal in which blood donations from Ethiopian Jewish immigrants were found to have been routinely destroyed (according to the Israeli newspaper, Maariv).

The scandal led to an uproar by thousands of Ethiopian Jews who stormed the office of Prime Minister Shimon Peres, in Jerusalem, on January 28. The Prime Minister defused the situation when he said publicly that he understood their anger. 

The Israeli Ministry of Health intends to pursue the existing policy but promised to re-evaluate it in the course of the year. The Advisory Council stated:

- The current policy prohibiting the use of blood donations is correct and necessary for the protection of Public Health;

- The questionnaire, which is filled out by every blood donor will from now on clearly state that the use of blood taken from donors is dependent upon medical considerations;

- The Blood Banks will continue to check Ethiopian donors for rare blood types; those donations found to contain these blood types will continue to be used as they are today;

- All members of the Ethiopian community will now receive Blood Bank insurance automatically (this means in case of a mistake by the Transfusion Service, they will be compensated automatically);

- Regarding the claim that there are techniques available for "heating of blood" in order to destroy viruses which may be found in the blood of "high risk" donors - these techniques contravene the international conventions to which Israel is signatory and they will not adequately protect the Public Health.

As a result of the anger demonstrated by the Ethiopian community in Israel and the commotion that followed outside the Prime Minister's office in Jerusalem, on January 28, at least 16 demonstrators were taken to hospital. The police claim a number of them were injured "by rocks and other objects thrown by individuals in the crowd."

The police gave their own figures as 41 injured. One police officer was struck by a rock that paralysed him from the waist down.

A number of observers believe the blood scandal was a blessing in disguise for the Ethiopian Jewish community in Israel who have faced a number of social-cultural obstacles since they were airlifted to Israel in large numbers from 1985 to 1991. Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Mrs Peres paid tribute to the Ethiopian community in Israel saying they are a humble peace loving people who had been provoked beyond restraint.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


258 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Research on Female Condom Adoption Continues


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 16, 1996 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Nairobi - In early 1993, the presence of the female condom was confirmed in Kenya. Although the device was then meant for display purposes only, a study about its acceptability among women in Kenya has begun.

The controversial female condom, available in Europe and North America since 1990, has found its way into Kenya. However it will not be accessible to the ordinary consumer until after June, pending findings of research being carried out about its acceptability.) 

A spokesperson of Family Health International (FHI) declined to comment on the condom saying that publicity was undesirable at this stage of the research work as it would probably rally groups traditionally opposed to the use of the condom against the research process.

The research is reportedly sponsored by Family Health International through its Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) Control and Prevention project, AIDSCAP. The United States Agency for International Development (USAID), on the other hand, is said to be "making available a small number of female condoms for research." On the ground is the Centre for Gender Training and Development, a local non-governmental organisation which is doing the ground work.

Scientists and health workers view the condom as a long-term strategy to provide women with more control over sexual behaviour and in decisions related to their own health. The World Health Organisation (WHO) projections indicate that between 30 to 40 million people will have been infected by the human immuno- deficiency virus (HIV) by the year 2000.

The current study, said to be also investigating women's perception of the female condom as a protective method against HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases, has already met the wrath of the Catholic church. The Catholic Secretariat's Family Life National Co-ordinator, Mrs. Angeline Kyonda, says that "condoms, whether for men or women are unacceptable (by the Catholic church) for they are not 100 per cent perfect and yet give the false impression as a prevention against AIDS. If we are working for the welfare of Kenyans and not manufacturers, we would promote and emphasize on the best way of avoiding AIDS and STDs according to the recommendations of the World Health Organisation (WHO)," Mrs Kyonda said.

She highlighted these recommendations as fidelity within marriage and chastity before marriage. "Let us tell people the truth about the shortcomings of the condom and let them make informed judgement," Mrs Kyonda added. She wondered whether the female condom will make a difference as a family planning device where, the male condom has shown failure rate of over 20 per cent among married couples and an even higher rate among teenagers when used as a device against pregnancy."

Mrs. Kyonda lamented that Kenyans were in the habit of unquestioningly embracing values and devices that eroded their morals and dignity. "Whereas we are tightening the noose around such vices as stealing, why are we promoting fornication and promiscuity through the promotion of condoms?" she asked.

However, a participant in the ongoing research told this writer she was glad she now had a means of protecting herself against AIDS and other STDs too. "The male condom favours men, why shouldn't women too have a device meant for them?" she wondered.

Kenya will not be the first African country in which this kind of study has been carried out. An acceptability study of the female condom was carried out in Zimbabwe last year among sex workers, urban women attending a family planning clinic in the capital Harare and volunteer Zimbabwean rural women.

According to the May 1995 edition of Reproductive Health Matters, a bi-annual magazine whose motto is "Promoting Safer Sex", over 50 per cent of women in all the three groups "said that they and their partners liked the condom very much and preferred it to the male condom." However, the publication adds, these positive responses were male-centred. The report adds that less than 10 per cent of the participants in the study said they did not like the female condom.

The main problems associated with the female condom in the Zimbabwe study were reportedly discomfort arising from the inner ring. Questions of sustainability and the cost of this device were also raised by the study in view of potential obstacles to the use of the female condom.

The female condom is a 17-centimetre long polyurethane tube with an outer ring meant to anchor outside and an inner ring designed to rest around the cervix.

Already, doubts are being raised about the effectiveness of this device both as a family planning method and means of protection against STDs and AIDS. Its predecessor, the male condom, has had a failure rate of "upwards of 20 per cent, both as a family planning device and a prevention against sexually transmitted diseases," according to a Nairobi gynaecologist who requested anonymity.

However, Reproductive Health Matters reports that female condoms are made of polyurethane plastic, that is sturdier than the latex used in male condoms potentially offering "greater protection and less frequent breakage."

The recently developed female condom which is not widely available outside Europe and North America, is reportedly meant to be one more step in the process of empowering women.

Rev. Fredrick Kibaki of the (Anglican) Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) says, "as long as it is used by married couples, then there is no problem about it." He too expressed fear that the condoms might eventually fall in the hands of teenagers, encouraging immorality.

Rosemary Akinyi, a married woman living in Nairobi says of the female condom; "People should look at it objectively. They should weigh its benefits against its disadvantages. And I think they will find the device liberating."

However Jane Kariuki, a business woman in Nairobi's Westlands region when asked about the future place of the female condom in Kenya retorted curtly; "I won't touch it and I won't talk about it."

Standing as major obstacles to the future of the condom in Kenya are not only social and cultural factors but also established institutions such as the Church. These, however, will have to face up to individual decisions which will finally make or break the future of the female condom.

Nevertheless, the biggest barrier to its accessibility among poor developing countries is said to be its cost. Going at the prohibitive price of US dollars 2.50 (Kenya shillings 140) each in the United States, the female condom is well beyond the average Kenyan's purchasing power. What this boils down to is that a Kenyan user would have to use the average per capita income of shs 14,300 in 1994 (US dollars 260) to buy only 100 female condoms.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


259 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Kenya Shaky Agreement Ends Media-Government Row


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 16, 1996 by Janes Macharia


LENGTH: 2054 words


 

Nairobi - The media fraternity in Kenya early February experienced a rare show of unity, as local journalists hosted Attorney-General Amos Wako, whom they accused of drafting Bills for legislation by Parliament, threatening the "existence of our profession, our source of livelihood and our only source of bread and butter," according to George Odiko, Secretary-General of the Kenya Union of Journalists (KUJ).

Opening the February 6 to 7 Press Council of Kenya and the Kenya Mass Media Commission Bills media workshop, organised to discuss the implications of recently introduced media bills, Attorney- General Amos Wako said; "there is no cause for alarm over the proposed laws as they are merely the draft initial working documents and are yet to become Bills."

At the workshop, the chief government legal adviser assured the press that the government was committed to "upholding the freedom of the press as enshrined in the Constitution." However, he maintained the position that every profession must have a system of registration, a code of conduct and an enforcement machinery which should be self-regulatory. 

This "tactical retreat," as the participants termed Wako's reassurance, did little to mollify the enraged journalists who included editors of the country's leading newspapers, foreign correspondents, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting representatives, lecturers and students from the University of Nairobi's School of Journalism, lawyers and observers from non- governmental organisations (NGOs). The workshop was jointly organised by the KUJ, the Kenya Professional Journalists Association (KEPJA) and the African Council for Communication Education (ACCE)-Kenya Chapter.

What do the offending bills say? They provide for the creation of the Kenya Mass Media Commission to regulate the operations of the mass media and the establishment of the Press Council of Kenya for the registration of journalists and mass media. The task of the Commission will be to maintain a register of all newspapers printed and published in the country, to license all broadcasting services, to issue broadcasting licenses - in short to act as a watchdog for the people's watchdog.

The composition of the Commission raises concern over its independence from government control. Journalists view as sinister the presidential appointment of its chairman, who in turn is to appoint eight members out of a panel of 13 to enforce a new code of conduct that journalists must comply with or face individual de- registration or that of their newspaper.

On the other hand, the Council Bill's section 5(e) states that its functions will be to register and maintain a register of all practising journalists in Kenya. In practice, one would have to prove that he or she is of "good moral conduct" before being issued with a license - but does not define what this conduct entails, say the journalists. The Bill requires journalists to renew their licenses every year and confers the power to withdraw licenses to the Council if somebody complains of being aggrieved by a story. "This will scare away potential investors and it means a journalist will only be professional for only one year before going for renewal of the license," a worried KUJ Secretary-General told participants.

Another fear expressed by most journalists at the workshop is that most of the members of the Fourth Estate in Kenya are not college- trained but have learnt what they do on the job. The bills require that to

be a registered journalist, one must have undergone a prescribed form of training locally or in a country recognized by the press council. Participants also argued that cartoonists, photographers and special correspondents, especially those who write on health or legal matters will be done away with.

The ambiguity inherent in the Bills can best be viewed in the stipulation that a newspaper is defined as any magazine or any printed matter that "contains news, or intelligence, or occurrences, of interest to the public, or any views, comments, or observations printed for sale or distribution and published periodically or at intervals not exceeding three months," only excluding business cards or letter-heads and brochures. The above mentioned observation, by Constitutional lawyer Prof Kivutha Kibwana of the University of Nairobi, elicited mirth among the participants. He termed the bills draconian saying, they "resemble the gagging of the press under Adolf Hitler's information act and apartheid laws formerly imposed in South Africa." He stated that the intended legislation was unconstitutional and in contravention of Section 79 which guarantees the freedom of expression to all Kenyans.

The news of the intended legislation was first reported in the independent weekly, Economic Review magazine on January 15, under the headline: Killing The Press. The initial government reaction to the press publicity and public reaction that ensued was to deny the existence of such drafts, through Attorney-General Amos Wako.

Faced with this pressure, the government finally buckled when on arrival from an East African Cooperation summit meeting in neighbouring Uganda, President Moi directed the Attorney-General to shelve the Bills until the matter was fully discussed by all concerned. This action let off a sigh of relief among media houses and set the ball rolling to hold a workshop to discuss among other things, the possibility of drawing up their own Bill to contain what journalists feel is relevant for their profession and explore channels of formalising a strong front which has sorely lacked among them upto now.

The Minister for Information and Broadcasting Johnstone Makau, had earlier dismissed the role of a task force appointed by the Attorney-General to look into the issue of reviewing press laws in 1994, saying: "The force is a waste of time and the government will not consider its recommendations." This had angered the members of the task force, made up of eminent media personalities, editors of all leading newspapers, book publishers and lawyers. Some had threatened to quit at the time but were prevailed upon by the A-G to stay on.

However, the dust had hardly settled after the press workshop than Hilary Ng'weno, Chairman of the Task Force resigned, citing personal reasons. Mr. Horace Awori former chairman of the Foreign Correspondents Association replaced him. Resolutions from the workshop include calls on the A-G to broaden the composition of the Task Force to include some representatives from the newly formed KEPJA and the editors of opposition newspapers.

The journalists also requested that at least two representatives from the workshop's organising committee be accommodated, called for the publicizing of the names of its members and removing the requirement that members be sworn to secrecy while on the Force. The final consensus was to form a Task Force of their own which will review the existing press laws, with a view to having them incorporated in a media bill which a committee was mandated to start working on, to be forwarded to the Attorney-General.

Calling on the participants to not only reject the proposed Bills but also come up with a draft Bill of their own, a former managing editor of Kenya's mass circulation daily, the Daily Nation, Mr. Joe Kadhi said: "Freedom of the press is of little meaning if it does not include freedom of information where all kinds of pretexts like bureaucracy makes certain files, information or interviews with officials inaccessible to journalists."

The question journalists kept asking themselves is whether the current laws are adequate or as has happened in the past, -- is the government out to harness the press now that general elections are to be held in 1997?

How is the average Kenyan going to be affected if these drafts become law? The media fraternity are unanimous that press freedom will be eroded and the diversity of opinion, especially from the opposition politicians and others critical of the government, will be a thing of the past.

A survey of the media scene in Kenya reveals that of the three main daily newspapers with a national audience, only one is independently owned, the other is the ruling party's mouthpiece and the third was recently sold by the British conglomerate Lonrho, to "international investors", suspected by media observers, to be linked to the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party. The two broadcasting stations, Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC) and Kenya Television Network (KTN) are government-controlled.

Only one national radio operates in the country run by the KBC. However, the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, which has refused to license several other private radio and television stations numbering more than 60, this month awarded a radio license to Kanu official Mark Too whose application was reportedly not on the waiting list of potential licensees and his company, Capital FM is said not to have been incorporated at the time of being given access to the airwave frequency. Too is also the Chairman of the East African Standard newspapers, recently sold by Lonrho.

The Mass Media Commission Bill exempts the KBC and government-owned newspapers from certain restrictions which it seeks to impose on privately owned media.

These laws, journalists say, are punitive to private investors as some seek to curtail the commercial viability of running a station without advertisers and present broadcasters with a threat of having their licenses revoked after eight years - meaning the high costs of establishing a station could be lost. KBC is not required to comply with these provisions hence the competition is unfairly skewed in its favour, say journalists. They add that in this case the public would lose out on its right to know.

Retired judge William Mbaya termed the Bills unconstitutional and accused the government of making a habit of legislating bills that are ultra vires the Constitution on several occasions in post- independent Kenya. He told participants at the seminar to come out strongly against the draft Bills because once they become laws, even the courts cannot intervene to remedy the crisis. "A court can only declare a statute unconstitutional but cannot repeal it, until Parliament does so," he said.

Other countries that have similar laws on the media in Africa include Nigeria, enacted in 1989 and again in 1992 via a decree, Ghana, since 1987, Sierra Leone and Uganda in 1995. All these governments have one thing in common - they are military regimes that have not been elected into office through the ballot, and just like Hitler's Germany and Stalinist Russia, they survive in power by keeping dissenting views under tight control.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


260 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Rwanda More Upheavals For Refugees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 16, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Nairobi - Another upheaval awaits Rwandese refugees in the Great Lakes region of central Africa, following Zaire's clear intentions to forcefully evict the refugee population who have lived in eastern Zaire for nearly two years. Tanzania and Burundi are equally insisting that the Rwandese must leave "as soon as possible".

Between April and August 1994 more than 2 million people from the majority Hutu tribe fled Rwanda at the peak of the civil war that eventually brought Tutsi dominated Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF) to power.

At least one million minority Tutsis lost their lives in the genocide perpetrated by extremist militias and the Hutu dominated army who fled into neighbouring lands fearing revenge from the victorious RPF. The Rwandese fled into Zaire and Tanzania with a smaller number going to Burundi. 

But now the authorities in Zaire, Tanzania and Burundi want the Rwandese to return home and are making that clear in very strong terms indeed.

It is expected that a mass movement of people could erupt again in the Great Lakes region of central Africa, if Zaire should decide to implement too vigorously, its plan to force an estimated one million Rwandese in Eastern Zaire to return home.

On February 8, Zaire's Interior Minister Gustave Mulumba Mbangula made it clear the Rwandese in the Goma area of Zaire had overstayed their welcome. He declared: "We will close the Kibumba camp. When that camp is empty, we will proceed to another, one by one, until all refugees have gone back to Rwanda."

In Tanzania, the authorities have issued a series of statements emphasising the need for the Rwandese to return home "as soon as possible." Tanzania which is Rwanda's neighbour to the east has 700,000 refugees in its camps.

On February 12, Tanzania's Interior Ministry issued a decree banning the activities of the Rally for the Return of Democracy, a Hutu organisation cum lobby group, that has been active in Ngara refugee camp in north-western Tanzania. The authorities also announced the arrest of 160 Rally supporters who have been active in dissuading refugees from returning to Rwanda.

The Hutu extremists fear that once the refugees return home, they will no longer have a power base. Moreover the extremists know they are wanted worldwide for the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. They are alarmed and desperate as the tide turns against them in the region.

In Zaire, the authorities have with effect from February 13, surrounded the camp at Kibumba with troops to ensure the refugees do not flee into the hills and the countryside around Goma in Eastern Zaire, as happened last August when Zaire first tried to evict the refugees from the camps operated by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). The Zaireans are likely to act contrary to their assurances to the UNHCR on August 7, that Zairean troops would not enter the camps. They promised to use persuasion instead of force.

But Rwanda's Vice-President and Defence Minister, Paul Kagame, said his men had intercepted radio messages by the Zaireans, saying Kibumba camp and another camp in Bukavu would be besieged by gendarmerie as a prelude to the forceful eviction of the refugees.

Hutu extremists and soldiers who have been training in camps housing military men in eastern Zaire with a view to invading Rwanda, appear to have received similar information regarding Zaire's true intentions.

Around February 10, hundreds of these former soldiers slipped out of their camps and fled deeper into the interior, where it will be difficult for the Zairean army to flush them out.

In the process, these marauders displaced hundreds of Tutsis who had settled in the Masisi area of Kivu Province, about 90 kilometres from the border with Rwanda. The affected Tutsis have lived in Zaire for more than a generation, having been displaced from Rwanda in the upheavals of the late 50s.

Zaire has acted in an ambivalent way in regard to the Rwanda tragedy and has turned a blind eye to the activities of these extremists. In fact, a United Nations mission to verify the activities of the extremists in the camps last January was denied assistance by the Zaireans and the mission returned to New York with no solid report.

Civilian Rwandese refugees living in the Goma camps retain fresh memories of what happened last August, when Zairean troops descended on their camps and forcibly bundled anybody they could grab onto lorries, subsequently dumping them at the border. Families were suddenly separated and, Zairean troops described as "ruthlessly efficient" - were accused of looting refugees' property in the confusion that followed.

Thousands of refugees broke away and fled into the hills and countryside around Kibumba and other camps. The whole operation only came to a halt after an international uproar.

By September 1995, over 16,000 refugees were back in Rwanda, forcefully evicted. After screening, many were allowed to return to their communes, but a few suspected genocide participants ended up in dangerously overcrowded prisons.

In order to restore a semblance of "dignity and security" to the eviction process, Sadako Ogata, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, agreed with President Mobutu Sese Seko on a planned approach to the whole process. This would comprise a daily return rate of 5,000 to 10,000 refugees. The UNHCR did not tell the world that its funds for Rwanda refugees - who require US dollars 1 million each day, had dried out.

Fernado del Mundo of UNHCR in Geneva, admitted at the beginning of February that the agency's Rwanda funds had been depleted with only US dollars 20 million left in the kitty.

Burundi's Tutsi dominated army have already forcefully closed down a number of Rwandese refugee camps on Burundi territory. At least 10,000 people from the Ntamba and Mugano camps chose to return home to Rwanda after Tanzanian authorities initially barred them from entering Tanzania territory.

On a visit to Ngara camp in Tanzania on February 9, the Rwandese Prime Minister Felicien Rwigyema, a Hutu, appears to have succeeded in convincing many more refugees that returning home is the best option for them. Tanzania has consistently pleaded poverty and urged the refugees to go home.

All in all it looks like most Rwandese refugees would be back on the road to Rwanda in the next six months.

They return home to an uncertain future. The Rwandese authorities have refused to declare a general amnesty. Those suspected of involvement in the genocide of 1994 will end up in prisons that are overcrowded with a high inmate death rate.

Furthermore, the Hutus, cannot be sure that returnee Tutsis whose families fled into exile in the late 50s, do not occupy their home and land already.

It is clear that Rwanda's humanitarian upheaval will continue for some time to come. However, Jane Matheson of British charity, Oxfam in Kigali, is optimistic that Rwanda has done better than she is generally credited with. Matheson points out what is generally little known, that one million refugees have returned home quietly on their own over the last 12 months.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996

February, 1996


Business Offshore Oil Conference Planned for Libreville


BYLINE: Offshore Magazine February 16, 1996


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Houston - Offshore Magazine, the world's leading publication for international offshore oil and gas exploration, development, and production, announces its presentation of Offshore West Africa '96, the region's first international conference and exhibition covering the booming offshore oil and gas industry and Africa's largest even focused on the petroleum industry.

To be held November 5-7 at the Okoune Palace Inter-Continental Hotel in Libreville, Gabon, the OWA 96 conference will feature timely presentations on topics of major interest not only to West African operators but to the offshore petroleum industry at large. 

Major speakers from both West Africa and around the world will discuss the dynamics of the region as well as practicalities in doing business in West Africa, including regulations, opportunities and technical issues.

Topics of particular interest include deepwater exploration, drilling, and development, subsalt technologies, extended reach and horizontal drilling, FPSO and subsea production systems, pipeline and infrastructural construction, as well as many other important issues.

All of Africa's petroleum producing nations' petroleum ministers and heads of state oil companies are invited to attend OWA96 as VIP participants, and many of those from West Africa will be featured on the final program. The President of

Gabon has been invited to address the attendees at the opening ceremony, which will feature representatives of each of West Africa's oil producing countries.

Full information on all aspects of OWA96 is available in brochure form and includes details of recent West African offshore discoveries and developments, as well as directions on registration and attendance. Copies of the OWA96 brochure/registration form are available from PennWell Conferences & Exhibitions or Offshore Magazine, 3050 Post Oak Blvd., Suite 200, Houston, Texas 77056 USA. Telephone (01) 713-963-6218, Fax: (01) 713 963-6284, E-mail: seang@pennwell.com, Internet: http://www.pennwell.com.

Africa News


February, 1996


South Africa and Nigeria Envoy Returns to Post


BYLINE: South African Department of Foreign Affairs February 14, 1996


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Pretoria - "The South African High Commissioner, H.E. Mr G.S. Nene, returned to Lagos on 11 February 1996, exactly three months since he was recalled by President Nelson Mandela for consultations in protest of the Nigeria government's summary executive of MOSOP leader Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other Ogoni's.

The South African Government has condemned in the strongest possible terms these executions which were carried out despite appeals for clemency by various governments, including Pres. Mandela himself. In addition, the South African Government wishes to express concern over the continued detention of former President Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, the presumed winner of the annulled 1993 presidential elections Chief M.K.O. Abiola, and a host of other political detainees and pro-democracy activists, including those suspected of involvement in the alleged coup plot of 1994. 

Without attempting to interfere with the due process of law in Nigeria, the South African Government expresses the hope that these detainees will be given unhindered access to legal counsel and their families. At the same time the South African Government appeals for the immediate release of all political prisoners where applicable.

In resuming his duties as High Commissioner to the Federal Republic of Nigeria, H.E. Mr G.S. Nene will continue to promote bilateral relations between the two countries. As an emerging democracy, South Africa is ready to fulfill its role in promoting the well-being of the entire African continent.

The recent upsurge in political uncertainty and instability which gripped several West African nations since the start of 1996, is highly regrettable. The South Africa Government therefore once again appeals to all those concerned, to join in the international community's march towards global democracy and the universal respect for all basic and fundamental human rights. In view of the strategic role that Nigeria fulfills in West Africa it also carries the responsibility to act as a model to be emulated by its neighbours. The South African Government accordingly welcomes the process of democratisation upon which the military government of Nigeria has embarked and expresses the hope that this process well continue unabated and without undue delays. South Africa will remain supportive of Nigerians' quest for a democratically elected government, representative of all its peoples.

The South African Government furthermore wishes to deny recent allegations by certain sources inside Nigeria as to South Africa's alleged support of Nigerian pro-democracy groups in order to "destabilise" the country. These reports are baseless and are not in the interest of expanding relations between both our countries.

The South African Government does, however, wish to reiterate its unequivocal support for all efforts to promote the growth of democracy everywhere in the world. This would also include listening and consulting with all parties representative of the Nigerian political spectrum. As part and parcel of these efforts no political leaders or groups inside or out of Nigeria would be denied a hearing by the South African Government.

At the same time, the South African Government will continue to forge its foreign policy on Nigeria in consultation with other Commonwealth governments, as was agreed at the most recent GHOGM meeting in Auckland. South Africa, together with seven other Commonwealth governments, will monitor the situation in Nigeria and will formulate its foreign policy regarding Nigeria within this framework, as well as in consultation with the member states of the Organisation for African Unity (OAU).

The South African Government accordingly regrets the Federal Government's rejection of the CMAG initiative which effectively denies Nigeria the opportunity to present its case to the Commonwealth of nations. Together with the other CMAG members, South Africa therefore wishes to reiterate its appeal to Nigeria to reconsider its denial and access to the CMAG delegation.

The South African Government, cognisant of the important role that sport has played in the process of bringing about peace and reconciliation amongst its citizens, again expresses its regret at the absence of the Nigerian "Super Eagles" football team from the most recent Africa Cup tournament. It is hoped that Nigerian sportsmen and women will in future be granted the opportunity by the Nigerian government to participate in international events.

Issued for the SA High Commission in Lagos by the Department of Foreign Affairs, Pretoria, 14 February 1996.

LANGUAGE: English
