Africa News


February, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Team Investigates Suspected Ebola Outbreak in Gabon


BYLINE: World Health Organization February 16, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Geneva - Acting on a request from the Government of Gabon, an international team of medical experts from the World Health Organization (WHO), Gabon and France has arrived in a remote village in northern Gabon to investigate an outbreak of suspected Ebola haemorrhagic fever which has killed 10 people and infected at least nine others.

All 19 persons are from the village of Mayibout, located on the Ivindo River in a sparsely populated area about 150 kilometers from Makokou, the provincial capital of Ogooue-Ivindo.

The patients were admitted to the provincial hospital in Makokou on 5 and 6 February exhibiting symptoms of high fever, bloody diarrhoea and severely reddened eyes. The nine survivors have been isolated as a measure to prevent further spread of infection, and appear to be recovering. 

Preliminary laboratory results on blood specimens which were taken from nine of the patients support the initial diagnosis of Ebola haemorrhagic fever. Confirmatory tests are currently underway.

In addition to the 19 cases admitted to the hospital in Makokou, four other persons are under surveillance in Mayibout for possible infection.

The initial source of transmission for the outbreak is reported to have been contact by the patients with a chimpanzee on 26 January. The circumstances are being investigated by the medical team, which is seeking to identify other persons who may have had contact either with the chimpanzee or with the Ebola victims and to institute appropriate infection control measures.

If confirmed, the outbreak of Ebola haemorrhagic fever in Gabon will mark the second appearance of the disease on the African continent since the epidemic in Zaire in 1995 which infected 316 people and killed 245, a 77% fatality rate. A single case of Ebola was confirmed in Cote d'Ivoire in December. The patient survived.

WHO is leading an international collaborative 2-year study project in the Tai Forest of C=F4te d'Ivoire aimed at identifying the natural host reservoir of the Ebola virus, which is the key to identifying its mode of transmission. This would help predict when and where Ebola outbreaks are most likely to occur and what behaviour modifications could prevent infection.

Source - http://www.who.ch/programmes/emc/pressrel.htm


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


264 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Uganda Latest Nation to Attack Corruption


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996 by Alex Bagenda


LENGTH: 1827 words


 

Nairobi - In ordinary East African lingua franca, it is known as "chai" (tea) or "kitu kidogo" (something small) but that is underplaying the magnitude of corruption which has obstructed the normal functioning of the social systems in Africa.

In the past, corruption used to be automatically connected with regimes in Africa and other under-developed regions but of late, European businessmen, politicians and bank officials have been mentioned in related cases. Corruption is not a monopoly of developing countries, be they in Africa, America or Asia.

Uganda's Inspector General of Government (IGG), Mr. Augustine Ruzindana, says "corruption which for a long time has been known as a very important channel for business contacts and deals between transnationals and leaders in the Third World, has to the dismay and despair of everyone involved in fighting corruption, been discovered to be quite common in the First World too."

A global phenomenon, corruption is perhaps as old as humanity. It is not a structural characteristic of any country or society. The interest which the World Bank and other multilateral institutions are beginning to show in the practice is therefore timely, as it will perhaps go a long way in attracting due emphasis in understanding and combating this problem. 

"At the time of independence in 1962, Uganda had a very promising future. At that time, the country was fighting three main enemies namely poverty, ignorance and disease. Today, one can add corruption and repression to the same list. Unfortunately, the new additions complicate the prevailing situation because they interfere with production and distribution of goods and services at all levels in all sectors of the economy," says Ruzindana.

Corruption is also an impediment to democracy because it subverts the democratic process of elections, of government administration, law enforcement and the legal process. It results in moral decay such that a practitioner of it whether one is a policeman, politician, civil servant or churchman loses a sense of values. Corruption saps the whole social fabric of a nation to the extent that it can be regarded as an inevitable way of life.

"Since independence, with the political upheavals we have had in Uganda, job insecurity became a major cause of corruption. Senior public servants suddenly had to maximise their earnings when they could since they were not sure how long they would stay in office," says Ruzindana.

In Uganda particularly and Africa in general, political leadership is always a transitory period which contributes a great deal to the practice of corruption.

"There is a great deal of insecurity at individual and systematic levels. This leads to official looting with the hope that when the inevitable happens, those stealing will have some accumulated savings to cushion their lives in exile," he added.

Another factor which has encouraged corruption is retrenchment. "Every now and then, the relevant ministers announce a reduction in the number of civil servants or soldiers. Since 'victims' are never identified, everyone feels the need to save for the expected lay-off and the level of corruption therefore increases," he notes.

In Africa, virtually every change of government, whether violent or peaceful, is on the platform of getting rid of corrupt officers. These changes are always followed by commissions of inquiry or tribunals, sometimes with extensive powers to combat corruption, but the malpractice still persists and seems to defy all measures put in place against it.

"We may, therefore, be tempted to conclude that perhaps we have not yet made a correct diagnosis of the problem or that the correct methods to deal with corruption have not yet been found or that maybe only half hearted measures are taken against corruption without the will to go all out and fight it.

Another conclusion that could be made is that perhaps the standards and values are largely still those of pre-industrial societies. Whatever answers are available for these questions, most people agree, perhaps with the exception of the beneficiaries of corruption, that corruption is an evil that must be combated in all societies," says Ruzindana.

Ruzindana highlights the following types of corruption which are common in Uganda: bribes, extortion, illegal use of public assets for private gain, over and under-invoicing, paying salaries to non- existing workers, paying for services not rendered (air supply), under-charging of taxes and duties as exports and imports involving false classifications, false tariffs, 10 per cent commission, fraud and embezzlement, misappropriation of assets, court decisions in which award for damages of very large sums of money do not correspond to the injury actually suffered and "loss" of court files.

Neglect or negligence of duty could also be classified as corruption since one is paid for "no work done".

However, what is considered as corruption in Africa may not be considered corruption in the developed countries. Also, types which are considered important in the developed countries may not be significant in Africa. Money laundering, drug trafficking and organised crime are now making hot news in some African countries.

Uganda's IGG says; "All these forms of corruption mentioned may have different causes. But the main conditions that provide a permissive environment for corruption to occur are often lack of a properly institutionalised system with the necessary control mechanism. Sometimes the wholesale breakdown of the entire system is the main cause.

He notes that in such cases, a feeling of immunity characterises the system, so that politicians and civil servants think that they can do anything without any adverse repercussions against the culprits.

On the effects of corruption in Africa, Ruzindana observes that it has eaten up national, social and economic progress and to some extent even political progress has been impaired.

Corruption involves the transfer of public resources, services and assets from public to private use. The diversion sometimes entails transferring funds to foreign countries thus causing harmful effects on economic development.

Says Ruzindana; "Corruption is coupled with outright economic and political instability and gross abuse of power. To be more specific, corruption has led to bad roads, poor medical services, poor schools, falling educational standards, disappearance of whole projects which have been funded and delayed completion of projects. Foreign aid has disappeared without leaving a trace of what was done with it."

Repairs of buildings and equipment, vehicles and roads were paid for but never carried out, goods paid for several times were never delivered and the 10 per cent became mandatory inorder to win tenders and

contracts. All this resulted in poor terms and conditions of services for all workers in Uganda, he adds.

"The sum total of all these accumulated losses in every area of public expenditure is colossal economic destruction. The majority of the population is adversely affected by corruption.

If Africa is to realise progress at a faster pace, corruption must be eliminated outright," says Ruzindana.

Uganda has openly acknowledged corruption as a major problem, hence the formation of the office of the IGG to investigate corruption on a permanent basis.

The IGG is charged with the duty of eliminating and fostering the elimination of corruption and abuse of public offices by taking necessary measures for the detection and prevention of corruption in public offices.

The IGG investigates the conduct of any public office which may be connected with or conducive to the following: the abuse of office or authority; the neglect of official duties and economic malpractices by the officer.

Since its inception in 1986, the IGG's office has been vigilant in curbing corruption but in most cases, advice given is ignored by those in authority.

The existing freedom of the press has given the Ugandan journalists a field day because corrupt officials are exposed to the public through the press.

Notes Ruzindana; "Accountability and transparency within public administration are gradually being established even though corruption persists as a major problem."

However he warns; "If the political leadership tolerates or encourages corruption by not punishing those who are corrupt within its own group, then corruption becomes uncontrollable. Corruption cannot exist without the connivance of the political leadership even if passive."

Corruption introduces discrimination and arbitrariness in decision making so that rules, regulations and procedures become less important. Corruption can only be eliminated when both the political leadership and the public make a concerted effort not to tolerate the practice.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


265 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Rural African Women Look To Church For Assistance


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996 by B. Agona and G. Mwangi


LENGTH: 1240 words


 
Nairobi - A middle-aged woman, weighed down by the load of firewood strapped onto her back, trudges along a dusty rural footpath. But the firewood is only part of her day's luggage. With it goes a basket full of vegetables, as her baby sleeps or chuckles to himself from his position -- strapped on her stomach. A girl of about nine years walks ahead of the woman. She too carries a heavy load of firewood. It is towards evening hours, yet it is still hot. A few paces behind them, a man carrying a hoe in one hand, walks leisurely, puffing away at his home-made cigarette. The family has been working on their shamba some six kilometres away.

On getting home, the woman goes to the kitchen to prepare the family's evening meal while her husband rests under a mango tree in the compound. After the meal, the man asks for water to bathe but the little water left in the house is not enough. 

The wife picks a jerrican and rushes to fetch water at the river, some two kilometres away. After taking his bath, the man walks to the nearby shopping centre to while away the evening. Meantime, his wife at home prepares to milk their only cow among a host of other evening chores.

According to a recently published United Nations report on women in Africa; "35 per cent of all African households are supported by women, for whom much of the daily work is without remuneration and the value of their household labour goes unrecorded." Further, the rural African women, usually poverty-stricken, form the larger part of this percentage.

Of late, there has been an upbeat in addressing issues adversely affecting women and formulating strategies to alleviate them. To date, four UN-supported world conferences on women have taken place - - Mexico City (1975), Copenhagen, Denmark (1980), Nairobi, Kenya (1985), and the just concluded Beijing, China conference held between August 20 and September 15, 1995.

Although mostly affected by issues discussed in such meetings, the rural suffering women in Africa are hardly included in delegations to these conferences. For instance, one East African delegation to Beijing comprised of well-off mostly urban women. A survey conducted by a local daily just before the meeting showed that nearly 70 per cent of that country's rural women were not aware of the conference in China.

Equally unfortunate, although pertinent, strategies adopted on issues affecting women in Africa such as economic empowerment and poverty reduction, violence against women, sexual harassment, women in education and training, the girl-child, and women political empowerment and decision making are not communicated to the rural women.

In Africa, the church is well placed to enlighten women on issues affecting them in order to improve their social, political and economic status in a changing world.

During a Mothers' Union conference held in Kenya's Western Province in the Butere Diocese of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) late last year, over 100 rural women leaders freely and courageously expressed their views on issues affecting them. Most speakers complained of harassment and hard work meted out to them by their husbands and other men in society. Guest speakers, who were drawn from among well known women leaders, advised the mothers on new developments in the struggle for women empowerment.

"Women had taken the church as a comforter and nothing else," said Dr. Musimbi Kanyoro, who is the Lutheran World Federation (LWF) Secretary for the Office for Women in Church and Society. She noted that it is time women in rural areas shed the dark ages of inferiority complex and regard themselves as people with a say in society. "Women in rural areas have remained in the dark, thereby paving way for oppression by their husbands out of their ignorance and fear," she observed.

Dr. Kanyoro said the church programme on women issues is working on strategies to change some structures in society so that women can get involved in matters that affect them without any form of gender discrimination.

A representative of the CPK Development Office, Ann Wachira, challenged members of the Mothers' Union to be self starters; "Do things out of your will and anxiety. Do not wait to be told what to do always......"

And the Maendeleo ya Wanawake (Women in Progress) - a national women's body - chairlady in Butere division advised the mothers to avoid idleness by forming self-help women's groups as these will help remove financial stress causing quarrels in some homes.

Bishop Horace Etemesi of the CPK Butere Diocese, in a concluding note, told the mothers to stop living under threats and harassment as the church and the state recognised them (women), adding, they should seek assistance from church elders without hesitation and where the matter is serious, let the relevant authority deal with such cases.

Other mainstream churches represented included the Catholic Church through the Catholic Women Association (CWA); the Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA), through Women's Guild, African Inland Churches (AICs) and Lutheran churches.

However, as awareness about issues affecting women grows, there is a need to caution women in Africa about the dangers of radical feminism. For instance, in the United States the feminist movement, now dubbed "movement gone wrong" by critics, is misleading women in their agitation for equal rights and opportunities. Critics say the movement has strayed from its primary purpose which spelt out the need for women to make a contribution in society commensurate with the individual's talents and energies. Instead of empowering women, they have actually "created a victim mentality that debilitates them," some argue.

Radical feminism presents itself as a source of ultimate meaning for women. It claims to answer the basic theological question, why women suffer.

"For many women, the radical movements have become a religion in America," reported the June 1994 edition of Christianity Today magazine.

A lady American lawyer reports in Christianity Today; "If we gain a new insight - that men and women are equals, only to loose sight of the timeless truth about being truly whole in Christ we make a bad bargain indeed."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


266 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Tribute To Slain African Priests


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Nairobi - 'They Are A Target' is a book about 200 African priests killed in the course of their service to God and mankind over the last 40 years.

The author, an expatriate Comboni missionary and journalist, tells the story of African priests who paid with their lives due to political, tribal, religious and social intolerance in their nations. The book covers 16 African nations.

Through the 207-page book, Father Neno Contran recalls the memory of otherwise forgotten padres, many of whom met their deaths under pressure of duty - serving a sick person, defending women, children and Africa's perennially vulnerable refugees. Sadly indeed, some died because an intoxicated bandit or soldier turned up at the door one nightfall and blasted away with an AK47. 

Some were shot while many more were simply hacked to death in the most gruesome manner imaginable. Father Contran does not conceal the details, even when the body of one murdered Luba (Zaire) priest is abused after murder. 'They Are A Target' is not just a book listing dead padres. It is also a good historical text that contextualises the death of many clergy and in the process reveals Africa's deeper weaknesses, particularly tribalism.

"The blood of these priests fell onto the African soil, in the furrow of the Holy Sacrifice of Christ," says Bernadin Cardinal Gantin of Benin who wrote the foreword to this book.

Cardinal Gantin says the book has helped redress an imbalance in the coverage of the heroism and sacrifices of indigenous African padres whose death rarely elicits coverage by Western media. "The mass media usually run a feature on an expatriate missionary killed in some corner of the continent but tend to ignore the killing of an African priest," laments Gantin.

The reader will be quick to notice - as Cardinal Gantin did - the striking similarity of circumstances in which the priests perished, whether in Sudan, Mozambique, Uganda, Rwanda or Angola.

History tends to repeat itself and the same pattern of ideology and tyrannical intolerance emerges and may emerge again. Some countries, like Malawi, do not have a single priest listed in this book, but one should keep in mind that official intolerance nearly cost the lives of Malawi's Bishops after the publication of their Pastoral Letter in 1992.

One may be forgiven for thinking the book is about the senseless slaughter of several dozen padres that took place in Rwanda between April and July 1994, following the death of that country's and neighbouring Burundi's Presidents in a suspicious plane crash on April 6. Ethnic massacres sparked by the incident left between 500,000 and one million Rwandese dead, and about two million fleeing into neighbouring countries, while more hundreds of thousands were displaced inside.

True, the Rwanda holocaust cost the lives of one Archbishop, two bishops, 96 priests, 64 Sisters, 45 Brothers and 28 lay consecrated persons but the book covers as many priests from elsewhere in Africa.

What is most disturbing is the premeditation that precedes the murder of many priests listed in 'They Are A Target'. In Sudan and Zaire during the Simba insurgency of the mid-sixties and Uganda during the regime of Idi Amin and later Rwanda in the holocaust of 1994, the killers methodically set out to injure and kill priests and bishops.

The highest ranking servant of the church who lost his life to the intrigues of tyrannical people was Emille Cardinal Baiyenda, the Archbishop of Brazaville, Congo.

Cardinal Baiyenda aged 50 years, Africa's youngest Cardinal - was kidnapped on the evening of March 22, 1977, and murdered during the same night. Sadly, he had ignored persistent rumours that he was next in line to be killed, after the assassination of President Marien Nguabi (Congo) on March 18, 1977.

On that fateful evening, a Land-rover pulled up in front of the Cardinal's residence, two people alighted and told the Cardinal that the members of the Military Council that had seized power, wanted to see him.

Perhaps only time will tell why Cardinal Baiyenda so unsuspiciously boarded the vehicle to his death. Although former President Massamba Debat was later executed for this "heinous act" he may have been a mere scapegoat.

The Pope described the loss as "a harsh blood toll paid by the church in the person of one of the most worthy men."

Many readers of this book will shed tears because of the senseless and brutal manner in which many of the priests were killed. One such was a Ugandan padre, Father Clement Kiggundu, editor of the Catholic newspaper, Munno.

The Archbishop of Kampala, E.K. Nsubuga, told mourners: "If you opened the coffin and saw what remained of him, you would be shocked."

His body was discovered at Namanve forest outside Kampala on January 14, 1993, "half burnt, a horrifying sight." He was killed during the regime of Iddi Amin, perhaps because he had the courage to publish in his newspaper the complaints of women whose husbands had mysteriously disappeared.

Father Kiggundu had a premonition about his death: "I feel they are pursuing me; now they are about to take me..." he told a priest friend, shortly before his death.

Father Nyadru William, a priest of the Logbara tribe of Uganda was murdered, apparently to assuage the spirits in preparation for a cattle raid by one tribal group in Karimoja District where he worked.

It appears that a few week before, a sorcerer had said that in order to procure a successful raid, the sacrifice of a person riding a motor cycle was required. Father Nyadru was on a motor cycle on that fateful day. Aged 31 years, he was killed on the road to Moroto.

Cardinal Gantin says of the priests; "They have written a new and beautiful page of the history of our evangelisation."

'They Are A Target' is jointly published by Paulines Publications, Africa and a Comboni Missionaries bi-monthly magazine, New People.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Niger New Military Regime Names All-Civilian Cabinet


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Niamey - Niger's new military leaders, facing increasing international isolation, have named an all-civilian government in which key cabinet ministers from the ousted leadership have been retained. They include the Finance, Defence and Foreign Affairs Ministers.

The coup has been roundly condemned by the international community, with the United States and European Union freezing aid to the West African state until democratic rule is restored. 

On January 27, Lieutenant-Colonel Ibrahim Bare Mainassara deposed democratically elected President Mahamane Ousmane and set up the Council for National Salvation. Col. Mainassara appointed the deputy governor of the Central Bank of West African States, Mr. Boukary Adji, as Prime Minister. The bank is based in Dakar, Senegal.

The new cabinet includes Mr Attaher Abdoulmoumine, one of the Tuareg rebel leaders who signed a peace accord with the government last April, as Secretary of State for the Interior.

Giving reasons for his takeover, Col. Mainassara said he wanted to end a 16-month stalemate between President Ousmane and his Prime Minister Hama Amadour, whose supporters held the majority in the impoverished country's parliament.

The new leaders have been making trips to neighbouring countries to rally support for their cause. Not surprisingly, one of those is southern neighbour and regional power, Nigeria, itself facing international isolation both for the execution last November of nine minority rights activists and continued military dictatorship.

Following his return from Nigeria, where he led a government delegation, the Vice-President of the ruling council, Colonel Youssoufa Maiga, said: "We were heard by President Sani Abacha and we were well understood."

He added: "Everything which affects Niger concerns Nigeria, and vice- versa, and that is why we went to Abuja."

Meanwhile, a national reconciliation forum set up by Col. Mainassara has recommended a six to 12-month transition to democratic rule. Meeting in a preliminary session on February 3, the forum repeated the military leaders' claims that political squabbling threatened to plunge mainly Muslim Niger into chaos.

The six to 12-month transitional period includes constitutional changes to strengthen the powers of an elected president and to drop the use of proportional representation voting. Changes were also proposed to limit the number of political parties to five.

"Most of the political parties have shown themselves to be parties based on family or geographical links within the framework of an outright multi-party system," the forum charged.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Benin Bishops Fear Violence In Polls


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Cotonou - Benin's Catholic bishops fear violence may erupt in the small West African nation of 7.5 million people, following intelligence reports that the various political parties in the country have set up militias ahead of presidential elections scheduled for March this year.

Bishop Robert Sastre of the Benin Episcopal Conference went on state television on February 5 to express the bishops' alarm at recent developments at home; "Constant rumours are reaching us from reliable state sources that armed militias are being established by the various political forces in the country." He read from a pastoral letter dated January 26.

This is the second time in less than one year that the Catholic Church leaders in Benin have warned about the deteriorating situation for the country's fragile democratic process.

They previously urged Beninois to undergo "a moral conversion" in order to make the six-year-old democratic experiment a success. They said the people of Benin themselves should bear the ultimate responsibility for their conservative attitude in the face of the challenges of the democratic process.

More significantly, the Catholic clergy reminded the leaders of the various political parties in the country that it was their patriotic duty to put the country before their partisan alliances.

The presidential elections in this West African nation are a continuation of the electoral process that started with parliamentary elections in March 1995. At least 2 million voters turned out to support contestants for 83 seats in parliament.

Political observers say incumbent President Nicephore Soglo of the Renaissance Party faces an uphill task against a candidate of the opposition alliance.

Africa News


February, 1996


Guinea Army Rebellion Leaves 50 Dead


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Conakry - Guinean authorities have ordered the arrest of troops involved in a mutiny after some 2,000 soldiers demanding higher pay and better working conditions rampaged through the west African state's capital killing 50 people and wounding 100 others.

The rebellious soldiers ran amok on February 2, looting shops in Conakry and shelling the presidential palace where President Lansana Conte was held up.

Most of the dead and wounded were civilians caught in the cross-fire. Some 300 soldiers occupied Conakry airport before commandeering civilian vehicles to transport them into the city, firing machine-gun volleys in the air. 

According to sources close to the president, at one point on February 3, a group of soldiers had captured Conte and taken him to the Alpha Yaya military camp where the rebellion began.

Conte then sacked his Defence Minister Abdourahmane Diallo, whom the troops blamed for a deterioration in their conditions, but accused non-commissioned army officers in cahoots with several senior officers of attempting to wrest the country's leadership from him.

A group calling itself the Committee for National Salvation had circulated leaflets in the capital saying the rebels would "fight on until the final victory." The document denounced "the disorder, corruption and nepotism" of the government.

On February 3, President Conte finally appeared to be giving in to the soldiers' demands and announced that negotiations with rebel troops had "wound up with an agreement". He appealed to them to "return at once to their units."

Addressing about 1,000 soldiers in Camp Samory, in the centre of Conakry, he said: "It is, from now on, to me that you must address all your problems."

The mutineers applauded him when he said that he was setting up a committee to look into troops' grievances, mainly salary increases.

President Conte said the demands of the soldiers concerned five points, all of which could be achieved, but he did not reveal what the points were.

Sources close to the government said the main point was about an amnesty for the rebels, and notably of five senior officers, considered leaders of the rebellion.

General Conte seized power in 1984 in a military coup, but in 1992, introduced a multi-party system and was elected president in December 1993.

Business resumed in Conakry on February 5 and Conte said he would introduce some changes in the army. He gave no details about the planned reform, but indicated that he would bring in military officers "able to educate the soldiers."

The order to arrest the mutineers issued by the Interior Ministry on February 6 seemed to contradict an earlier allusion to a possible amnesty by President Conte who, when asked about what he intended to do with the soldiers, said he would let "democratic institutions to do their job."

But even as the order to arrest was being issued, soldiers were circulating leaflets in the capital warning: "Let everyone be aware that, in case of arrests or reprisals, the entire army will retaliate energetically."

According to reliable sources some soldiers who took part in the rebellion had not returned to their barracks by last week and were still armed.

The Guinea Defence Ministry, in another attempt to placate the discontented army, had, meanwhile, announced plans to pay compensation to families of soldiers killed while serving in the strife-torn neighbouring Sierra Leone and Liberia.

An estimated 800 Guinean soldiers are serving in Sierra Leone alongside government forces fighting rebels there. The two countries have a military agreement which stipulates that each side will help the other in the event of aggression from a third party.

Other Guinean troops are deployed in Liberia as part of the Nigerian- led Economic Community of West African peacekeeping group sent there in 1990.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Sierra Leone Rebels Call Off Ceasefire Ahead Of Elections


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Freetown - Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels in Sierra Leone have called off a unilateral ceasefire, dashing hopes of peace talks to end the five-year-old civil war which has claimed thousands of lives and left this West African country's economy in tatters.

The move has further heightened uncertainty over general elections scheduled for February 26, which were nevertheless expected to be postponed to allow for peace talks between rebels and the National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC) government now led by Brigadier Julius Maada Bio.

Bio seized power from Captain Valentine Strasser on January 16 in a palace coup and immediately called on the rebels to come to the negotiating table without any preconditions. In response, Foday Sankoh's RUF declared a one-week ceasefire and said they were dropping all previous demands, including the withdrawal of foreign forces from Sierra Leone. The ceasefire was to be extended for the duration of talks. 

The rebels also urged the government to postpone the elections until the war was brought to an end. The new NPRC leadership agreed not to attack the rebels' positions while peace talks were under way.

But last week, the rebels announced that the ceasefire was off because several of their positions had come under fire from government forces.

Government soldiers, they claimed, "aided by the Executive Outcomes war machine attacked our positions at several fronts in Togo, Pejehun and Bo areas (about 100 kilometres east of the capital, Freetown) along the Bo-Taiama highway between January 28 and January 30, 1996."

A few days earlier, the government claimed several villages in the east had been attacked by RUF rebels. But in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) from Abidjan, Ivory Coast, ans RUF spokesman denied the claims, saying the attackers were bandits exploiting the situation.

Troops from the Executive Outcomes, a South African mercenary firm, along with those from Nigeria and Guinea have been assisting the Sierra Leonean army to end the rebellion.

Meanwhile, RUF rebels are reported to have captured three South Africans guarding the Sierra Rutile titanium mine in the southern town of Mobimbi. A local newspaper is quoted as saying the three are members of the Executive Outcomes.

With the RUF ceasefire off, it is not clear how soon peace talks would begin and whether the elections would go ahead as planned. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), while maintaining its role as a humanitarian organisation, has said it would facilitate the talks by providing communication and other equipment.

Meanwhile, by the time of going to press, reports indicated that Brig. Bio had made his first contact by radio with rebel leader Foday Sankoh. Both men pledged their commitment to holding peace talks to resolve the crisis at home.

Brig. Bio is reported saying he was ready to hold peace talks without preconditions anytime. However, Sankoh once again said he opposed foreign involvement, an apparent reference to foreign forces fighting alongside Sierra Leonean government forces.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Kenya New Catholic Diocese Created


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Nairobi - A new Catholic diocese has been created in Kenya, bringing to 20 the total number of dioceses in the country. At the same time, two local clergy have been consecrated bishops, bringing to 22, the total number of Catholic bishops in this East African country.

The new diocese of Kericho in the Rift Valley Province, was carved out of Nakuru Diocese. It comprises two administrative districts, Kericho and Bomet which serve 15 parishes. 

Spread out over 2,600 square kilometres, Kericho has some 190,330 Roman Catholics within an estimated local population of 1.2 million people.

Bishop Philip Anyolo, the newly consecrated diocesan head, was ordained priest in 1983. He studied philosophy and theology locally and abroad.

The new bishop has served the Catholic Church in Kenya as parish priest, diocesan secretary for the Eldoret Diocese and the chaplain of Moi University in Eldoret.

Newly consecrated too is Rt. Rev. Boniface Lelle, 48, for Kitui Diocese in the country's Eastern Province. He replaces Bishop Emeritus William Dunne, who has retired after reaching the canonical age of 75. Bishop Lelle becomes the first local bishop to head the diocese, which has 20 parishes serving some 90,564 Catholics.

Both ceremonies, held early this month were presided over by Cardinal Jozef Tomko, the Prefect of the Congregation for the Evangelisation of People at the Vatican. He was assisted by several local bishops, led by Cardinal Maurice Otunga, the Archbishop of Nairobi.

Speaking at the inauguration of Kericho Diocese, Cardinal Tomko challenged church leaders to be fearless as they shepherd the faithful.

In another development, Cardinal Tomko on February 4 travelled to Isiolo, about 272 kilometres north of Nairobi to create a new apostolic vicariate and consecrate Fr. Luigi Locati, 66, as the bishop Apostolic Vicar.

The Apostolic Vicariate of Isiolo was carved out of Meru Diocese. Isiolo district, is in Kenya's arid and semi-arid region and has a high concentration of Muslims. Out of the estimated 84,000 people within the jurisdiction, only 20,000 are Catholics. The vicariate will administer seven parishes.

The Catholic Church in Kenya was instituted in 1953, after Nairobi, then under the Vicariate of Zanzibar, became an archdiocese and Metropolitan of the Ecclesiastical Province of Kenya.

The church currently enjoys a membership of over 10 million followers within the national population of 27 million people.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Uganda Group To Lobby For Rights Of "Second Wives"


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Kampala - A lobby group calling itself the Second Wives and Concubines Association of Uganda (SWICAU) has been formed in the Ugandan capital to fight for the rights of "the other woman" in a polygamous relationship.

The acting chairperson of SWICAU is Mrs. Bethel Clare Mwanje, a career civil servant.

During the inauguration ceremony last month in the suburbs of Nansana, some 15 kilometres from here, the SWICAU chairperson noted that one of the association's primary goals is to improve the image of women in this category in the eyes of the churches and society. She asserted that second wives "are people of honour and fidelity." 

The state-owned New Vision reported that the ceremony brought together some 200 Ugandan women from a cross section of the society who included human rights lawyers, businesswomen and other professionals.

It is important to get the churches, the law and society to change their attitude towards women in a polygamous relationship, said Mrs Mwanje.

Noting that "society despises second wives and the law segregates them when it comes to inheritance of property following the man's death, particularly when the second wife or concubine has borne children with him," Mrs Mwanje also lamented the illegitimacy of children produced in such unions.

Society at large - including the churches - should also remember that women are often lured into relationships by married men who are aware they are committing bigamy but fail to state the fact to the woman. "Women are always blamed irrespective of the man's fault," she added.

Polygamous unions are a fact of life in Uganda as indeed in many parts of Africa. In a subsequent editorial, the state-owned daily New Vision pointed out that in Uganda, husbands hierarchically grade their wives in numerical order. "This has caused strain and stress in society. Co-wives get into conflict and rivalry as they compete for the husband's affection. This does not augur well for the stability of the family and upbringing of the children." Grading of women also compounds their marginalisation.

The commentary suggested that ideally, SWICAU should not only popularise second wives and concubines but rather "should take centre stage in social reform to crusade against these marital anomalies. They should vigorously educate young girls on the plight of being second or lower status wife or concubine in a polygamous union."

The daily noted that church teachings would be compromised to accommodate the goals of SWICAU.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Sudan Political Parties In Southern Sudan Discuss Unity


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Nairobi - Political parties in southern Sudan have been discussing various options that can bring viable political development in the region.

At a five-day meeting organised in the Kenyan capital by the Union of Sudan African Parties (USAP) between January 8 and 12, speakers gave their views about the formation of an alliance or forum to advance political developments in southern Sudan. 

Professor Barri Wanje of the Patriotic Resistance Movement (PRM) suggested that all political parties in southern Sudan, should form an alliance for viable and effective political development in the region.

An official of the South Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) Dr. David Chan however opposed the creation of an alliance, saying that the concept calls for political and legal technicalities, that would be best handled by a political forum.

Dr. Chan, who is the spokesman for SSIM told APS in an interview that it was sad that the SPLA/M (Sudan People's Liberation Army/ Movement), did not attend the Nairobi meeting, although they were invited.

"They missed a good chance to come forward and argue out their case as to how best we as Sudanese people can bring about the eargely awaited democratic development in southern Sudan," he added.

Reporting on the Nairobi meeting, Light and Hope for Sudan, a bi- monthly newsletter for the Christian Initiative for Peace in Sudan committee in its January 1996 issue, says; "The aim of the on-going series of meetings is to develop a democratic way to settle policy differences between southerners and to evolve strategy instead of differences leading to interfactional violence. The existence of this initiative changes the political scene entirely and makes it possible for the south to put its case in the international community."

Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large Anglicans Join Campaign For Gay-Lesbian Tolerance


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 12, 1996


LENGTH: 680 words


 

London - Some 300 Anglican leaders, including three primates and South Africa's Archbishop Desmond Tutu, have put their names to an appeal for greater tolerance of homosexuals.

The full-page appeal, which was to appear in British religious press on February 9 does not explicitly call for the Church of England to ordain gay ministers or to sanction homosexual marriages, but extends support to the Christian Movement of Gays and Lesbians, which has campaigned actively for these goals, the British Sunday Telegraph reported on February 4.

Besides Tutu, signatories to the appeal include primates Michael Peers of Canada, Richard Holloway of the Scottish Episcopal Church and Edmond Browning of the Episcopal Church in the United States, the Sunday Telegraph said. 

It is to be published a few days before a church synod on February 12 (today).

Anglican officials believe the appeal will revive a debate on homosexuals that could split the church even more than did the issue of the ordination of women ministers.

Spokesman for the Archbishop of Canterbury George Carey declined to comment on the report.

The move by the Anglicans, the official church of England, is the latest in a series of campaigns by different church leaders urging societies to change their rigid attitudes against homosexuals and lesbians to that of tolerance.

On January 24, Zimbabwe's Catholic bishops also stepped into the row over gay rights sparked by Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe and condemned any attempt to "harass, persecute or torture" homosexuals.

Mugabe, who is himself a Catholic, faced international condemnation last year for likening gays to "beasts", saying that they had "no rights", and threatening to throw them in jail.

In an unusual pastoral letter, the Zimbabwe Catholic Bishop's Conference said it wanted "to distance the church from any attempts to institute a 'witch-hunt' or hate campaign against persons with homosexual tendencies."

The letter made the point that the Catholic church saw homosexuality as a "disorder", adding that "what is not in accordance with God's will as expressed in our nature cannot be claimed as a 'human right'."

At the same time, "while we want to eliminate a disease wherever it exists, we do not eliminate those who suffer from it," the bishops said.

"It is therefore not right for anyone, including government, to harass, persecute or torture people simply because they are known to have this inclination."

The human rights aspect of the issue was raised in August last year when the government banned a gay and lesbian group from participating in the Zimbabwe International Book Fair, which had human rights as its theme.

Faced with international condemnation from Western governments -- including a group of 70 United States congressmen who sent him a protest letter and demonstrators in South Africa who dubbed him "Africa's Hitler" -- Mugabe, 71, was unrepentant.

He told the American congressmen to "keep their sodomy, bestiality, stupid and foolish ways to themselves," and went on to describe homosexuals as "worse than pigs."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


275 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Computer Firm Sued For Contract Breach


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 12, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka -Nikuv Computers has been sued by a Zambian private company for breach of contract.

Legal counsel for Chris Furniture, Kenneth Shepande, filed the writ of summons in the Lusaka High Court on Thursday, February 8, 1996, which read in part: "The plaintiff's claim is for the sum of K3.569,000 being the balance of a K17, 460,000 contract price for the delivery of computer tables to the defendant."

Chris Furniture is claiming interest at the ruling bank rate from January 24, 1994, collection charges and costs. Chris Furniture managing director, Chris Ndhlovu, said Nikuv had asked his company to make them 300 desks valued at K17 million. 

"We accepted the deal and went into contract with them, but they later said we must first make them 170 desks worth K9 million of which they only paid us K5 million," Ndhlovu said. "They asked us to suspend our business and concentrate on the desks since they needed them ready by January this year."

He said the conditions of the deal were that if the furniture was delayed, 25 per cent penalty would be surcharged against Chris Furniture. "I do not understand why we cannot be paid since we met their deadline, though they delayed by supplying us materials late and making payment for the deposit by giving us a postdated cheque," he said.

Nikuv's project manager, Gershom Korda, also confirmed the deal. "Go and ask Ndhlovu if we were pleased with his job," Korda said in an interview last week. "If the desks were delivered in time, if he met all our obligations and why we really do not want to pay him." Ndhlovu says he does not know the reasons why Nikuv cannot pay him since they do not want to talk to him.

He said when he went to inquire about his money, Korda ordered a paramilitary officer to throw him out of his office. "I do not know exactly what we did to these people," Ndhlovu carped. "We delivered their desks in time and I am sure they were satisfied with our work."

Ndhlovu said the remaining balance cannot be said to be the 25 per cent penalty. "The remaining balance is so far much more than the 25 per cent penalty," Ndhlovu said. "We have been swindled and we have sued them for over K7 million."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

276 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Police Deny Post Search Story


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 12, 1996 by Mukalya Nampito


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Police have described the lead story of last Friday's issue of The Post as 'blatant lies' whose sole purpose is to discredit the integrity of the Zambia Police Service.

The story claimed, quoting unnamed police sources, that President Frederick Chiluba was making desperate maneuvers to execute a second search on Post newspaper offices and its three editors in which incriminating documents, linking the paper's top editors to artificial clandestine activities aimed at creating insecurity in the country, are expected to be planted by state security personnel. 

Police public relations officer, Francis Musonda, categorically dismissed the story headlined "ANOTHER POST RAID" saying the police took strong exception to the allegations.

"At no time has the police service been associated with such unpalatable and unprofessional tendencies aimed at compromising its core value of delivering high quality service," Musonda said in a press statement last Friday. "Besides we do not have names of the security officers mentioned in the story."

The story claimed a plan for the second search of the paper was to be executed by officers from the Criminal Intelligence Unit (CIU) of the Zambia Police Service and was to be headed by district intelligence officer, Musole.

The paper claimed that Musole was to be assisted by detective chief inspector Chiyabi from CIU (State House). The paper also named other security personnel to be used in the claimed search as Capt. John Mwaba from the military intelligence, and a Lt. Col. Mulenga from the Zambia National Service.

Last week police raided the offices of The Post on both Cha Cha Cha Road and Chandwe Musonda Road in search of material related to the constitution of Zambia and its adoption. The raid followed President Chiluba's decree banning the paper's edition 401 of Monday.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


Arts, Music and Culture Piracy Prompts Boycott Threat by Two Bands


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 2, 1996 by Jeff Kapambwe


LENGTH: 354 words


 

Lusaka - Two local bands have threatened to boycott recording their works
in Zambia because of the increasing rate of piracy on foreign music which
has caused the sale of local music.

Serenje and Masasu Kalindula bands have decided to with-hold their work
until remedial measures to stop exploitation of artists' were initiated by
the government. 

Serenje band leader Syman Kaseba and Masasu band leader John Mulemena
contended, in separate interviews, that the high rate of piracy in the
country was stiffling their business prospects.

"We have lost more than 90 per cent of our sales because piracy is
growing rapidly and there is no control of the practice and we cannot
continue like this," Kaseba said.

He added: "Piracy had become rampant and government should speed up the
implementation of the laws contained in the literary and performing rights
act because this is the way we earn our living."

Mulemena concurred with Kaseba and accused the government of ineptitude
in curbing the practice despite unveiling the act which came into effect
last year. "We have done the best we can to ensure that we meet the demands
of our fans but we are getting little or nothing from our efforts as most of
the tapes are dubbed and find their way on the market before we realise
anything from the original tapes."

He added: "when is government going to enforce the act to make
musicians enjoy their sweat?"

Zambia Union of Musicians (ZUM) official said efforts to eradicate
piracy has reached an advanced stage. Government says they were working with
immigration department, police and ZUM.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

February, 1996


Arts, Music and Culture Maluma Hits The Ausie Top Chart


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 2, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's own Larry Maluma has hit the Australian top chart with
his latest album called Motions. The album, according to that country's
musical journal Melbournes Music and Entertainment Weekly, has lyrics
combined in English and some Zambian native languages. 

It has rated the work of Maluma who has been in that country for more
than eight years as very talented. "Maluma is a very clever
composer/arranger of reggae and pop(abeit heavily augmented with
percussion)," it read.

The publication says that each song has been a perfect progression of
verse building to chorus being supported by a truly fitting combination of
instruments and female backing voices. The highlights are the sweet
reggae-inflected What about me, the soulfully optimistic 'Its Gonna Be
Alright'
and jive track Reggae 'N' Soul all recorded by the ABC studios.

This is the fifth album.

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia President Instructs Cops to Arrest Post Editors


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 2, 1996 by Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Police have been instructed by President Frederick Chiluba to
arrest Post editors and charge them with criminal libel for their stories
about the President's parentage, birth place and alleged forgery of a form
two certificate.

The President's public relations and press aide, Richard Sakala, told
journalists from the government owned and controlled media on Wednesday that
State House was finally ready to take Post editors to court to be criminally
prosecuted under the defamation of the President law. 

Sakala said the editors would be prosecuted for publishing stories
claiming Chiluba was born in a Zairean hospital at Chibambo Mission.

The President had earlier bragged, in the open, that he could not have
been born at Chibambo Hospital because it was only built after his birth and
accused the paper of imagining its existence. His reaction came after the
return of a State House sponsored "investigative" team to Chibambo led by
Sakala.

Documentation and information from people who know the area has, however,
disproved the President's claims about Chibambo not being in existence in
1944. And the President has so far not given a categorical position on his
birth place having claimed before that he was born in Chamboli Kitwe, be
fore his relatives last year named Musangu village as his birth place.

And he himself has recently claimed he was in fact born in Wusakile,
Kitwe.

According to Sakala, Post editors, will also be charged with offences
relating to their reports that the President has no form two certificates
and at one time borrowed one from a Frederick Chiluba, now with Chipata's
Luangwa Industries, to advance himself.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Independence To Be Sought For Auditor General


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 2, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - The office of the Auditor General should be brought under the
direct supervision of parliament to make it more independent says an
opposition member of parliament.

Petauke UNIP member of parliament Lavu Mulimba said in parliament
yesterday that retaining the Auditor General's office under the executive
erodes its independence. "It is important that the Auditor General's office
is not seen and treated as part of the executive because it removes the
essence
of its independence," Mulimba said.

Mulimba also called for the Auditor General to be given leverage to hire
his own staff instead of depending on personnel division of cabinet office.

Luangeni UNIP member of parliament Johnstone Jere in his contribution
called for enhanced training and improvement of conditions of service for
officers from the Auditor General's office to enhance its effectiveness. He
also called for the office to be allowed to charge government offices for i
ts service and should impose higher charges for those found with
expenditures about their budgets.

And Chilubi MMD member of parliament Chisala Mponda complained about
failure of the office to present audited reports to parliament's public
accounts committee within the stipulated period.

Responding to the contributions, Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda agreed
that the K2.5 billion allocated in this year's budget for the Auditor
General's office was still insufficient but said it was as far as government
would give from the K4.2 billion it asked for. He invited a write-up from
members calling for the de-linking of the office from the executive so that
the matter could be studied.

Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Ruling MMD Has 'Secret' Vote Centres


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 2, 1996 by Rueben Phiri


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - Clandestine voter registration centres have been uncovered at
private domestic homes in Lusaka, the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team
(ZIMT), has claimed.

ZIMT vice-president Isaac Zimba said in Lusaka yesterday his organisation
had discovered one such centre at a home in Kaunda square stage 2. Zimba
said the house, number 29, belongs to a ruling MMD official who he could not
name. 

According to ZIMT only members of the MMD were being registered at the
Kaunda Square house. " I went to the house after a tip-off and found a
person who I learnt was the area branch chairman addressing cadres saying
they could register at the house instead of going to stand on queues," Zimba
sa
id. "I also presented my national registration card and my old voters card
to the man who went into the house and a short while later came out with a
filled in application form which he gave to me," said Zimba, displaying the
form.

Director of Elections Rabson Mwansa refused to comment on the matter and
referred all queries to the Lusaka City Council who he said were the agents
for the voters' registration exercise in Lusaka. "That question should be
directed to the people that are directly responsible for the registratio
n exercise," Mwansa said in an interview yesterday.

Lusaka province registration officer John Mulenga, however, confirmed
receiving reports about the clandestine registration centres in Kaunda
square.

But it is not clear where the centres were drawing the registration
documents from and whether they were genuine and accounted for. "Its
extremely shocking," Mulenga said in an interview yesterday. " But we are
carrying out investigations to establish exactly where the house is."

The card given to Zimba was marked region:05, District:04, station:227
and serial number: 0792. Mulenga said these details could be traced to
Masasa polling station in Munali constituency. He could, however, not say
whether any domestic houses have been apportioned registration duties and
admit
ted there was a possibility that political parties could connive with
electoral agents to get into an arrangement which guarantied registration
for as many of their members as possible.

He said all documentation in the voter registration exercise were "state
property which should be properly accounted for".

"The application forms are accountable documents given to the
registration officers in the field who sign for them on the equipment issue
form and are expected in return to prepare a control sheet which indicates
the forms issued," Mulenga explained. The reports come in the wake of
continued fe
ars of massive rigging of this year's presidential and general elections as
of irregularities in the registration of voters under the Israeli firm
Nikuv.

LANGUAGE: English
