Africa News


February, 1996


Zambia Minister Harangued for Attacking Judges


BYLINE: Post of Zambia February 2, 1996 by Kunda Mwila, Reuben Phiri and Mukalya Nampito


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - Judges, lawyers, unio-nists and politicians yesterday expressed
their outrage at continued attacks on the judiciary. They were particularly
incensed by finance minister Ronald Penza's attack oN industrial relations
court.

Deputy chief justice Bona-venture Bweupe, who has just returned from
medical treatment in South Africa after a road accident last December, said
Penza's attacks where unbecoming of a senior government minister. 

"We do not need to be confrontational with each other as arms of
government," justice Bweupe said in an interview at home yesterday. "It was
unfortunate that the words came from the minister who is supposed to know
better and protect the judiciary."
Justice Bweupe, however, advised members of the judiciary to refrain from
responding to the attacks and concentrate on their job. "We should not even
answer back to justify our judgments," Bweupe said from his home in Lusaka.

But High Court Judge Kabazo Chanda has a different view. Judge Chanda
says while the public was free to comment on judgments he will not condone
personal attacks. "The integrity and personality of the judges are not for
public attack. Tearing the character of a judge into pieces publicly is con
temptuous," Justice Chanda said. "Anyone who or any newspaper which fancies
that kind of pastime is countering imprisonment for wantonly lowering the
dignity of the court in this country, which dignity we cherish so much."

Penza said, on ZNBC's 'Tell the Nation' radio programme on Wednesday
morning, that the Industrial Relations Court ruling a warding a 45 per cent
salary increment to civil servants was "irresponsible" and deplored the
court's "low understanding of economic issues". "The judgment was very
irrespo
nsible because you cannot give yourselves hefty salary increases when your
budget is funded by foreigners," Penza said. " I would rather lose my job
than contribute to the running down of the economy."

Justice Bweupe, however, advised that if government felt aggrieved by the
judgment it can ask the Attorney General to appeal. And registrar of the
High Court of Zambia, Ruth Zulu, said government should respect the judgment
because they were the ones who took the matter to court.

Civil Servants Union of Zambia secretary general Japhet Mo-onde said the
statement by Penza has angered his members. He called on Penza to resign
from his job if he cannot accept the judgment. "He will definitely not be
missed," Moonde charged. And National Union of Public Service Workers gener
al secretary, Davis Chingoni, agreed with Moonde and warned of "severe
labour consequences if government went by Penza's stand".

State counsel Daniel Lisulo said: "We cannot allow them to erode the rule
of law by their criminal statements, characters like Penza must be cited for
gross contempt of court." And an enraged civil servant in the office of the
permanent secretary in Solwezi, Dick Chama, said "public workers wer
e fed up with Penza". In Lusaka unionised workers will today hold an
emergency meeting at Penza's Ministry of Finance headquarters to work out a
workers stand to Penza's statement.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


283 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Western Sahara Security Council Extends Mission Until 31 May


BYLINE: United Nations February 7, 1996


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

New York -The Security Council this afternoon extended the mandate of the
United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO) until
31 May.

At the same time, the Council supported the intention of the
Secretary-General, "in the absence of meaningful progress towards completion
of the Settlement Plan", to bring the situation to the immediate attention
of the Council and, in such an eventuality, to submit a detailed programme
for a
phased withdrawal of MINURSO.

The Council took that action by unanimously adopting Security Council
resolution 1042 (1996), by which it also expressed deep concern about the
stalemate that hindering the identification process and the consequent lack
of progress towards completion of the Settlement Plan.

Noting the views expressed by the Government of Morocco and the Frente
Popular para la Liberacion de Saguia el-Hamra y Rio de Oro (POLISARIO), the
Council called on the two parties to consider additional ways to create
confidence between themselves and to facilitate the implementation of the S
ettlement Plan.

The Settlement Plan, which was accepted by the two parties on 30 August
1988 and approved by the Council on 27 June 1990 in its resolution 658
(1990), entails the holding of a referendum without military or
administrative restraints, to enable the people of Western Sahara to choose
between ind
ependence and integration with Morocco. 

The meeting, which was called to order at 12:50 p.m., was adjourned at
12:51 p.m.

When the Security Council met this afternoon to consider the situation in
Western Sahara, it had before it a report of the Secretary-General (document
S/1995/43 and Corr.1). In his report, the Secretary-General advises that the
Council may want to consider two options. The first would be to ext
end the mandate of the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western
Sahara (MINURSO) until 31 May, thus allowing time for the identification
process to be resumed and an opportunity to test the political will of the
parties. If at any time before the expiry of the extended mandate there ap
peared to be no or very little improvement, the Secretary-General would
bring the matter to the attention of the Council.

As a second option, he suggests, the Council might decline approving a
further extension unless it was accompanied by the condition that
outstanding problems be resolved by specific dates. Consequently, plans
should be prepared for a phased withdrawal of MINURSO. The
Secretary-General's Specia
l Envoy has conveyed to the parties and observer States the readiness of the
Council to contemplate the withdrawal of the Mission despite concern that
withdrawal could have destabilizing effects on the region.

The Secretary-General's report was issued in response to the Council's
request in resolution 1033 (1995), for the Secretary-General to provide
options for its consideration, including the orderly withdrawal of MINURSO
in the event intensified consultations failed to lead to agreement. The Coun
cil also asked for information on the findings of the Secretary-General's
Special Envoy following consultations with the Government of Morocco and the
Frente Popular para la Liberacion de Saguia el-Hamra y Rio de Oro
(POLISARIO), the two parties to the settlement plan. The consultations were
part
of the Secretary-General's effort to resolve differences hindering the
identification of applicants eligible to vote in the referendum on Western
Sahara.

According to the report, the POLISARIO has agreed to proceed with the
identification of all applicants included in the 1974 census, that is,
subfractions for which lists of sheikhs or alternates from both parties have
already been established. The POLISARIO continued to decline to cooperate in
the identification of another large group of applicants -- certain tribal
groups which were not represented by subfraction in the 1974 census. The
POLISARIO held the view that applications from persons other than those
belonging to subfractions specifically represented in the census were not
admi
ssible. Further, it would withdraw from the entire process if there was any
attempt to identify such applicants with the participation of a sheikh from
one side only. In his discussions with the POLISARIO, the special Envoy
emphasized that the Identification Commission was obliged to process all a
pplications submitted on time. The Acting Special Representative of the
Secretary-General also advises that if both parties cooperated fully, and
the Identification Commission were to be expanded to its full complement of
11 identification centres, it would be possible, in theory, to complete the
identification process in 22 weeks or so, or, if the Commission operated at
half capacity, in about 44 weeks. Allowing for appeals, a period ranging
from six months to one year would be required to complete the identification
process. At the time of the report, the total number of persons identifi
ed was 60,257.

The Council as a whole or individual Member States may also wish to
consider ways to assist the parties in establishing a dialogue, the
Secretary-General says. Contacts between the parties could be arranged on a
confidential basis. For progress to be achieved, the two parties must have
vision
of the post-referendum period. The Secretary-General encourages all
concerned to help the parties to achieve such a vision. Other aspects of the
settlement plan that need to be addressed are the code of conduct,
confinement of troops and exchange of prisoners of war.

During the reporting period, the Secretary-General states, the
cease-fire was violated on one occasion when the POLISARIO tried to restrict
the movement of the military observers. The situation was resolved after
some discussion. On 19 November, 186 Moroccan prisoners of war were
repatriated w
ith the assistance of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)
and the Governments of the United States and Argentina.

Draft Resolution

The full text of draft resolution 1042 (1996) reads as follows:

"The Security Council,

"Reaffirming all its previous resolutions on the question of the Western
Sahara,

"Having considered the report of the Secretary-General of 19 January
1996 (S/1996/43 and Corr.1),

"Welcoming in this context the visit to the region by the Special Envoy
of the Secretary-General from 2 to 9 January 1996,

"Noting the views expressed by the Government of Morocco set out in the
report of the Secretary-General, "Noting also the views expressed by the
Polisario Front set out in the report of the Secretary-General,

"Reconfirming its commitment to assist the parties to achieve a just and
lasting solution to the question of Western Sahara,

"Reiterating the fact that, for progress to be achieved, the two parties
must have a vision of the post-referendum period,

"1. Reiterates its commitment to the holding, without further delay, of
a free, fair and impartial referendum for the self-determination of the
people of Western Sahara in accordance with the Settlement Plan which has
been accepted by the two parties referred to above;

"2. Welcomes the report of the Secretary-General of 19 January 1996;

"3. Decides to extend the mandate of the United Nations Mission for the
Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO) until 31 May 1996;

"4. Expresses deep concern about the stalemate which has been hindering
the identification process and the consequent lack of progress towards
completion of the Settlement Plan;

"5. Calls upon the two parties to cooperate with the Secretary-General
and MINURSO in resuming the identification process, overcoming obstacles
hindering completion of that process, and implementing all other aspects of
the Settlement Plan, in accordance with the relevant resolutions;

"6. Encourages the two parties to consider additional ways to create
confidence between themselves and to facilitate the implementation of the
Settlement Plan;

"7. Supports the intention of the Secretary-General, in the absence of
meaningful progress towards completion of the Settlement Plan, to bring the
situation to the immediate attention of the Council, and invites the
Secretary-General in this eventuality to submit for consideration a detailed p
rogramme for a phased withdrawal of MINURSO, in accordance with the second
option contained in his report of 19 January 1996;

"8. Requests the Secretary-General to submit a report by 15 May 1996 on
the implementation of the present resolution;

"9. Decides to remain seized of the matter."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


284 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Liberia Report to the UN Security Council


BYLINE: United Nations February 7, 1996


LENGTH: 760 words


 

New York - Letter dated 26 January 1996 from the chairman of the Security
Council committee established pursuant to Resolution 985 (1995) concerning
Liberia addressed to the president of the Security Council.

I have the honour to transmit herewith the report of the Security Council
Committee established pursuant to resolution 985 (1995) concerning Liberia
containing an account of the Committee's activities since its establishment
until 31 December 1995. The present report, which was adopted by the C
ommittee under the no-objection procedure on 26 January 1996, is being
submitted in accordance with the note by the President of the Security
Council of 29 March 1995 (S/1995/234). 

(Signed) Gerardo MARTINEZ BLANCO Chairman Security Council Committee
established pursuant to resolution 985 (1995) concerning Liberia 96-01976
(E) 300196/... *9601976* Annex

Report of the Security Council Committee established pursuant to
resolution 985 (1995) concerning Liberia.

I. INTRODUCTION

1. By its resolution 788 (1992) of 19 November 1992, the Security
Council, acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,
imposed a general and complete embargo on all deliveries of weapons and
military equipment to Liberia.

2. On 13 April 1995, the Security Council, in paragraph 4 of its
resolution 985 (1995), established a committee consisting of all members of
the Council to undertake the following tasks and to report on its work to
the Council with its observations and recommendations:

(a) To seek from all States information regarding the action taken by
them concerning the effective implementation of the embargo imposed by
paragraph 8 of resolution 788 (1992);

(b) To consider any information brought to its attention by States
concerning violations of the embargo, and in that context to make
recommendations to the Council on ways of increasing the effectiveness of
the embargo;

(c) To recommend appropriate measures in response to violations of the
embargo imposed by paragraph 8 of resolution 788 (1992) and to provide
information on a regular basis to the Secretary-General for general
distribution to Member States.

3. The Committee's bureau, as elected at its first meeting of each year,
consists of a Chairman and two Vice-Chairmen. The Chairman is elected in
his/her personal capacity for the calendar year. For 1995, the bureau
consisted of Ambassador Gerardo Martinez Blanco (Honduras) as Chairman, with
th
e delegations of Indonesia and Italy providing the two Vice- Chairmen.

4. The Committee adopted the present report under the no- objection
procedure on 26 January 1996. The purpose of the report is to present a
factual summary of the Committee's activities since its establishment in
1993 until 31 December 1995, during which time it held two meetings.

II. SUMMARY OF THE ACTIVITIES OF THE COMMITTEE DURING THE REPORTING
PERIOD

5. At its 2nd meeting, held on 25 May 1995, the Committee considered and
adopted the guidelines for the conduct of its work, which were transmitted
to all States and international organizations on 7 June 1995. In addition,
an appeal was also addressed on the same day, by means of a press releas
e, to governmental or non-governmental organizations as well as individuals
for any information they might have on violations or suspected violations of
the embargo imposed against Liberia (United Nations press release SC/6049).

6. During the period under review, the Committee did not receive from
Member States any reports on alleged violations of the arms embargo.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


285 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Nigeria Statement by Dr. Owens Wiwa


BYLINE: Greenpeace February 1, 1996


LENGTH: 2560 words


 

Transcript of 'a testimony' by Dr. Owens Wiwa (brother of Ken Saro Wiwa),
steering committee member of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni
People (MOSOP).

FIRST MEETING WITH BRIAN ANDERSON

I first met Brian Anderson the chairman and managing director of Shell
Nigeria on the Queens birthday party 1995 in Lagos, and he promises to my
wife to help, to see that Ken gets adequate medical attention, he says he
will see what he can do and we leave at the end of the party and I write of
my encounter to Ken send it through my wife who leaves this day to see Ken
and through this letter we are very happy to learn that Ken has been taken
to the hospital the military hospital for the first time after being in
detention for about 11 months.

SECOND MEETING WITH BRIAN ANDERSON

Well I asked him if he would use his influence to stop the trial
announced so that Ken can get can get out of the illegal detention and so
that negotiation can start between Shell and the Ogoni people. And he says
that's difficult, but not impossible but that the international campaign is
hurting Shell and the Nigerian government and if we can stop the campaign
that he might be able to do something. So I tell him that I don't have the
power to do that, but however I will pass the information to Ken, and he
also at that time said I should try and get into the press - to get a press
release and get him a copy, you know mentioning the fact that there is no
environmental devastation in Ogoniland and I just say how can I do that, you
mean I tell the world that what we've been saying ever since 1990 is a lie,
there is no way I will do that. And that happened at our second meeting.

THIRD MEETING WITH BRIAN ANDERSON

I wrote to Ken and Ken replied back with a letter to Brian Anderson where
he gives him two scenarios. The first one - Ken gets killed and becomes a
martyr or they (Shell) did the right thing, use their influence with the
Nigerian government and get him out of their illegal detention and stop th
e charade of the tribunal. And when that happens the lobby with the writers
will stop, the lobby by the human rights groups will stop and that remains
the environmental campaigners and when the environmental lobby sees that he
is now discussing with Shell they will lower or stop their campaign.

Mr Brian Anderson tells me that he will no longer be available for
further discussion as he'll be travelling frequently but that I should
continue the discussion with Mr Achebe. Mr Achebe stresses the importance of
continuous dialogue and after a week I phone Achebe and I'm told he's in
Germany
I phone again a second time and I'm told he's in Abucja and I phone again
and I'm told he's in Port Harcourt holding meetings with other Ogoni people
and I phone another time and he's not in the office and all this time I'm
leaving my number and my messages and I don't get any reply so I now swit
ch back to phone Anderson both in his office and in his house. Now I phoned
the first time in his house and they tell me he's at a cocktail party I
phone another time and he's having lunch and I ask whether I can phone after
lunch I don't get any answer, but I still phone and still he's not availa
ble and I phone another time and I hear he's not around you know and then I
sort if get the message and I write back to Ken that it appears that I'm
being avoided and Ken writes back - that I shouldn't bother as it appears a
decision has been made.

DEVASTATION OF OGONILAND

Ogoni environment is devastated.

I got involved in Ogoniland after coming back to Ogoni after my
University medical school and then the first thing that struck me is that
the trees around my father's house the oranges and the guavas are no longer
there the ones there are not producing any fruit and they sort of shrunken.
Then I go to the hospital and the spectrum of diseases I see there is quite
different from the ones I was taught at school or the ones I saw in other
places I'd worked in Nigeria.

A lot of respiratory diseases - high incidence of asthma, cancer,
bronchitis and I'm quite surprised and also some bizarre skin diseases and a
high level of miscarriages which is quite different from other areas in
Nigeria that are not producing oil. And the land Ogoni is a small place
about 404 square miles 12 miles by 32 and large expanse of land that nothing grows on because of the oil spillages that have happened because of oil blow outs gas flares all over Ogoniland. You don't know when it is night it's always glowing. With the noise from the flow stations - it's very deafening and the people speak rather they shout the way of talking because they have to
get across to the other person. And the pipe line gas and oil pipelines
criss-crossing the whole place on the surface of the ground passing in front
of houses at the back of houses on farm land unprotected.

SHELL CLAIM SABOTAGE BY OGONI

Shell claims that the environmental devastation in Ogoniland is due to
sabotage of the installations by Ogoni people, as far as I know no Ogoni
person no MOSOP activist has ever been convicted of sabotage of oil
installations. The Ogoni people would be the last people on earth to go near
the Shell installations because they know that if anything goes wrong on the
pipelines or on the installations it is their land which they hold precious
that will be spoiled - that will be devastated it is their streams from
which they fish and drink water that will be polluted because their is no
piped on water in Ogoniland it's only the water from the streams so no Ogoni
person will go near any Shell installation for sabotage because that would
lead to spillage and we understand spillages and devastated land more than
any people in this world.

EVIDENCE THAT SHELL ARE INVOLVED WITH MILITARY

I drive down to the village of Korokor-tai when I get there I meet
another young man on the ground in a pool of blood at the feet of his mother
and I'm told that he was shot by Major (Okuntino??) who had come there in
the Shell bus accompanied by Shell executives and they had come to the
village, said they were coming to look for Shell trucks. In my clinic in Bori
Ogoniland I see the police constable coming to my clinic to tell me that all
Ogoni people in the police in Ogoni land have been transferred out and I'm
scared and he shows me the posting order transferring them and immediately
I get to my car because that's frightening and go to visit my brother in
hospital and I tell him what I've just heard and give him the police posting
order and he immediately writes on it telling the world about what is
happening and he's afraid that the first episode of genocide is being
planned against the people, the Ogoni people.

I see foreign journalists in Bori and I ask what's happening they said
they heard that there's shooting a journalist from the Guardian of London
and one from the Independent. And I take them to the village Kaa where most
of my patients come from and we arrive there and it's like a small atomic
bomb has been placed on the village I mean dropped on the village,
everything the market is completely destroyed, the school the houses even
the trees are on the ground and it is very very frightening and we do know
this time there were police, I mean a military presence in Ogoniland.

They were stationed not too far from my clinic so I go back to the army
and ask them what has happened, and we go back there and they see the place
and one of the officials says that he hasn't seen this sort of thing even
while he was serving in Liberia that no destruction has ever been to this level and in that particular incident 35 people are killed and it continues
like that another 7 Ogoni villages are all destroyed and a total of about
one thousand people are killed in these raids by people using sophisticated
weapons on unarmed villages and my patients tell me that the soldiers a
rrived across Andoni river with Shell boats and while all this is going on
we notice the presence of Shell helicopters hovering around and we're
actually very very worried.

DETENTION OF OWENS WIWA

On the 26th December 1993 on Boxing day I'm in my house with my wife
who's pregnant and her sister as well come to spend Christmas with us and a
captain in the Nigerian army Captain Tunde Odina comes in and has a beer in
my house and eats the food my wife has prepared and at the end of it he tells me to take a holiday, to leave Ogoniland go to Lagos or somewhere. At about 5 O'clock another Major comes in he calls himself Major Akintola of the Army Intelligence Unit at the Brigade in Bori camp and he tells me that the governor of the state Lieutenant Colonel Komo wants to see me and Barika Idamkue because at this time Barika Idamkue is the secretary of the Ogoni
Relief and Rehabilitation Committee and I'm the coordinator so I mean we go
there happily thinking that the Governor wants to give some relief to the
people so at the end of the conversation I tell him that I was told by
a captain, Captain Tunde Odina that I was to be arrested.

So the Governor tells me that is not true that is just one of the rumours
that we hear and keep telling people and there's nothing like that so I go
back to my house have dinner with my family and go to bed. At about 2am the
same captain who had come to my house you know to eat and drink comes
in shouting, breaking my door and asks where is Dr Wiwa, I say well I'm here
and then the other soldiers climb the fence and generally make noise and
then I ask what is the matter and he tells me you are, by the order of the
Federal Republic of Nigeria you are under arrest.

So I go back to my room change into my clothes and go into the 504
military vehicle and the other soldiers enter squeeze me in and they take me
straight to the country home of Mr Ledum Mitee the Deputy president of MOSOP
and repeat the same sort of thing they did in my house and bring the guy i
nto the car and then the soldiers are coming inside too with their guns
reeking of alcohol and marijuana and generally threatening us you know, and
took us straight to the Air force base in Port Harcourt and later to the
house of the government reservation division in Port Harcourt.

And we stayed there until the 4th of January at about 5 O'clock or so
Major Okuntimo comes in to meet us and to discuss. We ask him why we are
detained he doesn't tell us anything, all he says is he's following his
orders and then curiously asks us that since MOSOP is big it's powerful that
we should join forces with him you know to see that one Mr Lawson-Jack senior
executive of Shell in Port Harcourt is removed and we tell him that we don't
do things like that. We talk about ideas and how to change corporate behaviour in terms of the environmental devastation of Ogoniland we are not in for removing individuals and all that and he insist and so we ask him why, why do you want the man off? and then he explains that the man has been undercutting him in his payments that he was also receiving from Shell.

And after our discussion he tells us that we are released and on getting
out I meet my mother-in-law and I ask about my wife and she answers that
they are fine, I say what do you mean they are fine? I only have one wife,
so she says they are fine that you have a child I said a child ?, she said yes, a son, I said yes how do I know it's a son I said I dreamt you know but then my wife is not due but I rushed down to the hospital that she's supposed to have delivered and I go in there and see her very happy and beside her there's, there's a young kid you know all red and cries when he sees me and I go and pick up my son and I feel very happy and I decide to forget and forgive my detention because that has brought me a son and asked my wife how everything happens and she tells me that after they are taking me away after some hours when daylight was coming she decides to come and look for me.

And at this time there are many roadblocks manned by the army in
Ogoniland and she is stopped in one of the roadblocks and she comes out, she
is asked to come out of the car, she comes out and they ask her who she is
and she tells the person that she's my wife and they say Oh that trouble
maker so they ask her to identify herself further, she says she's a housewife
and housewives don't carry ID cards. So they search her and they decide to
search her person and she doesn't like that and the army man tell her to go
into the stream, the stream is polluted covered with oil, my wife doesn't
know how to swim.

She protests, she gets the gun, they put up the gun pushing her from the
back and she is pushed into the pond, into the stream but because of her
hydrophobia she comes out and then the man aims the nozzle of the gun at her
pregnant abdomen and then contractions start to come on and that process
leads her to the hospital and my baby comes out born on January 4th Ogoni
day and that's how I get my child.

Dr Owens Wiwa, December 1 1995

February, 1996


Lawyer Who Represented Saro-Wiwa Detained, Then Released


BYLINE: Africa News Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Washington, D.C - Nigerian Lawyer Olisa Agbakoba was detained several times this weekend after returning from an international trip,
according to Felix C. Morka, coordinator of the Nigerian Human
Rights Community Liaison Office in the U.S.

Olisa Agbakoba was one of the lawyers who represented activist Ken Saro-Wiwa, who was hanged last year by the Nigerian government. Mr. Morka, who operates a Washington, DC based liason office for the Lagos based
Civil Liberties Organisation and the Constitutional Rights
Project, released the following statement on Monday 5 February:

Mr. Olisa Agbakoba, founder and ex-president of the Civil Liberties Organization (CLO) was arrested at about 7pm on Saturday, February 3, 1996 by agents of the State Security Services (SSS) at the Lagos Murtala Mohammed International Airport upon his arrival from London.

He was questioned for over an hour regarding his recent travel in
Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States and then released. However, his International Passport and other travel documents were seized by the agents. On Sunday, February 4, 1996, Mr. Agbakoba was rearrested at his home by four state agents and taken to the SSS office where he was further questioned for over two hours.

He was later released with an order to report back today, Monday
February 5, 1996. Mr. Agbakoba's passport has not been released to him.

(On Monday evening, Felix Morka in Washington said that Mr. Olisa
Agbakoba was feeling ill on Monday and did not go back to the SSS
office. He remained at his home in Lagos.).

287 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Ethiopia Israeli Premier Defuses Row Over "Ethiopian Blood"


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nairobi - Millions of Israelis are reportedly embarrassed by the revelation in an Israeli newspaper Maariv on January 24, that the Israeli Blood Transfusion Service routinely destroyed blood donated by the Ethiopian Jewish community, commonly called Falashas (or Fereshmura in Hebrew, a term that also encompasses Ethiopian "Christianised Jews").

Maariv reported that the discarded blood packs had instructions directing that such donated blood be destroyed, because the donor came from Ethiopia. The newspaper said it was feared that the Fereshmura (Ethiopian Jews) had a higher prevalence of HIV infection.

Following the Maariv account, thousands of Ethiopian Jews took to the streets to protest what they saw as a "racist" practice against them. 

Prime Minister Shimon Peres acted quickly to defuse Ethiopian Jewish anger - he offered his government's sincere apologies to the immigrant community, saying his government had not been aware of what was going on. This was echoed by the Israeli government spokesman Uri Dromi who asserted that the agency's reaction was not government policy.

However, the spokeswoman for the Israeli Blood Transfusion Service said they had taken the decision purely on medical grounds. Although she avoided mentioning HIV or the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome AIDS, she emphasised that the Fereshmura had "a higher percentage of transfusion related illnesses."

Asked why they had continued to encourage the Ethiopian community in Israel to donate blood if they knew it would be destroyed anyway, she replied that they did not wish to segregate them.

Jonathan Meeidan spokesperson for the Israeli Embassy in Nairobi, described the whole episode as unfortunate. He said hardliners in Israel tended to fear that, relative to the rest of the Israeli community, "the immigrant community had comparatively higher HIV infection rates."

Meeidan discounted racial connotations in the decision, saying Israeli society was generally "very conservative" with a very low rate of HIV infection.

The Ethiopian Jewish and Ethiopian Christianised Jews number about 50,000. Most of them arrived in Israel from Ethiopia in the mid- eighties through "Operation Solomon", an airlift which was initially conducted secretly and sponsored by the Israeli government and also supported by the College of Rabbis. At the time of the airlift, Ethiopia was in the grip of twin calamities of famine and civil war in which hundreds of thousands perished.

Ethiopian Jews claim to be descendants of one of the ten lost tribes of Israel. Their Ethiopian name, Falashas is of Amharic origin, meaning "strangers in Ethiopia," an allusion to the perception that they trace their lineage to the tribe of Dan.

In their oral literature, they speak of their origins from the time of King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba who lived 10 centuries before Christ. This legendary account of their roots appears to be supported by the fact that they practised a form of Judaism that existed around the time King Solomon's temple was destroyed by marauding Babylonians some 600 years before Christ.

However, some scholars have discounted these accounts and suggested instead that the Falashas were converted to Judaism in the 6 century A.D (after Christ) by a migrant Jewish community that lived in Upper Egypt.

The breakthrough for them came in 1975 (ten years before "Operation Solomon") when the Israel Chief Rabbinate recognised them as Jews but ruled that all Ethiopian Jews would have to undergo a symbolic conversion to remove any doubts about their Jewish status. Some Ethiopian Jews resented this process saying they were "the true and original Jews."

During the secret airlift from 1985, a number of Ethiopian Christians took advantage, posing their children as Jews to gain automatic citizenship in Israel. But when such cases were discovered, a controversy erupted. Questions were asked as to whether such children or children of mixed Christian and Jewish marriages should be symbolically initiated.

After Meles Zenawi overthrew Mengistu Haile Mariam in the early 90's, thousands of "Christianised Jews" were allowed to migrate to Israel. There are Ethiopian Jews who converted to the Orthodox faith early this century, some say, in order to advance their economic status in Ethiopia. Many of these people had been abandoned weeping at Addis Ababa Airport when the original "Operation Solomon" concluded in the early 90s.

For many Ethiopian Jews, arriving in Israel for the first time constituted a real cultural shock. For example, they were surprised to find that some Israelis routinely violated the Sabbath or even ate forbidden foods. On the other hand, to the Israelis, the Fereshmura were more difficult to assimilate into their new homes than Jews from the Eastern Block. It took long for them to fit into the more Europeanised Israeli society.

There were serious accusations that the Ethiopian Jews were often segregated against or housed in deprived areas of cities. Many Israelis went out of their way to encourage them to assimilate faster including inviting them into settlements (Kibutz).

The blood transfusion episode is unlikely to damage the image of Israeli in Africa given the speedy apologies offered by the Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres after the uproar by the Ethiopian community in Israel.

In recent years Israel has enjoyed "a second coming" in Africa where the country now supports many technical and economic schemes.

As we went to press it was reported that the Ethiopian government had summoned the Israeli ambassador in Addis Ababa to express "deep concern" over the treatment of the Ethiopian Jews.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


288 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Kenya Poor With No Collateral -- But Able to Repay Loans


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Nairobi - For Faith Mbithe Musembi, 28, God's miracles sometimes include providing money to His needy faithful. Four years ago Mbithe prayed daily for God's deliverance from the bondage of a vicious circle of poverty. She says, "Jehovah must have heard my prayers."

Today, Mbithe runs her own hair salon and a dress-making kiosk, employs four assistants and is in the process of expanding her hair dressing business. She attributes her success to continuous prayers and the Kibera Savings and Credit Initiative (KSCI), a loan scheme for the poor of the sprawling Kibera slums in Nairobi, home to some 500,000 people. 

"Perhaps we are unique, where others ask for tangible guarantees before risking out their money, all we do is trust that our creditors will pay. Of course they have to begin by saving some money with us," said Seth Munyambo a senior field officer with the Ambassador Development Agencies (ADA), an organisation supporting the Kibera Savings and Credit Initiative.

He says; "When the programme started in 1993, we hoped to cater for the needs of small business people who had nobody other than God to turn to for financial assistance."

However, ADA, a local Christian non-governmental organisation and other interested supporters who have make KSCI a reality, had more in store for the people of Kibera. "We too intended to reach out the Gospel of Christ to the people of Kibera, be they Christians or non- Christians," added Munyambo.

For Dorcas Ojwang, 55, the programme is nothing short of a big reward. A fishmonger, she has yet to secure a loan because her savings "are not enough for what I have in mind," she notes. However, she has benefitted immensely from the Bible study lessons that go with the business management classes which have now become an integral part of the programme. "I love God. Every time we meet, it is as if I get closer to Him," she says, referring to KSCI's weekly group meetings.

Dorcas notes that through the KSCI, she has also learnt how to relate to customers, which in turn has boosted her business and income. "Before I started attending our weekly meetings, I used to think that customers always come on their own. Now I know that I must entice them," she adds.

Mr. Munyambo says there is no point in lending money to small scale business people who do not have any management skills in the first place. "Many of our members come with very little knowledge of record keeping. Often they too are very poor managers of the little incomes that come their way. This of course compounds their poverty. We took it upon ourselves to teach them business management techniques as well," he told this writer.

Auma Ndururu, a 50-year-old vegetable vendor conceded that the best she had learnt from the programme was record keeping.

Thus what had started as a small prayer group meeting at Mr. Fredrick Okwaro's delapidated shoe-maker's kiosk in 1993 has grown into a savings and credit programme, seeking to nourish the slum dwellers' temporal and spiritual needs. Explains 39 year-old Okwaro, a father of seven and one of the pioneer members of KSCI: "We were barely 20 faithful attending evening Bible lessons run by pastors from the African Inland Church (AIC). Then we suggested that we be assisted in our daily struggles to survive too."

Luck was on their side. Along came Larry Warren of the New Direction Ministries, a Christian organisation based in California, United States, which volunteered some initial financial assistance to Kibera Savings and Credit Initiative. Still, the ground work would have been very difficult, but thanks to the contribution of Ambassador Development Agencies' financial, manpower and co-ordination efforts. In time, other bodies keen on assisting the needy such as the Christian Reformed World Relief Committee (CRWRC) also threw in their weight.

To date, well over 80 Kibera slum dwellers have received KSCI loans amounting to Kshs.400,000 million (about US dollars 7,000). Among beneficiaries are water, vegetable and charcoal vendors, groundnut peddlers and fishmongers. "Our biggest problem today is having to cope with the increasing number of slum dwellers who need our loans," says Munyambo.

As if conspiring to complicate Kibera Savings and Credit Initiative's problems even more, Nairobi's population is growing at an alarming rate. From a mere 400,000 people in 1962, the population of Kenya's capital city rose to 569,000 people in 1969, 827,775 in 1979, and then skyrocketed to 1.2 million people in 1989. It is expected to hit the three million mark within the next four years according to the official national censors and the 1994/95 national development plan. Over half of this population is expected to live in slum areas which do not have electricity, sewage disposal systems and decent housing among other basic services.

However, KSCI loans do not come that easily. To be fully fledged members of KSCI, Kibera residents must commit themselves to attend weekly meetings, show willingness to learn business management skills and Bible lessons, run some small scale business and save with the programme anything between shillings 20 and 400 (between 30 cents and US dollars seven) per week for a minimum of six months. After eligible members have been granted loans thrice and re-paid each of them as scheduled, they "graduate" and are expected to be introduced to commercial banks by the scheme, Munyambo told this writer.

ADA's senior field officer was glad to note that the scheme has had no defaulters so far. The only non-payment he cited was due to the death of some debtors. "The good news is, the repayment rate is a whooping 98 per cent," he added. Perhaps this is a pointer for commercial money lenders -- the penniless, with absolutely no form of collateral can also be trusted with loans.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Somalia Extremists Tighten Grip as Fighting Spreads


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

Somalia is in the throes of another humanitarian tragedy as civil war engulfs the entire war-wrecked Horn of Africa nation, amid tightening of the grip by Muslim fundamentalists over the northern half of the capital controlled by self-styled Somali interim president Ali Mahdi Mohamed.

On January 23, an Islamic Sharia Court issued a decree here banning day-time sale of all foodstuffs in hotels, restaurants, bars and food kiosks in the northern half of the city during the fasting month of Ramadhan which began on January 22. The decree said those found guilty of violating the order would be punished according to Islamic laws which last year included either; ailing offenders throughout the fasting period or whipping them in public.

The decree also stated that materials, equipment and utensils used for serving food during the banned time would be confiscated by Ali Mahdi's Somali Salvation Alliance (SSA) faction which controls northern Mogadishu.

Immediately the order was announced, armed Islamic militiamen were seen patrolling the streets of northern Mogadishu to try and stop several small underground pubs from operating. 

But in the southern part of the capital which is controlled by Somalia's main warlord General Mohamed Farah Aideed's United Somali Congress/Somali National Alliance (USC/SNA), all hotels, restaurants and tea shops opened their doors and served food normally to the public, except for a few very religious men who closed their business out of respect for Islam and to protect their reputation.

On January 8, militiamen of north Mogadishu's Islamic Sharia Court pounced on a music concert and arrested 30 members of the band performing on stage at the basketball playground in the city's 1st July Street. They also surrounded and then arrested the people who were watching the concert, but released them after 30 minutes of questioning, eyewitnesses said.

Those detained included Somalia's top singer Mahamud Kon Garboosh, 30-year-old Binti Omar Ga'al, famous entertainer Abdillahi Amiir Rooble "Aow-kuku" and composer Ma'alim Mayser.

Two days later, the musicians were sentenced by the court to receive 20 lashes each and some were publicly flogged on January 10, triggering outrage in the divided city. Some of the women arrested while performing at the concert were not flogged after they were found to be pregnant, but the court ruled that their sentences will be carried out after they had given birth. Musical equipment belonging to the band was also confiscated by the court.

Band leader Abdullahi Liman accused the Sharia Court of serious human rights violations because the lashes caused serious injury to some of those punished.

"We will be forced to cross the green that divides the city between warlord Ali Mahdi and Aideed and live in the south, where we could again be penalised for composing songs broadcast by north Mogadishu radio in support of Ali Mahdi and the Sharia Court," Liman said.

But Sharia Court implementation chairman Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Muhyadin, denied that his courts were violating human rights through the sentences, and instead accused the musicians of poisoning the morals of Somalis by performing dirty dances, an act which was not compatible with Islamic Sharia law.

The self-designated head of Somali National Theater, Halima Khalif Magol also joined in the criticism and accused the Sharia Court of overreacting and violating the value of Islam.

"Even in Saudi Arabia, the seat of Islam, there are folklore dancers," said Magol, a supporter of Aideed's unrecognised government. She vowed that the southern Mogadishu government will take all necessary measures to prevent what she characterised as "nonsensical interference against national art by fundamentalists."

Magol, who heads a militia musical band supporting Aideed, has also been accused recently of forcing Somali singers and musicians unwilling to join the clan-based band to flee south Mogadishu into the northern part of the city.

Aideed, Ali Mahdi's arch rival, formed a new government last June after he was declared interim-president of Somalia for three years on June 15 by a conference of his supporters. But other armed Somali clan factions and the international community, except Libya, have refused to recognise it.

The religious developments in northern Mogadishu have been complicated by the fast-spreading civil war between Aideed's armed militiamen and those of other Somali clan factions opposed to his rule.

On January 19, at least 27 people were killed and 32 others wounded in fighting overnight between fighters loyal to Aideed and forces of rival Rahanwein clan in the southeastern town of Huddur, according to reliable sources.

Fighting erupted when militiamen belonging to the Rahanwein Resistance Army (RRA) launched an attack on the town in an attempt to dislodge Aideed's fighters who captured it on January 16, in a battle that left another 18 people dead and others wounded.

The fighting in Huddur is part of a major struggle between Aideed and opposing clan factions in the fertile Lower Jubba valley of south and southwest Somalia in the past few months. The fighting has centred around the major towns of Baidoa in the southwest and the key port of Kisimayo in the south.

Aideed, whose original power base was in south Mogadishu, captured the southwestern city of Baidoa last September in a lightning strike at the head of a column of 600 men.

Huddur, the third largest town in southern Somalia, with a population of some 100,000, had been held by the RRA -- local clansmen -- whom Aideed's militiamen had ousted from Baidoa. They have made sporadic attacks on Baidoa since its capture, but have been unable to retake it.

Aideed has also taken the war to the southern port of Kisimayo, the stronghold of local military strongman General Mohamed Said Hirsi Morgan, where several heavy clashes have occurred for the control of surrounding villages. General Morgan's faction supports Ali Mahdi's faction and its alliance of former Aideed's financier-turned arch political rival Osman Hassan Ali "Atto", who leads a rival faction of the USC/SNA.

Heavy fighting has also broken out in Somaliland, former northern Somalia region which declared itself an independent republic after dictator Mohamad Siad Barre was overthrown in 1991.

On January 16, a pitched battle between loyalist and opposition forces in parts of the breakaway republic left at least 59 fighters dead, 130 wounded and the major city devastated, according to reports coming into the Somali capital through field radios.

The fighting in Burco, the second biggest city in the region, pitted supporters of "President" Mohamed Ibrahim Egal against militiamen backed by Aideed's vice-president and former Somaliland's first President Abdurahaman Ali "Tuur", who was ousted by elders in 1993 in favour of independent Somalia's first Prime Minister Egal. Tuur has since become a vice-president in the Somali "government" proclaimed by General Aideed last June and favours reunification.

Although each side claimed victory, the radio traffic monitored in Mogadishu said both sides had withdrawn and the population had fled, leaving the city to freelance looters on January 16.

Residents were reported to be sheltering in nearby villages, but short of food, water and shelter. Burco is some 170 kilometres east of Hargeisa, Somaliland's "capital." No international aid agencies have worked in this town since the start of regular clashes between the two forces in early 1995.

Somaliland, a former British colony, split off from the rest of Somalia, formerly Italian, when Siad Barre was overthrown in 1991, but it has not received any international recognition.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Sudan Church Council Moves from Kenya to Southern Region


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 667 words


 
Nairobi - The New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) is in the process of moving its headquarters from the Kenyan capital, Nairobi to Narus, a region in southern Sudan controlled by the Sudan Relief and Rehabilitation Association (SRRA), which is an arm of the Sudan Peoples' Liberation Army/Movement (SPLA/M).

According to reports published in the February edition of NSCC News, some staff houses are expected to be completed and ready for occupation by the end of this month. The construction of the council's new headquarters is reportedly funded by the Norwegian Church Aid (NCA). 

The bulletin further reports that although the NSCC Executive Committee has not given a deadline for moving into the new offices, the secretariat was working with Bishop Paride Taban of Torit Diocese in southern Sudan on the new site.

Commenting on the transfer of offices from Nairobi to southern Sudan, NSCC Relief Coordinator Mr Rob Haarsager told APS, the move was necessitated by the need to be "closer to the churches and the people." Haarsager noted that it was easier to get information about the people and respond faster if they worked among them.

Haarsager conceded that the day to day running of the NSCC "will be a bit more difficult because of potential insecurity." However, he pointed out that on the other hand, Narus had been secure for some time now and in any case, NSCC was only returning to a region which had previously hosted its head offices.

The New Sudan Council of Churches, established in 1989 with the motto, "Serving All God's people," based its headquarters in Torit, southern Sudan until 1992 when the Islamic government of Sudan took control of the area and forced the council to move its secretariat functions to Nairobi. The NSCC still maintains a logistics office in the Ugandan capital, Kampala.

The NSCC was set up to work in areas under the control of Sudan People's Liberation Army/ Movement (SPLA/M), since the Sudan Council of Churches (SCC), located in the capital, Khartoum, was not able to contact and service the churches in the SPLA/M areas in the south.

The NSCC says it hopes to provide "visible expression of the unity of Christians in the task of proclaiming the gospel of salvation."

Its goals, the council adds, include gathering "representatives of churches and Christian agencies working in the SPLA/M administered areas for periodical conferences and counsel regarding the spiritual and general welfare of all." Other goals include the breaking down of barriers that separate the Sudanese people and the promotion of one human family in justice and peace.

The NSCC which "exists to support the work of member churches enjoys the membership of all churches in southern Sudan either as full members or associate members. Its full members include : African Inland Church, Catholic Church, Coptic Orthodox Church, Episcopal (Anglican) Church of Sudan, Evangelical Church, Presbyterian Church of Sudan and the Sudan Interior Church.

Nationally, NSCC is a member of the Sudan Council of Churches which in turn is a member of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), and the Geneva-based World Council of Churches (WCC).


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


291 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Egypt Government to Bring 5,000 Mosques Under State Control


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Cairo - Some 5,000 mosques in Egypt will be put under government control in March in a bid to prevent fundamentalists from spreading extremist thoughts from their pulpits, Prime Minister Kamal al-Banzuri told parliament on January 27.

Out of the 140,000 private mosques in Egypt, the Ministry of Religious Affairs now controls 25,000 and will add another 5,000 this March," Banzuri said.

Banzuri said his government plans to focus on building "grand mosques" which would also hold social services such as clinics and schools. 

In late 1992, after Muslim militants launched a violent campaign to topple the government, the state launched a plan to take control of all of the private mosques in Egypt at a rate of 5,000 per year.

Under the plan, state-appointed imams run the mosques and give the Friday sermon.

Muslim militants used private mosques to spread their ideas through sermons against the state and as bases for their meetings, as well also providing social services to the poor through the mosques.

Banzuri's announcement came as Egyptian police announced that they had arrested five Muslim militants and broken up the biggest ever attempt to smuggle arms from Sudan to Egyptian fundamentalists.

Zuheir Awad Salah, a Sudanese, brought into Egypt 15,000 machine-gun rounds sent by leaders of the Jihad militant group in Sudan to their followers in Egypt, police said on January 27.

Five Egyptians helped store the cache in the desert outside Kom Ombo, 900 kilometres south of Cairo, in preparation to distribute if for attacks.

Security services, who had been hunting down the gang for the past month, discovered the cache and arrested the five, police said.

It was the largest arms shipment captured in Egypt since Islamic militants began their violent campaigns to topple the government of President Hosni Mubarak in March 1992, police said.

Cairo accuses the Islamic military regime of President Omar Hassan el- Beshir of Khartoum of backing the fundamentalists and has announced regularly raids on shipments infiltrating across their border from Sudan.

Six extremists were condemned to death on January 13 for arms smuggling. On January 18, Egypt said it would explain to the United States its complaint filed against Sudan at the United Nations Security Council during a visit there by US Ambassador to the UN Madeline Albright.

On January 16, Security Council members voted unanimously to condemn Sudan for not extraditing three suspects linked to a plot to kill Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Ethiopia last June.

After the end of closed-door sessions by the 15-member council, this month, council president, John Weston of Britain, said some members envisioned further action including a resolution against Sudan.

Diplomats reported that Botswana was leading the non-aligned nations in a discussion of a text. Weston himself met with Sudanese Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Osman Mohamed Taha to complain about armed incursions into Ethiopia.

Ethiopia, which sought an emergency meeting of the council, is seeking the extradition of three people allegedly linked to an Islamic terrorist group that tried to kill Mubarak last June when he landed in Ethiopia for a summit of the Organization of African Unity (OAU).


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


292 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Uganda Reshuffle Upsets Anglican Church


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Kampala - In a major reshuffle, the (Anglican) Church of Uganda has endorsed a one-year sabbatical for controversial eastern diocese of Busoga Bishop Cyprian Bamwoze.

Bishop Bamwoze who has been accused by Busoga Christians of misusing church funds, last October wrote to former Archbishop Rev. Yonah Okoth, saying he would only go on sabbatical leave if he was paid "sterling pounds 10,000 as benefits."

Archbishop Okoth had suggested the sabbatical as a way of easing the crisis in Busoga Diocese which had split the church into two factions, with the anti-Bamwoze group appointing Rev. Samwiri Lubogo as rival bishop. 

In a statement published here on January 28, the House of Bishops dismissed Bamwoze's demands saying, "the church does not have the funds" and instead directed that "Bamwoze goes on a one-year sabbatical leave beginning February 1.

"The Archbishop (Livingstone Nkoyoyo) will also act as Busoga's Bishop in the absence of (Bishop) Bamwoze," said the statement, published after a lengthy meeting of the House of Bishops in the Church of Uganda western parish of Kingansano in Rukungiri District.

Attempts by APS to get comments from Bishop Bamwoze were unsuccessful. His telephone number repeatedly rang without response.

The action by the Church of Uganda came after a hard-hitting open letter by the leader of the anti-Bamwoze faction Canon John Nabeta on January 26, appealing to Archbishop Nkoyoyo "to translate his new anti-corruption policy into action by cleaning up Busoga Diocese."

Archbishop Nkoyoyo announced early this year that he would crack down on unnamed "corrupt and inefficient Bishops and other church leaders," in a move precipitated by the recent change of the Church of Uganda Constitution, empowering him to "take full control of all church matters. The Archbishop also said he would instill "dynamism into the church by replacing over staying bishops with new ones."

Other changes announced by the House of Bishops include the appointment of the bishop of west Buganda Rt. Rev. Christopher Senyonjo as the dean of the Church of Uganda Province.

The Church of Uganda also resolved that Rev. Canon Evans Kisekka be enthroned as bishop of the newly formed North Eastern Diocese of Luwero on July 7. Rev. Kisekka who has been heading the Anglican Pastoral College at Namugongo near Kampala, takes over from retired Rev. Nesusera Bugimbi.

The measures in Uganda's Anglican church were announced shortly before the enthronement of Rt. Rev. John Kahigwa as bishop of the north western Kigezi Diocese. He took over from retired Bishop Dr. Yusitas Ruhinda.

During the enthronement at Kinyansano Parish, Rukungiri District, where the Church of Uganda House of Bishops announced the changes, Archbishop Nkoyoyo appealed to church leaders "not to look at their offices as gardens of riches but noble duties of leading people to God."

"The office of a bishop is not an eating house for him alone but for all Christians he is leading," Nkoyoyo said amidst applause from thousands of Christians attending the ceremony.

The Archbishop decried "wide spread corruption in the Church of Uganda," saying such vices had influenced increasing members of the church to join other Anglican sects.

Uganda's Vice-President Dr. Specioza Wandira Kazibwe, who represented President Yoweri Museveni at the function appealed to the church to join government in "forging development and unity in the country."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

293 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1996


Science and Health World Bank Boosts Efforts to Eradicate Killer Weed


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Nairobi - The World Bank has agreed to fund a five- year programme to rid East Africa's Lake Victoria of the water hyacinth, a weed that is threatening the lake's ecosystem.

According to a United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) publication, Our Planet, released early this year, the World Bank will provide US dollars 20 million to rehabilitate and strengthen the management of the lake's resources.

The 70,000 square kilometre lake, the largest fresh water body in Africa, is commonly shared between Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania. Being the source of the River Nile, its waters are vital for the survival of the Sudan and Egypt. More than 100 million people derive sustenance within its basin area. 

The rapid spread of the water hyacinth is the single biggest threat to Lake Victoria's ecosystem. The lake has more than 200 indigenous fish species, many of which could be wiped out by the rapid depletion of oxygen from its water.

On the Ugandan side in particular, the water hyacinth has multiplied so fast that it continually threatens to stall the production of electricity at the Owen Falls hydroelectric station in Jinja.

The Uganda Railways Corporation reported late last year that it spends the equivalent of US dollars 2,000 per day, just to clear the weed from the marine pier at Port Bell, near Entebbe.

Meanwhile, plans to use the controversial herbicide 2-4D to control the water hyacinth are already raising concern among Ugandan environmentalists who fear the substance will have a massive secondary damaging effect on the lake's ecosystem.

A Ugandan environmentalist Asikia Muhammed says the National Task Force for the Control of Hyacinth is preparing to use 2-4D to fight the weed. He has threatened to take court action to stop them.

Muhammed argues that 2-4D was banned in Europe in 1993 as well as some parts of Asia and Africa "because it is highly toxic to fish."

He says 2-4D has high persistence in the environment and was potentially hazardous to human beings since it is a cancer causing agent.

But the executive director of the task force professor Okedi said they would contest any court action. He said his task force would take all necessary steps "to minimise possible harmful effects of any methods applied for the control of the water hyacinth."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February, 1996


South African Soldiers Held for Church Massacre


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 840 words


 

CAPE TOWN February 1 - Two members of the South African National Defence Force have been arrested in connection with the 1993 attack on a church here in which 11 people died and 56 were injured, police announced on January 26.

Both suspects are former members of the now-defunct Azanian People's Liberation Army (APLA), which was absorbed into the new national defence force along with other liberation forces after the first all- race elections in 1994.

APLA was the armed wing of the black radical Pan Africanist Congress, which is now represented in parliament.

Charged along with the two soldiers will be a 19-year-old prisoner held at Cape Town's Pollsmoor prison on an unrelated robbery charge. 

Armed men stormed the St. James' Anglican Church in Cape Town's upmarket Kenilworth suburb during an evening mass on July 25, 1993, sprayed the congregation with bullets and hurled hand grenades.

Although people of different races were attending the service, the attack was widely regarded as racially motivated because of the white character of the surrounding suburb.

Among the dead were three visiting Russian sailors. One of the attackers was arrested and convicted last year. "We never gave up. We always knew who the outstanding suspects were, but we were not able to find them," said Police Superintendent Des Segal, who headed the investigating team.

On January 19, police arrested the 19-year-old, who has not been identified, on a robbery charge.

Although he gave a false name, the young man was soon identified as one of those wanted for the St. James' massacre. His arrest was followed by those of a 30-year-old major and a 24-year-old corporal in the defence force, both natives of the former black homeland of Transkei.

The major was picked up in Oudtschoorn, in Western Cape province, and the corporal in Bloemfontein, in the Free State, on January 17. The suspects' names will be released when they appear at Wynberg Magistrates Court.

Police appealed to the media to refrain from publishing photographs of the accused, saying that their identification will be a crucial element in the coming trial.

The arrests come as President Nelson Mandela embarked on a shuttle diplomacy to bring peace to KwaZulu-Natal, meeting Zulu King Goodwill Zwelithini on January 25 and later in the day in Pretoria with Zulu nationalist leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi.

Mandela said he would meet Buthelezi, head of the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) and Home Minister in the Government of National Unity, after more than three hours of talks at one of Zwelethini's residences at Nongoma, in the north of troubled KwaZulu-Natal province.

The South African President said the monarch had approved a meeting between Mandela and the province's 250-plus traditional chiefs before a planned "imbizo" -- a gathering of the Zulu nation -- in a bid to end the province's decade-old, undeclared civil war that has claimed more than 14,000 lives.

Mandela had already met separately over the past week with Zulu King Zwelithini and his estranged uncle, Buthelezi, after launching his latest initiative to end the conflict between followers of his African National Congress (ANC) and the IFP.

He and Buthelezi announced January 22 that they had agreed to jointly address an imbizo.

Treading gently in the complicated world of Zulu politics and tradition, Mandela is being extra careful as he tries to seek a consensus between his own vision of a unified South Africa and the elements at play in the province: - Buthelezi and the IFP, who maintain their hard line in seeking autonomy for their KwaZulu-Natal stronghold; - The "amakhosi" -- the chiefs -- who are mostly IFP-aligned and thus divided in their loyalties between Buthelezi and their traditional King; - and the King, still a strong symbolic figure, but his power apparently reduced since he publicly withdrew his support from Buthelezi and decided to remain "above politics' -- a move interpreted by most chiefs as an alignment with the ANC.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February, 1996


Mozambique Official's Detainee Remark Criticized by Clergy, Lawyers, Politicians


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Maputo - Mozambican Catholics, lawyers and politicians joined human rights activists on January 26 to express outrage at the Interior Minister's comments on deaths of suspected criminals held in police custody.

Head of the Catholic Church in Maputo, Archbishop Alexandre Maria dos Santos said he would seek a meeting with the minister.

"I know the situation of prisoners is very serious. Many people held in prisons are victims of enemies in power or are victims of hatred," Archbishop Dos Santos said, warning that as long as justice does not prevail, Mozambican jails would always be overcrowded. 

Main opposition and ex-rebel leaders Afonso Dhlakama of the Mozambican National Resistance (RENAMO) condemned minister Manuel Antonio's remarks about detainees and prisoners.

"There is no government in Mozambique," he said, urging citizens to remain calm while he tried to discuss the issue with President Joaquim Chissano.

The minister acknowledged earlier last week that prisoners starved to death in Mozambique, but he added his ministry did not have any food for them because nobody asked them to commit crimes.

"A man has to die. He has his limits. When his time is up, it is over. He goes. It is not because they have been maltreated," the minister said.

The president of the Bar Association, Carlos Cauio, described Antonio's remarks as a plot against humanity.

The daily independent MediaFax quoted parliament's standing committee as expressing concern at the minister's statements, saying they deserved urgent analysis.

Immediately after the minister made the remarks on January 25, a human rights group demanded that he should be sacked, accusing him of making callous statements over the deaths of suspects in police custody.

In comments to the daily newspaper Noticias on January 29, Antonio said: "Has the Ministry of Interior got food for them? No it hasn't. These men who die, it is really because there is no food for them. They are not maltreated."

The Mozambican Human Rights League (LDH) said in a letter to President Chissano that "a leader who makes this kind of statement should be relieved from duty."

The league's president Alice Mabota said that prisoners were often held beyond the legal limits of pre-trial detention and that what little food was available was stolen by officials.

Africa News


February, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Theologians Challenged on Inculturation


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service February 5, 1996


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Nairobi - Kenyan Catholic Bishop Ndingi Mwana a' Nzeki has challenged African theologians to help the Church inculturate the Gospel message.

Bishop Mwana a' Nzeki of the Nakuru Diocese in Kenya's Rift Valley Province, noted it is the wish of the Catholic hierarchy in Africa to help make the Gospel message indigenous to the people. However, he pointed out that such a goal will be best realised when supplemented by efforts from the local clergy.

"The entire Catholic hierarchy on the African continent and even the Pope (John Paul II) himself is for the idea of inculturating the Christian message. But the total realisation of the goal, would have to be realised through the contribution of the local clergy and laity in general," noted Bishop Ndingi. 

The Kenyan prelate was speaking here on January 29, at the launching ceremony of a religious book-Towards An African Narrative Theology, authored by two Catholic priests, Rev. Fr. Joseph Healey and Donald Sybertz of the Maryknoll Missionaries. Bishop Ndingi has written the foreword to the book.

The 416-page publication is an attempt by the authors to show the centrality of African cultures and values in bringing closer the Christian message to the African people through the use of proverbs, sayings, riddles, stories, myths, plays and songs.

The authors have graphically used between 300 and 400 African proverbs and sayings, drawn from 102 African languages to expound the Gospel.

In his address during the launching ceremony, Bishop Ndingi described the book as an impressive attempt by the authors to "implement what the historic synod for African bishops (held in Rome in 1994) resolved to do--inculturate the Christian message."

"I would like at this juncture to challenge the African theologians to use the richness of the book towards their goal -- implementing the recommendations of the synod, one of them being the inculturation of the gospel message," said the Nakuru bishop.

He stressed; "In particular, this book looks at the cultural riches of African oral literature such as proverbs, sayings and stories. I hope that these examples and reflections will help African priests, seminarians and other pastoral workers to rediscover their African roots and make connections to their preaching, teaching and evangelisation."

Bishop Ndingi called for more research on the centrality of African values and traditions as related to Christian teaching. He said this would hopefully authenticate the Gospel message, thus dissuading some African Christians from living at the spiritual crossroad between faith in Christian teachings and the African medicineman or diviner.

Addressing invited guests, Fr. Healey said, "although we have authored the book, it really (book) belongs to the scores of African elders, who committedly and intelligently narrated and interpreted the many proverbs and sayings to us.

"We have simply transmitted the theological reflections and the insights of the African people and communities," he explained.

And to symbolise the centrality of elders and the entire African communal system in the compilation of the book, Fr. Healey presented the first two copies of the book to a Kenyan elder, Peter Kiarie and a youth, Maureen Ngala respectively.

Meanwhile research work on Sukuma proverbs is currently in process. According to Fr. Healey, a book on these proverbs will be published next year.

"Alphabetical Collection of 6,000 Sukuma Proverbs will be the title of this book," Fr. Healey told APS.

Asked why the Sukuma ethnic group of western Tanzania has been selected for the intensive research, Fr. Healey responded; "One of the reasons was that the group is the second largest ethnic group in eastern Africa, with an estimated 5 million people." The Sukuma live around Musoma, Mwanza and Shinyanga regions of north-western Tanzania.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
